Project Description: Purpose: To support 3rd i Films' San Francisco International South Asian Film Festival and associated public programming. Additional Project Description: Showcasing the work of local and international South Asian artists in documentary, narrative, and experimental genres, screenings will be accompanied by talks with visiting artists and panel discussions focused on issues pertinent to South Asian communities. Intended Beneficiaries: Festival programming will serve the public, with a focus on residents from the greater San Francisco Bay Area and South Asian communities. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support 3rd i Films' San Francisco International South Asian Film Festival and associated public programming. Additional Project Description: Showcasing the work of local and international South Asian artists in documentary, narrative, and experimental genres, screenings will be accompanied by talks with visiting artists and panel discussions focused on issues pertinent to South Asian communities. Intended Beneficiaries: Festival programming will serve the public, with a focus on residents from the greater San Francisco Bay Area and South Asian communities. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support 3rd i Films' San Francisco virtual International South Asian Film Festival and associated public programming. Dedicated to showcasing the work of local and international South Asian artists in documentary, narrative, and experimental genres, screenings will be accompanied by talks with visiting artists and panel discussions focused on issues pertinent to South Asian communities.

To support the San Francisco International South Asian Film Festival and associated public programming. Dedicated to showcasing the work of local and international South Asian artists, the festival will showcase films across narrative, documentary, and experimental genres. This year's festival will include a special focus on women filmmakers, featuring the work of artists such as the award-winning documentary director of Gulabi Gang (2012), Nishtha Jain. Throughout the festival, screenings will be accompanied by talks with visiting artists and panel discussions focused on issues pertinent to South Asian communities.

To support the San Francisco International South Asian Film Festival. The multi-day festival will include screenings of feature films, documentaries, and short films - classic and contemporary - by South Asian filmmakers from around the world. Programming will also include panel discussions and artist talks.

To support the San Francisco International South Asian Film Festival. The event is a multi-day festival featuring classic and contemporary films, documentaries, and short films, offering authentic representations and issues of relevance to South Asians. Filmakers from around the world participate. The festival will spotlight screenings and programming featuring India's Dalit community. Programming will also include panel discussions.

To support the San Francisco International South Asian Film Festival. The festival will screen full-length features, documentaries, and short films by independent South Asian filmmakers from the United States, India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Canada, and Europe. The festival's focus - its screenings, media artist presentations, and panel discussion - is intended to offer a diverse range of perspectives on the lives of South Asian people in places through the world.

To support the South Asian International Film Festival and related dance and music performances. The annual festival will focus on South Asia's diverse dance and music traditions and will screen narrative and documentary features and shorts by independent filmmakers from the United States, South Asia, and the South Asian Diaspora.

To support the South Asian International Film Festival. Held at San Francisco's Castro and Roxie Theaters, the 11th annual festival will include full-length features, documentaries, and short films by South Asian filmmakers from the United States, India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Europe, and Canada, including filmmaker Sabiha Sumar.

To support the South Asian International Film Festival. The 10th annual festival will include full-length features, documentaries, and short films by South Asian filmmakers from the United States, India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Europe, Canada, and the South Asian diaspora.

To support the South Asian International Film Festival. The eighth annual festival will screen full-length feature films, documentaries and short films by media artists and independent filmmakers from the United States, Bangladesh, India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Canada and Europe.

To support the Annual San Francisco South Asian International Film Festival. The sixth annual festival will screen feature full-length films, documentaries and short films by media artists and independent filmmakers from the United States, Bangladesh, Canada, England, India, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.

To support the Annual San Francisco South Asian International Film Festival. The festival will screen films and host workshops by media artists from India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, England, Canada, and the United States.

To support the 4th Annual South Asian International Film Festival. Now in its fourth year, the festival will include the screening of features, documentaries, short films, and in some cases discussions between the filmmaker and the audience.

To support script and score restorations and the production of "Three Sisters", a musical play by Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein II. Co-artistic director and musical theater historian Greg MacKellan will restore the production script with score restoration and new chamber orchestrations by musical director Dave Dobrusky.
To support the restoration, revival, and staged concert performance of Harold Arlen and Yip Harburg's 1937 musical, Hooray For What.
To support the production of a CD recording. 42nd Street Moon will record a CD of the 1938 Cole Porter score, "Leave it to Me."

To support the exhibition Pax Americana by American artist David Gurman at the Luggage Store. Constructed in collaboration with a team of experts in seismology, music, robotics, and electromechanical engineering Gurman's installation (or Pax Americana) will convert real time seismic data into a water feature created to reflect vibrations recorded from data feeds indicating real-time action in international conflict zones.

To support completion of an online archive documenting the 20-year exhibition history of the Luggage Store. The archive will include more than 2,000 visual images, biographical information, video footage, DVDs, newspaper articles, and critical writing.
To support Short Cuts. The mentorship program at Luggage Store Gallery targeted to emerging artists and art students is designed to advance curatorial and exhibition organizing skills.

To support production of an online archive documenting the 16-year exhibition history of the Luggage Store. The archive will include more than 1,000 visual images, biographical information, video footage, DVDs, newspaper articles, and critical writing.

To support an exhibition to mark the 15th anniversary of the Luggage Store Gallery, including related educational programs. Catalog removed as a required product 4/22/08. The exhibition will feature new work by approximately 30 artists whose work was once shown at the gallery.

To support outdoor performances, arts programs, visual arts exhibitions, and the 11th annual In the Street Theater Festival. The project provides free, professional quality, community-based multidisciplinary arts programming for culturally and economically diverse residents of San Francisco's Tenderloin and Mid-Market Corridor neighborhoods.
To support free arts programming in a low-income neighborhood. The project will feature outdoor performances, visual arts exhibitions, and the 10th annual "In the Street Theater Festival."

To support free arts programming serving low-income San Francisco residents. The project will feature outdoor performances, the ninth annual In the Street Theater Festival, and visual arts exhibitions.

To support free arts programming for inner-city audiences; including performances and exhibitions. This project will feature outdoor arts presentations, the eighth annual In the Street Theater Festival, and exhibitions.

To support free arts programming in a low-income neighborhood of San Francisco. This project will feature outdoor arts presentations, the seventh annual In the Street Theater Festival, exhibitions, and arts education programs for under-served youth and adults.

To support outdoor arts presentations, the Sixth Annual San Francisco In the Street Theater Festival, and arts education programs for low-income youth and adults. The project will focus on art forms reflecting the center's culturally-diverse neighborhood and will target under-served youth and adults for arts education activities.

To support outdoor arts presentations, the fifth annual In the Street Theater Festival, and arts education programs for economically disadvantaged residents of the city's Tenderloin district. The project will focus on art forms reflecting the culturally diverse neighborhood and will target at-risk youth for arts education activities.

Purpose: To support the publication of an anthology of student writing. Additional Project Description: 826 National will work with a national student editorial board to solicit and select writing from across the organization's nine chapters and online learning platform, 826 Digital. Amplifying the voices of students, with a focus on including girls and nonbinary students, the anthology will feature a foreword by a professional author or other influential adult and will serve as a mentor text for students across the 826 Network. Intended Beneficiaries: Project activities will benefit students participating in the 826 Network. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support 826 Digital, an online platform for educators. With the goal of inspiring young people to unlock the creative power of storytelling, the site provides teachers nationwide with curated resources such as ready-to-use lesson plans that align with Common Core standards. In addition to developing new curricular content, the organization will improve the user experience by offering site enhancements such as "how to" resources in Spanish and English.

To support 826 Digital, an online platform for educators. Designed to get students excited about creative writing, the site provides teachers nationwide with resources such as ready-to-use lesson plans that align with Common Core standards. In addition to developing new teacher training modules, the organization will increase its outreach to educators outside its current network, including in rural communities.

To support 826 Digital, an online platform for educators. Designed to get students excited about and engaged in creative writing, the site provides teachers nationwide with resources such as cross-curricular lesson plans that align with Common Core standards and a curated student writing gallery searchable by grade level, theme, and literary style.

To support 826 Digital, an online platform for educators. Designed to get students excited about and engaged in creative writing, the site provides teachers nationwide with resources such as cross-curricular lesson plans that align with Common Core state standards and a curated student writing gallery searchable by grade level, theme, and literary style. In addition to developing new content for 826 Digital, the organization plans to evaluate the platform and refine site features and functionality based on user feedback.

To support the development of 826 Digital, a multimedia platform that includes creative writing resources. The platform will provide educators nationwide with inspirational creative writing resources. These include cross-curriculuar lessons that align with Common Core state standards, as well as a curated student writing gallery searchable by grade level, theme, and literary style. 826 National plans to evaluate the plaform and its impact through online surveys, user reviews, and website analytics, among other means.

To support a variety of publications and online tools to help teachers, parents, and students get access to quality creative writing instruction. Programs include a licensing platform for the organization's Storytelling  Bookmaking program; new curriculum books; the digitization of current curriculum books; and an annual brochure of 826 National and chapter books.

Purpose: To support creative writing programs and publication of student work. Additional Project Description: Students from underperforming schools will learn writing and editing skills through in-school creative writing workshops led by professional writers and augmented by in-person or virtual visits from other authors. Students' work will be published in an anthology edited by a youth advisory board and will include a forward written by a guest author. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve high school students from low-income communities. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support creative writing programs and publication of student work. Additional Project Description: Students from underperforming schools will learn writing and editing skills through in-school creative writing workshops led by professional writers. Students' work will be published in an anthology. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve high school students from low-income communities. Intended Outcomes: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support creative writing programs and publication of student work. Taught by professional artists, students from under-performing schools will learn writing and editing skills through one-on-one tutoring sessions, workshops, field trips, and artist residencies; their work will be published in chapbooks, quarterlies, an anthology, and student newspapers.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support writing programs and the publication of student work. Professional artists will teach creative writing to underserved youth in under-performing schools.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support writing programs and the publication of student work. Professional artists will teach creative writing to underserved youth in under-performing schools.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support writing programs and the publication of student work. Professional artists will teach creative writing to at-risk youth in under-performing schools.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support writing programs and the publication of student work. Professional artists will teach creative writing to at-risk youth in under-performing schools.

To support the creation and world premiere of "In the Maze of Our Own Lives". Playwright and founding ensemble member Corey Fischer, artistic director Aaron Davidman, and filmmaker Sam Ball will create a mixed media theater piece based on the history of the Group Theater from 1931-1941.

To support the development and production of a new theater work through the Middle-East Project. Artistic Director Aaron Davidson will oversee the collaboration between the ensemble and guest artists.

To support the creation, development, and presentation of a new theater work. Una Noche de Suenos Vidi: A Dream of Flowers is an ensemble-created theater work directed by Artistic Director Helen Stoltzfus.
To support the development and presentation of a new theater piece. Based on the biblical Song of Songs, the play will be written and directed by co-artistic director Naomi Newman.

To suppor the consortium of the Network of Ensemble Theatres for its 2000 conference and festival. The festival will bring together more than two dozen ensemble companies dedicated to creating original works through the ensemble method to network, showcase works, collaborate and address significant issues in the theater field.

To support the creation, development, and presentation of "See Under: Love." See Under: Love, inspired by the work of the same name by Israeli novelist and critic David Grossman, will be developed by A Traveling Jewish Theatre (ATJT) and premiered as part of the 2000/2001 season.

To support the expenses associated with a multi-state national tour. A Traveling Jewish Theatre will mount a 20th Anniversary National Tour of a new work celebrating Yiddish poetry, entitled Diamonds In The Dark, encompassing a minimum of 20 half-week residences in diverse communities throughout the U.S.

To support the Intensive Training in Collaborative Theatre Making program for students and the subsequent implementation of a full apprenticeship program that will pass on A Traveling Jewish Theatre's unique methods of ensemble theater creation to a new generation of theater artists. A Traveing Jewish Theatre (ATJT) has a long history of creating work through its exploration of myth, history, religion, politics and culture. ATJT is one of the few theater companies in the U.S. that is committed to developing work with ensemble theater creation. In the summer of 1997, ATJT will launch its first Intensive Training in Collaborative Theatre Making, a six-week program in which participants will receive training in improvisation, movement and voice and will then develop, write, stage and perform a full-length original theater piece under the direction and leadership of ATJT's current ensemble. Six to ten students will participate in the Intensive Training in the pilot year and each summer thereafter. Beginning in 1998, ATJT has requested Arts Endowment support to link the summer Intensive Training with an apprenticeship program that will span the entire season. An average of two students will be selected each year from the Intensive Training's participants and invited to join the ensemble as apprentices. The long-term goal of the project is to integrate successful apprentices into the permanent ensemble.

To support the second year of an alternative touring network for ensemble theaters by the Network of Ensemble Theatres (NET), a consortium comprised of A Traveling Jewish Theatre, Bloomsburg Theatre Ensemble, Cornerstone Theater Company, Dell'Arte Players Company, The Independent Eye, Irondale Ensemble Project, and Touchstone Theatre. As the lead member of the consortium entitled Network of Ensemble Theatres (NET), A Traveling Jewish Theatre is requesting support for the continuation of an alternative touring network by and for ensemble theaters. The member ensembles share a common creative process and non-hierarchical structure in which the delineation between playwright and performer and/or between artist and manager often are blurred. In the first year of the program sufficient funding was secured to present four ensemble works. During this grant period, it is planned that eight works would be presented so that each member company will tour its own work and also present another member's work in its home locale. A Traveling Jewish Theatre serves as fiscal sponsor for the project and is responsible for general project management, grant administration and reporting. Each member ensemble shares responsibility for the matching funds, to be derived primarily from ticket income, state and regional tour subsidy programs and local funders.

Purpose: To support the development and presentation of a new staged capoeira production and related programming. Additional Project Description: Information collected from elders will be used to create a new work portraying the contributions of Artistic Director Marcia Tredler, known as Mestra Cigarra, and other women to the Afro-Brazilian tradition of capoeira. Lectures, workshops, and panel discussions will enhance the performance, which will feature music, dance, videos, and spoken-word. Intended Beneficiaries: The performance and ancillary activities will benefit the Brazilian immigrant community, artists, and capoeira enthusiasts in the Bay Area and beyond. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

To support planning and rehearsals for a series of educational workshops and a culminating performance. The artistry of capoeira, a Brazilian tradition combining choreography and martial arts, will be celebrated in a week-long residency of master artists from across the United States and around the world. Artists will include Brazilian master Antonio Marcelo Rodrigues Trindade (Mestre Cobra), who will present workshops about capoeira, as well as a concert. Some activity may take place virtually.

To support the Spirit of Brazil festival. The artistry of capoeira, a Brazilian tradition combining choreography and martial arts, will be celebrated with a two-week residency of master artists from Brazil. The artists will present lectures on capoeira's history and meaning, as well as workshops on capoeira's movements and music. The residency will culminate with a performance at the San Francisco International Arts Festival.

To support a capoeira residency and performance program for students in San Francisco-area schools. Students from underserved communities will learn capoeira, a traditional Afro-Brazilian art form that combines self-defense, acrobatics, and music. Weekly classes, taught by professional teaching artists during the school day and summer, will help students understand the art form's music, historical and cultural history, and performance concepts. Students will work in partners and as a group, interacting in an atmosphere that encourages creativity and spontaneity. Emphasis will be placed on teamwork, concentration, and the use of movement, rhythm, and song as methods of expression.

To support a capoeira residency and performance program for students in San Francisco area schools. Students will learn capoeira, a traditional Afro-Brazilian art form that combines ritual, self-defense, acrobatics, and music in a rhythmic dialogue of the body, mind, and spirit. Students will develop their physical and cognitive skills through weekly classes with professional artists, learning the physical elements of the art form, the music, historical and cultural information, and performance concepts. Students will work in partners and as a group, interacting in an atmosphere that encourages creativity and spontaneity. Emphasis will be placed on teamwork, concentration, and the use of movement, rhythm, and song as methods of expression.

To support a capoeira residency and performance program for students in San Francisco area schools. Students will learn capoeira, a traditional Afro-Brazilian art form that combines ritual, self-defense, acrobatics, and music in a rhythmic dialogue of the body, mind, and spirit. Students will develop their physical and cognitive skills through weekly classes with professional artists, learning the physical elements of the art form, the music, historical and cultural information, and performance concepts. Students will work in partners and as a group, interacting in an atmosphere that encourages creativity and spontaneity. Emphasis will be placed on teamwork, concentration, and the use of movement, rhythm, and song as methods of expression.

To support capoeira arts residency programs led by traditional artists in underserved Oakland and San Francisco elementary schools. Each arts education standards-based lesson combines singing, berimbau and percussion playing, capoeira movement, cultural context, and concludes with students performing together in a circle called roda.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support after-school and summer classes in the aesthetic movement, songs, musical instruments, and history of capoeira. Led by Mestranda Marcia "Cigarra" Treidler, students will learn capoeira movements, sing an appropriate repertory of songs in Portuguese, play traditional instruments, and perform creatively in the roda, the circle formed by students and teachers coming together.

To support the "Spirit of Brazil Festival" and educational activities. The Festival will expand the public's awareness of Brazilian folk arts through a series of performances, lectures, and workshops.
To support the Encuentro del Canto Popular concert. International artists together with local artists perform nueva cancion (new song) music rooted in the Latin American experience.

Organization Name: African American Art and Culture Complex
Project Description: To support the multidisciplinary exhibition The Black Woman is God. Co-curators will work with a curatorial advisory committee and issue a call for artists, with a focus on soliciting work by African-American women in a variety of media.

Organization Name: African American Art and Culture Complex
Project Description: To support planning costs for the multidisciplinary exhibition The Black Woman is God. Co-curators will work with a curatorial advisory committee and issue a call for artists, with a focus on soliciting work by African-American women in a variety of mediums.

Organization Name: African American Art and Culture Complex
Project Description: To support the work of emerging African-American playwrights and performers. The project will connect theater professionals with emerging artists to help them hone their craft and provide career mentorship. Participants will be selected by an advisory committee made up of local African-American performing arts leaders. The selected artists will receive technical assistance, rehearsal and performance space, as well as outreach and marketing services to create higher visability for their art.

Organization Name: African American Art and Culture Complex
Project Description: To support a series of presentations by solo performance artists, part of AfroSolo International. Spoken word artists Lemn Sissay, Yossi Vassa, Danny Beaty, and Aya de Leon will participate in performances and community workshops.

Purpose: To support the theater's 20th anniversary production of Cinderella. Additional Project Description: The story will be adapted and updated by company artists, who also will lead by director Devin Cunningham. The production will be livestreamed and recorded for national distribution. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit theater artists in San Francisco and theater audiences nationwide. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Discipline / Field: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support personnel costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support actor salaries for a virtual production of William Shakespeare's Henry V, in a new translation into modern English by Lloyd Suh. The translation will feature updated language to allow audiences to better connect with the content of the play, and it will be set on the basketball court of an urban neighborhood.

To support the production and performance of "Xtgione," an adaptation of Sophocle's "Antigone," with related activities. Playwright Nambi E. Kelley and director Rhodessa Jones, with musical direction from songwriter and performer Tommy Shepherd, will develop this new work that will speak to the untimely deaths of youth as a result of gang violence. Project activity will include workshops and matinee performances at public schools prior to the premiere of the work during the African-American Shakespeare Company's 2015 season.

To support a production and adaptation of Shakespeare's "Twelfth Night" directed by L. Peter Callender in collaboration with jazz musician/composer Marcus Shelby and his orchestra. The play will be set in the early 1940s era of big band, swing, and jazz.
To support the development of playwright Robert Henry Johnson's commissioned project "The Othello Papers".

Purpose: To support staff salaries and travel for the creation and presentation of "Lineage" with choreography by Artistic Director Alonzo King and music composition by jazz pianist Kris Bowers. Additional Project Description: The work will explore universal themes of suffering and facing obstacles. The performance will be presented at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts. Accompanying engagement activities will include open rehearsals, lecture-demonstrations, and recorded conversations with Bowers and King. Intended Beneficiaries: Audiences and artists in the San Francisco Bay Area will benefit from this project. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support the restaging and presentation of "The Collective Agreement," by Artistic Director Alonzo King. The work includes an orchestral score and light installation by long-time collaborators jazz pianist and composer Jason Moran and artist Jim Campbell. The piece will be a part of performance programs for the company's 40th anniversary season.
To support the creation of a new work by choreographer Alonzo King and vocalist Lisa Fischer. The work will use dancers from LINES Ballet to explore the spiritual convergence of music and movement.

Discipline / Field: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support personnel costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
To support preparations and rehearsal costs for a new work by choreographer Alonzo King. The project will support the development of choreography and artistic fees.

To support the creation and world premiere of a ballet by Alonzo King, in collaboration with the Kronos Quartet. The work will be presented at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco as part of Alonzo King LINES Ballet's 35th anniversary season, which coincides with the Kronos Quartet's 45th anniversary. Performances will be accompanied by engagement activities such as behind-the-scenes videos posted online, post-performance question-and-answer sessions, and a lecture-demonstration with Kronos Quartet.

To support the creation of a new ballet by Alonzo King, in collaboration with Indian tabla master Zakir Hussain. Creation and performances of the work will take place in San Francisco. Archival information about the 35-year history of collaboration between King and Hussain will be available online and in the lobby of performances. Other engagement opportunities may include post-performance question-and-answer sessions and public discussions at LINES Dance Center about the intersection of ballet and classical Indian music.

To support the LINES Ballet Guest Choreography project. LINES Ballet will engage choreographers with a variety of dance styles to work with the pre-professional students of the LINES Ballet Training Program and the LINES Ballet Summer Program. Emerging and seasoned choreographers will set work on hundreds of students, and each student will have an opportunity to work with multiple choreographers. The project will culminate in a final performance at a professional theater in San Francisco.

To support the LINES Ballet Guest Choreography project. LINES Ballet will engage choreographers with a variety of styles to work with the pre-professional students of the LINES Ballet training program and the LINES Ballet summer program. Emerging and seasoned choreographers will set work on hundreds of students, and each student will have an opportunity to work with multiple choreographers. The project will culminate in a final performance at a professional theater in San Francisco.
To support the LINES Ballet Guest Choreography project. LINES Ballet will engage diverse choreographers to work with the pre-professional students of the LINES Ballet training programs.

To support the LINES Ballet Guest Choreography project. LINES Ballet will engage approximately 25 diverse choreographers to work with the pre-professional students of the LINES Ballet training program, and the LINES Ballet Summer Program.

To support the creation and presentation of work by choreographer Alonzo King, in collaboration with bassist and composer Edgar Meyer. The project will include post-performance question-and-answer sessions, as well as free family activities before Sunday performances.

To support the creation of a new work by artistic director Alonzo King. The new work will infuse the classical form of ballet with Sephardic song, music originating from the Jewish communities of medieval Spain and Portugal.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work by Artistic Director and choreographer Alonzo King in collaboration with architect Christopher Haas. The new work will premiere as part of LINES Ballet's fall home season at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work by Artistic Director and choreographer Alonzo King. The new work will premiere as part of LINES Ballet's fall home season at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.
To support the creation and presentation of a new work by Artistic Director Alonzo King. The work will be created in collaboration with legendary jazz saxophonist Pharoah Sanders.
To support the creation and presentation of a new work by artistic director and choreographer Alonzo King. The work will be presented at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.

To support the creation and presentation of a work choreographed by artistic director Alonzo King in collaboration with Moroccan musicians. The work will be presented at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts Theater and at the Mountain View Center for the Arts.
To support the creation and presentation of a new work by choreographer Alonzo King in collaboration with composer and conductor Michael Tilson Thomas.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work based on folk-based musical forms from the American South by Artistic Director Alonzo King. The piece will be based on folk-based music from the American South, and will premiere at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.
To support creation of a new dance work. This work will be choreographed by Alonzo King to music by Polish composer Pawel Syzmanski.
To support creation of a new work. Artistic Director Alonzo King will create a piece to music by Nzamba Lela, a group of musicians from the Central African Republic.

To support a multimedia dance project and gallery installation. The project, choreographed by Yaelisa, incorporates flamenco dance and music, classical music, and spoken text with onstage projections of flamenco photography by Lena Herzog.

To support creation and presentation of a new ballet by choreographer Alonzo King. The ballet will have stage effects designed and created by interdisciplinary artist Ed Tannenbaum in consultation with lighting designer Axel Morgenthaler.
To support the presentation of a national tour.
To support the creation and presentation of a world premiere ballet by Artistic Director Alonzo King. The piece will be set to previously unrecorded music by Henryk Gorecki.

To support the development of "Passage of the Muse," a 45 minute flamenco choreography for theater based on the "Cante Hondo" (Deep Song). Composed to original music by Juan Antonio Suarez, the piece will include a reciting of poetry by a Spanish actress, singing of traditional lyrics by flamenco singers, two guitarists, a cellist, three additional dancers, and slides of paintings.
To support the creation of a ballet choreographed by Alonzo King with music by Zakir Hussain.

To support the American Bach Soloists Festival  Academy. The early music academy will offer conservatory-level students and professional musicians the opportunity to study and perform Baroque music side-by-side with faculty. The coinciding festival will feature free and ticketed concerts, master classes, lectures, and other events. Concerts may include a performance of Bach's Mass in B Minor and other large-scale works. Also planned is the annual Baroque Marathon, a series of free chamber music concerts by academy participants that may last as long as eight hours.

To support the Handel Celebration. Marking the 250th anniversary of G. F. Handel's death and the ensemble's 20th anniversary season, period-instrument concerts will feature large choral anthems and the composer's "Music for Royal Fireworks."

To support the presentation of historically informed choral performances and pre-concert lectures. A consort of viols will accompany singers in a program of performances of choral works by 16th- and 17th-century English composers, including William Byrd, Orlando Gibbons, and Henry Purcell.
To support historically informed performances of J.S. Bach's St. Matthew Passion (1729). The performing forces will match those employed by the composer at his church in Leipzig.

Purpose: To support actor salaries for the production of "The Headlands" by Christopher Chen, directed by Pam MacKinnon. Additional Project Description: Inspired by the noir fiction subset of the crime fiction genre, the play tells the story of Henry, an amateur sleuth setting out to solve the murder of his father. Henry's investigation leads him to question the foundation of his memories, as the truths behind the family stories he was told as a child begin to emerge. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit theater artists and audiences in San Francisco. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support actor salaries for the production of Fefu and Her Friends by Mara Irene Forns, directed by Pam MacKinnon. Additional Project Description: Set in New England during the spring of 1935, the play follows a group of wealthy friends gathered to discuss a charity event they are planning. As the narrative progresses, the performance will evolve into an immersive study of personality, relationships, experiences, and the audience's own perceptions of reality. The audience will be divided up into sections and travel throughout the theater's facility to see different scenes of the work. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit theater artists and audiences in the San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the commissioning, development, and production of a new virtual theater work by Christopher Chen, directed by Pam MacKinnon. Based on the concept of bluffing in a card game, the interactive work will offer audience members the opportunity to choose the ending of each performance.

To support actor fees for a production of Toni Stone by Lydia R. Diamond. The play explores the experiences of the first woman who played professional baseball in the 1940s, and is based on the biography Curveball, The Remarkable Story of Toni Stone by Martha Ackmann. The theater also will publish an in-depth performance guide and offer workshops and discussions for audience members.

To support a production of Rhinoceros by Eugene Ionesco, adapted and directed by Frank Galati. Originally written as response to the rise of fascism in 20th-century Europe, the production will be updated for contemporary audiences. Related community outreach activities include audience discussions, interactive workshops, and a comprehensive study guide for students and educators.

To support a production of "Vietgone" by Qui Nguyen. The historical romantic comedy is about two Vietnamese refugees who navigate the bewildering and foreign landscape of 1970s America. Nguyen employs pop-culture references, comic book characters, and contemporary language to make this historic era accessible to today's audiences. Moving from hilarity to heart-wrenching drama, "Vietgone" examines what it means to rebuild a family when one has no home. The production will be part of the theater's continued efforts to engage with the growing Asian-American population in San Francisco.

To support a production of "A Thousand Splendid Suns" by Ursula Rani Sarma. The adaptation of the novel by Khaled Hosseini is set in contemporary Afghanistan, and explores a friendship between two women from different backgrounds. Together they struggle to survive sectarian violence and changing political winds. The story reveals Afghan class and gender politics and confronts misconceptions about the roles of women in Middle Eastern cultures. Afghan artist Humaira Ghilzai may serve as a cultural consultant for the project to provide historical accuracy and assist in outreach efforts to the communities represented in the play.

To support the production of "Monstress." The project includes two one-act plays inspired by Lysley Tenorio's short story collection titled "Monstress." Theater artists with Filipino connections will adapt Tenorio's stories for the stage. Writer Philip Kan Gotanda, will adapt "Save the I-Hotel" and Sean San Jose will retell the title story "Monstress."

To support a production of James Fenton's adaptation of "The Orphan of Zhao," with direction by Artistic Director Carey Perloff. Actor BD Wong will star in this ancient Chinese epic about a doctor who sacrifices his only child in order to save the heir of a famous clan that has been eradicated by a violent political regime. Often described as the Chinese "Hamlet" and the first Chinese play to be translated in the West, it has inspired countless operas, plays, and movies.

To support the premiere of "Stuck Elevator" by writer Aaron Jafferis and composer Byron Au Yong. Based on the true story of an undocumented immigrant who survived 81 hours in a Bronx elevator, the Chinese American hip-hop opera portrays a Chinese food deliveryman struggling for freedom from debt, human smugglers, and untrustworthy coworkers, and his attempts to escape his physical and existential fate.

To support the West Coast premiere of "Scorched" by Lebanese-born Canadian playwright Wadji Mouawad, directed by artistic director Carey Perloff. Set in a fictional war-torn Middle Eastern country, the play explores the chaos and suffering caused by war, and the relationship between family and identity as it tells the story of immigrant twins who receive a surprising request in their late mother's will.

To support the world premiere of a musical adapted from "Tales of the City" by Armistead Maupin, which will be created by composers Jake Shears and John Garden and librettist Jeff Whitty, directed by Jason Moore. In close consultation with the novelist, the musical will re-invent the lives and adventurous spirit of the 1970s characters and residents of "28 Barbary Lane" that captured the imagination of readers of the serial published in The San Francisco Chronicle.
To support the world premiere of "The Tosca Project". The movement-based theatrical production will be co-created by artistic director Carey Perloff and choreographer Val Caniparoli.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support a world premiere production of "War Music," a large-scale original play created by Lillian Groag. The work will be based on contemporary British poet Christopher Logue's English-language adaptation of Homer's The Illiad.

To support the production of John Ford's "Tis A Pity She's A Whore" with accompanying educational activities. Artistic director Carey Perloff will direct the rarely produced Jacobean tragedy with original music composed by Tony Award winning composer Ducan Sheik.

To support the world premiere production of "After the War," a new play by Philip Kan Gotanda. The playwright will collaborate with artistic director Carey Perloff, composer Anthony Brown, and members of the American Conservatory Theatre core company of actors.

To support the production of "Happy End" by Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill. Artistic Director Carey Perloff will direct Happy End by Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill, with music direction by Constantine Kitsopoulos.

To support the adaptation and production of "The Voysey Inheritance" by Harley Granville-Barker. Playwright David Mamet will adapt the original version of the 1905 play; Carey Perloff will direct the production.

To support the development and world premiere production of "Levee James," a new play by Sherry Shephard-Massat. Israel Hicks, director of the project's workshop production at the O'Neill Playwrights Conference, is slated to direct.
To support pre-production activities for the world premiere of a new play, "Malaya," by Chay Yew.

To support the production of a new translation of Maxim Gorky's"Vassa Zheleznova" by American playwright Constance Congdon. Artistic Director Carey Perloff will direct the production featuring Olympia Dukakis and members of the theater's new core acting ensemble.

To support production expenses for performances in alternate venues featuring third-year students from the A.C.T. Conservatory Advanced Training Program for actors. The productions will promote awareness of the Conservatory as a community asset.

To support the workshop phase of a collaborative work of music theater, "The Difficulty of Crossing a Field," based on a short story by Ambrose Bierce, with libretto by Mac Wellman, score by David Lang, and the participation of the Kronos Quartet. The American Conservatory Theater (ACT) is seeking support for the workshop phase of a collaborative work of music theater, "The Difficulty of Crossing a Field," based on a short story by Ambrose Bierce with libretto by Mac Wellman, score by David Lang, and the participation of the Kronos Quartet. The project will feature a collaboration between artistic director Carey Perloff, playwright Mac Wellman, and composer David Lang. The work is part of two major new thrusts of A.C.T. to nurture the careers of diverse contemporary playwrights in A.C.T. mainstage productions and to build fruitful collaborative relationships with multi-disciplinary Bay Area cultural institutions.
To support the 28th annual American Indian Film Festival. At the 2003 festival, documentaries and feature films will be presented along with work by emerging Native American filmmakers.

To support the 2002 annual American Indian Film Festival and the quarterly film journal INDIAN CINEMA ENTERTAINMENT. At the 27th anniversary festival, documentaries and feature films will be presented along with work by emerging Native filmmakers.
To support the annual American Indian Film Festival and the quarterly film journal INDIAN CINEMA ENTERTAINMENT.
To support the 1999 annual American Indian Film Festival and the quarterly film journal INDIAN CINEMA ENTERTAINMENT.

To support the 1998 American Indian Film Festival and the publication of the nationally distributed film journal "Indian Cinema Entertainment." The American Indian Film Institute (AIFI) will conduct its 23rd annual American Indian Film Festival in 1998 which is expected to draw an audience of over 5,000 people. Attendees will see films by and about Native Americans which normally are not available through commercial venues, home video, or television. As part of the festival, AIFI sponsors "Media Forums," which encourage discussions with audience and makers, and which build artistic and economic relationships as well as a sense of community for American Indian filmmakers. Topics under consideration for the forums include a Native Screenwriting Forum, Film Financing for Native American Filmmakers, and Native American Film Promotion and Distribution. AIFI also publishes "Indian Cinema Entertainment" ("ICE"), a quarterly film journal dedicated to all aspects of Native filmmaking (acting, directing, writing, cinematography, etc.). The magazine's run of 2,500 issues is distributed to a paid subscription base of 700 individuals and organizations and to industry professionals, public agencies, and educational institutions. In addition, "ICE" provides editorial

Purpose: To support an artistic fellowship program. Additional Project Description: The program provides administrative and artistic tools required to transition from a career in performance to leadership. The selected fellow, choreographer Natasha Adorlee, will be mentored in board governance, financial oversight, production design, marketing, and development. Adorlee is in her final year of the program, which will include multiple performances of her new work using 3D projection technology. Intended Beneficiaries: The fellowship program and public performances will serve the selected fellow as well as the San Francisco Bay Area's technology and arts communities. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support "Stronger in the Broken Places," a dance film choreographed by Amy Seiwert. The film will explore re-forming identity when outside influences fracture one's sense of self. Seiwert will collaborate with Marc Bamuthi Joseph for a spoken-word libretto and Daniel Bernard Roumain for a musical score.

To support the innovative use of projections and lighting for the SKETCH series, an annual creative laboratory for ballet-based choreography Several choreographers, including Amy Seiwert and Ben Neeham-Wood, will create a new ballet for the dancers in the company. Each year the SKETCH series is focused on a theme and this year's theme explores using projection as a theatrical lighting source. There will be a work-in-progress showing prior to the premiere at ODC Theater in San Francisco.

Purpose: To support a presentation of Towards Opulence, directed by choreographer Anne Bluethenthal in collaboration with the ensemble Skywatchers. Additional Project Description: Skywatchers is an intergenerational, community-based group comprising residents of San Francisco's Tenderloin neighborhood. The work uses movement, spoken-word, and music to reflect the voices and experiences of the residents. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit participants and audiences in San Francisco's Tenderloin neighborhood including those who are unhoused and low- to no-income. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Purpose: To support multidisciplinary arts activities that address health equity in San Francisco's Tenderloin district. Additional Project Description: The project will bring together Tenderloin residents and health providers to share stories of trauma through dialogue, storytelling, music, and movement during workshops, community forums, and collaborative site-specific performances, and collected within an audio and video story archive. The project is a partnership of ABD Productions (a multi-ethnic, mixed-ability community-based performing arts ensemble) and San Francisco Arts Commission, the city's Planning Commission, Department of Public Health, and University of California San Francisco's Center for Community Engagement. This project will encourage communication among healthcare providers and low-income Tenderloin residents, as well as between city agencies. It will align with multiple city agency efforts to address health and wellness for housing insecure residents. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit residents and healthcare providers of San Francisco's Tenderloin district. Intended Outcome: The arts are integrated into the fabric of community life.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the presentation of Life in the Containment Zone Under Quarantine, directed by choreographer Anne Bluethenthal in collaboration with the ensemble Skywatchers. Skywatchers is an intergenerational, community-based group comprising residents of San Francisco's Tenderloin neighborhood. The work uses movement, recorded text, and video projection to reflect the voices and experiences of the residents.

To support Skywatchers: At the Table, a series of community workshops, events and site-specific performances, in partnership with the San Francisco Arts Commission. Working in collaboration with residents of the Tenderloin neighborhood, ABD Productions will hold community meetings and arts-based workshops to explore issues related to implementation and sustainability of housing for the homeless. Based on content generated in these meetings, ABD Productions will facilitate creation of site-specific community performances and artistic activities to engage residents to be performers, foster a sense of pride and ownership within the community, and challenge negative narratives about the neighborhood and homeless populations.
To support the concert of Algerian Amazigh vocalist and musician, Takfarinas.

Purpose: To support a multimedia showcase of Arab women in the arts. Additional Project Description: This program will feature virtual and in-person film screenings, live multimedia performances, and poetry readings, accompanied by discussions with guest artists. The program will also tour to additional locations across the United States. Intended Beneficiaries: Festival programming will serve general audiences in San Francisco, as well as national audiences through online and touring events. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support personnel costs for the Arab Film Festival and related public programming. Additional Project Description: Highlighting Arab cinema and culture, virtual and in-person film screenings will be accompanied by public events, including moderated panel discussions and networking opportunities for filmmakers. Intended Beneficiaries: Festival programming will serve general audiences in San Francisco and Los Angeles, as well as national audiences and filmmakers. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the Arab Film Festival and related public programming. Highlighting Arab cinema and culture, the film screenings will be accompanied by public events, including moderated panel discussions and networking opportunities for filmmakers. Festival activities will be presented virtually and in person.
To support the "Beginner's Guide On the Road Project." The organization will produce and disseminate online professional development resources.

To support NEW VILLAGE PRESS. The publication presents case studies of grassroots projects about cultural heritage and neighborhood spirit that serve immigrant communities, children, youth,the physically ill, and other underserved populations.

To support the Open Architecture Challenge. The 2012 challenge is an ideas competition that invites architects and designers from around the world to develop innovative urban design and land use solutions for the re-purposing of former and decommissioned military sites.

To support the planning and development phase of Building Blocks for Sustainable Schools, a pilot program for greening schools nationwide, in consortium with United States Green Building Council's Center for Green Schools. The project will develop a technical and financial assistance program to support green renovation and modernization of existing school facilities.
To support the expansion of the Open Architecture Network. Both the content and the accessibility of the Web site

To support the second volume of Design Like You Give a Damn. The book will include case studies of design projects in the built environment that address systemic poverty, support community development, and provide shelter to the homeless and the displaced.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support The 2009 Open Architecture Challenge: Portable Classrooms, an online design competition. The project will invite K-12 students and teachers to partner with architects in their community to design innovative and viable alternatives to portable classrooms.

To support Phase III of the 2009 Open Architecture Challenge: Portable program, Classrooms design competition, in consortium with Do Something Inc. Architecture for Humanity will help participant students develop and implement a series of activities and exhibitions in their communities related to the 2009 Open Architecture Challenge: Portable Classrooms design competition.

To support a workshop and international competition for the design and planning of refugee shelter sites. The project will bring together relief professionals, architects, and designers to envision innovative and sustainable shelter alternatives.

Organization Name: Art of the Matter Performance Foundation
Project Description: To support the premiere of inCIVILITY: A Seat at the Table by choreographer Deborah Slater. Deborah Slater Dance Theater will co-present the work with ODC Theater. The piece will explore themes of humanity, power, and place through dance, interactive technical design, text, and music.

Organization Name: Art of the Matter Performance Foundation
Project Description: To support the creation of a new work "Time's Arrow," by Artistic Director Deborah Slater. Slater will collaborate with composer/performer Darren Johnston and lighting/set designer Allen Willner to investigate the idea of "love over time." Working with StoryCorps, and through interviews with centenarians, aging boomers, and millennials, the work will demonstrate life's complexity of change, aging, enduring loss, and how we are transformed by these experiences.

Organization Name: Art of the Matter Performance Foundation
Project Description: To support the San Francisco Butoh Festival 2002. The program will revolve around Japan's leading female contemporary choreographers, and offer a program of symposia, workshops, master classes, and performances.

Organization Name: Art of the Matter Performance Foundation
Project Description: To support the San Francisco Butoh Festival 2001. The Festival will present NIBROLL, a group based in Japan, and Katsura Kan, master Butoh artist from Thailand, and offer performances, workshops, master classes, and a symposia.

To support expansion of the Online Library for Interactive Video and Engagement (OLIVE). Devoted to growing a curated collection of short films that explore themes of mental health, expansion of the web portal will include resources and interactive features such as online discussions with filmmakers and free curriculum guides for use in schools. Select films are also used in workshops focused on media literacy and mental health awareness at high schools and colleges throughout California, with expansion planned to additional schools across the country.
To support the commissioning, development, and production of a new play by Philip Kan Gotanda with accompanying outreach activities. 4CD and #5 ANGRY RED DRUM will be developed and workshopped.

To support the production of WALLS by playwright Jeannie Barroga and the MY WALLS Letter project. The play depicts stories of Vietnam soldiers as they prepare for the unveiling of Maya Lin's Vietnam War Memorial in Washington, DC.

To support the "NewWorks Incubator," a workshop program that will develop, produce, and electronically publish new plays about the Asian Pacific American experience. Under the oversight of playwright Philip Kan Gotanda, the program will combine a research and development model with a conservatory approach to create new plays.
To support a workshop led by Chay Yew. The script will focus on the history and lives of four Chinese women living in San Francisco from 1850 to 2000.

To support the creation of an original theatrical work about Asian Pacific Islander American and Chicano/Latino issues and the intersection of the two communities. The work, tentatively entitled Party Like It's 1999, will engage writers and performers from four different theater groups to develop a collection of comedy skits, monologues, and musical numbers.

To support production costs for a new play written and directed by Philip Kan Gotanda entitled "The Sisters Matsumoto" to be produced in San Francisco and focusing on three sisters in Stockton, California in 1951 and how their lives are changed by their experience of internment during World War II. Philip Kan Gotanda's play, tentatively entitled "The Sisters Matsumoto," will focus on the lives of three sisters in Stockton, CA in 1951 and how their lives are changed by their experience of internment during World War II. In writing this new work, Mr. Gotanda will draw upon his expertise as a playwright - developed over nearly twenty years of working in the professional theater, upon his personal experience as a descendent of former detainees, the oral histories of family and other detainees, and the existing body of research on the exclusion and detention of Japanese Americans during World War II. Asian American Theater Workshop has already received a grant from the Civil Liberties Public Education Fund to commission and develop the new play. During the script development phase, former detainees from the local community will be invited to attend the workshop reading and provide feedback. Arts Endowment funds will support production costs. It is planned that a majority of the participating artists will be direct descendants of interned Japanese Americans.

To support the Asian American Women Arts Resource Initiative. The online research resource will focus on the presentation and documention of contributions by Asian-American women in the arts. A redesigned and upgraded website will include expanded access to the digital catalogue of artists' work and the organization's archival collection of promotional materials, catalogues, photographs, videos, and audio recordings. The initiative will make selected collections available online to the public and provide a comprehensive history of Asian-American communities and cultures by celebrating the work of Asian-American women artists.

To support a multidisciplinary art exhibition inspired by the life and work of Japanese-American civil rights leader Yuri Kochiyama. The exhibition will feature invited and juror-selected emerging and established artists from around the country. Priority outreach will be focused on Asian- and Pacific Islander-American, African-American, and Latino communities, but the exhibition will be open to artists of all ethnicities and genders. Exhibition programming will include a panel discussion. The primary exhibition site will be SOMArts Culture Center in San Francisco, with a smaller satellite exhibition held in Oakland.

To support "A Place of Her Own," a multidisciplinary arts exhibition and accompanying programs featuring selected Asian American women artists. Artists will be selected by guest curators Rene Baldocchi, Director of Public Programs at the de Young Museum in San Francisco; Margo Machida, Assistant Professor of Art History and Asian American Studies at the University of Connecticut; and Inson Choy, independent curator and exhibition development consultant.

Organization Name: Asian Art Museum Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: Purpose: To support an exhibition that explores the connection between the visual arts and dance of the Indian cultural sphere. Additional Project Description: Featuring as many as 123 artworks from more than 20 museum and private collections, the exhibition will be augmented by film clips, historical photographs, and a variety of educational materials. The exhibition will highlight the importance of dance to the societies of South and Southeast Asia and the Himalayas. Intended Beneficiaries: The exhibition will serve students, teachers, and audiences, including those who self-identify as South or Southeast Asian or Himalayan. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Organization Name: Asian Art Museum Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support an exhibition of Korean portraiture from the Joseon dynasty. The exhibition will feature portraits created during the Joseon kingdom which lasted five centuries and will include an exploration of the production process, including rare sets of draft examples alongside finished portraits, the social norms associated with portrait-making, and the historical significance of the officials pictured.

Organization Name: Asian Art Museum Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Organization Name: Asian Art Museum Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support "Emperors' Treasures: Chinese Art from the National Palace Museum, Taipei." The exhibition will explore the roles of eight major rulers of the Song, Yuan, Ming, and Qing dynasties. Visitors will learn about China's history, artistic legacy, culture, and history through the presentation of more than 150 bronzes, jades, ceramics, paintings, calligraphies, and other curios, many shown in the U.S. for the first time. A bilingual media guide will enrich the displays with stories of the emperors' personal lives and the aesthetic sensibilities of their reigns. Extensive educational programs and public events are planned.

Organization Name: Asian Art Museum Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support an exhibition of Asian contemporary art, "Phantoms of Asia," and an accompanying catalogue. Curated by the chief curator of the Mori Museum in Tokyo, the exhibition will examine the spiritual, religious, and cultural environments of Buddhism, Shinto, Confucianism, Taoism, Hinduism, and Islam, and how these environments coexist multi-dimensionally in Asia and abroad through magic, folklore rituals, oracles, and religious services.

Organization Name: Asian Art Museum Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the touring exhibition Shanghai: 1850 to Present, with accompanying education programs. As Shanghai's sister city, San Francisco will present the exhibition to coincide with Shanghai's 2010 World Expo.

Organization Name: Asian Art Museum Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

Organization Name: Asian Art Museum Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the exhibition "Samurai," with accompanying catalogue and education programs. Most of the objects selected for the exhibition have never before been seen outside of Japan.

Organization Name: Asian Art Museum Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the touring exhibition "Power and Glory: Court Arts of China's Ming Dynasty" with accompanying catalogue and education programs. The exhibition will be the first major exhibition in the United States to focus on China's Ming court arts.

Organization Name: Asian Art Museum Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the exhibition "Princes, Palaces, and Passion: The Art of India's Mewar Kingdom," with accompanying catalogue and education programs. This will be the first exhibition outside of India to focus on the former princely state of Mewar.

Organization Name: Asian Art Museum Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the exhibition THE ELEGANT GATHERING: THE YEH FAMILY COLLECTION, with accompanying catalogue and education programs. The exhibition of Chinese calligraphies and ink paintings, in the museum's permanent collection, will use the ancient tradition of "yaji," or "elegant gatherings," to explore the social, historical, and political contexts surrounding the collection.

Organization Name: Asian Art Museum Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the touring exhibition THE KINGDOM OF SIAM: ART AND CULTURE OF CENTRAL THAILAND 1350-1800, with accompanying catalogue and educational programs. The exhibition will highlight the little known arts of the Thai kingdom of Ayutthaya, and will provide American audiences with their first opportunity in 25 years to see classical art from Thailand.

Organization Name: Asian Art Museum Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the exhibition ARTS OF THE GORYEO DYNASTY, with accompanying catalogue and education programs.

Organization Name: Asian Art Museum Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support conservation of lacquer decorative art objects. An additional goal of the project is to help establish professional standards for the treatment of lacquer objects.

To support staff salaries and artistic fees for the rehearsal period of a new site-responsive, multimedia dance project by Lenora Lee Dance. The performance will take place on Alcatraz in San Francisco Bay, and will focus on incarceration, detention, reconciliation, and justice. Audiences will travel through Alcatraz by following the dancers in an interactive performance.

To support the creation and presentation of composer/performer Dohee Lee's "The I-ching Project: Flux--Passages of Change." The work will incorporate a unique combination of improvisational brass, string, percussive sounds, film, lights, and movement.
To support the creation and presentation of a new work incorporting Odori (dance), Taiko (drums), and shinobue (Japanese flute). The project will culminate with an 11th Anniversary Concert.

To support the commissioning, development, and presentation of a new work by composer Francis Wong and librettist Genny Lim. Shanghai 1948: George and Noela's Story (working title) will be scored for jazz ensemble and two vocalists.

To support Talking Roots Arts Collective. Through artist-in-residence programs, the project will offer after-school classes in poetry, theater, and dance for Asian and Pacific Islander youths, ages 12 to 18, in Central and East Oakland.

To support the fifth annual Asian Pacific American Arts and Heritage Festival. The multidisciplinary and multi-venue festival is a consortium effort with the Japanese Cultural and Community Center of Northern California.

To support the consortium project Day of Remembrance. This annual cultural arts and education presentation is organized in rememberance of the World War II incarceration of Japanese American and Japanese Peruvian civilians.

To support a series of residencies, performances, workshops, and an exhibition. APICC will partner with Bindlestiff Studio and the Chinatown Community Development Corporation to provide artists in residence with space at sites in San Francisco's Chinatown and South of Market Area neighborhoods, as well as technical, marketing, and event production support. Programming will be offered virtually as necessary.

To support the United States of Asian America Festival, a multidisciplinary arts festival celebrating Asian and Pacific Islander American culture. Guest artists composer and pianist Jon Jang and visual artist Sami See will present new work at the festival, serve as jurors to select festival performers, and provide mentorship for festival artists. Activities may be presented virtually.

To support a a multisensory dance performance and community-centered ceremonial process focusing on collective Pilipino cultural survival, healing and spiritual reclamation. Throughout the residency, Lead artist Alleluia Panis, the Asian Pacific Islander Cultural Center, artists and community members will reflect on the impact of colonial trauma through dancing, singing, telling stories, and public performance rituals drawn from indigenous Filipino practices and reimagined for a contemporary diasporic setting.

To support the production and exhibition of short films for Cinematic SF. The film series will highlight the daily experiences and untold stories of San Francisco's underserved communities. Selected media artists will create films in local San Francisco neighborhoods covering topics such as displacement, gentrification, cross-cultural understanding, and historic preservation. Once completed, the films will be screened at local community organizations, accompanied by panel discussions, and made available to view online.

To support the development and production of marketing materials promoting Asian American and Pacific Islander American cultural organizations. Organizations such as Asian Improv aRts, Kearney Street Workshop, and the Chinese Cultural Center will benefit from the collaborative marketing project that will focus on the Bay Area Asian and Pacific Islander community.

To support a retrospective exhibition of Flo Oy Wong, a mixed media artist. The exhibition will be part of the Annual United States of Asian America Festival at the SomArts Cultural Center in San Francisco.

To support the 10th annual United States of Asian America Festival. The festival will present arts programs featuring contemporary Asian American artists and arts organizations at various San Francisco venues.

To support the 9th annual United States of Asian America festival. Now in its ninth year, this multidisciplinary festival takes place in numerous San Francisco venues including the South of Market Cultural Center.

To support the eighth annual United States of Asian American Festival. Asian American artists will present traditional and contemporary events in various artistic disciplines, including a Hawaiian music and dance performance and films by South Asian Muslim filmmakers.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel, facilities and marketing expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organizations constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

Purpose: To support the creation and exhibition of new works through a residency program for immersive sound artists in the San Francisco Bay Area. Additional Project Description: Founded by artists Stan Shaff and Doug McEachern in the early 1960s, Audium is one of the first art spaces dedicated to the exploration of spatial sound composition and performance. Participating artists will receive stipends to compose and publicly perform new site-specific works for Audium's facilities. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit sound artists and composers in the San Francisco Bay Area, as well as general audiences attending the public performances. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support the creation and exhibition of new works through a residency program for immersive sound artists in the San Francisco Bay Area. Founded by artists Stan Shaff and Doug McEachern in the early 1960s, Audium is one of the first art spaces dedicated to the exploration of spatial sound composition and performance. Participating artists will receive stipends to compose and publicly perform new site-specific works for Audium's facilities, which consists of 176 speakers and a fully customizable audio mixing board and lighting system.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organizations constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support literary programming in cities across the country. Contributors to and editors of the poetry and prose anthology "Imaniman" will give free readings and workshops in Latino and Chicano communities in such cities as Austin, Los Angeles, San Antonio, San Francisco, and Washington, D.C. Published by Aunt Lute Books, the anthology explores the work of writer Gloria Anzaldua. Local partner organizations will conduct outreach to promote activities to community members.

To support the publication and promotion of "Good Girls Marry Doctors." The project is an anthology of essays by second generation South Asian women authors on such topics as identity, sexuality, class, and generational conflicts. The essays will focus on cultural pressures felt by daughters of South Asian descent. Aunt Lute will maintain an online community forum and present panel discussions around the country to futher explore issues raised in the anthology.

To support the publication and promotion of print and electronic books by American Indian and Chicana authors. The press will promote the books through social media, touring authors in pairs, reviving partnerships with local community organizers, and maintaining proactive blogs on the press's Web site with suggested writing projects and other incentives.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.
To support the publication and promotion of "Beautiful and Dark" by Spanish author Rosa Montero.
To support the publication and promotion of a new work of multicultural fiction by a woman writer. The press will tour the author to diverse communities across the country.

To support the publication and promotion of MIKO KINGS by Choctaw author LeAnne Howe. Ms. Howe will go on an extensive eight-city tour coinciding with the broadcast of her one-hour special on the Choctaw nation on public television.
To support the publication of an anthology of twentieth century U.S. women writers.
To support publication and promotion of FAR AND BEYON', a novel by Unity Dow of Botswana.

To support publication and related costs for a new series of books by Native American women. Aunt Lute Books will tour its featured author to areas of the country with large Native American populations, including Washington, California, Montana, Minnesota, and parts of the South and Southwest.
To support publication and related costs for an anthology of writings by women. Aunt Lute will publish Babaylan, Fiction and Poetry by Filipina and Filipina American Women.

To support the publication and national distribution of two books in Aunt Lute's Translation Series: the first novel of Chinese writer Yan Jeling, and Cuban writer Mirta Yanez's HAVANA IS A VERY BIG CITY; with associated multi-city national reading tours. PROJECT DESCRIPTION: Mirta Y ez's volume of short stories, Havana Is A Very Big City, chronicles women's lives in contemporary Cuba. Previous translations from the press include I Remember, an anthology of memoirs by women refuges from the former Yugoslavia, and Reclaiming Medusa, a volume of short stories by Puerto Rican authors. Founded in 1982, Aunt Lute publishes books concerning contemporary issues for women and people of color.
To support creation and presentation of a new work. The work will be based on Carmen Amaya, the woman who incorporated virtuoso footwork that was previously only in the male domain.
