To support the creation and presentation of a flamenco dance piece influenced by ballet. Artistic Director Rosa Montoya and choreographer Carlos Carvajal will create a piece to Maurice Ravel's Rapsodie Espagnole.

Purpose: To support the Preservation Access Program, which provides affordable access to video and audio preservation services. Additional Project Description: Selected through an open submission process, artists and cultural organizations will receive subsidized access to archival-quality preservation, digitization, and collection assessment services to preserve artistically significant audio and video collections. Approximately 700 hours of audiovisual material, including film and media in early digital formats, are expected to be preserved and made accessible to the public, including curators, educators, and researchers. Intended Beneficiaries: This program will serve media artists and audiences nationwide, as well as archives, museums, libraries, educational institutions, and other organizations that hold arts-related media collections. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the National MediaMaker Fellowship Program and related audio and visual preservation services. Additional Project Description: Through the MediaMaker Fellowship Program, participating artists will receive stipends and access to production equipment, professional development opportunities, hands-on training, mentorship, and convenings to develop peer networks, further their careers, and develop new projects. In addition, through an expansion of Bay Area Video Coalition's Preservation Access Program, fellows will have the opportunity to receive collection assessment and preservation services for their film works and to use preserved footage in new documentary films. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve participating artists, with a focus on filmmakers from underrepresented communities. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

Purpose: To support staff costs for the MediaMaker Fellowship Program. Additional Project Description: Activities include planning for the 2023 round of the program and selection of the new fellows. The fellows will be selected through an open call application process. Fellows will receive participation stipends, professional development opportunities, hands-on training, industry mentorship, and in-person and online convenings to develop peer networks, further their careers, and develop new projects. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve emerging filmmakers from across the United States. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel, facilities, and marketing expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organizations constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support staff salaries and administrative costs for the provision of video and audio preservation services. Through the Preservation Access Program, BAVC will work with media artists and cultural organizations across the country to ensure that artistically significant works are preserved and made accessible to the public for live and online exhibition and distribution. As many as 700 hours of audiovisual material and media in early digital formats are expected to be preserved.

To support staff salaries and administrative costs for the provision of video and audio preservation services. Through the Preservation Access Program, the Bay Area Video Coalition will work with media artists and cultural organizations across the country to ensure that artistically significant works are preserved and made accessible to the public for live and online exhibition and distribution. Approximately 350 hours of audiovisual material as well as media in early digital formats are expected to be preserved

To support the National MediaMaker Fellowship Program. Fellows selected through an open call application process will receive participation stipends and access to production equipment, professional development opportunities, hands-on training, industry mentorship, and in-person and online convenings to develop peer networks, further their careers, and develop new projects.

To support the National MediaMaker Fellowship Program. BAVC will provide selected nonfiction media artists with stipends and access to production equipment, professional development opportunities, hands-on training, and industry mentorship to further their careers and develop new works.

To support program staff, travel, lodging, and fees associated with the National MediaMaker Fellows Program that fosters the careers of nonfiction media artists. BAVC will provide selected artists with access to production equipment, project development, hands-on training, stipends, and exhibition and distribution strategies to further their careers. Fellows receive mentorship with nonprofit partners, distributors, journalists, interactive developers, funders, and curriculum specialists to develop new works. In addition to traditional filmmaking, the program will include support for the incubation and development of new work in expanded media formats, such as interactive games, multi-platform documentaries, and mobile apps.

To support the provision of video and audio preservation services. Through the Preservation Access Program, the Bay Area Video Coalition will work with media artists and cultural organizations across the country to ensure that artistically significant works are preserved and made accessible to the public for live and online exhibition and distribution. Approximately 700 hours of audiovisual material as well as media in early digital formats are expected to be preserved.

To support the provision of video and audio preservation services. Through the Preservation Access Program, the Bay Area Video Coalition will work with media artists and cultural organizations to ensure that artistically significant works are preserved and made accessible to the public for live and online exhibitions. Approximately 700 hours of audiovisual material as well as media in early digital formats are expected to be preserved.

To support the National MediaMaker Fellows Program. With a focus on documentary media artists, BAVC will provide selected artists with access to production equipment, project development, hands-on training, and exhibition and distribution strategies to further their careers. Fellows will work with mentors such as journalists, nonprofit partners, distributors, interactive developers, funders, and curriculum specialists to develop the strongest possible project. Since expanding the program to include new media, fellows also will have the opportunity to produce interactive games, transmedia documentaries, and mobile apps.

Category: National Arts and Humanities Youth Program Awards
Project Description: In recognition of Next Gen. The after-school media arts program provides high school students from low-income families in San Francisco, California, with beginner- and advanced-level video and audio production training, paid internship opportunities, individual mentorships, and career development services.

To support the provision of video and audio preservation services. Through the Preservation Access Program, the Bay Area Video Coalition will work with media artists and cultural organizations to ensure that artistically significant works are preserved and made available to the public for live and online exhibitions. Approximately 300 hours of audiovisual material as well as media in early digital formats are expected to be preserved.

To support the MediaMaker Fellows program. With a focus on documentary media artists, the program provides selected artists with access to production equipment, project development, hands-on training, and exhibition and distribution strategies to further their careers. Fellows will work with mentors such as journalists, nonprofit partners, distributors, interactive developers, funders, and curriculum specialists to develop the strongest possible project. Since expanding the program to include new media, fellows also have produced interactive games, transmedia documentaries, and mobile apps.

To support the MediaMakers Fellows Program and the required product of copies of work produced. With a focus on documentary media artists, the project provides the selected artists with access to production equipment, project development, hands-on training, and exhibition and distribution strategies to further their careers. Fellows will work with mentors who are journalists, nonprofit partners, distributors, interactive developers, funders and curriculum specialists to develop the strongest possible project. Since expanding the program in recent years to include new media, fellows have also produced interactive games, transmedia documentaries, and mobile apps.

To support the provision of video preservation services. Through the Preservation Access Program, the Bay Area Video Coalition will work with media artists and cultural organizations to ensure that artistically significant works are preserved and made available to the public for live and online exhibitions. Hundreds of hours of video and audio will be preserved. Recent clients include Dance Theatre of Harlem, The Poetry Center and American Poetry Archive, and Video Data Bank.

To support the MediaMakers Fellows Program Targeted to as many as six documentary makers, the project provides the selected artists with access to production equipment, project development hands-on training, and exhibition and distribution strategies to further their careers.

To support the provision of video and audio preservation services. Through the Preservation Access Program, the Bay Area Video Coalition will work with artists, museums and other cultural institutions to ensure that historically significant artworks are preserved and accessible to the public for live and online presentations. Past clients include the Long Beach Museum of Art, the Dance Heritage Coalition, the Walker Art Center and artists such as William Wegman, Nam June Paik and Joan Jonas.

To support the provision of video preservation services to media artists and cultural organizations. Services include the recording, retrieval, and preservation of audio and video art as well as the distribution of that content to the public.

To support the Mediamaker Fellows program. The program provides independent video artists and producers with the technical assistance and resources they need to finish their projects. Eight emerging and mid-career artists will be selected for the year-long program; they will have access to BAVC's state-of-the-art facilities as well as receiving technical training through BAVC's digital media workshops.

To support the Factory Hybrid Filmmaking Project, a pilot program for young filmmakers. The project will test strategies to develop, distribute, and engage audiences for filmmakers who are producing traditional digital and Web-based (Web-native) short films.

To support the Mediamaker Fellows program, providing local filmmakers with the technical assistance and resources needed to finish their projects. There will be up to eight emerging and mid-career artists selected for the year-long program; they will have access to BAVC's state-of-the-art facilities as well as receiving technical training through BAVC's digital media workshops.

To support low-cost audio and video preservation services to artists and arts organizations throughout the nation. Services include the recording, retrieval, and preservation of audio/video art and of performances archived on various media, as well as the dissemination of information to the public.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support ongoing, low-cost audio and video preservation services to artists and arts organizations throughout the nation. Services include the recording, retrieval, and preservation of audio/video art and of performances archived on various media, and the dissemination of information to the public.

To support the Mediamaker Awards and Mediamaker Advance programs, in consortium with KQED-TV (the San Francisco PBS affiliate). These programs will provide independent video artists and producers with the technical assistance and resources they need to finish their projects.
To support "Frameworks: Connecting Artists to New Media Technologies." The program will help media artists at all levels of experience learn to use sophisticated digital production equipment.

To support ongoing, low-cost audio and video preservation services to artists and arts organizations throughout the nation. Services include the recording, retrieval, and preservation of audio/video art and of performances archived on various media, and the dissemination of information to the public.

To support the Mediamaker Awards and MediaMaker Advance programs in consortium with KQED-TV. These programs will provide independent video artists and producers with technical assistance and resources they need to finish their projects.

To support ongoing, low-cost audio and video preservation services to artists and arts organizations throughout the nation. Services include the recording, retrieval, and preservation of audio/video art and art on media, and the dissemination of information to the public.

To support the Mediamaker Awards and MediaMaker Advance programs in consortium with KQED. In collaboration with KQED-TV (the San Francisco PBS affiliate), these programs will provide independent video artists and producers with technical assistance and resources they need to finish their projects.

To support ongoing, low-cost, video preservation services to artists and arts organizations throughout the nation. Services include the recording, retrieval, and preservation of video art and art on video, and the dissemination of information to the public.

To support the Mediamaker Awards and an artist residency in consortium with the San Francisco Art Institute. In collaboration with the San Francisco Art Institute, these programs will provide independent video artists and producers with critical technical assistance and the resources they need to finish their projects.
To support, in consortium with Southern Exposure, a program to provide independent video artists and producers with critical technical assistance and the resources they need to finish their projects.

To support ongoing, low-cost video preservation services to artists and arts organizations throughout the nation. Services include the recording, retrieval, and preservation of video art and art on video, and the dissemination of information to the public.

To support the Videomaker Awards and the Artist-in-Residence Program. These programs will provide independent video artists and producers with critical technical assistance and the resources they need to finish their projects.

To support on-going, low-cost video preservation services to artists and arts organizations throughout the nation. Services include the recording, retrieval, and preservation of video art and art on video, and the disssemination of information to the public.
To support the Artist Equipment Access Program, a consortium project. The program provides training, technical assistance, and equipment access services to artists and independent producers.

To support the provision of national video preservation services to artists and arts organizations and other related activities. Services include: the recording, retrieval, and preservation of video art and art on video, and the dissemination of information to the interested public.

To support development and dissemination of a DVD that contains a curriculum for the preservation of electronic art. The DVD will feature a preservation overview; discussions with conservators, artists, curators, and technicians; curriculum targeted at training professionals in the field; and case studies of projects to conserve electronic art.

To support the provision of national video preservation services to artists and arts organizations and other related activities. This includes: the recording, retrieval, and preservation of video art and art on video; and the dissemination of information to the interested public.

To support the provision of national video preservation services to artists and arts organizations and other related activities. This includes the recording, retrieval, and preservation of video art and art on video, the dissemination of information to the interested public, and convening a symposium on video preservation for conservators.

To support the provision of national video preservation services to artists and arts organizations and other related activities. This includes the recording, retrieval, and preservation of video art and art on video, and the dissemination of information to the interested public.

To support the provision of national video preservation services to artists and arts organizations, including the recording, retrieval, and preservation of art on video, and the dissemination of information to the interested public. Since 1975, the Bay Area Video Coalition (BAVC) has been a leader in providing low-cost access to sophisticated production equipment to artists and arts organizations. In the early 1990s, BAVC took the initiative to expand its offerings into the video preservation field. It worked with artists, arts organizations, and archivists to develop video preservation standards and then resurrected obsolete equipment so works could be restored. During this grant period, BAVC will continue to build its video preservation infrastructure by providing low-cost access to its preservation services and increasing its outreach to other artforms, particularly dance, theater, and literature. BAVC's high quality remastering service for old, i.e., unplayable, videotapes is now indispensable for the media arts and other arts fields.

Organization Name: Bayview Hunters Point Center for Arts & Technology
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel costs for a media arts training program for youth. Additional Project Description: Students from underserved communities will use cutting-edge technology and gain various media arts skills such as filmmaking, graphic arts, and animation. As paid interns, students will receive mentoring from seasoned industry professionals from organizations like Facebook, LucasFilm, and Pixar. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve youth from underserved communities in the San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Organization Name: Bayview Hunters Point Center for Arts & Technology
Project Description: To support personnel costs and student stipends for a media arts training program for youth. Students from underserved communities will learn how to use technology and gain various media arts skills such as filmmaking, graphic arts, and animation. Arts instruction will occur in-person as well as online. As paid interns, students will receive mentoring from seasoned industry professionals from organizations such as Netflix, LucasFilms, and Pixar.

Organization Name: Bayview Hunters Point Center for Arts & Technology
Project Description: To support arts instructor salaries and student stipends for a media arts training program for youth. Students from underserved communities will use cutting-edge technology and gain a variety of skills in media arts such as filmmaking, music production, and graphic design. As paid interns, students will receive mentoring from seasoned industry professionals from organizations such as Netflix, LucasFilms, and Pixar. Activities will take place virtually as necessary.

Organization Name: Bayview Hunters Point Center for Arts & Technology
Project Description: To support staff salaries for a media arts training program for youth. Students will use cutting-edge technology and gain a variety of skills in media arts such as filmmaking, music production, and graphic design. As paid interns, students will receive mentoring from seasoned industry professionals from organizations such as Netflix, LucasFilms, and Pixar.

Organization Name: Bayview Hunters Point Center for Arts & Technology
Project Description: To support a media arts training program for youth. Students will use cutting-edge technology and gain a variety of skills in media arts such as filmmaking, music production, and graphic design. Students also will receive training to develop their artistic expression, critical thinking, and communication skills. As youth media producers, participants will collaborate to create programming for a youth-created TV show.

Organization Name: Bayview Hunters Point Center for Arts & Technology
Project Description: To support the BAYCAT Youth Powered Media Program. Students will develop skills such as artistic expression, critical thinking, and effective communication, while receiving comprehensive instruction in digital media arts technology. As youth media producers, students will collaborate to create programming for the award-winning, youth-created TV show, "Zoom In."

Organization Name: Bayview Hunters Point Center for Arts & Technology
Project Description: To support the BAYCAT Youth Powered Media Program. Students will develop skills such as artistic expression, critical thinking, and effective communication, while receiving comprehensive instruction in digital media arts technology. As youth media producers, students will collaborate to create programming for the award-winning, youth-created TV show, "Zoom In."

Organization Name: Bayview Hunters Point Center for Arts & Technology
Project Description: To support a series of public film screenings and related activities that will share media produced by artists from underserved communities throughout San Francisco. The media will be works created by local artists about challenges faced by low-income communities in the Bay Area.

Organization Name: Bayview Hunters Point Center for Arts & Technology
Project Description: To support the BAYCAT Youth Powered Media Program. Students will develop skills such as artistic expression, critical thinking, and effective communication, while receiving comprehensive instruction in digital media arts technology.

Organization Name: Bayview Hunters Point Center for Arts & Technology
Project Description: To support the BAYCAT Youth Powered Media Program. Students will develop skills such as artistic expression, critical thinking, and effective communication, while receiving comprehensive instruction in digital media arts technology.

To support the ninth annual piNoisepop Festival, an Asian and Filipino American music festival. Bands from the entire United States will perform original music of various genres, from folk to rock and hip-hop.
To support the Big Art for Small Towns project in Fernley, Nevada. During the project period, up to three pieces of large-scale sculpture will be installed in a new city-owned park in Fernley.

To support "The Bike Bridge," a public sculpture created of reclaimed bike parts for installation at the gateway of the Uptown Merritt Art Park. "The Bike Bridge," the middle phase of a larger revitalization effort being conducted by the Foundation and the City of Oakland, will engage youth from East and West Oakland in the creation of the work under the leadership of selected professional artists.
To support the planning and research phase for an exhibition of Native American and Australian Aboriginal art.

Organization Name: Boys & Girls Clubs of San Francisco
Project Description: To support visual arts instruction for young people. Full-time art directors and guest artists will provide after-school and summer instruction in a wide range of media such as drawing, sculpture, painting, metal work, woodworking, printmaking, silk screening, ceramics, and photography.

Organization Name: Brava! For Women in the Arts
Project Description: Purpose: To support artist fees for the development and production of Larry, with book, music, and lyrics by Gayle Romasanta and Bryan Pangilinan, and directed by Billy Bustamante. Additional Project Description: The musical will tell the story of the 1965 Great Delano Grape Strike and labor leader Larry Itliong, who organized farm workers in the mid-20th century. Community engagement activities will include post-show discussions and a free student matinee performance. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit musical theater artists and audiences in San Francisco. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

Organization Name: Brava! For Women in the Arts
Project Description: To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Organization Name: Brava! For Women in the Arts
Project Description: To support "Remember Los Siete," a multimedia performance by Vero Majano. The world premiere will integrate archival film, audio recordings, and live performances to tell the story of seven young Central American men who were accused and ultimately acquitted of killing a police officer in San Francisco's Mission District in 1969. "Remember Los Siete" is constructed from archival 16mm, Super-8, 8mm, and home movies with audio narration by Majano and her interviewees.

Organization Name: Brava! For Women in the Arts
Project Description: To support the premiere of "The Mathematics of Love" by Cherrie Moraga. The work is a meditation on death and dying and examines the role of "spirit" as told through the bodies of people forgotten by history. Moraga will be in residence to work with her artistic team to finalize the script and participate with the play's director in production meetings with designers, the stage manager, and Brava personnel. To encourage exchange with the community, the project also includes public artist talks and presentations.

Organization Name: Brava! For Women in the Arts
Project Description: To support the creation and workshop production of a new play, "A/Way: The Urban Tao" by Kate Rigg.

Organization Name: Brava! For Women in the Arts
Project Description: To support a large-scale outdoor collaborative theatrical production. "Entre Vivos y Muertos, entre La Tierra y el Cielo" will be a created for the annual Day of the Dead activities in San Francisco's Mission District.

Organization Name: Brava! For Women in the Arts
Project Description: To support the world premiere production of "Okra" by Anne Galjour. The project is a new play exploring the mysteries of family and the complexity of race relations between Cajun and Creole communities in a small town in Louisiana.

Organization Name: Brava! For Women in the Arts
Project Description: To support the presentation of a world premiere play. "Apertura Modotti" will be presented in the spring of 2001 at the renovated Brava Theater Center in the Mission District.

Organization Name: Brava! For Women in the Arts
Project Description: To support programmatic and administrative expenses associated with arts education programming. An Arts Education Director position will be created to administer Brava's experiential arts education programs serving at-risk youth.

Organization Name: Brava! For Women in the Arts
Project Description: To support the creation and presentation of "Mission Magic Mystery Tour," a new work developed in collaboration with Culture Clash and filmmaker Lourdes Portillo through community-based workshops in the Mission District of San Francisco. "The Calle Veinticuatro Project" ("The 24th Street Project") is a theatrical piece that will be created by the members of Culture Clash, the premiere Chicano theater ensemble, about the Mission district, one of the most vibrant and endangered neighborhoods in San Francisco. The project will provide an opportunity for the Brava Theater Center to work with these nationally significant artists. The collaborators will develop the stories and interviews of Mission District residents into an original theater work. BRAVA and Culture Clash will identify an advisory group of community members who will guide the selection of interviewees. The collaboration will also involve participants in BRAVA's youth programs through a series of talleres or workshops to advance their writing and acting skills. The project also includes a series of community discussions or charlas where issues of cultural identity and unity will be explored with participation from San Francisco Mayor Willie Brown, members of the Board of Supervisors, local police, transportation, public works, business and youth representatives.

To support the Early Childhood Arts Education Training Program in the Visual and Performing Arts. This program provides teachers with training workshops and artist residencies to enhance their skills in delivering arts programs specifically for young children.
To support the Business Volunteer for the Arts program. Small and mid-sized arts organizations will be matched with experienced, volunteer consultants to address specific organizational challenges.

To support the Business Volunteer for the Arts program. Small and mid-sized arts organizations will be matched with trained business volunteers who will assist the organizations with specific organizational challenges.

Organization Name: California Assembly of Local Arts Agencies
Project Description: To support the Institute for Strategic Community Alliances Public Information and Access Initiatives, a statewide network. This project will nurture and expand local arts agency coalitions.
To support ChicaChic. The multi-faceted project will feature contemporary Chicana artists in an exhibition, a mass transit public art project, and a series of educational forums.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: Purpose: To support a workforce development program for formerly incarcerated individuals. Additional Project Description: California Lawyers for the Arts will partner with Los Angeles arts organizations to deliver a job training and employment program focused on careers in the creative economy. Program activities, which are designed to reduce recidivism, include paid internships, mentorships with arts administrators, on-the-job training, and career counseling. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve formerly incarcerated individuals in California, providing a pathway to permanent employment. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support continued expansion of the multistate Arts in Corrections initiative. Trainings and technical resources incorporating previously completed arts in corrections evidence-based research will inform state arts agency leaders and local arts agencies providing arts instruction as a rehabilitative tool in state prisons and county jails.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support a teaching artist workforce development pilot program for formerly incarcerated individuals. California Lawyers for the Arts will partner with the City of San Diego Commission for Arts and Culture, San Diego State University, and local arts organizations to deliver programming to incarcerated individuals who are interested in pursuing a career in the arts upon their release. Formerly incarcerated individuals will be trained as teaching artists and offered salaried positions at arts organizations. Programming may be conducted virtually as necessary. The program will provide a viable workforce opportunity for returning citizens and serve as a model that could be replicated in cities throughout California.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support a multistate expansion of the Arts in Corrections initiative, and general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Informed by previously completed arts in corrections evidence-based research, state arts council leaders will recruit local arts agencies to provide arts instruction as a rehabilitative tool in state prisons and county jails. California Lawyers for the Arts will provide technical assistance through trainings, evaluation, outreach and other planning tools to develop and implement the expanded programming.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support a national conference on arts in corrections. The conference will include training for artists and arts organizations working with incarcerated populations, as well as a specific professional development track for local arts agencies, with workshops on topics such as program administration models, artist selection, and outreach to local justice system officials. The planned curriculum for the conference draws from a previous multi-year, evidence-based research and demonstration project that California Lawyers for the Arts conducted in partnership with the William James Association and the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation. Their findings demonstrated reduced disciplinary incidents and recidivism for inmates engaged in the arts.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support artist residencies in county jails. In partnership with local arts agencies in California communities, the organization will provide technical assistance, recruitment and training of artists, and program outreach to local law enforcement. The residencies will enable the inclusion of arts programming as a rehabilitative tool in county jails. The organization will facilitate inmate participation in surveys and interviews designed to measure the impact of the arts programming, publish a findings report for distribution to local and state officials, and produce a guidebook on the project that will be available for use in other states.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support artist residencies in county jails. The organization will provide technical assistance, recruitment and training of artists, and program outreach to local law enforcement. It will work with local arts agencies in several California communities to enable the inclusion of arts programming as a rehabilitative tool in county jails.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support a national conference and technical assistance consultancy focusing on arts-in-corrections.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support a statewide arts-in-corrections program and a technical assistance program. In addition to implementing an arts-in-corrections program in its home state of California, CLA will disseminate development strategies for arts-in-corrections programs to professionals in the corrections field, as well as conduct a feasibility study of a national organization proposed to support arts-in-corrections providers. CLA also will assist other organizations such as Texas Accountants and Lawyers for the Arts with related efforts.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support a statewide arts-in-corrections program culminating in a national conference and a technical assistance project for Texas Accountants and Lawyers for the Arts. In addition to continuing an arts-in-corrections demonstration program in their home state, CLA will host a national conference on the topic.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support the expansion of Arts Arbitration and Mediation Services and the Arts-in-Corrections Initiative. Arts Arbitration includes mediation training for intellectual property disputes and the Arts-in-Corrections Initiative will support arts projects in state correctional facilities.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support training and public meetings on a variety of legal topics for arts professionals. This three-part project includes the development of a mediation training program for intellectual property disputes; the Arts and Environmental Initiative for individuals interested in addressing environmental issues through the arts; and the Arts-in-Corrections Initiative to support arts projects in correctional facilities.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support the California Lawyers for the Arts E-Learning Project, providing artists with specifically designed Internet access to business and legal knowledge to help improve their business practices. The E-Learning system will be designed to provide information - such as copyright and trademark laws - that will be targeted to the artists and arts organizations that use California Lawyers for the Arts services.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support the expansion of property sites for community-based art spaces and artist studios as part of the ArtHouse project. Plans for the Hunter's Point Shipyard area will include a multimedia center for mentoring youth in the digital arts and an outdoor theater as well as artists' studios and multi-tenant spaces for arts organizations.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support the expansion of ArtHouse. Strategies and collaborative efforts will facilitate the development of artists studios and multi-tenant spaces for arts organizations in San Franciscos Hunters Point Shipyard.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support the expansion of ArtHouse. Strategies and collaborative efforts will facilitate the development of artists' studios and multi-tenant spaces for arts organizations in San Francisco.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support the expansion of ArtHouse. Technical support, seminars, and Web-based information will focus on the development of new strategies for California artists and arts organizations to secure permanent and affordable live/work space.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support the expansion of ArtHouse. The program will provide technical support, seminars, and Web-based information on how to develop affordable space to artists and arts organizations in the Bay Area.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support the expansion of ArtHouse. The program will provide technical support, seminars, and Web-based information on how to develop affordable space to arts organizations in California.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support expansion of ArtHouse. The program will provide workshops and Web-based resources on how to develop affordable space to arts organizations in Northern California.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support the evaluation, documentation, and dissemination of the results of CultureCore, a consortium project. The program is designed to expand the development of youth through cultural enrichment and exposure.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support the expansion of ArtHouse. The project will provide technical services, legal referral, and mediation programs to enable Bay Area artists and arts organizations to develop long-term control of affordable space.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support the documentation and evaluation of the California Lawyers for the arts job training program. Initiated in 1999, this training program will continue to train and place low-income workers and welfare recipients in apprenticeships and arts employment, and begin to publish and disseminate the results of the program in 2000-2001.

Organization Name: California Lawyers for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support a national outreach strategy to make mediation services, in which artists or arts organizations can settle disputes without costly litigation, more widely available through expansion of Arts Resolution Services to Texas, Colorado, Illinois, Missouri, New York, and Washington D.C. California Lawyers for the Arts (CLA) provides legal and educational programs for artists and arts organizations of all disciplines. It maintains four staffed offices, in Santa Monica, Oakland, Sacramento and San Francisco, providing a diverse range of legal services so that artists and arts groups may gain greater competence in handling the business aspects of their creative activities. In this project CLA, working with Texas Accountants and Lawyers for the Arts, Colorado Lawyers for the Arts, St. Louis Volunteer Accountants and Lawyers for the Arts, Washington, DC Area Lawyers for the Arts, Lawyers for the Creative Arts (Chicago) and Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts (NY), seeks to strengthen and make more widely available Arts Resolution Services, a mediation program to help its constituency resolve disputes without costly litigation. Project activities include development of a website and an outreach campaign to inform the public of these services, creation of curricula and training materials for arts leaders, and conducting training programs in conjunction with major conferences in 1999 and 2000. Expansion of
To support the PEER Project, a poet-in-residence and peer-review program. Students in kindergarten through 12th grade will be taught writing skills by accomplished poets.

To support the PEER Project. Through this poet-in-residence and peer-review project, students in grades K through 12 will learn poetry appreciation and writing from accomplished poets-in-residence at their schools.

To support the Poetry Residency and Education Project. The primary purpose of this project is to create a five-week standard "Introduction to Poetry" curriculum for use in participating schools during poet-teacher residencies.

To support the Composition Program. The project will comprise residencies for emerging composers, the creation and premiere of new chamber works, a free public concert of works by established living composers, and residency activities with guest composer Judith Shatin.

To support a concert of works by American composers, a composer residency, and educational activities during the California Summer Music Festival. Concert repertoire will include works by faculty composer David Tcimpidis and guest composer Keith Fitch.

To support the Composition Program. It will comprise residencies for emerging composers, the creation and premiere of new chamber works, a free public concert of works by established living composers, and residency activities with guest and Grawemeyer Award-winning composer George Tsontakis.

To support a comprehensive music education summer program for children and youth from across the country. Young pianists, composers, and string players will be engaged in a series of hands-on learning opportunities including private music lessons, chamber music ensembles, master classes with guest artists, and public performances.

To support the implementation of the Composition  Theory Skills Program. Designed to provide opportunities for young musicians to create and perform contemporary music, youth will participate in the creation, reading, rehearsal, performance, and recording of new works.

To support the Composition Program for student composers. Up to ten student composers will create, rehearse, and record their original work; receive private lessons; attend group seminars, master classes, and lecture-demonstrations with a resident composer; and use private time for composing music.

To support a composition program for student composers to create, rehearse, and record their original work. During the three-week summer program, student composers will receive private lessons; attend group seminars, master classes, and lecture- demonstrations with a resident composer; and use private time for composing music.

To support a curatorial fellowship and online screening series. Through a fellowship program, guest curators will receive stipends to conduct research, curate programs and author accompanying texts for a free online screening series.

To support the development of an online archive and back end technical work to update the Canyon Cinema collection. Expanded online offerings will include access to archival materials and ephemera, film criticism, video interviews, and documentation of performances. The collection includes the work of such media artists as Chick Strand, Bruce Baillie, Carolee Schneemann, and Stan VanDerBeek.

To support Canyon Cinema's film and media distribution program, including a curated series of programs featuring rare works by underrepresented artists. Dedicated to independent and experimental media art, works from the Canyon Cinema collection will be made available to the public in a variety of formats, including 16mm and 35mm film prints, digital files, and through online streaming platforms such as Kanopy. In addition, scholars and specialists will curate as many as six programs to be digitized and packaged for distribution featuring rare works by women and LGBTQ artists from the collection, accompanied by curatorial essays.

To support Canyon Cinema 50. Dedicated to independent and experimental media art, works from the Canyon Cinema collection, many in 16mm format, will be selected for restoration, digitization, and exhibition. Visiting filmmakers and staff will participate in discussions accompanying the screenings. The exhibition also will tour to venues across the country.

Purpose: To support dance performances and the development of an interactive sculpture. Additional Project Description: Choreographers Antoine Hunter and Jodi Lomask will work in collaboration with Max Kazemzadeh and students at Gallaudet University, the largest deaf university in the United States, to integrate responsive LED lighting into a sculpture and a performance piece with the sculpture. Intended Beneficiaries: This project will serve deaf and hearing communities at Gallaudet University and in the Washington, DC, area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support Capacitor XR, an initiative that utilizes sculpture, live dance, gallery presentations, virtual reality animation, and augmented reality experiences. Through augmented reality, audiences can touch, climb on, and dance on motion sculptures after the company's live performances at a visual arts exhibition at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.

To support the presentation of "Synaptic Motion" at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in partnership with the Gazzaley Lab at University of California San Francisco and the Grey Area Foundation. Choreographer Jodi Lomask will create a dance with circus and aerial elements that will include video images created via magnetic and electrical scanning of the brain of the choreographer, performers, and audience members. The evening-length work will be created in collaboration with neuroscientists, data artists, a NASA robotics engineer, filmmaker RJ Muna, composer Toni Martin Dobrzanski, jazz musician Sascha Jacobsen, installation artist Calli Beck, and the dancers.

To support the presentation of "Okeanos," by choreographer Jodi Lomask, in partnership with the Aquarium of the Bay in San Francisco. The organizations will produce a 60-minute dance production with four dancers, two contortionists, an acrobat, and an aerialist, along with abstract aerial objects, a video, and an underwater film.

To support a collections management project. The goals of the project are to document and preserve the permanent collection and to secure the necessary systems and tools for ongoing documentation and preservation.

Purpose: To support year-round artist development programs for independent documentary filmmakers. Additional Project Description: Intended to support artists in the early stages of their projects, the program will provide filmmakers with the tools to develop story-driven and cinematic films, including mentorship and advisory services, development of the creative materials needed to pitch films to potential partners, and feedback on scenes, samples, and rough-cut edits. Intended Beneficiaries: The artistic development programs will benefit independent filmmakers in the early stages of their projects. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Mission Urban Arts. Students will apprentice with master artists while receiving counseling and academic tutoring services.
To support the exhibition "Resilient City: Strength by Design" and the Good Design Challenge as a part of the Architecture + the City Festival.

To support the Architecture and the City Festival. The month-long event will include a visual arts exhibition and a series of design challenges. Local artists will be commissioned for the exhibition representing various San Francisco housing typologies and neighborhoods. The design challenge projects to be presented at the festival will address topics such as multigenerational housing, neighborhood safety, earthquake resistant dwellings, and the homeless population.

To support the Civil Salon Project: Design Thinking for Social Innovation. The project will pair as many as three designers with local governement agencies in San Francisco for one month residencies and a series of public meetings to explore issues and propose solutions for challenges to urban livability.

To support Architecture of Consequence: Bay Area and Dutch Designers Respond to the Future. Through an exhibition and symposium during the Center's 2011 Architecture and the City festival in San Francisco, 12 Dutch and 12 San Francisco Bay Area architect/designers will respond to the global problems surrounding topics of food, health, energy, density, social cohesion, and diminishing resources.

To support the Architecture and the City Festival: Film Series, in consortium with the San Francisco Public Library. Activities to be co-presented with the San Francisco Public Library include the "Meet the Filmaker and Architect," and also a new participatory component that encourages audience members to consider their relationship to place by creating short films or videos.

Purpose: To support CAAMFest, a media arts festival dedicated to Asian and Asian American cinematic works, and related public programming celebrating Asian American culture. Additional Project Description: Held in-person and online during Asian Pacific American Heritage Month, CAAMFest will present documentary, narrative, animated, and experimental works, accompanied by conversations with filmmakers and artists. Additional festival programming will include multimedia performances, youth screenings, and workshops presented in partnership with community organizations. Intended Beneficiaries: This project will serve online viewers nationwide, with a focus on audiences in the San Francisco Bay Area and the Asian American community, as well as participating artists, organizational partners, and venues. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support CAAMFest, a media arts festival that showcases the work of Asian and Asian-American artists, and related public programming. Additional Project Description: Held in-person and online during Asian Pacific American Heritage Month, CAAMFest will present documentary, narrative, animated, and experimental works, accompanied by conversations with filmmakers and artists. Additional festival programming will include multimedia performances, youth screenings, and workshops. Intended Beneficiaries: This project will serve online viewers nationwide, with a focus on San Francisco and Oakland audiences and the Asian-American community. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Purpose: To support a professional development initiative focused on Asian-American documentary filmmakers in the Midwest. Additional Project Description: Through research, network-building, and a convening, the Center for Asian American Media will work with independent producers, organizations, and media partners to provide new avenues of support and strengthen leadership development opportunities with a focus on serving Asian-American filmmakers in the region. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve the independent film and media arts field in the Midwest, with a focus on the Asian American documentary filmmaking community. The initiative also will benefit the independent media arts field nationwide. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support CAAMFest, a media arts festival that showcases the work of Asian and Asian-American artists, and related public programming. Held during Asian Pacific American Heritage Month, CAAMFest will present documentary, narrative, animated, and experimental works, accompanied by conversations with filmmakers and artists. Additional festival programming will include multimedia performances, youth screenings, workshops, and the program Memories to Light: Asian-American Home Movies, featuring a collection of home movies from the Asian-American community. Programming will be presented virtually as necessary.

To support CAAMFest, an online media arts festival that showcases the work of Asian and Asian-American artists, and related public programming. Held during Asian Pacific American Heritage month, CAAMFest will present documentary, narrative, animated, and experimental works, accompanied by question-and-answer sessions with filmmakers and artists.

To support a national symposium on Asian-American film and associated public screenings. Coinciding with CAAM's 40th anniversary, the virtual public symposium will engage filmmakers, artists, scholars, educators, critics, and arts organizations to discuss the history, impact, and future of Asian-American film and media. In addition, classic Asian-American cinema will be showcased in free virtual screenings.

To support CAAMFest, a media arts festival that showcases the work of Asian and Asian-American artists and related public programming. Held in San Francisco and Oakland, CAAMFest presents documentary, narrative, animated, and experimental works in film and video, as well as live events, multimedia performances, and music. Screenings are accompanied by question-and-answer sessions with filmmakers and subject matter experts. Additional festival programming will include CAAM's signature program, Memories to Light: Asian-American Home Movies, featuring a collection of home movies from the Asian-American community.

To support the strengthening and development of a peer network and strategic infrastructure for Asian American documentary filmmakers working in the American South. Center for Asian American Media (CAAM) will conduct activities that include research, data gathering, and regional strategic meetings to create a comprehensive strategy for connecting southern filmmakers to regional and national documentary and cultural organizations. A summit convening will take place with leading regional media arts organizations such as Appalshop, the Southern Documentary Fund, and the Southern Circuit, to assess the state of the American South for Asian American filmmakers and identify specific needs, potential partnerships, and strategic opportunities. An additional convening will take place at CAAMFest in San Francisco.

To support CAAMFest, a media arts festival showcasing the work of Asian and Asian American artists, and related public programming. Held in San Francisco and Oakland, CAAMFest presents documentary, narrative, animated and experimental works in film and video, as well as live events, multimedia performances, and music. Starting in 2018, the festival will be held in May, coinciding with Asian Pacific American Heritage Month. Additional festival programming may include free screenings of curated films from Muslim Youth Voices, a national initiative of the Center for Asian American Media (CAAM), followed by panel discussions with youth filmmakers and Muslim American speakers; and Memories to Light: Asian American Home Movies, featuring a collection of films from the Japanese American community with an original score composed by jazz musician Mark Izu.

To support the CAAMFest, a media arts festival showcasing the work of Asian and Asian-American artists. Held in San Francisco, Oakland, and San Jose, CAAMFest showcases documentary, narrative, animated and experimental works in film and video, as well as live events, multi-media performances, and expanded ventures into the music and culinary arts worlds. Festival attendees will have the opportunity to participate in activities and curated experiences that provide a deeper context of Asian-American filmmaking and gain a greater understanding of the diversity and richness of contemporary Asian-American cultural voices through educational panels and discussions. Additional festival programming may include free screenings of curated films from Muslim Youth Voices, a three-year national initiative of the Center for Asian American Media (CAAM); and Memories to Light: Asian American Home Movies, featuring a collection of films from California's Central Valley rural farming communities.

To support the development and production of a film based on a script written by Chang-rae Lee and directed by Wayne Wang. Focused on the shifting landscape of San Francisco's Asian American community identity, the story centers around a family dinner.

To support CAAMFest 2016, a media arts festival showcasing the work of Asian and Asian-American artists. Held in San Francisco, Berkeley, and Oakland, the festival features film, music, and digital media as well as live events and multimedia performances. Festival programming will include screenings from the filmmaking workshop "Muslim Youth Voices" and works portraying untold stories of Asian and Asian-American experience.

To support CAAMFest, a media arts festival showcasing the work of Asian and Asian-American artists. A copy of the festival catalogue is the required product. Held in San Francisco, Berkeley, and Oakland, the festival features film, music, and digital media as well as live events and multimedia performances.

To support Memories to Light: Asian American Home Movies, a national media arts engagement and preservation project. Through the preservation of home movies from 1930s to the '80s, Memories to Light explores the Asian-American experience, including issues of immigration, assimilation, personal journeys, and milestones. The preserved movies are edited into short films and presented with musical accompaniment in museums, cultural centers, and Asian-American film festivals. Commissioned films and performances are also available on the Memories to Light website, www.caammedia.org/memoriestolight.

To support CAAMFest, a media arts festival showcasing the work of Asian and Asian-American artists. Held in the spring, the event features film, music, and digital media as well as live events and multimedia performances.
To support the 31st San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival. The event will showcase new work by and about Asian Americans and Asians.
To support the 30th "San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival." The event will showcase new work by and about Asian Americans and Asians.

To support "Memories to Light: Asian American Home Movies," and associated outreach activities. The Center for Asian American Media will request home movie footage from the Asian American community and create an interactive Web site and curate national touring exhibitions from the collected material.
To support the 29th San Francisco Asian American Film Festival. The event will showcase new work by and about Asian Americans and Asians.

To support the production and post-production of a public television program about ukulele virtuoso Jake Shimabukuro. A one-hour film portrait will capture the artist's performances before sold out crowds, as well as intimate moments of life on the road and visits home to his native Hawai'i, where he has risen from local hero to international star.
To support the 28th San Francisco Asian American Film Festival. The event will showcase new work by and about Asian Americans and Asians.
To support the development of a video documentary featuring North Indian dance master Chitresh Das and tap dancer Jason Samuels Smith. The half-hour program is intended for public television.
To support the San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival. The film festival will showcase new work by and about Asian Americans and Asians.
To support the San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival and other exhibition activities. The film festival will showcase the work of new Asian Pacific American film and video makers.

To support production and post-production costs for a documentary on the making of the opera THE BONESETTER'S DAUGHTER. The film will offer a behind-the-scenes look at the collaboration between librettist Amy Tan and composer Stewart Wallace.
To support the San Francisco Asian American Film Festival and other exhibition activities. The film festival will showcase the work of new Asian Pacific American film and video makers.

To support completion and distribution costs for a documentary film by Arthur Dong on the history of the Chinese in American feature films. The 90-minute film will be a multi-layered look at American cinematic history from the early 1900s up to the present day through the lens of the Chinese American experience.
To support the San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival and other exhibition activities. The film festival will showcase the work of new Asian Pacific American film and video makers.
To support the San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival and other exhibition activities. The film festival will showcase the work of new Asian-Pacific American film and video makers.
To support the San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival and other exhibition activities. The film festival will showcase the work of new Asian Pacific American film and video makers.
To support the San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival and other exhibition activities. The film festival will showcase the work of new Asian Pacific American film and video makers.
To support the San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival. The 10-day event showcases the work of new Asian Pacific American film and video makers.

To support Asian American Media: The Millennium Project. As part of its 20th anniversary, the National Asian American Telecommunications Association will publish a series of articles, organize panels, and convene a conference to assess the state of Asian American media arts.

To support the publication and national distribution of an educational catalog that will feature the nearly 200 film and video artworks in its collection. This distribution catalog will be primarily offered, in print and on-line, to educational institutions.

To support the publication and national distribution of up to two educational catalogs which will facilitate the accessibility of Asian-American films and videos by teachers and students from junior high school through college. Today, as Asian populations continue to grow at a rapid pace nationally and as school districts around the country continue to lose resources, the National Asian American Telecommunications Association (NAATA) sees a greater need now to find ways for its titles to reach schools directly both for the empowerment of Asian American students as well as for greater understanding between and among students and teachers. To meet this need, NAATA will curate a selection of appropriate works from its collection for the junior high/high school audience and do the same for students in higher education. It will then design, publish, and nationally distribute two catalogs, one specifically for educators of junior high and high school students and one for instructors and professors of college/university students. These catalogs will contain titles of Asian-American and Asian films and videos suitable for these age groups at reduced prices. In addition, NAATA staff will travel to various educational conferences to display and market this distribution effort.

Organization Name: Center for New Music San Francisco, Inc.
Project Description: To support Soundvoice, a series of music workshops. The workshop participants will include residents of San Francisco's Tenderloin, Sixth Street Corridor, and Mid-Market neighborhoods struggling with homelessness and poverty. Professional musicians will provide music education and creation opportunities focused on the field of new music; the project will culminate with a public performance.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: Purpose: To support the publication and promotion of international literature. Additional Project Description: Planned publications through Two Lines Press will include titles in translation by Jazmina Barrera (Mexico), Maria Judite de Carvalho (Portugal), Astrid Roemer (Suriname/the Netherlands), and Pirkko Saisio (Finland). In addition, the press will publish Franco-Caribbean poetry and contemporary writing from Kiswahili through its Calico Series, and offer the online literary journal Two Lines. Intended Beneficiaries: The publications will benefit readers nationwide. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries experience the international exchange of artists, arts, and cultural traditions.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: Purpose: To support the publication and promotion of international literature. Additional Project Description: Planned publications through Two Lines Press include titles in translation by Masatsugu Ono (Japan), Jazmina Barrera (Mexico), Dorothee Elmiger (Switzerland), and Hemley Boum (Cameroon). The press also will publish a collection of Russian poetry and a compilation of literature and visual arts, and offer the online literary journal Two Lines. Intended Beneficiaries: Publications will benefit readers nationwide. Intended Outcomes: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support the publication and promotion of international literature. Planned publications through Two Lines Press include titles in translation by authors such as Maria Judite de Carvalho (Portugal), Wolfgang Hilbig (Germany), Bruno Lloret (Chile), and Elvira Navarro (Spain). The center also will publish a title through the Calico series, which spotlights vanguard works of translated literature, and offer the online literary journal Two Lines.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support the publication and promotion of international literature. Planned publications through Two Lines Press include titles in translation by authors such as Masatsugu Ono (Japan) and Marie NDiaye (France), as well as a young adult title by Kim Sagwa (South Korea). Through its new Calico book series, the press also plans to publish special edition titles focusing on Chinese speculative fiction and Arabic poetry in translation.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support the publication and promotion of the journal Two Lines, as well as books in translation. Dedicated to building an audience for world literature, the journal will include a special folio of under-translated Mexican authors, as well as fiction, poetry, and essays exploring the future of translation. Planned books to be published through Two Lines Press include titles by such authors as Joo Gilberto Noll (Brazil) and Duanwad Pimwana (Thailand). The center's website will feature excerpts from the journal in addition to author and translator interviews, essays, and other content.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support the publication and promotion of an issue of the journal "Two Lines," as well as books in translation. Dedicated to building an audience for world writing, the journal will include special folios highlighting underrepresented languages and genres. Books published through Two Line Press will highlight the ethnic, cultural, and gender diversity of international literature. The center's website will offer a searchable database of authors and translators, as well as interviews, essays, and other dynamic content.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support the publication and promotion of print and electronic versions of the journal "Two Lines," as well as books in translation. Dedicated to building an audience for world writing, the journal often features writers who are well known in their own languages but unknown in English. Books, published through Two Line Press, will highlight the ethnic, cultural, and gender diversity of international literature.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support the publication and promotion of print and electronic versions of the journal "Two Lines," as well as books in translation. Dedicated to building an audience for world writing, the journal often features writers who are well known in their own languages but unknown in English. Books selected for publication will highlight the ethnic, cultural, and gender diversity of international literature.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support the publication and promotion of print and electronic versions of the "Two Lines" annual anthology of world literature and books in translation. The books will be promoted via social media and tours of both authors and translators. The center has been publishing "Two Lines" for 20 years to make international literature available to English readers and to build an audience for world writing.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support print and electronic publications by Two Lines Press, including books in translation and an annual anthology of world literature. The press will offer exclusive online content and podcasts and promote its publications through its website.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support the print and electronic publication and promotion by Two Lines Press of books in translation, as well as an anthology of international literature. Two Lines will publish exclusive online content monthly and will promote its publications through its blog, podcasts, author/translator interviews, videos, and social media.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support the publication and promotion of "Two Lines," an annual anthology of international writing in translation. The center will publish two collections of Arabic literature in addition to expanding their exclusive online content, and inaugurating a series of monographs.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support "Two Voices," a reading series spotlighting international writers and translators. The readings are available on the center's Web site with full audio, photographs, and selections of presented materials.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support training for teachers and writers to integrate poetry and translation into New York city classrooms, in consortium with the Teachers  Writers Collaborative The Center will create an online community to share and discuss research findings, experiences, curriculum, and student work.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support the publication and promotion of anthologies of literature in translation. The center will publish one book of Francophone literature and one of Arabic literature.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Poetry Inside Out in consortium with the Teachers  Writers Collaborative The program will introduce bilingual students, ages 8 to 18, to Spanish literature with the goal of increasing language proficiency in both English and Spanish through literary translation.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support the publication and promotion of the literary anthology Two Lines. A strategic marketing plan will also increase book sales and reach new audiences.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support Lit  Lunch, a bilingual lunchtime reading series. The monthly program presents a writer working in a foreign language, whose work is read or performed in the original language and also in English.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Poetry Inside Out. The program will introduce bilingual students, ages 8 to 13, to Spanish literature with the goal to increase language proficiency in both English and Spanish through literary translation.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support "Poetry Inside Out," a program that will introduce students to Spanish literature and increase language proficiency in both English and Spanish through literary translation. Targeted for bilingual students ages eight to 13, the program will also demonstrate the possibility of turning bilingual abilities into translation skills for career and educational opportunities.

Organization Name: Center for the Art of Translation
Project Description: To support Poetry Inside Out. Targeted for bilingual students, the program will introduce students to Spanish literature, increase language proficiency in both English and Spanish through literary translation, and demonstrate the possibility of turning bilingual abilities into translation skills for career and educational opportunities.

Organization Name: Center on Juvenile and Criminal Justice
Project Description: To support production costs for a documentary film on the poet Piri Thomas. x A 90-minute film intended for PBS broadcast, "Every Child is Born a Poet" also will be screened at community centers across the country.

To support the Community Arts Program for homeless and poor artists in the Tenderloin neighborhood of San Francisco, California. The program provides artists with scheduled or drop-in studio time in a variety of media, including painting, drawing, ceramics, and digital media.

To support workshop, exhibition, and publication components of the Community Arts Program. The project will provide professional arts training to the population of the Tenderloin neighborhood of San Francisco.

To support the expansion of the Community Arts Program. The project will consist of a weekly series of artist workshops and exhibitions in both on-site and off-site galleries for homeless residents of San Francisco's Tenderloin district.

To support expansion of services of the Community Arts Program for homeless and at-risk artists in the Tenderloin district, one of San Francisco's poorest neighborhoods. The project will include increased studio time, a weekly series of workshops, and exhibition opportunities.

Popular Name: aka Chitresh Das Dance Company & Chhandam School
Project Description: To support YATRA, Masters of Kathak  Flamenco. NEA National Heritage Fellow Chitresh Das, a master of the North Indian kathak dance tradition, will collaborate with Spanish flamenco artist Antonio Hidalgo Paz to create and present a new work highlighting the commonalities between kathak and flamenco dance genres.

Popular Name: aka Chitresh Das Dance Company & Chhandam School
Project Description: To support "Shiva: Creation, Preservation, Destruction," a narrative dance about the royal court of North India. NEA National Heritage Fellow Pandit Chitresh Das will direct and choreograph a suite of works featuring dancers, master Indian musicians, and multimedia images. The project will involve as many as 19 artists and reach an audience of approximately 2,300.

Popular Name: aka Chitresh Das Dance Company & Chhandam School
Project Description: To support the creation of a new narrative dance "Darbar," and its performance by the Chitresh Das Dance Company. Heritage Fellow Pandit Chitresh Das will choreograph and direct DARBAR, a performance using traditional Kathak dance, master Indian musicians, and multimedia images to tell a story of the royal court of North India.

Popular Name: aka Chitresh Das Dance Company & Chhandam School
Project Description: To support performances of traditional solo Kathak dance, artists residencies, and outreach activities. NEA National Heritage Fellow Pandit Chitresh Das will present solo dance recitals. Educational outreach programs for grades K-12 will be offered in conjunction with the performances, which will benefit approximately 9,000 individuals.

Popular Name: aka Chitresh Das Dance Company & Chhandam School
Project Description: To support "Traditions Engaged," an international festival and symposium of Indian dance forms. The project will be held in San Francisco and Los Angeles and bring dancers, critics, scholars, and the public together to discuss and present all seven forms of classical Indian dance.

Popular Name: aka Chitresh Das Dance Company & Chhandam School
Project Description: To support the U.S. tour of "India Jazz Suites," a collaboration between Indian kathak master Pandit Chitresh Das and African American tap dancer Jason Samuels Smith. Portions of the work will focus entirely on rhythms, with varying combinations of footwork, recitation of the North Indian classical language, and percussion on tabla and jazz drums.

Popular Name: aka Chitresh Das Dance Company & Chhandam School
Project Description: To support solo performances of Kathak, an endangered classical dance of North India, and related educational programs. The artform requires knowledge and understanding of complex rhythmic patterns that are sponstaneously produced through footwork, recitation, and movement that harmonize completely with the percussionist.
