Popular Name: aka Chitresh Das Dance Company & Chhandam School
Project Description: To support the tour of an evening-length collaborative work. East as Center features master artists Chitresh Das, Govindan Kutty, and Ni Ketut Arini.

Popular Name: aka Chitresh Das Dance Company & Chhandam School
Project Description: To support the collaborative performance project TARANG. Chitresh Das will collaborate with the percussionist Abhijit Banerjee and mandolinist Snehashish Majumdar along with other musicians blending both North and South Indian classical music and dance.

Popular Name: aka Chitresh Das Dance Company & Chhandam School
Project Description: To support the Kathak at the Crossroads conference, a consortium project. The conference will bring the international Kathak community to one location and explore Kathak through performances, panel discussions, forums, papers, lecture demonstrations, and workshops.

Popular Name: aka Chitresh Das Dance Company & Chhandam School
Project Description: To support the presentation of a collaborative work. Chitresh Das, Abhijit Banerjee, and Swapnamoy Banerjee's collaboration will culminate in the world premiere of a work entitled, "Pancha Jati."

Popular Name: aka Chitresh Das Dance Company & Chhandam School
Project Description: To support the development and production of the new work "Sadhana." Sadhana will incorporate Kathak dance of North India and multi-media formats as a forum for relating the artistry, technique, vision, and life experience of Chitresh Das and his journey, bridging the gap between the ancient origins of the art form and modern American society.

Popular Name: aka Chitresh Das Dance Company & Chhandam School
Project Description: To support a consortium project to produce a dance drama. This collaborative effort between Chhandam Chitresh Das Dance Company and Gamelan Sekar Jaya is based on the Mahabharata, an epic story of Hinduism and its association with mythology.

To support the publication and promotion of multicultural and bilingual board books for early readers. The press will enter phase three of the First Voice: Early Reader Initiative to survey and assess the books' impact on children, their families, and childhood development professionals.

To support activities related to the Early Reader Initiative, including the publication and promotion of multicultural and bilingual board books and testing read-aloud books. The Press will continue a five-year program to encourage reading among Indigenous and Spanish/bilingual children.
To support the publication and promotion of volumes of multicultural and bilingual board books for early readers. Proposed titles may include bilingual works in Spanish, English, and Chinese.
To support the publication of and educational programming for volumes of multicultural and bilingual children's literature by authors and artists of color.

To support the publication and promotion of bilingual children's books for Mexican American and South Asian communities. The press will promote the books to librarians, educators, and the general public at book fairs around the country.
To support "LitLinks," an Internet residency project. This virtual author-in-residence project combines literature and technology through yearlong literature-based writing programs for youth.

To support "LitLinks," an Internet residency project. Through four virtual author-in residence programs, this project offers an innovative, literature-based approach that will stimulate students to investigate their own backgrounds and communities and then express themselves in writing and publish online.

To support LitLinks, a series of online residencies connecting low-income youth with established writers and artists. Projected sites include elementary and middle schools, and community-based literacy programs in California, Texas, New York, Colorado, Minnesota, Georgia, and Washington, DC.

To support LitLinks, a series of online residencies connecting low-income youth with established writers and artists. Projected sites include elementary and middle schools, and a community-based literacy programs in California, Texas, and Washington, DC.

To support the Young Innovators Workshop series. In partnership with local digital media artists, the museum will present bi-weekly studio workshops in which youth will produce their own original digital media art and technology-based projects, such as drawings using SpinBots, 3-D printing, wearable art, and Instagram-based digital photography.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Zeum After School Program (ZAP). Youth from San Francisco's South of Market neighborhood will receive in-depth instruction in figure design and clay animation to create short animation films.

To support Zeum Presents, a series of free multimedia and performing arts presentations. Community-based arts organizations will use Zeum's facilities and technical and administrative support to create and present work to students and adults.

Popular Name: aka Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company
Project Description: To support Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company's tour. Each touring engagement will include performance of works selected from the company's repertoire that combines traditional Chinese dance movements with choreographer Lily Cai's contemporary aesthetic, as well as outreach activities for youth.

Popular Name: aka Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company
Project Description: To support Lily Cai Dance Company's national tour. Each touring engagement will include an evening-length performance of pieces from the company's permanent repertoire, an interactive Chinese traditional dance workshop for children and families, a master class for dancers drawn from four ancient Chinese movement concepts, and a presentation about the history of Chinese settlements in the area.

Popular Name: aka Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company
Project Description: To support a tour of the Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company to five California communities. With the tour, Cai aims to provide Chinese American audiences access to professional performing arts experiences, and hopes to introduce many new audience members to contemporary Chinese American dance and music.

Popular Name: aka Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company
Project Description: To support a tour of the Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company. The full-length concert will feature works choreographed by Cai, her newest piece, What We're Missing, and Silk Cascade.

Popular Name: aka Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company
Project Description: To support the tour of Silk Cascade by the Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company. The full-length concert, featuring a trio of dances choreographed by Artistic Director Lily Cai, will tour to five cities with large Chinese populations including Los Angeles, Seattle, Minneapolis, Boston, and Houston.

Popular Name: aka Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company
Project Description: To support the development and presentation of a concert by choreographer Lily Cai and composer Gang Situ that will be performed by Chinese-American dancers and musicians in San Francisco. The Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company will combine traditional Chinese music and dance elements with contemporary American stagecraft and digital technology.

Popular Name: aka Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company
Project Description: To support performances, residency activities, and tour of THE LOST OF THE RED-TASSELED SPEAR, created by choreographer Lily Cai and composer Gang Situ.

Popular Name: aka Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company
Project Description: To support a tour of traditional Chinese dance and outreach activities. The dance performances will be accompanied by Chinese music and will incorporate contemporary American stagecraft.

Popular Name: aka Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company
Project Description: To support touring dance performances and outreach activities. The performances will combine traditional Chinese dance and music with contemporary American stagecraft.

Popular Name: aka Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company
Project Description: To support the creation and presentation of "SHE--Portraits of The Chinese Woman." The concert will consist of stories about the strength, passion, and character of Chinese American women. Lily Cai-choreographer, Gang Situ-music mix, and Mathew Antaky-lighting.

Popular Name: aka Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company
Project Description: To support the development and presentation of new interdisciplinary works. The program will feature premiere presentations of works which reflect the convergence of the performing arts and digital technology.

Popular Name: aka Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company
Project Description: To support performances by the New Century Chamber Orchestra, the Alexander String Quartet, and erhu instrumentalist Jie-Bing Chen in a full-length concert of string compositions by composer Gang Situ. These concerts, featuring original works that explore contemporary American art, culture, and society, will be held at San Francisco's Herbst Theater in the year 2000.

Popular Name: aka Lily Cai Chinese Dance Company
Project Description: To support the creation of a three-year strategic plan. Prepared with the assistance of a consultant, the plan will guide the organization through the year 2002.

Organization Name: Chinese Culture Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: Purpose: To support a group exhibition and public programming. Additional Project Description: Selected local and international artists will create works that explore racism and its impact on San Francisco Chinatown neighborhoods. Public programming will include artist panels, screenings, and workshops. Intended Beneficiaries: The exhibition and programming will serve participating artists, San Francisco Chinatown residents, as well as the larger Bay Area creative community, residents, and visitors. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Organization Name: Chinese Culture Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: Purpose: To support a solo exhibition and commission by artist Cathy Lu (b. 1984). Additional Project Description: The artist will create sculptural works that explore the difficulties experienced by people of color targeted by racial violence during the COVID-19 pandemic. Community engagement will include workshops and public talks with youth on social justice. Intended Beneficiaries: The exhibition and programming will serve San Francisco residents, including youth. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Organization Name: Chinese Culture Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Organization Name: Chinese Culture Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support an exhibition exploring issues related to gender equity, civil rights, and inclusion. The exhibition will feature selected works and new commissions by contemporary artists in response to key events related to the concept of space, equity, and ownership in marginalized communities. This project honors the Women's Suffrage Centennial.

Organization Name: Chinese Culture Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support "Xian Rui: Ten Years" an exhibition featuring contemporary visual arts. To celebrate the tenth anniversary of Xian Rui, the Chinese Culture Center's flagship solo exhibition series, the organization will present new work, with an emphasis on Asian-American visual artists. "Xian" meaning "new" and "Rui" meaning "sharp" will offer a thought-provoking look at contemporary Chinese culture by highlighting artists who use Chinese art forms and techniques, or derive inspiration from Chinese heritage. Ancillary programs will include artist talks and panel discussions.

Organization Name: Chinese Culture Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support a media art installation by Chinese video artist Xu Tan (b. 1957). A storefront in Chinatown will serve as a pop-up gallery and art-making studio. Tan, working with the community and in collaboration with local artist Justin Hoover, will explore the use of language and dialogue to create a "Keywords Mural" created with Chinatown youth.

Organization Name: Chinese Culture Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the exhibition "Now is the Moment for Ink: Contemporary Chinese Ink Painting In America" with accompanying catalogue and public programs. The exhibition, a survey of the development and flourishing of the ink painting tradition in the U.S., is being collaboratively organized by and exhibited at the galleries of the Chinese Cultural Center and San Francisco State University, and will be accompanied by a scholarly catalogue, education programs, and is expected to tour to Sweden.

Organization Name: Chinese Culture Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn. Amendment #1 (11/19/10): Clarification of titles of positions supported (as opposed to the roles they play for certain projects.)

Organization Name: Chinese Culture Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the presentation of an opera by composer Gang Situ. Based on Mozart's Don Giovanni, the work will fuse musical elements of traditional Cantonese opera with those of Western composition.

Organization Name: Chinese Culture Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support, in consortium with the Chinese Performing Arts Foundation, the Cantonese Opera Heritage Project. The project will include a series of lectures, workshops, and exhibitions designed to raise awareness of the prominent role Cantonese opera has played in San Francisco over the past 150 years.

Organization Name: Chinese Culture Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support an exhibition and catalogue featuring the Cantonese art form of Shiwan ceramics. Curated by So Kam Ng, Professor of Asian Art History at San Francisco State University, the project is a collaboration between Asian and U.S. scholars.

Organization Name: Chinese Culture Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support planning and implementation of the exhibition "Room within a Room: Intimacy Inside Chinese Women Chambers." The project will explore the status of women in traditional Chinese society and the art forms that surrounded them in their intimate quarters.

Organization Name: Chinese Culture Foundation of San Francisco
Project Description: To support a series of exhibitions featuring contemporary and traditional Chinese art. The project includes paintings by Hong Kong artist Li Wei On, and paper-folding constructions by Chinese-American artist Nancy Loo Bjorge.
To support the Cine Latino Film festival and a curated film series. More than 120 films will be presented to an estimated audience of 7,000 people.
To support the Cine Latino Film Festival. Over 90 films will be presented to an estimated audience of 5,000 people.
To support the 2002 Cine Latino Film Festival. The festival attracts over 5,000 people and is the only West Coast venue to present work by and about Latinos.
To support the 2001 Cine Latino Film Festival. Scheduled to be held in September 2001, this event will showcase the work of Latino producers.
To support the eighth annual Cine Latino Film Festival. Scheduled to be held in September 2000, this event will showcase the work of Latino producers.

To support the presentation of the seventh annual Festival Cine Latino showcasing the work of Latino producers. Cine Latino annually attracts an audience of over 5,000 people and is the only west coast venue for this type of showcase. The festival will exhibit films and videos by and about Latinos, with a special emphasis on work which represents the complexity of the Latino experience while negating stereotypes often portrayed in mainstream media images. The festival will also include programs for youth and elder populations, seminars and discussions, and family matinees. Different genres of media art will be screened, i.e., documentaries, multimedia installations, and traditional narrative films.

Purpose: To support the creation and presentation of a dance performance project by Sarah Crowell and Keith Hennessy. Additional Project Description: Crowell and Hennessy will create works using both dance and community process to explore potential approaches for racial healing. Each choreographer will work with their own cast of dancers, but come together for conversations and works-in-process showings, eventually deciding whether or not to merge the casts and work together or continue to make separate works as part of a shared performance evening. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit artists and audiences interested in a creation process and performance that centers queer and multi-racial listening, dialogue, healing, and exchange. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support "Span," a new work in five movements created by artists Pamela Z and Carole Kim. Inspired by the history, architecture, engineering, and cultural impact of bridges, "Span" will explore bridges from a literal and metaphorical perspective. The piece will be scored for a chamber music ensemble and use interactive multimedia, electronic processing, and sampled sounds.

To support the development and premiere of "Babylon is Burning," a theatrical adaptation of Jeff Chang's book "Can't Stop Won't Stop: A History of the Hip-Hop Generation." Dan Wolf of Felonious, a hip-hop music and theater collective, will collaborate with Co-writer/Director Sean San Jose of Campo Santo. The work will incorporate movement, music, rap, and film to portray the hip-hop generation.

To support the further development and premiere of "Cat Lady," a darkly comic ensemble work for five performers, anchored by solo performer and writer Kristina Wong. The multimedia theater piece incorporates the psychology behind hoarding, pick-up artist techniques, anecdotes from unmarried women who live alone with cats ("cat ladies"), and Wong's attempts to simultaneously end racism and get her own pet to stop spraying.

To support the creation and presentation of "Suicide Barrier: Secure in Our Illusions." Choreographer Ledoh and his Salt Farm dance company will collaborate with video artist Perry Hallinan in the creation of an installation and performance work.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support the creation and presentation of the LED Kimono Project. Composer Miya Masaoka will create an interactive performance/installation featuring a musical instrument in the form of a kimono -- constructed of thousands of light-emitting diodes (LED).
To support the development and presentation of "Palestine, New Mexico," a new play by Latino theater ensemble Culture Clash.
To support artist residencies by La Pocha Nostra. Week-long residencies will take place in Anchorage, AK and San Antonio, TX.

To support the creation and development of workshop performances of "Califas 2000" by composer Gustavo Galindo, with a bilingual libretto by Guillermo Gomez-Pena and Roberto Sifuentes. This interdisciplinary opera, set at the end of the twenty-first century, is a collaborative work with choreographer Sara Shelton Mann, visual artist Enrique Chagoya, video artist Gustavo Vazquez, and lighting designer Penny Remsen.

To support rehearsal and production costs of La Pocha Nostra's Borderscape 2000 for performances in San Francisco. Borderscape will be an original performance piece that explores the American experience from a Chicano perspective.

To support the creation and development of a large-scale multimedia work, Borderscape 2000, by Guillermo Gomez-Pena and Roberto Sifuentes in collaboration with other artists that will explore immigrant and race issues through a futuristic setting in an America governed by a Chicano President and a Native American Vice President. : Borderscape will be an original performance piece that uses new technologies to explore the American experience from a Chicano perspective. The project will make extensive use of technology such as advanced sound equipment that introduces real-time sound distortions into live performance. Multimedia technology will be used to create visuals and projections and closed circuit video will magnify the performers= expressions, gestures and actions onto video screens located above the stage. Borderscape 2000 aims to demonstrate the ability of performance art to stimulate thoughtful public dialogue on complex issues and to increase cross cultural understanding and communication. The work will premier at San Francisco=s Theater Artaud and offer residency activities with artists= roundtables on the use of new technologies in contemporary art; public lectures and panel discussions on the role of contemporary art in defining the national identity; a workshop on Atechno-performance art@ with a Chicano perspective; and an open meeting of the local arts community on the subject of representation and race in the

Purpose: To support staff salaries for a series of circus performances. Additional Project Description: A series of free circus arts performances will be presented in outdoor venues throughout the San Francisco Bay Area. Performances will include classic circus acts reimagined for a modern world, accompanied by original music performed live. In partnership with Prescott Circus Theatre, a youth development program, young circus artists ages 11-13 will perform in the pre-show. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit featured artists and youth performers, as well as diverse audiences at open-air venues, many of which are located in geographically under-resourced and low-income neighborhoods in the Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support the Clown Conservatory program. The project will be a multidisciplinary professional training program in physical comedy, clowning, and vaudeville. The 24-week program, taught by master clowns, circus artists, and circus historians, will train professional and professional-track performing artists in narrative clowning, character creation, circus arts, and performance. The training will help prepare artists to meet the demands of today's international circus, film, and theater job market. The conservatory will culminate with an agent showcase, as well as the development and performance of a full-length, fully-scored circus show that will be recorded so that participants obtain audition materials.
To support the presentation of TRACES, an original production of 7 fingers circus.

To support the creation and performance of an original circus production by the Center's professional performing troupe, the New Pickle Circus. The production will continue New Pickle's work toward the development of a new American circus aesthetic.

To support the creation, rehearsal, and presentation of an original circus production. The New Pickle Circus will integrate the work of guest artists, including Chris Lashua, and company performers to create a circus performance featuring acrobatic skills.
To support the creation, production, and touring of an original circus piece. The New Pickle Circus, the professional performing company of Circus Center, will create and perform a new holiday show.

To support the creation, development, and presentation of a new circus performance. The New Pickle Circus, San Francisco School of Circus Arts' performing company, will present a holiday show for regional touring.

To support development and implementation of a two-year comprehensive professional training program in the circus arts. Pre-professional students of circus arts will benefit from small class sizes and performance opportunities throughout the Bay Area as a key part of their training.

To support expenses associated with establishing a full-time clown-training program. The establishment of this program is an integral part of the School's plan to offer an all-encompassing course of study in all facets of circus performance.

To support the creation of short documentary films and a public art installation celebrating the cultural assets and creative entrepreneurs of the Western Addition, a historically Black neighborhood in San Francisco, in partnership with the San Francisco Arts Commission. The films will focus on the Buchanan Mall, a public plaza that is slated for renovation. The project is expected to support collaborations between residents and city government to ensure renovations respond to the local communitys needs and vision and will include virtual activities.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support a series of visual arts exhibitions and related programming commemorating the 50th anniversary of the San Francisco Arts Commission Galleries. Exhibitions will be curated in partnership with local cultural organizations and feature programming such as artist talks, gallery tours, and panel discussions. Activities may take place either in-person or online.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support San Francisco WritersCorps, a creative writing program focused on youth from underserved communities. Working primarily in language arts classrooms and using creative writing activities thematically linked to literature, writers will work in schools for approximately eight months to supplement the curricula and strengthen students' writing skills. Activities will take place during and after the school day, primarily in underserved public schools, juvenile halls, arts and social service organizations, and public libraries. Support for teaching artists includes monthly cohort meetings and professional development trainings. Students' work will be published in anthologies, chapbooks, and broadsides; recorded for social media; and performed at a variety of poetry events, including the annual literary festival WordStorm.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support WritersCorps, a creative writing program serving youth from underserved communities. The program serves youth from underserved communities. Working primarily in language arts classrooms and using creative writing activities thematically linked to literature, writers will work in schools for approximately eight months to supplement the curricula and strengthen students' writing skills. Activities will take place during and after the school day, primarily in underserved public schools, juvenile halls, arts and social service organizations, and public libraries. Support for teaching artists includes monthly cohort meetings and professional development trainings. Students' work will be published as well as recorded for social media, and performed at a variety of poetry events, including the annual literary festival WordStorm.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support Affordable Housing and Sustainable Communities for San Francisco Artists. Working in partnership with the Mayor's Office of Housing, the Council of Community Housing Organizations, and private developers, the commission will offer comprehensive services integrating outreach, education, individualized support, workshops, peer-support, and access to the municipal services necessary to meet the basic eligibility requirements for affordable housing. Outreach will focus on low- to moderate-income artists to ensure that individuals are aware of the affordable housing options available.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support WritersCorps, a creative writing program serving at-risk youth in underserved public schools. Working primarily in language arts classrooms and using creative writing activities thematically linked to literature, writers will work in schools for approximately eight months to supplement the curricula and strengthen students' writing skills. The students' work will be published in anthologies, chapbooks, and broadsides; recorded on audio CDs; and performed at a variety of poetry events.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support the Chinatown Alleyways Project. The multidisciplinary program includes a pop-up gallery and studio serving local youth, neighborhood performing arts festivals, and cultural education workshops and tours. The project builds on three phases of work pursued by the Chinatown community during the past 30 years to revitalize and advance the role of its alleyways, which play an important socioeconomic role in the community's life and livelihood. It is a partnership between the San Francisco Arts Commission, the Chinese Culture Foundation, and the Chinatown Community Development Center. San Francisco's Chinatown is a densely populated neighborhood of 100,000 people with a median family income of $24,000, home to a dynamic mix of residents, businesses, schools, churches, family associations, and nonprofits that have deep roots there or have recently arrived at this significant immigration gateway.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support the Market Street Prototyping Festival. Artists, designers, and the public will be invited to submit ideas that will improve and activate Market Street, the city's main artery. The festival will become a testing ground for design and public art prototypes that will foster a more connected, beautiful San Francisco. During the festival, the community will experience the proposed design elements and public art, and will be invited to provide feedback to inform longer-term projects for temporary or permanent installation. San Francisco Arts Commission, the San Francisco Department of Planning, and Yerba Buena Center for the Arts will oversee project activities that will bring inspiration to the city's major infrastructure project, Better Market Street (the street is slated to be redesigned completely by 2018).

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support an exhibition of commissioned new work by emerging and mid-career Bay Area artists. The exhibition will be the inaugural exhibition at the commission's recently expanded galleries. SFAC Galleries Director Meg Shiffler and independent curator Kevin Chen will curate the exhibition. Visual artists under consideration include Zeina Barakeh, Anne Colvin, Victor De La Rosa, Ala Ebtekar, Charlene Tan, Lava Thomas, and Tsherin Sherpa. The artists are first- or second-generation immigrants that create connections between cultural heritage (mythology, folklore, spirituality, artistic practices) and modern urban life.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support WritersCorps, a creative writing program serving at-risk youth in underserved public schools. Working primarily in language arts classrooms and using creative writing activities thematically linked to literature, writers will work in schools for approximately eight months to supplement the curricula and strengthen students' writing skills. The students' work will be published in anthologies, chapbooks, and broadsides; recorded on audio CDs; and performed at a variety of poetry events.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support data aggregation and inventory analysis for the San Francisco Community Arts Stabilization Trust Space and Facility Capacity Building project. In partnership with the CAST, existing data on San Francisco's physical cultural assets will be aggregated and examined for missing data sets. An inventory of potential cultural assets such as vacant single-tenant properties, properties with master leasing potential, and underutilized community rooms in buildings owned or leased by nonprofits, will be conducted for use in the cultural community space-matching program. Northern California Community Loan Fund will work with CAST and act as an intermediary to arts groups. The Grants for the Arts and the Office of Economic  Workforce Development also will provide strategic input.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support the implementation and evaluation phase of a comprehensive strategic planning and community engagement initiative. Working with consultants, the arts commission will expand its municipal impact to integrate the role of arts and culture in all aspects of civic life. The long-range strategy development will include evaluation and assessment of the planning process and implementation of new policy in service to the greater arts ecosystem. The process of creating the plan will include all sectors of the local arts community throughout the city's 11 geographically and ethnically diverse districts.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support San Francisco WritersCorps, a creative writing program targeted toward at-risk youth in underserved public schools. Working primarily in language arts classrooms and using creative writing activities thematically linked to literature, writers will work in schools for approximately eight months to supplement the curricula and strengthen students' writing skills.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support the ARTery Project, featuring site-specific installations and performances to take place in the Mid-Market Cultural District. The commission will solicit proposals for funding for an innovative site-specific installation or performance - giving priority to neighborhood artists and groups - while inviting applicants citywide to envision community art activation projects.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support "WritersCorps," a creative writing program for at-risk youth in underserved public schools. Working primarily in language arts classrooms and using creative writing activities thematically linked to literature, writers will work in under-performing schools for approximately eight months to supplement the curricula and strengthen students' writing skills.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the WritersCorps, a creative writing program targeted toward at-risk youth in underserved public schools. Working primarily in language arts classrooms and using creative writing activities thematically linked to literature, writers will work in under-performing schools to strengthen students' writing skills.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support an exhibition and related activities featuring the work of Elizabeth Axtman, David Huffman, and Travis Somerville. The multi-sited exhibition, focusing on three Bay Area artists whose work explores race in America, will be installed in two of the Commission's gallery spaces and will also include an online component and a community-based, site-specific location.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support the development of the Mid-Market Cultural District. The comprehensive community development strategy has several components that include a lighting design competition, activation of vacant storefronts and sidewalks, and installation of art in storefronts.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the WritersCorp program. Professional artists will teach creative writing targeted toward at-risk youth in underserved public schools.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support tours, signage, lighting, and other costs related to the monumental sculpture "Three Heads Six Arms," by Zhang Huan. Created by contemporary Chinese artist Zhang Huan, the sculpture is on the San Francisco Civic Center Plaza.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the WritersCorps program. Professional artists will teach creative writing targeted toward at-risk youth in underserved public schools.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the WritersCorp program and 15th anniversary activities. Professional artists will teach creative writing targeted towards at-risk youth in underserved public schools.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support Spiraling Echoes: A Sound Sculpture for the Rotunda of San Francisco City Hall. A site-specific sound installation by Bill Fontana will translate the visual experience of the architecture in the rotunda into sound.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the WritersCorps program. Professional artists will teach creative writing to at-risk youth in underserved public schools.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Writer's Corp. Professional artists will teach creative writing to at-risk youth in underperforming schools.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support Writer's Corp programming that enables professional artists to teach creative writing to disadvantaged youths in underperforming schools. Student work will be published in chapbooks and in the annual Writer's Corp anthology. They will particpate in the Youth Poetry Slam League and other poetry events after school. WritersCorps will also develop a plan to replicate the project in other communities.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support arts education and professional development programs in elementary schools and child development centers throughout the San Francisco Unified School District. The project will provide artist residencies, professional development, and team-teaching opportunities.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support ongoing, comprehensive arts education and teacher development programs. The program will provide ongoing arts education activities for all elementary school and child development center students and professional development for educators in the San Francisco United School District.

Organization Name: City and County of San Francisco, California
Project Description: To support the conservation of a mural installation by Jose Moya del Pino created in 1935 that is located in the Center for African and African American Art and Culture, a municipally-owned and operated facility. The conservation will be conducted by Anne Rosenthal, as lead conservator, and her assistant Gregory Thomas. The overall project will be conducted over six months including the conservation of the mural, written and photographic documentation of the project, educational materials, as well as the installation of a protective barrier for the mural. Jose Moya del Pino, influenced by master mural artist Diego Rivera, was commissioned by the Acme Beer Company to create a set of murals. Conservation of this historical mural would serve to preserve the legacy of an important regional artist.

To support First Voice's residency and workshop production of "Uncle Gunjiro's Girlfriend" in San Francisco, Salt Lake City, and Chicago, and its world premiere in San Francisco. Climate Theatre, acting as fiscal agent for First Voice Theatre, is seeking support for a production and tour of "Uncle Gunjiro's Girlfriend" by Brenda Wong Aoki. This project has the potential to introduce a work about the historical experiences of Japanese Americans to the American theatrical repertoire. The work will be rooted in oral histories collected from Ms. Aoki's relatives recounting, with Aoki's artistic vision, the diversity of experiences of Japanese Americans during World War II. Three workshop productions and community-based residency activities will take place in San Francisco, Salt Lake City, and in Chicago's Highland Park neighborhood prior to the world premiere at San Francisco's Solo Mio Festival in September 1998.

Organization Name: Community Educational Services of San Francisco
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Blasted By Culture in consortium with Asian Improv aRts. The project will provide opportunities for children to learn theatrical singing and movement from the Huangmei, Beijing, and Kunqu styles of Chinese opera.

Purpose: To support free, year-long Latin and jazz music education programs for students. Additional Project Description: In the Mission District Young Musicians Program, teaching artists will provide bilingual instruction to students through private lessons and performance classes focusing on Latin music from Mexico, Cuba, Colombia, Puerto Rico, and the United States. Students in the Teen Jazz Orchestra will participate in a jazz ensemble and learn about music theory, jazz history, and music composition. Each program will provide multiple community-based performance opportunities for youth. Intended Beneficiaries: Programming will serve middle and high school students, many from underserved communities, in the San Francisco area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the Young Musicians Program (YMP). This free program for diverse middle and high school students from underserved communities focuses on a variety of musical styles including Latin, Jazz, popular, and classical. The Mission District YMP is a bilingual program and focuses on repertoire and skills fundamental to Latin traditional and popular music. YMP works with students nominated by their public school music teachers. The project also provides group classes in chamber music, jazz and string orchestra, and theory and music history to advanced students. Each component provides multiple community-based performance opportunities for youth.

To support the Young Musicians Program (YMP). Copies of the assessment tools are the required final product. This free program for diverse, underserved students focuses on a variety of musical styles including Latin, Jazz, and classical. Middle and high school students participate in individual lessons, music theory, and ensemble classes taught by master artists. The project's three components - Mission District YMP, Inner City YMP, and Comprehensive Music Program - serve different populations and use varied approaches. The Mission District YMP is a bilingual program primarily for Latino youth and focuses on repertoire and skills fundamental to Latin traditional and popular music. Inner City YMP works with students nominated by their public school music teacher to study chamber music, jazz, and string orchestra. The Comprehensive Musicianship Program provides lessons to advanced students. Each component provides multiple community-based performance opportunities for youth.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Young Musicians Programs. Middle and high school students will participate in weekly instrumental music classes, individual private lessons, guest artist workshops, and have opportunities for performance.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Comprehensive Musicianship/Inner City Young Musicians program. Professional musicians will provide free ensemble and musicianship classes for underserved middle and high school students.

To support the Comprehensive Musicianship/Inner City Young Musicians program. Professional musicians will provide free ensemble and musicianship classes for underserved middle and high school-aged students.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support an after-school multimedia arts youth internship program. Teaching artists join community media makers in training and mentoring young urban teens to create original, social issue documentary and narrative shorts, audio segments, music videos, and feature length films.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support digital multi-media and video training. Participants will study media literacy, creative writing, film arts appreciation, story development, screenwriting, basic photography, hands-on learning with still and mini digital video camcorders, sound and lighting equipment, and Final Cut Pro digital editing tutorials.

To support the exhibition, "Jewish Folktales Retold: Artist as Maggid." The exhibition will focus on newly commissioned work by contemporary artists created in response to fairy tales, folktales, tales of mysticism, and the supernatural from the 16th century to the present. A few selected artists for the commissions are sculptor, Michael Arcega (b. 1973); photographer, Dina Goldstein (b. 1969); new media artist, Mads Lynnerup (b. 1976); and painter, Vera Iliatova (b. 1975). The exhibition, its online catalogue, and public programs such as gallery talks, educator-led tours, lesson plans and teacher trainings, art making for families, and storytelling performances, will engage diverse artists and audiences in a shared exploration of storytelling and its enduring power to inspire creativity in the visual arts.

To support the exhibition "From Generation to Generation," with accompanying catalogue. The exhibition will explore issues related to ancestral and collective memories. Public programming will include partnerships with community organizations to develop complementary curriculum for middle school and high school students, addressing issues relating to the Holocaust, international genocide, racism, and prejudice.

To support a group exhibition and catalogue, "N.E.A.T: New Experiments in Art and Technology," featuring Bay Area artists. The museum will commission artists to create new works that use or react to digital technology. The exhibition will include a range of seminal figures who virtually invented the field of art utilizing digital technology, to other artists who are reimagining it. The exhibition will include artists who have been working to reconcile electronic innovation with aesthetic practice. While generally falling within the genre of sculpture, pieces in the show will include works with light, sound, and video.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support the production of a catalogue to accompany the exhibition "New Works/Old Story: 80 Artists at the Passover Table." The exhibition and catalogue will showcase new works by leading local, national, and internatinal artists who have been invited to explore the meaning and form of the Seder plate.

To support commissioned artworks for the exhibition "In the Beginning" with accompanying catalogue and education programs. In the Beginning is the inaugural exhibition of newly commissioned site-specific work for the museum's new facility in downtown.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: Purpose: To support an exhibition featuring the work of Lee Mingwei at the de Young Museum. Additional Project Description: The exhibition will feature a new commission alongside seven of Mingwei's (b. 1964) participatory installations that seek to dissolve the boundaries between artist, art object, and viewer. The project will include other contemporary artists who will be invited to make work in response to works in the museum's permanent collection. The exhibition will be accompanied by live and virtual educational programs. Intended Beneficiaries: The exhibition will serve museum visitors from the San Francisco Bay Area, as well as tourists from across the United States. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: Purpose: To support a leadership training and professional development program at the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco. Additional Project Description: Participants in the paid program will engage in rigorous hands-on, syllabus-based training focused on museum education and culture; facilitate in-gallery discussions of the permanent collection; and learn from museum workers who are committed to advancing diversity, equity, inclusion, and access in the field. The museum will collaborate with organizations such as the University of California, Berkeley's Ethnic Studies department, City College of San Francisco, and Bay Area Emerging Museum Professionals to recruit for the program. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve the community and emerging professionals seeking a career in the arts. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support public programming at the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco. The museum will produce Virtual Wednesdays, a digital program that focuses on new opportunities to interpret the collection and exhibitions, as well as Local Voices, a podcast that highlights perspectives from Bay Area visual artists, musicians, scholars, community leaders, and thinkers aimed to reframe exhibitions and collections through relevant and local narratives.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the exhibition Early Rubens, organized by the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco. The exhibition will feature approximately 70 works focusing on the early career of Peter Paul Rubens (1577-1640) at the Legion of Honor Museum. Rubens' wide-range oeuvre, 1608-20, includes altarpieces, portraits, hunt and mythological scenes, and decorative pieces in oil paint and tapestry. The exhibition will be the first to explore this watershed period, featuring works that have never traveled to the West Coast, and in some cases, to the United States. The exhibition also will demonstrate how Rubens established himself as the foremost painter of the Northern Baroque, and examine his mastery of multiple visual styles and subject matter. A scholarly catalogue and an array of public programs, including live performances by Belgian musicians and lectures, will accompany the exhibition. In addition, K-12 programs such as docent-led school tours and hands-on art activities will be offered.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the exhibition "The Cult of the Machine: Precisionism and American Art." Presented at the de Young Museum, the exhibition will feature approximately 150 works by modernists such as Charles Sheeler, Georgia O'Keeffe, and Charles Demuth. The expansive exhibition will shed scholarly light on the aesthetic and intellectual concerns of Precisionism, underlying the development of an important strand of American Modernism. Public and educational outreach will include a catalogue, live performances by local musicians, hands-on art activities, films, artist demonstrations, scholarly talks, and school programs.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the exhibition "Stuart Davis: In Full Swing" and related educational and public programming. Co-organized by the Whitney Museum of American Art and the National Gallery of Art, the traveling exhibition pays tribute to Stuart Davis (1892-1964), one of the most important innovators in the evolution of American modernism and abstraction. With approximately 75 works on display, ranging from his early paintings of commercial products from the 1920s, to the canvas that was on his easel at the time of his death, the exhibition highlights Davis's unique ability to assimilate pop culture influences-the aesthetics of advertising and the rhythms of jazz-with the lessons of Cubism. The de Young will be the only exhibition venue west of the Mississippi. Comprehensive public programming at the de Young is planned to complement the exhibition.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the exhibition "Ed Ruscha and the Great American West" and related public programming. The exhibition at the de Young Museum will include more than 100 paintings, drawings, prints, photographs, and artist books in nine narrative sections that survey Ruscha's (b. 1937) fascination with the American West. The exhibition will explore a range of themes and motifs including the Western road trip by automobile, the Hollywood sign, the degradation of the Western landscape, urban sprawl, and Ruscha's iconic word images that encapsulate the language, history, and mood of the ever-changing Western scene. A variety of public programming is planned, including film screenings, lectures, panel discussions, an audio tour, and a printmaking residency for a local emerging artist.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the exhibition "Jewel City: Art of the Panama-Pacific International Exposition" at the de Young Museum, with an accompanying catalogue. The exhibition will commemorate the centennial of the 1915 World's Fair in San Francisco that marked both the opening of the Panama Canal and the post-earthquake reconstruction of the city, by reassembling American and European paintings, sculptures, murals, works on paper, and ephemera from the original "Jewel City" exhibition. The exhibition will explore diverse aspects of the content, display, reception, and legacy of this landmark event.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the exhibition and catalogue "Modernism from the National Gallery of Art: The Robert and Jane Meyerhoff Collection." The exhibition brings highlights from this collection of post-World War II art including important works by Jasper Johns, Roy Lichtenstein, and Frank Stella to the West Coast, with the de Young Museum as its venue.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the exhibition "Richard Diebenkorn: The Berkeley Years, 1953-1966," at the deYoung Museum, with an accompanying catalogue. Through the presentation of more than 100 paintings, drawings, and watercolors, the exhibition will explore Diebenkorn's (1923-93) oscillation between abstraction and figuration during the 13 years he was living in Berkeley.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the exhibition "Olmec: Colossal Masterworks of Ancient Mexico" at the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, with accompanying education programs. The exhibition will present a wealth of recent discoveries ranging from portable objects to monumental sculpture.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the exhibition "Shifting Currents of Asian American Art: 1900-1970," with accompanying catalogue and education programs. The exhibition seeks to advance scholarship and provide greater awareness of this under-represented and under-appreciated subgroup within American art history.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support conservation treatment of key French furniture pieces and an important frame in the European art collection. Dating from the 18th century, the works are anchors of the museum's survey collection of European art.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the touring exhibtion HATSHEPSUT: FROM QUEEN TO PHARAOH, with accompanying education programs. The exhibition, organized in collaboration with the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will highlight the art created during the reign of the female pharaoh Hatshepsut, who ruled ca. 1479-1468 B.C.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Category: National Arts and Humanities Youth Program Awards
Project Description: In recognition of the Museum Ambassador Program, which introduces public high school students to museums and the visual arts as resources for exploration and learning, while developing their academic and professional skills.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support conservation treatment of key furniture pieces and important frames for paintings in the American art collection. Dating from the 18th to the early 20th century, the works are anchors of the museum's comprehensive survey of American art.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the touring exhibition "Courtly Art of the Ancient Maya," with accompanying catalogue and education programs. The exhibition wil focus on the art styles of different Mayan cities in the period dating from 650 to 800 A.D.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support a consortium project of an exhibition of the work of Dutch artist Michael Sweerts (1618-1664), with accompanying education programs. The exhibition is being organized in collaboration with the Wadsworth Atheneum, Hartford, CT, and the Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support a traveling retrospective exhibition of the work of American painter Wayne Thiebaud, with accompanying catalogue and education programs. The exhibition, which will open mid-2000 coinciding with the artist's 80th birthday, will trace his career from the 1950s to the present.

Organization Name: Corporation of the Fine Arts Museums
Popular Name: aka Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
Project Description: To support a traveling exhibition titled "Picasso and the War: 1937-1945," with accompanying catalogue and education programs, scheduled to open in San Francisco and then travel to New York. The proposed exhibition will present for the first time in the United States approximately 75 still lifes, portraits, city scapes, and figure paintings tracing Pablo Picasso's response to the apocalyptic events that occurred in Europe from the Spanish Civil War through World War II, including studies for one of the artist's masterpieces, "Guernica," drawn from public and private collections from around the world. The goal of the project is to present to American audiences a first-time opportunity to see the evolution of forms and symbols in Picasso's work in response to war, the reflection of his political views in his art, his depiction of life as an avant garde artist in Paris under German occupation, and the interactions among media in his work of this period. A 230-page, fully illustrated catalogue, interpretive object labels and wall texts, introductory gallery guides, films, symposia, family programs and extensive promotional activities will accompany the exhibition, enhancing its appeal for the general public as well as scholars.

Purpose: To support the Artist Residency and Commissioning program, which provides space and support for emerging and mid-career choreographers. Additional Project Description: The program supports residencies for dance and performing artists on various tracks, focusing on contemporary work; culturally specific work; and innovative, technologically-engaged work. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve choreographers and performance artists, as well as audiences who attend the culminating performances. Intended Outcome: Arts leaders develop professional skills and strategies.

Purpose: To support the Artist Residency and Commissioning program, which provides space and support for emerging and mid-career choreographers. Additional Project Description: The program supports residencies for dance and performing artists on various tracks, focusing on contemporary work; culturally specific work; and innovative, technologically-engaged work. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve choreographers and performance artists. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support the Artist Residency and Commissioning (ARC) program, which provides space and support for emerging and mid-career choreographers. The ARC program supports residencies for dance and performing artists on various tracks: Edge, focusing on contemporary work; and Combustible, focusing on innovative and technologically engaged work. Some project activity may take place virtually.

To support the Artist Residency and Commissioning Program, which provides space and support for emerging and mid-career choreographers. The ARC Program supports five-month residencies during which artists will create and perform new works. ARC provides three annual residency tracks for dance and performing artists: Edge, focusing on contemporary work; Performing Diaspora, focusing on culturally specific work on the edge of tradition; and Combustible, focusing on innovative and technologically engaged work. Activities include work-in-progress showings where residents and the public provide feedback on the work.

To support the Artist Residency and Commissioning (ARC) Program, which provides space and support for emerging and mid-career choreographers to create new works. The ARC Program supports five-month residencies during which artists will create and perform new works. ARC provides three annual residency tracks for dance and performing artists: Edge, focusing on contemporary work; Performing Diaspora, focusing on culturally specific work on the edge of tradition; and Combustible, focusing on innovative and technologically engaged work. Activities include work-in-progress showings where residents and the public provide feedback on the work, as well as a mentor for each resident artist.

To support the Artist Residency and Commissioning (ARC) Program. The program identifies local emerging and mid-career choreographers whose work is ready to be appreciated by a larger audience and provides space and support for those artists to create new works. The ARC Program supports as many as three, five-month residencies during which artists will create and perform new works. ARC provides three annual residency tracks for dance and performing artists: Edge, focusing on disruptive contemporary work; Performing Diaspora, focusing on culturally specific work on the edge of tradition; and Combustible, focusing on innovative and technologically engaged work. Activities include work-in-progress showings where residents and the public provide feedback on the work, as well as a mentor for each resident artist.

To support dance artist residencies. The program will identify local emerging and mid-career choreographers whose work is ready to be appreciated by a larger audience. CounterPULSE will provide space and support for those artists to create new dances. During the residency, selected artists will develop, teach, and perform new works. Activities include work-in-progress showings where residents and the public provide feedback on the work. The residencies will culminate in a fully produced premiere of the works, which will run during two weeks.

To support the CounterPULSE Artist Residency and Commissioning (ARC) Program. The program will identify local emerging and mid-career choreographers whose work is ready to be appreciated by a larger audience. CounterPULSE will provide space and support for those artists to create new dances. During the residency, some of the artists will develop, teach, and perform new works. Activities also will include work-in-progress showings where residents and the public provide feedback on the work, and fully produced premieres of the work.

To support the CounterPULSE Artist Residency and Commissioning (ARC) Program. The program will identify local choreographers whose work is ready to be appreciated by a larger audience, and will provide space and support for those artists to create new dances. Activities will include the creation and progress showings of contemporary works.
To support the CounterPulse Artist Residency and Commissioning (ARC) Program. Activities will include the creation and presentation of contemporary works and one full-length world premiere.

To support artist residencies. The 2012 ARC Program will consist of two, six-month residencies during which four artists (two per session) will rehearse, collaborate, teach and perform new work in a shared program.

To support the CounterPULSE Performing Diaspora program, for dance artists who are using traditional performance as a foundation for experimentation and innovation, in consortium with the National Steinbeck Center. The program will include residencies, creation of works, festivals, a symposium, discussion series, and an interactive online platform.

To support the Artist Residency and Commissioning Program (ARC) for local emerging and mid-career choreographers. The program will include residencies during which artists will rehearse, collaborate, teach, and perform new work.

To support the Artist in Residence Program for local emerging and mid-career choreographers. The program will include residencies during which artists will rehearse, collaborate, and perform new work.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support the Artist Residency and Commissioning Program for local emerging and mid-career choreographers. The program will include at least two six-month residencies during which up to four artists will rehearse, collaborate, teach, and perform new work.

To support the Artist in Residence Program for local emerging choreographers. The project will include developmental feedback sessions, outreach to local non-dance communities, and the presentation of original works of contemporary choreography.

To support the Artist in Residence program for local emerging choreographers. The project will include developmental feedback sessions, public workshops, outreach to local non-dance communities, and the presentation of original works of contemporary choreography.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work by choreographer Jess Curtis. The work will be presented at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in the United States and at tanzbaustelle and Fabrik Potsdam in Germany.

Purpose: To support art programming and professional development opportunities with a focus on artists with developmental disabilities. Additional Project Description: Teaching artists will partner with participants to define their goals and provide community engagement. Artists will have the opportunity to curate an on-site exhibition, initiate an art-making project, and lead a public art-making workshop. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit Bay Area artists. Intended Outcome: Arts leaders develop professional skills and strategies.

Purpose: To support a series of exhibitions and art-making activities for artists with developmental disabilities. Additional Project Description: Artists will work with the organization's exhibition and studio program team to develop online and in-person exhibitions, present works, and participate in workshops taught by teaching artists. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit Bay Area artists. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support a series of exhibitions and art-making activities for artists with developmental disabilities. As many as 50 artists with developmental disabilities will work with the organization's exhibition and studio program team, virtually and in-person, to develop online and in-person exhibitions, present works, and assist with workshops taught by teaching artists.

To support a series of programs connecting Mexican and Latin American folk art to contemporary artmaking. Artists with developmental disabilities, working alongside other artists and community members, will learn traditional textile embroidery and "cartonera" or papier-mch techniques and collaborate with artist Ana Teresa Fernandez to create multimedia art installations at different venues within San Francisco.

Organization Name: Croatian Cultural Center of San Francisco
Project Description: To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Organization Name: Croatian Cultural Center of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the Saints Kiril  Methody Festival of Bulgarian Arts and Culture. The festival will present traditional Bulgarian vocal and instrumental music and dance through a series of performances, workshops, and special presentations for children.

Organization Name: Croatian Cultural Center of San Francisco
Project Description: To support Hungarian Dance House. Hungarian artists will present music, dance, crafts, and food. A special program of children's dance is planned and the Hungarian ensemble Forras will provide music for the audience to participate in the dances.

Organization Name: Croatian Cultural Center of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the San Francisco Croatian Heritage Festival. Croatian master artists and ensembles will perform and offer classes in tamburitza playing and klapa (a capella) singing. The festival will also present traditional Croatian foods and provide opportunities for community singing and dancing.

Organization Name: Croatian Cultural Center of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the 2012 San Francisco Tamburitza Festival. The Festival will present Croatian American Tamburitza ensembles and soloists who, in addition to performing, will lead master classes, jam sessions, provide music for dancing, and participate in a panel discussion about Tamburitza music in the lives of Croatian people.

Organization Name: Croatian Cultural Center of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the "Cultural Crossroads Program." The project will present a series of concerts representing various Balkan communities living in the San Francisco area.

Organization Name: Croatian Cultural Center of San Francisco
Project Description: To support CroatiaFest 2008. Activities include a concert featuring traditional music and dance, a tamburitza master class, a film screening, and a photography exhibit.

Organization Name: Croatian Cultural Center of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the "CroatiaFest." This project supports a multidisciplinary event featuring various Croatian art forms.

Organization Name: Croatian Cultural Center of San Francisco
Project Description: To support fifth annual Bulgarian Music and Dance Festival. The festival will offer master classes in traditional dance and vocal music and an evening concert featuring Bay Area ensembles and soloists.

Purpose: To support the development and production of Shipping  Handling by Star Finch, directed by Lisa Marie Rollins. Additional Project Description: The futuristic work will explore the relationships of communities and individuals to artificial intelligence. The story will be structured as an evening out at the theater, told in reverse order. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit theater artists and audiences in San Francisco. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support a production of The Displaced by Isaac Gomez. Written as a thriller, the play explores the topics of gentrification, displacement, and ancestry. Related project activities will include workshops with community partners and post-show conversations.

To support a collaboration with the hip-hop orchestra Ensemble Mik NaWooj (EMN), to create a cross-disciplinary, participatory workshop performance. The piece tells the story of a young woman grieving the violence, materialism, isolation, and selfishness in her community who meets two fellow travelers who aid in her search for renewed hope. The production will be directed by Artistic Director Mina Morita. Star Finch will write the script, with original compositions by EMN Founder JooWan Kim.

To support the final development and premiere of "A Tale of Autumn" by Christopher Chen. A modern-day fable explores themes of political power, notions of cultural hierarchy, and the power of corporate personhood in present day capitalism. The work is inspired by Shakespeare's "Richard III" and "Macbeth" and popular "quest-for-power" TV shows.
To support the premiere of "Mechanics Of Love" by Dipika Guha.

To support the development and premiere of "The Late Wedding" by Christopher Chen. Based on novels by Italo Calvino, the play will examine themes of intimacy and distance, dislocation, and transience in Internet-age relationships.

To support the development and world premiere production of "The Taming" by Lauren Gunderson. Based on Shakespeare's "The Taming of The Shrew," the comedic play will portray the female voice in American politics and explore potent elements of female characters within the Bard's work.
To support the world premiere production of "One Big Lie" by Liz Duffy Adams.

Purpose: To support artist fees and facility costs for an annual dance and music festival. Additional Project Description: The festival will focus on Caribbean diaspora artists and include mainstage performances in San Francisco, along with workshops and other special arts events. Artists and founders of CubaCaribe, Ramon Ramos Alayo and Jamaica Itule Simmons, will work together with the community to curate the festival programming. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve residents and visitors of the Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Organization Name: Cultura y Arte Nativa de las Americas
Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organizations constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

Purpose: To support the production of Sappho, a new play written by Aimee Suzara and directed Nailah Unole Didanasea Harper-Malveaux. Additional Project Description: Inspired by Estelle Anna B. Lewis' Sappho of Lesbos, a verse play written in 1868, the project will investigate the evolution of queer identities across generations and centuries. Performances will be presented virtually due to COVID. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit theater artists and audiences in San Francisco. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support the premiere of "Ondine" by Katharine Sherman. Based on an ancient mermaid myth that inspired Jean Giraudoux's seminal 1938 work of the same title and Hans Christian Andersen's "The Little Mermaid," Sherman's "Ondine" is a contemporary retelling of the story of a water spirit who comes to land to be with her lover. The production will be directed by Founding Artistic Director Rob Melrose. The playwright will be in residence in San Francisco for the duration of the rehearsal period leading up to the world premiere production.

To support the New Experimental Plays Initiative. The project will include the premiere of "Mt. Misery" by resident playwright Andrew Saito, as well as the commission and development of two new plays by Saito. The initiative also will consist of workshops of new works by a diverse group of playwrights through the theater's experimental play festival, RISK IS THIS. The festival also includes "Who is Heiner Mueller?" by Mark Jackson, and "Caught" by Chris Chen.

To support the commission and world premiere of "Tender Loin," written and directed by Annie Elias. The work will be about the people and places in the district where Cutting Ball Theater is located, developed through a compilation of interviews with neighborhood merchants, workers, and residents, woven into a documentary-style theater piece.

To support the Strindberg Cycle, a presentation of all five chamber plays by Swedish playwright August Strindberg, in consortium with scholars from the Unversity of California at Berkeley's Department of Scandinavian Studies. The project will be performed with a digital technology component to engage audiences and create space for dialogue, featuring an open access Web site to provide multiple avenues for audience participation, access to historical and contextual information, and multimedia documentation of the work.

To support the development and production of the new play "Tontlawald" by Eugenie Chan. Developed in collaboration with director Paige Rogers and an ensemble of actors using song and the movement-based techniques of Polish experimental theater director Jerzy Grotowski, the play will build on the Estonian fairy tale of the same name, which tells the story of a young girl who flees the beatings of a cruel stepmother.

To support the world premiere productions of two new plays. The project will include a production of and Jesus Moonwalks the Mississippi by Marcus Gardley directed by Amy Mueller, and Bone to Pick  Diadem by Eugenie Chan directed by artistic director Bob Melrose.
