To support productions of Samuel Beckett's "Endgame" and "Bone to Pick" by Eugenie Chan. Both productions will be directed by artistic director Rob Melrose.

To support Call  Response, a concert program by the Cypress String Quartet with related educational activities. A new work by composer Philippe Hersant, created in response to Bela Bartok's String Quartet #4 and Beethoven's String Quartet in E minor, Op. 59 #2, will be performed at the Marines Memorial Theater. Educational activities will include school visits, classroom guides for teachers, free tickets to participating students, and pre-concert lectures.

To support "Call  Response," a concert program featuring a new work by composer George Tsontakis, with related educational activities. Tsontakis' "String Quartet #6," created in response to Schubert's seminal "String Quartet in G," will be performed at the SF Jazz Center and at the 92nd Street Y in New York City. Educational activities will include school visits, online classroom guides for teachers, free tickets to participating students, and pre-concert lectures.

To support Call and Response, a concert program featuring a new work by composer Jennifer Higdon with related educational activities. The work will be performed by the Cypress String Quartet and soprano Christine Brandes and based on the poetry of former U.S. Poet Laureate W. S. Merwin.

To support Call and Response, a commissioning, performance, and educational program featuring composer Elena Ruehr and the Cypress String Quartet. The new work will be created using works of literature as inspiration.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support "Inspired by America," an interdisciplinary film and chamber music program produced in consortium with the Krannert Center for the Performing Arts. Producer/director Michael Schwarz will create a film of readings and images based on Dr. Jacob Needleman's book "The American Soul," with integrated performances by the Cypress String Quartet.
To support Call and Response, a performance and outreach project. Up to four concerts and outreach activities will bring music into communities of the San Francisco Bay Area.

Organization Name: Dance Brigade A New Group from Wallflower Order
Project Description: Purpose: To support the creation and production of From Guinea to Cuba. Additional Project Description: A collaboration between Susana Arenas Pedroso and Duniya Dance  Drum Company, the work will be a dance and music performance influenced by the cultural, political, and reciprocal relationship between Guinea, West Africa and Cuba. The production is a part of Dance Mission Theater's College of African Diasporic Arts. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve artists, audiences, and communities in San Francisco's Mission District, including people who identify as Black, Latinx, and Afro-Latinx. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

Organization Name: Dance Brigade A New Group from Wallflower Order
Project Description: To support a consortium project to create and present a multi-disciplinary aerial performance piece at the San Francisco International Airport. In collaboration with QCC: Center for GLBT Art and Culture, choreographer Joanna Haigood, filmmaker Julie Dash, and composer/instrument maker Walter Kitundu will create and perform DEPARTURE AND ARRIVAL.

Organization Name: Dance Brigade A New Group from Wallflower Order
Project Description: To support the development and workshop performances of SUPERACION, directed by Eddy Armando, and performances and residency activities by Grupo Cultural Yuyachkani from Peru, in consortium with SOMARTS.

Organization Name: Dance Brigade A New Group from Wallflower Order
Project Description: To support a consortium project involving residencies by contemporary Russian and German dance/movement theater companies. In partnership with the New College of California, the companies will work with students and local arts groups while in residence in San Francisco.

Purpose: To support the San Francisco Dance Film Festival. Additional Project Description: The festival includes dance films created for the camera, full-length recordings of stage productions, documentaries, and virtual reality experiences. Additional programming includes the Co-Laboratory, which brings choreographers, filmmakers, dancers, composers, engineers, and more together to create new films which will premiere at the San Francisco Dance Film Festival. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit artists participating in the festival, live audiences in San Francisco, and online audiences. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the San Francisco Dance Film Festival. Programming includes the Co-Laboratory which brings choreographers, filmmakers, dancers, composers, engineers, and others together to create new screendance films which will premiere at the San Francisco Dance Film Festival.

To support the San Francisco Dance Film Festival's convenings including screendance films, documentaries, and live performance. The festival will happen in two parts with the fall convening focusing on feature film screenings and documentaries and the spring convening on live performance. Programs may be conducted completely virtually if necessary. Additional programming includes the Co-Laboratory, which will bring together Rising Out of the System (R.O.O.T.S.) The Movement and filmmaker Yoram Savion to combine a range of dance genres to form a narrative of what it means to be Black, to be a dancer, and to be from Richmond, California.

To support the San Francisco Dance Film Festival. The festival will feature film screenings, select live performances, question-and-answer sessions, and discussions. Additional programs include the Co-Laboratory, which brings together choreographers, filmmakers, dancers, composers, musicians, photographers, and lighting designers in a unique partnership to create films to premiere at the festival.

To support the San Francisco Dance Film Festival. The festival will feature as many as four days of film screenings around the city, select live performances, question-and-answer sessions, and discussions. Additional programs include the Co-Laboratory, which brings together choreographers, filmmakers, dancers, composers, musicians, photographers, and lighting designers in a unique partnership to create films specifically for the festival.

To support the annual WestWave Dance, in partnership with SAFEhouse, which will include the presentation of works by Bay Area choreographers in a shared program at Z Space and at ODC Theater in San Francisco. The project will also include a reprise of the "Monday a Month" program, a series of curated programs to be presented the second Monday of each month between August and October.

To support the WestWave Dance festival. As part of the 20th anniversary celebration, there will be a "Choreographers and Composers Consortium," which will result in the commission of up to four collaborative works by pairs of dance and musical artists.
To support the 2010 West Wave Dance Festival. The festival includes presentations of emerging and mid-career Bay Area artists and will take place at the Cowell Theatre in San Francisco.

To support the 18th annual West Wave Dance Festival In partnership with the Dancers' Group, the project presents emerging and mid-career Bay Area artists and will take place at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.
To support the 2008 West Wave Dance Festival. The project presents emerging and mid-career Bay Area artists, and will take place at Project Artaud Theater in San Francisco.
To support the 16th annual West Wave Dance Festival. The festival presents emerging and mid-career Bay Area artists, and will take place at Theater Artaud in San Francisco.
To support the 15th annual Summerfest/dance Festival. The festival presents emerging and mid-career Bay Area artists.
To support the presentation of the 14th annual summer festival. The Summerfest/dance Festival will take place over three weeks and feature the work of up to 32 choreographers.

Purpose: To support In Dance, a free online quarterly publication that promotes dance artists and activities in the San Francisco Bay Area. Additional Project Description: The publication gives readers in-depth information on performance opportunities and a behind-the-scenes look at the work being created by local artists as well as by those in other parts of the country. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit artists and audiences in the San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support In Dance, a free online quarterly publication that promotes dance artists and activities in the San Francisco Bay Area. The publication gives readers in-depth information on performance opportunities and a behind-the-scenes look at the work being created by local artists as well as by those in other parts of the country.

To support In Dance, a free online quarterly publication that promotes dance artists and activities in the San Francisco Bay Area. The publication gives readers in-depth information on performance opportunities, and a behind-the-scenes look at the work being created by the region's artists as well as by those in other parts of the country.

To support In Dance, a free print and online monthly publication that promotes dance artists and activities in the San Francisco Bay Area. The publication gives readers in-depth information on performance opportunities, as well as a behind-the-scenes look at the work being created by the region's artists as well as by those in other parts of the country.

To support In Dance, a free print and online monthly publication that promotes dance artists and activities in the San Francisco Bay Area. The publication includes a comprehensive performance calendar, summer workshop guide, articles, previews of dance companies, feature articles, personal perspectives on dance, and special interviews and features. Articles give readers in-depth information on performance opportunities, as well as a behind-the-scenes look at the work being created by the region's artists as well as by those in other parts of the country.

To support "In Dance," a free print and online monthly publication that promotes dance artists in the San Francisco Bay Area. The publication includes a comprehensive performance calendar, summer workshop guide, articles, previews of dance companies, feature articles, personal perspectives on dance, and special interviews and features. Articles give readers an in-depth, behind-the-scenes look at the work being created by the region's artists and by those in other parts of the country as well.

To support "In Dance," a free print and online monthly publication that promotes dance artists in the San Francisco Bay Area. The publication includes a comprehensive performance calendar, summer workshop guide, articles, previews of dance companies, feature articles, personal perspectives on dance, news listings, an article archive, and special interviews and features. Articles give readers an in-depth, behind-the-scenes look at local, regional, and national artists and the work that they are creating. Past issues of "In Dance" are searchable in an archive on the Dancers' Group's website. Dancers' Group will publish and print "In Dance" monthly, with double issues in January/February and July/August.

To support "In Dance," a free print and online monthly publication that promotes dance artists in the San Francisco Bay Area. The publication includes a comprehensive performance calendar, summer workshop guide, articles, reviews of dance companies, personal perspectives on dance, classes, performance auditions, job postings, and grant news listings. Past issues of "In Dance" will now be searchable in an archive on the Dancers' Group's website.

To support "In Dance," a publication targeted to dance artists in the San Francisco Bay Area. The issues appear in print as well as on the Web, and include a comprehensive performance calendar, summer workshop guide, reviews of dance companies, performance auditions, job postings, grant news listings, and downloadable podcasts of special interviews and features.

To support "In Dance," a publication targeted for dance artists in the San Francisco Bay Area. The issues appear in print as well as on the Dancers' Group Web site, and include a comprehensive performance calendar, summer workshop guide, reviews of dance companies, performance auditions, jobs, grant news listings, and downloadable podcasts of special interviews and features.

To support "In Dance," a publication targeted for dance artists in the San Francisco/Bay Area. The issues appear in print as well as on the Dancers' Group Web site, and include a comprehensive performance calendar, summer workshop guide, reviews of dance companies, performance auditions, jobs, grant news listings, and downloadable podcasts of special interviews and features.
To support expansion of the publication In Dance, for movement-based artists in the San Francisco Bay Area. The publication appears in print as well as on the Dancers' Group Web site.

To support the expansion of the publication IN DANCE. The only publication in the San Francisco Bay area dedicated to movement-based art and arists appears in print as well as on the Dancers' Group Web site.
To support the expansion of the publication IN DANCE, for movement-based artists in the San Francisco Bay Area. The publication appears in print as well as on the Dancers' Group Web site.

To support the expansion of IN DANCE publication in print and through a Web site and podcasts. The project will expand readership, make dance more visible to the public, and create networking, resource, and other opportunities for dance artists, locally and nationally.

To support the 8th annual San Francisco Hip Hop DanceFest, presenting hip-hop dance artists from across the United States. The DanceFest also includes performances by Bay Area youth dance companies and masters classes with visiting artists.

To support the creation and presentation of site-specific dances along one of San Francisco's trolley lines. The third annual San Francisco Trolley Dances will bring together the local dance community and the San Francisco Municipal Railway (MUNI) for two weekends of free performances.

To support the creation and presentation of site-specific dances along one of San Francisco's historic trolley lines. Trolley Dances will involve the local dance community, the San Francisco Municipal Railway, and the inner city communities of downtown San Francisco
To support the creation and presentation of a new work. The piece will look at man's inhumanity to man, and will continue Robert Moses' interest in religion and its impact on society.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work entitled "A Biography of Baldwin" inspired by writer James Baldwin. The piece, A Biography of Baldwin, is inspired by the writer James Baldwin and will involve a collaboration with the media designer Austin Forbord.

To support Open Dance Studio, a component of the Bay Area Celebrates National Dance Week. The main program of this event is Open Dance Studios, which allows dance artists and organizations to highlight their programming in their own neighborhoods.

Purpose: To support an online publication series in "Places Journal" about the built environment of the U.S. highway system. Additional Project Description: The series will consist of as many as four articles drawing from new scholarly research exploring how the highway system might be newly understood and creatively adapted or redesigned. The editors will commission emerging and established public scholars, drawing from the fields of history, geography, architecture, landscape architecture, and urban planning. Each article will be accompanied by illustrations that include both commissioned photography and archival images, and will be supported by related public programming and a communications campaign. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit readers of "Places Journal," which include design field scholars and practitioners, as well as general audiences. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.
To support the 2006 San Francisco World Music Festival. Presentations will take place in various San Francisco venues and will showcase international music artists and performers from the Bay Area.

To support the creation of "Prince Lanling," a new dance theater performance work in consortium with Gamelan Sekar Jaya. The work will integrate Chinese, Balinese, and Western dance music and text with projections to create a new interpretation of a Chinese folk tale.

Organization Name: D-Rev: Design for the Other Ninety Percent
Project Description: To support staff time and travel related to the refinement of the functionality and design of the ReMotion Knee. An affordable, high-performance prosthetic knee joint, the ReMotion Knee uses a polycentric mechanism that mimics natural knee movement, enabling low-income above-knee amputees to return to work, school, and daily activities. Through its blog and website, D-Rev will continue to share industrial design lessons learned in the process of iterating the ReMotion Knee, and will collect feedback from users.

Organization Name: D-Rev: Design for the Other Ninety Percent
Project Description: To support design refinements for Comet, a phototherapy device designed to treat severe neonatal jaundice in unserved markets. Comet designers and engineers will work with partnering organizations in India and Nepal to reduce the device's size in order to make it more affordable and accessible to clinics and microhospitals in less industrialized economies.

Organization Name: D-Rev: Design for the Other Ninety Percent
Project Description: To support the development of an interactive online platform for product designers working on social impact projects. An online platform will enable designers from multiple locations to receive real-time user feedback on the effectiveness of their designed products and to collaborate on new design iterations for products that serve the world's most underserved populations.

To support a playwriting program for youth. Designed to serve incarcerated San Francisco and San Mateo County teenagers, the playwriting and educational tutoring program will pair professional theater artists with youths to create and develop original, one-act plays. Playwriting instructors and theater artist mentors will teach young writers the fundamentals of playwriting through lectures, group discussions, and seminars. The program will culminate in staged readings of the work that will be performed by professional actors for participants, parents, teachers, and peers.

To support the Playwriting Workshops. The program will provide arts education services to incarcerated teenagers. Each workshop cycle will provide as many as ten, three-hour sessions to detainees who will be mentored one-on-one to create and develop one-act plays. Workshops will take place inside San Francisco's Juvenile Justice Center, the Success Center of the San Francisco Youth Summer Program, the San Mateo County Youth Services Center, and Camp Kemp for Girls. Participants will explore conflict through dialogue, create characters, and how to write a dramatic climax and resolution. Each workshop will culminate with the reading of participants' plays by professional actors before an audience of parents, peers, teachers, probation officers, and invited members of the public.

To support the Playwriting Workshop. Intended to serve incarcerated San Francisco and San Mateo County teenagers, the playwriting and educational tutoring program will pair professional theater artists with youths for one-on-one mentoring to create and develop original, one-act plays. The plays will be performed by professional actors at staged readings for the participants' parents, teachers, peers, probation officers, and invited members of the public.

To support the Playwriting Workshop. Designed for incarcerated San Francisco and San Mateo County teenagers, the playwriting and educational tutoring program will pair professional theater artists with youths to create and develop original, one-act plays, which will be performed by professional actors at staged readings for participants' parents, teachers, and peers.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Playwriting Workshop. Designed for incarcerated San Francisco and San Mateo County teenagers, the playwriting and educational tutoring program will pair professional theater artists one-on-one with youths to create and develop original, one-act plays, which will be performed by professional actors at staged readings for participants' parents, teachers, and peers.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Playwriting Workshop. Designed for incarcerated San Francisco and San Mateo County teenagers, the playwriting and educational tutoring program will pair professional theater artists one-on-one with youths to create and develop original, one-act plays.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Playwriting Workshop program. Designed for incarcerated San Francisco and San Mateo County teenagers, the playwriting and educational tutoring program will pair professional theater artists one-on-one with youths to create and develop original, one-act plays.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Playwriting Workshop. Designed for incarcerated San Francisco and San Mateo County teenagers, the playwriting and educational tutoring program will pair professional theater artists one-on-one with youths to create and develop original, one-act plays.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Playwriting Workshop. Designed for incarcerated San Francisco and San Mateo County teenagers, the playwriting and educational tutoring program will pair professional theater artists one-on-one with youths to create and develop original, one-act plays.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support A Dream and a Plan for Tomorrow (ADAPT), a playwriting workshop and educational tutoring program. Designed for incarcerated San Mateo County teenagers, the project will involve professional theater artists working one-on-one with youths to create and develop original, one-act plays.

To support A Dream And A Plan For Tomorrow, a playwriting workshop and educational tutoring program. Designed for incarcerated San Mateo County teenagers, the project will involve professional theater artists working one-on-one with youths to create and develop original, one-act plays.

To support educational activities for youth in consortium with the San Francisco Community Music Center. Ensemble musicians will work with students at the music center and in San Francisco public schools providing individual instruction, group lessons, workshops, and free tickets to performances.
To support new music concerts. Two concerts are planned featuring music of composers Elliott Carter and Olivier Messiaen (1908-92), in celebration of each composer's 100th birthday.

To support concerts featuring works of composer Peter Maxwell Davies. The British composer's works will be programmed in context with other works by a diverse group of local and international composers.

To support a workshop of a new opera score, "Every Man Jack," by composer Libby Larsen and librettist Philip Littell in consortium with the Sonoma City Opera. The workshop will help the composer determine how the production elements will work together.

To support contemporary, classical chamber music concerts. Four concerts by the Earplay ensemble will take place in the winter of 2000 and spring of 2001 at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.

To support concerts of contemporary chamber music. Performances by Earplay, a contemporary music ensemble, will take place at the Yuerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco and center around the theme of the ende of the millennium by pairing 20th century classics with new pieces by some of the coming century's talented young composers.

To support the 2001 International Film Financing Conference. This annual event was established to encourage and increase collaborations between American producers and international film production entities.

To support the 2000 International Film Financing Conference. This annual event was established to encourage and increase collaborations between American producers and international film production entities.

To support the 1999 International Film Financing Conference. This annual event was established to encourage and increase collaborations between American producers and international film production entities.

To support the 1998 International Film Financing Conference, an annual event established to encourage and increase collaborations between American independent producers and international film production entities. Begun in 1994, the International Film Financing Conference (IFFCON) prepares independents to participate more knowledgeably in an international media community by beginning to close the information gap between U.S. producers and foreign producers and buyers. Each year 60 producers spend two days in an intensive workshop setting. There are panels on everything from the legal implications of international financing to specific case studies, round- table discussions, private one-on-one meetings with producers and financiers, and informal social events. Panelists are selected based on their interest and ability to finance and/or acquire independent U.S. films. Previous panelists have come from Hong Kong (Media Asia), Canada (Fims Transit), Germany (ZDF), Japan (Uplink), etc. Two films which have happened because of IFFCON matchmaking are Some Mother's Son (a U.S./Irish Film Board co-production), and Crumb.

To support the development of a modern secular adaptation of "Las Posadas Mojadas," a seasonal pageant and play about immigrants seeking refuge. The adaptation will be designed as a touring production that will bring theater to underserved audiences in San Francisco and nationwide.

To support the presentation and tour of one play and the development of a new play. The company will tour "Rosita's Day of the Dead," by Artistic Director Rodrigo Duarte Clark, throughout the Southwest.
To support the staging of "La Pastorela Endiablada". El Teatro De La Esperanza has created a secular adaptation of the traditional Mexican shepherds' play.

To support the Tu-Solo-Tu Festival, a performance series of new solo works created and developed by Latino solo artists. Bay Area and nationally selected artists will explore Chicano and Mexican theatrical forms (teatro revista/actos/carpa/corrido), as applied to solo performance and contemporary themes with emphasis on bi-cultural and bilingual.

To support a Southwest tour of "Rosita's Jalapeno Kitchen" and the creation of a modern adaptation of "El Popul Vuh" for the theater's mainstage and future tour. El Teatro de la Esperanza is seeking support for a two-part project during 1998-1999. The proposal is to tour "Rosita's Jalapeno Kitchen" in the Southwest and Midwest of the U.S. and to create a modern adaptation of "El Popul Vuh" for Esperanza's mainstage and a future tour. Both of these plays will fulfill the theater's mission of creating a theatrical aesthetic that is rooted in the culture, language, history, and mythology of the Latino in the U.S. The theater is committed to bringing its original, bi-lingual plays to both rural and urban audiences, with a special emphasis on low-income Latinos, young and old.

To support an art instruction program for residents of Bay Area nursing homes. Building upon nearly 15 years of experience, Eldergivers will hire professional artists with teaching experience to conduct workshops for underserved seniors.

To support expansion of an art instruction program for residents of Bay Area nursing homes. Building upon more than ten years of experience, Eldergivers will hire professional artists with teaching experience to conduct workshops for institutionalized seniors.

To support an art instruction program for Bay Area seniors in nursing homes. Building upon ten years of experience, Eldergivers will hire professional artists with teaching experience to conduct workshops for institutionalized seniors.

Purpose: To support the continued development, presentation, and tour of "Grain of Tooth Inside of Sand (SAND)," a multidisciplinary dance production. Additional Project Description: SAND will premiere at San Francisco's Dance Mission Theater and will deepen engagement with community members through panels, discussion groups, and restorative justice circles. Intended Beneficiaries: The work will benefit participating artists and audiences in the Greater San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.
To support the West Coast premiere of "The Shaker Chair," by resident playwright Adam Bock. The play will be directed by Anne Kauffman.

To support the commission, workshop, and production of a new play by Adam Bock. The work, tentatively titled "Thursday", will make use of an associative narrative structure to explore the question of: How do repeated images create story?

Purpose: To support artist fees for the San Francisco Trolley Dances festival. Additional Project Description: Held in the fall, this annual site-specific, free dance festival features the work of local choreographers along a MUNI/Metro light-rail line. The accompanying educational program Kids on Track provides youth with access to public art and contemporary dance. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit audiences and community members in San Francisco, with a focus on the dance community, residents of SoMa (South of Market) and Chinatown, and MUNI's ridership. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support artist fees for the San Francisco Trolley Dances festival. Held in the fall, annual site-specific, free dance festival features the work of local choreographers along a MUNI/Metro light-rail line. The accompanying educational program Kids on Track (KOT) provides youth with access to public art and contemporary dance.

To support artist fees for the San Francisco Trolley Dances festival. The annual site-specific, free dance festival features the work of local choreographers along a MUNI/Metro light-rail line. The accompanying educational program Kids on Track (KOT) provides youth with access to public art and contemporary dance.

To support artist and company fees for the presentation of San Francisco Trolley Dances. The annual site-specific, free dance festival features the work of local choreographers along a MUNI/Metro light-rail line. The accompanying educational program Kids on Track (KOT) provides youth with access to public art and contemporary dance.

To support San Francisco Trolley Dances in its 15th anniversary year. The Epiphany Dance Theater presents a site-specific, free dance festival featuring the work of local choreographers along a MUNI/Metro light-rail line every year. The educational outreach program Kids on Track (KOT) provides inner-city youth with access to public art and contemporary dance. In the weeks prior to the trolley performance, KOT will offer in-school workshops about site-specific performances at Bay Area schools. Additionally, there will be a special ticketed performance tour in honor of the anniversary.

To support the world premiere of "Last Blue Couch in the Sky" and the 2017 San Francisco Trolley Dances (SFTD). The premiere work is a site-specific outdoor and indoor traveling dance journey. SFTD is an annual site-specific, free dance festival featuring the work of local choreographers along a MUNI/Metro light-rail line. The educational outreach program for SFTD is Kids on Track (KOT), which provides inner-city youth with access to public art and contemporary dance. In the weeks prior to the performance, KOT will offer in-school workshops about site-specific performances at Bay Area schools.

To support the presentation of the San Francisco Trolley dances. This annual site-specific event is presented free to the public alongside the MUNI/Metro light rail line in San Francisco. The 2016 festival will be located along the Market Street Corridor and in the Castro District. The educational component Kids On Track (KOT) will provide inner-city youth with access to public art and contemporary dance. In the weeks prior to the performance, KOT will offer in-school workshops about site-specific performances at Bay Area schools. Students will be invited to attend a special light rail tour of the performances prior to the festival, each of which will conclude with a question-and-answer session with the featured artists.

To support the presentation of the San Francisco Trolley Dances. This annual site-specific event is presented free to the public along the MUNI/Metro light rail line in San Francisco. The public sites where the performances take place are chosen for their historical and/or architectural experience, and MUNI trains and trolleys move the audience to each site. The project also will include the educational component Kids On Track (KOT), which provides inner-city youth with access to public art and contemporary dance. In the weeks prior to the performance, KOT offers in-school workshops on site-specific performances at Bay Area schools. Students are invited to attend a special light rail tour of the performances prior to the festival, each of which concludes with a question-and-answer session with the featured artists.

To support the "San Francisco Trolley Dances." The festival includes presentations of free site-specific contemporary dance performances presented along a different city trolley or San Francisco Municipal Railway (MUNI) route each year.

To support the "San Francisco Trolley Dances" and associated community outreach activities. This festival includes presentations of free site specific contemporary dance performances, presented along a different city trolley or San Francisco Municipal Railway (MUNI) route each year.

To support the creation and presentation of the annual San Francisco Trolley Dances, a series of site-specific dance performances that will take place along one of San Francisco's trolley lines, free of charge. For two weekends, volunteers will guide audiences from site to site via trolley and on foot.

To support the creation and presentation of site-specific dances along one of San Francisco's trolley lines in consortium with the Dancers' Group. In partnership with Dancers' Group, a Bay Area dance service organization, the sixth annual San Francisco Trolley Dances will bring together the local dance community and the San Francisco Municipal Railway for two weekends of free performances.

To support the creation and presentation of site-specific dances along one of San Francisco's trolley lines. The fifth annual San Francisco Trolley Dances will bring together the local dance community and the San Francisco Municipal Railway (MUNI) for two weekends of free performances.

To support the presentation of "Uksus" by composer Erling Wold and librettists Yulia Izmaylova and Felix Strasser. Based on a true story, the opera takes place in Leningrad in the 1930s and tells the tale of a literary avant-garde association whose members sought to debunk the Stalinist system. The libretto will be translated into English.

To support the production of the San Francisco Asian American Storyfest. The inaugural Asian storytelling festival will feature guest artists such as Brenda Wong-Aoki, Alton Chung, Arif Choudhury, and Anne Shimojima. Festival activities will include performances and a panel discussion on the power of storytelling and its importance in the building of bridges among the several Asian/Asian-American groups in the Bay Area.

To support TALES of PANGU, a full-length interdisciplinary program featuring the Gay Asian Pacific Alliance Men's Chorus. Woven with music and song from the men's chorus, the work will present ancient Chinese creation myths and detail the stories of Pangu, a central figure in Chinese mythology.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support the creation and presentation of new Asian storytelling pieces as part of an apprentice training program. Using the spoken word, movement, and music, the Eth-Noh-Tec ensemble will create and perform new works for audiences throughout the Bay Area.

To support a Bay Area tour of "Takashi's Dream," an original production dramatizing the life journey of a man who survived the bombing of Hiroshima when he was eight years old. Takashi Tanemori, whose life is the inspiration for the piece, will participate in a post-performance dialogue with artists and audiences after each performance.
To support the 19th annual San Francisco Fringe Festival. The festival provides performance opportunities for emerging artists to perform and develop audiences for their work.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support DIVAfest 2007, the sixth annual theater festival dedicated to producing new plays by women. The festival will feature the world premiere of CRYSTAL DAZE AND MUDDY DEATHS, a new play by Deborah Eubanks, as well as workshops and staged readings of other new plays by women.

To support the fourth annual "DIVAfest," a festival dedicated to fostering new works by women writers. The project includes commissioning, development, and the full production of new works by, for, and about women.

To support the presentation of new works by women writers through DIVAfest 2004. The festival will feature productions of new plays, including BOXCAR BERTHA by Kerry Reid, staged readings of works in progress, and a benefit reading of works by local writers.

Purpose: To support a media arts installation that explores the relationship between humans and the natural world and related programming. Additional Project Description: Using media such as video footage and aerial and satellite imagery, selected works will explore the ways human-centered activities have and continue to alter the earth's environment. The installation will be paired with artist talks and workshops designed for audiences of all ages. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit audiences in San Francisco communities and throughout the Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support a multidisciplinary performance series that showcases shadow as an artistic medium. Theater design, moving image projection, dance, live musical performance, and hand-built sculptural objects may be integrated in presented works. Additionally, artists will conduct workshops to provide audiences with the opportunity to gain deeper insight into the artistic process, learn about the common objects used to create the works, and be inspired to explore artmaking on their own.

To support Artistic Practice towards Urban Resilience (APUR), in partnership with the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering at the University of California, Berkeley. APUR will immerse artists in a multi-scale investigation of transportation systems, community, and governance related to the impacts of climate change in the San Francisco Bay Area. In conjunction with the Resilience of Infrastructure as Seas Rise (RISeR) project--a consortium of academic institutions, research labs, nonprofits, and government entities--APUR will explore how artists approach the problem of sea level rise and its impact on city infrastructure, as well as how artistic conceptualization of climate data can inform, inspire, and empower communities at risk. The project will include a colloquium connecting professional artists directly with scientists to investigate how artistic approaches can further community engagement and learning. Through a collaborative residency, selected artists will develop prototypes of platforms and data presentations to support a public education and resiliency campaign.

To support a series of multidisciplinary works and presentations celebrating the importance of light to the arts. Using items such as emulsion, film, lenses, mirrors, projectors, and screens, artists will create work that illuminates the physics of light that are fundamental to their creative practices.

To support Begin Here. A project featuring artist-led workshops, artists and teaching artists will work with peers to illustrate, examine, and improve lesson plans for arts instruction. Additional project activities will comprise a symposium and a website assisting artists who teach the public.

To support residencies and creation of art works by contemporary artists on Pier 15, the Exploratorium's new home. Works by Nina Katchadourian, Raphael Lozano Hemmer, and The Lucky Dragons will be installed on a 50,000 square foot public promenade over the water.
To support an artist-in-residence program. Participating artist will create new work exploring issues related to audience engagement and interaction via social media and hand-held devices.
To support the New Frontiers project. The project consists of artist research residencies at the Exploratorium's future home.

To support a series of artist residencies with accompanying education programs. The residencies will place an emphasis on the interplay of handcraft and technology in contemporary art and public engagement with the work.
To support a residency program for artists to investigate the nature of place. Artists will be provided with housing, workspace, technical assistance, and a monthly stipend.

To support the residencies of Nigel Heyler and Ali Momeni in the Listening: Making Sense of the Sonic Soup project. The residencies will investigate sound and listening through the creation of new works and site-specific sonic installations that will become part of the museum's permanent collection.

To support artist residencies focused on miniature programmable technologies in sound, film, kinetic sculpture, and activated environments. The artists will develop and present hands-on public art and technology workshops at the Exploratorium and other science centers in the United States.
To support artist residencies and gallery installations. Artists working in sound, electronic music, photography, film, and video will participate in the project.

To support the development of Web-based and wireless arts programming that incorporates the Exploratorium's upcoming new location into site-inspired work. Senior artists at the Exploratorium will collaboarate with technology experts to utilize the impending move to explore and connect with potential patrons, other arts organizations, and historical context in the new neighborhood.
To support the commissioning of works by artists Helen DiMichiel, Walter Kitundu, and Joanna Haigood. The commissioned pieces will be integral to two museum initiatives in science and education.

To support a consortium project for the development of integrated arts learning activities focused on artist James Turrell's monumental art installation in the Arizona Desert's Roden Crater. The interconnections between art and science will be explored through an interactive Web site and related classroom activities.
To support artists' residencies to create installations for the museum's collection of science exhibitions.
To support 2nd Wednesdays. The series pf performances and installations will be presented within a cafe atmosphere and broadcast live over the Internet.

To support the continuing development and presentation of a millennium exhibition to explore the interplay between scientific explorations of the body and images of self. The exhibit will feature new commissioned art, interactive exhibits, imaging technology, performances, films, events, and live webcasts.

To support a residency project in which several artists will create new works as part of a new museum exhibit area called "Seeing." Each of the works will engage visitors in examining the scientific, social, and cultural influences that shape how we see the world.

To support the implementation of a new logo designed to increase public identification with the museum as part of audience development activities. Specific activities will include implementation of a new museum identity through redesign of all museum graphics, a membership study and development of a membership plan, a feasibility study for a major endowment and capital campaign, a board retreat, and use of a term endowment to leverage lead gifts to launch the campaign. These initiatives follow an extensive planning process conducted over the past several years that resulted in a five-year strategic plan in 1996. The museum is an interactive, populist institution whose members comprise families, artists, teachers, and scientists, rather than the higher-level financial memberships found in other types of museums. Increasing the membership base will be critical to providing financial stability for the organization. Consultants will develop a membership plan to identify means of member acquisition, increase member acquisition and renewal rates, and improve member benefits and services. The feasibility study will test the likelihood of raising $35 million in private gifts to renovate the Palace of Fine Arts facility and to augment the current endowment.

Popular Name: aka San Francisco International Arts Festival
Project Description: Purpose: To support the San Francisco International Arts Festival. Additional Project Description: In partnership with San Francisco State University (SFSU), the festival will feature music, dance, theater, and spoken-word performances by a culturally diverse group of artists living in the Bay Area as well as international artists. Festival programming will be aligned with the SFSU academic program, and complementary educational activities will be offered to the campus population and surrounding communities. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival will benefit featured artists as well as San Francisco-area audiences, including the SFSU campus community and residents of the Lake Merced and West Portal districts of San Francisco. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Popular Name: aka San Francisco International Arts Festival
Project Description: To support the San Francisco International Arts Festival. The two-day festival will feature outdoor performances by artists from the Bay Area.

Popular Name: aka San Francisco International Arts Festival
Project Description: To support the artist fees, travel and subsistence as part of San Francisco International Arts Festival. The nearly 3-week festival will feature about 180 performances by artists from the Bay Area and more than a dozen countries. Most artists will engage in residencies that typically includes three or four performances a week, and at least one educational or outreach activity. All artists will be asked to present a master class or lecture that the general public can attend at no cost.

Popular Name: aka San Francisco International Arts Festival
Project Description: To support international artists at the San Francisco International Arts Festival. The festival will feature a variety of performances by artists from the Bay Area and approximately 10 different countries. Artist fees, per diems, hotel costs and legal fees to support international artists performing at the San Francisco Arts Festival.

Popular Name: aka San Francisco International Arts Festival
Project Description: To support the premiere of Devorah Major's "Classic Black" at the San Francisco International Arts Festival. "Classic Black" is based on the lives of African Americans in the Bay Area during the 18th century.

Popular Name: aka San Francisco International Arts Festival
Project Description: To support the San Francisco International Arts Festival. Artists will perform and conduct residency outreach activities during the multidisciplinary festival. Accompanying project activities may include classes, workshops, lectures, and interactive audience discussions.

Popular Name: aka San Francisco International Arts Festival
Project Description: To support the presentation of the Polish theater company Teatr Zar as part of the San Francisco International Arts Festival. Poland's Teatr Zar will present Gospels of Childhood by Polish artistic director Jaroslaw Fret.

Purpose: To support a creative writing fellowship. Additional Project Description: This Fellowship will support activities that contribute to the recipients creative development and artistic growth, including writing, research, and travel. Intended Beneficiaries: This fellowship will benefit the artistic and professional growth of the recipient. It will also benefit readers nationwide. Intended Outcomes: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support the creation and production of Split, by choreographer Charles Slender-White. The work will consider the evolution of the LGBTQ+ identity formation for more than a century. Split will be performed hundreds of times by a rotating cast for small audiences, creating an intimate performance experience.

To support "India  Africa: A Birthday Celebration for John Coltrane," a touring project of the Asian American Orchestra, directed by Dr. Anthony Brown. The twin themes of "India  Africa" reference two seminal extended works composed and recorded by Coltrane which reflect his most profound musical and cultural influences.

To support public art planning and the commissioning of preliminary design concepts for the SOMA Pilipinas Cultural District. The project will focus on cultural planning and public art site analysis led by a team of landscape architects, community planners, artists, and community organizers. The project will also include design charrettes to generate a portfolio of potential projects for the district.The project is primarily a partnership between the Filipino-American Development Foundation (the core sponsor for the SOMA Pilipinas Cultural District) and the San Francisco Arts Commission, supported by numerous community partners. The project's goal is to increase visibility and community pride of long-time residents as well as contribute to the economic vitality in SOMA Pilipinas, which was designated a cultural district in 2016 and is the hub of San Francisco's Filipino-American community.
To support educational programs and related activities.
To support media arts educational programs and facilities access. The project will include programs for youth, emerging, mid-level, and established artists.

To support the production, promotion, and distribution of the pilot episode for a new television series that will explore intersections of contemporary art, science, and philosophy. MEETING OF THE MINDS is planned as a new series of 13-half hours for national broadcast.
To support the production and post-production costs for an experimental film by Ernie Gehr. The New York Project (working title) will capture the sounds and sights of Manhattan.
To support production and post-production costs for an experimental documentary by Lourdes Portillo. The film will investigate Mexican boomtowns and their impact on traditional ways.
To support the Artist Professional Development Initiatve. The project will include programs for youth, emerging, mid-level, and established artists.
To support post-production and related costs for an animated film by Suzan Pitt. "El Doctor" is about a crotchety old doctor who, when visited by Santa Esmeralda, begins to see the world differently.

To support completion costs for a documentary film by Arthur Dong on the history of the Chinese in American feature films. The 90-minute film will be a multi-layered look at American cinematic history from the early 1900s up to the present day through the lens of the Chinese-American experience.
To support the production of a silent experimental film by Nathaniel Dorsky. Dedicated to the spirit of devotional song, the film will explore the external surface of objects.
To support the 9th MadCat Women's International Film Festival and national tour.

To support production and post-production costs for a documentary film by Lynn Hershman. Changing Worlds: Art, Women and Revolution will examine the feminist art movement from 1968 through the present.

To support the production of an experimental film by Jay Rosenblatt. The film will combine interviews, archival footage, live action, music and ambient sounds, and text to examine the various aspects of the act of suicide.

To support the Emerging Filmmaker Initiative. The program will provide media artists with workshops, seminars, classes, facilities access, peer mentorship, and information services to cultivate new voices.
To support research and development and the subsequent production of experimental documentary films by Naomi Uman.

To support a film titled "No Mouse Music! The Story of Chris Strachwitz and Arhoolie Records." The project will explore the vernacular music Strachwitz brought to the attention of middle America via recordings of Cajun, Zydeco, country, blues, klezmer, old-time tunes, and Tex-Mex.

To support production and post-production costs for a television documentary by Ruby Yang. A Moment in Time will be a history of Chinese Americans through their movie-going experiences in American Chinatowns.

To support educational and exhibition activities. Designed to assist media artists from beginner to advanced, the program will offer special workshops and seminars as well as enhanced exhibition opportunities.
To support production and post-production costs for a documentary video by Les Blank. Butch Anthony is about the life and work of the self-taught artist from Alabama.
To support the Ninth Street Media Arts Consortium. Four media arts organizations, housed in the same building, will share resources, staff, and facilities that serve artists and audiences.
To support the eighth MadCat Women's International Film Festival. Films will be presented to an audience in California.
To support the production costs for an experimental documentary by Elizabeth Thompson.

To support the Ninth Street Media Arts Consortium, a project in which four media arts organizations, all housed in the same building, will share resources, staff, and facilities that serve media artists and audiences.
To support post-production costs for a one-hour documentary by Victoria Funari. Maquilopolis will profile women workers in Tijuana's assembly factories.
To support the post-production costs for a documentary by Les Blank. White Feathers, Black Bones is about the life and vision of David Hoffman, an American tea importer.
To support the Masters Project. Designed to assist mid-career media artists, the program will offer special workshops and seminars as well exhibition opportunities.
To support the production of a narrative animated film by Suzan Pitt. "El Doctor" is the story of a very old doctor whose views are transformed when a a fictional saint visits him.

To support production and post-production costs for a one-hour film by Erin Sax and Caitlin Manning. The Prison Show is about a 20-year old call in radio program that reaches inmates in Texas prisons and the community that has formed around the show.

To support the post-production costs for an experimental documentary film by Naomi Uman. Mala Leche will examine the life of an immigrant family living in the small agricultural town of Pixley, California.

To support production and post-production costs for a documentary on composer Lou Harrison. LOU HARRISON: A WORLD OF MUSIC will be a feature-length film that will examine Lou Harrison's personal and professional life.
To support post-production costs for a documentary program by John Hewitt. Smokestack Lightnin' tells the story of the blues artist Chester Arthur Burnett, also known as Howlin' Wolf.
To support the production of an experimental documentary film by Jay Rosenblatt. Phantom Limb will be about loss and grief.

To support the Ninth Street Media Arts consortium, a project in which four media arts organizations, all housed in the same building, will share resources, staff, and facilities. Already viewed as a national model of partnership, the consortium will formalize its processes to include joint decision-making, governance, and program delivery.
To support the production of an experimental silent film by Nathaniel Dorsky. This new work will explore the meaning of devotion.
To support the Artist to Artist project. This mentorship program will encourage emerging and mid-career artists to connect with more established media makers to further develop their skills.

To support continuing production costs for a documentary film by Roko Belic, Jaszmine Dellal, and Adrian Belic. FREEDOM WRITERS is a story about a low-income high school English class and its extraordinary teacher.

To support the community distribution strategy for the documentary "Downside UP." The documentary relates the conversion of a New England industrial mill into MASS MoCA, America's largest contemporary art museum.

To support production and post-production costs for a documentary tracing the history and impact of the Ballets Russes companies and dancers. "Ballets Russes: A Living Legacy" will cover the eighty-year+ story of the blend of Russian, American, Canadian, Cuban, and Latin American dancers and their impact on the dance, theater, and film communities during the 20th century.

To support Direct the Future, an initiative that will provide filmmakers with equipment and access to create new work. Film Arts Foundation has, for 24 years, offered media makers traditional 16mm film production tools.

To support a consortium project in which five media arts organizations, all housed in the same building, will share resources, staff, and facilities. The Ninth Street Media Arts consortium, already viewed as a national model of partnership, will formalize its processes to include joint decision-making, governance, and program delivery.

To support the post-production, premiere, and distribution of an experimental documentary film by Lourdes Portillo. "Senorita Extraviada" will explore the untold story of the continuing serial murders of young women in the U.S.-Mexican border town of Juarez.
To support the production of an experimental documentary film by Ellen Bruno. LEPER Will be a meditation on the impermanence of life.
To support post-production and distribution costs for a documentary film on Wilma Elizabeth McDaniel. This project will profile an artist representing the Okies.

To support research, development, and production for a multi-part television series on the roles, impact, and the depiction of Chinese in the American motion picture industry. Directed by Arthur Dong, THE CHINESE IN HOLLYWOOD PROJECT will bring to light the contributions that Chinese have made both in front of and behind the camera.

To support a consortium project wherein several film/video exhibitors will create an innovative partnership to support their festivals' publicity. The "Festival Swing Shift" is designed to help the organizations make more effective use of their limited resources, reduce duplication of efforts, and strengthen the community impact of their public presentations.

To support the production of an experimental narrative film by Trinh Minh-ha. Night Passage will tell the story of three characters traveling on a bus while each at the same time is experiencing a spiritual journey as well.

To support the post-production costs for a documentary portrait of Harry Hay by Eric Slade and Jack Walsh. Using archival footage, interviews, and photographs, this documentary will chronicle Mr. Hay's life.
To support presentation services for media artists. This includes the annual Film Arts Festival of Independent Cinema; the curated programs "Short Circuit Film" and "True Stories"; and its Web site.

To support production of "Sing It, Tell It," a three-part public television series documenting the historical and living heritage of African-American music. The series will examine the contributions of African-American music from the 1880s through World War II and the civil rights era, to the present.

To support post-production costs for a television documentary by Ruby Yang on young residents of Hong Kong. Intended for national broadcast on PBS, the documentary will chronicle one year in the lives of these young people during Hong Kong's transition from British to Chinese sovereignty.

To support post-production costs for a documentary video by Lourdes Portillo on the slain singer Selena Quintanilla. Planned for festival showings and broadcast on public television, the film's focus will be on Selena's influence in the Latino community.

To support "Providing the Tools," a new initiative to help media artists produce, exhibit, and distribute their work. This includes a targeted expansion of Film Arts Foundation's (FAF) classes, monthly publication, web site, facilities offerings, and marketing its exhibition program.
To support the research and development costs for a publication on the history of Canyon Cinema.

To support the production and post-production of a documentary film on the gospel singer Marion Williams, that will be made available for national distribution. "Packin' Up: Marion Williams  the Philadelphia Gospel Women" will be a one-hour documentary portrait of one of America's greatest singers and the important influences that her hometown of Philadelphia had in the early development of black gospel music. One of the major female gospel singers of the post-World War II era, Marion Williams was the lead vocalist for the Ward Singers greatest hits including "Surely God is Able" and "Packin' Up." She established her own group, the Stars of Faith, 1958. Her style inspired countless gospel singers as well as pop singers like Little Richard and the Isley Brothers. Her role in the Broadway production of "Black Nativity" (script by Langston Hughes) brought national and international attention to the gospel field in the 1960s. In 1965, she pursued a solo career, singing in Europe, Africa, and the Middle East. In 1992, Ms. Williams was honored for her life's work at the Kennedy Center. At the time of her death in 1994, Ms. Williams was recognized as one of the 20th century's most prominent vocalists, joining the ranks of Mahalia Jackson, Bessie Smith, and Billie Holliday.

To support the post-production costs for a documentary video by Veronica Selver on KPFA-FM, the flagship station of the Pacifica Network, intended for national distribution and broadcast. "KPFA On-The-Air" will follow the station's evolution. Its story will be told by current and former programmers and listeners, artists, musicians, community activists, poets, and media critics. Archival footage will provide historical context. As this country's first community radio station and oldest listener sponsored station, KPFA, based in Berkeley, California, has contributed to the political and cultural trends within and far beyond the Bay Area. KPFA was prescient with its in-depth coverage of the 1950s anti-nuclear activists and the early Civil Rights Movement, as well as the Free Speech and Anti-War movements. On the cultural front, the station first offered a forum to Beat poets and many new music composers, and has devoted daylong programming to Joyce's "Ulysses," the Grateful Dead, and to award-winning radio drama.

To support the production of a one-hour documentary by Anne Makepeace, examining the life and work of the photographer Edward S. Curtis from the perspective of his Indian subjects and their descendants, intended for national broadcast on PBS. Between 1900 and 1930 Edward S. Curtis photographed and recorded more than eighty American Indian tribes--from Mexico to the Arctic, from the Rockies to the Pacific--creating an astonishing body of work: forty thousand photographs, the first full length ethnographic motion picture, ten thousand wax cylinder recordings, twenty volumes of ethnographic text with accompanying portfolios, and several books of Indian stories. By the beginning of the 20th century, the American Indian population had been reduced to five per cent of their pre-contact numbers. Curtis and his contemporaries had good reason to fear that all Indian cultures would vanish. Often accused of romanticizing his subjects, he wanted to show the beauty of Indian life and framed out the poverty and signs of acculturation on the reservations. He frequently showed people in traditional or ceremonial dress, engaging in activities that in some cases hadn't been practiced in many years. The film will address Curtis' framing out of the realities of his subjects' lives, his use of the romantic, pictorialist style, and his sometimes dubious methods of getting photographs

To support a planning and stabilization project whereby the organization will evaluate its programs and possibly expand or change some of the services it offers. Film Arts Foundation (FAF) provides more than 3,500 film and video artists a year with a comprehensive range of services: classes, facilities access, exhibition opportunities and fiscal sponsorship. Because the tools of filmmaking evolve practically on a daily basis, FAF needs to take a careful look at its production and editing equipment. The days when 16mm cameras and a steenbeck were all that a filmmaker needed are over. What do artists need now? Who else is providing equipment access and what tools do they have? Should FAF expand its facilities program to meet the needs of its constituency, or does it need to? FAF's exhibition program centers around an annual film festival devoted to Bay Area Artists, with other screenings offered monthly. To increase audiences and earned income, FAF needs to develop marketing strategies and target potential filmgoers. FAF's education and training programs could also generate more income. FAF would like to study the feasibility of restructuring its classes and workshops to a) either offer a "Filmmaker Certificate" to those who complete a series of seminars, or

To support the completion costs for "Through Yup'ik Eyes," a television documentary about the lifeways of the Yup'ik Eskimo people of southwest Alaska, as interpreted by the storyteller and commentator John Active of Bethel, Alaska. The film is intended to provide the American public with an understanding of the values of a culture that is little-known beyond the state of Alaska. As a traditional storyteller and NPR commentator, Mr. Active possesses a unique ability to articulate the differences between the Native and non-Native worlds. He brings his extraordinary sense of humor to stories that reveal different aspects of Yup'ik life, many of them centered around the traditional subsistence lifestyle of his people (e.g. seal hunting and berry-picking) which embody a value system that has enabled their cutlure to persevere. "Through Yup'ik Eyes" will be distributed to Native villages throughout Alaska, to PBS stations, and to secondary schools and colleges. Producer/Director: James S. Culp. Yup'ik Cultural Expert: Mary Stachelrodt. Oral Historian: William Schneider.

Purpose: To support For Us, By Us, an incubator program for documentary filmmakers based in the Bay Area. Additional Project Description: In partnership with Re-Present Media, the program will provide emerging and mid-career filmmakers access to workshops, networking opportunities, and mentorship from industry professionals to bring projects to completion. Intended to nurture career paths for a diverse cohort of Bay Area documentary filmmakers, participants will be selected through an open call process with a special emphasis on underrepresented voices who are centering personal stories from within their communities. Intended Beneficiaries: This project will benefit participating filmmakers from the Bay Area, as well as program mentors and industry partner organizations. Intended Outcome: Arts leaders develop professional skills and strategies.

To support the production costs of Fiddles on Fire, a documentary film featuring virtuoso fiddlers who have shaped their traditions. Two additional fiddlers will be documented and the film will undergo post-production activities, such as editing, mixing, and color correction. The completed film will be readied for distribution. Once it has been completed, the film will be distributed through theatrical and broadcast suppliers, educational organizations, and the Internet.

To support post-production and completion costs for a documentary about pioneering filmmaker Ricky Leacock to be directed by Gina Leibrecht. The recently deceased Ricky Leacock, (a protege of Robert Flaherty) along with D.A. Pennebaker and the Maysles brothers, Albert and David, are credited with the cinema verite movement of the 1960s and were responsible for such films as "Primary" and "Crisis."

To support artist fees for the development and world premiere of a new, multidisciplinary theatrical work by Brenda Wong Aoki in collaboration with Mark Izu. Inspired by the writers' family legacies, the project will incorporate true stories from the community spanning more than a century of San Francisco history. Performances will incorporate text, film, dance, and live music.
To support the tour of "Kuan-Yin: Our Lady of Compassion." The multidisciplinary performance work will travel to venues in the U.S. and include educational outreach activities.
To support the documentation of a performance of "Sun Cycles" for archival purposes. The performance will offer a contemporary interpretation of a creation myth using the Japanese art form, Gagaku.

To support phase two of KUAN YIN: OUR LADY OF COMPASSION. This work combines spoken word, jazz, solo performance, and multimedia production with Japanese gagaku, noh theater, and other Asian performing arts traditions.

To support the creation and presentation of SUN CYCLES: THE JOURNEY OF 1000 YEARS. The interdisciplinary concert will combine American jazz, spoken word, Japanese Gagaku and Bagaku music and dance, and Noh theater.

Purpose: To support the development and premiere of "If I Give You My Sorrows," an evening-length, apparatus-based dance work and an accompanying art exhibition. Additional Project Description: The new work continues exploring themes from "The Decarceration Trilogy," a series of dance works made by community members and artists affected by the prison system, including Artistic Director Jo Kreiter. The art exhibition will feature works by incarcerated women artists, organized by Rahsaan Thomas and formerly incarcerated activist Betty McKay, accompanied by a series of public talks modeled on the restorative justice process. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit general audiences in the San Francisco Bay Area, with a focus on artists and community members affected by the prison system. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the creation and production of a new work by choreographer Jo Kreiter. Additional Project Description: The aerial dance work will explore themes of sexual violence, survivor advocacy, incarceration, and transformative justice. The piece will premiere at Zaccho Studio and will include time for dialogue and processing of the topic with social service organizations Community Works, Prison Renaissance, and restorative justice experts. Intended Beneficiaries: This project will benefit the artists involved and audience members and participants who identify as survivors, those who have caused harm, as well as prison impacted communities. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support the creation and production of The Apparatus of Repair by choreographer Jo Kreiter. The work is a public art performance featuring aerial dance that brings focus to the concept of restorative justice, a process and belief that the path to justice lies in problem-solving and healing rather than punitive isolation.

To support performances of Meet Us Quickly With Your Mercy by choreographer Jo Kreiter. The work is a public art performance featuring aerial dance that brings together Black, Jewish, and female histories on the topic of incarceration and secondary incarceration experienced by loved ones. The piece aims to create opportunity for reconciliation between people who have experience with incarceration.

To support the creation of sets and costumes for The Wait Room, by Artistic Director Jo Kreiter. The new work incorporates dance, music, and oral history interviews with women whose families are fractured by incarceration. The Essie Justice Group will help support the interviews which will frame the conceptual arc of the piece, and composer Pamela Z will use the oral histories as a sonic language to inform the creation of the work.

To support the creation and presentation of "Tender," an aerial dance work. The project is a large scale public art performance that will take place in the Tenderloin neighborhood of San Francisco, off the ground on the exterior walls of the Cadillac Hotel. Flyaway Productions will collaborate with Vietnamese composer Van-Anh Vo, the Tenderloin Museum, Code Tenderloin, and the Asian Art Museum.

To support the creation and presentation of "The Right to be Believed." The site-specific performance will bring awareness through aerial dance and dialogue to a serious sociopolitical issue: a lack of credibility for women. Collaborators will include photojournalist Lynn Johnson and hip-hop composer MADLINES. Free performances will premiere in San Francisco's Tenderloin neighborhood at the University of California's Hastings Law School.

To support the creation and presentation of a site-specific aerial work by choreographer Jo Kreiter. Along These Lines will illuminate the issue of wage insecurity among female garment workers. The project will take place in San Francisco's Tenderloin neighborhood, in and above Continuum Alley, bordered by a labor hall, a tech company, and an active sweat shop. Collaborators on the project include composer Rupa Marya and designer Sean Riley. Outreach activities such as curbside conversations will occur as the project is being created. Yerba Buena Center for the Arts will present free performances of the site-specific work.

To support the creation and presentation of a site-specific work, "Multiple Mary and Invisible Jane," choreographed by Jo Kreiter. A collaboration with journalist Rose Aguilar and composer Pamela Z, the work will be created on the west wall of the Warfield Theater. The project will focus on older homeless women in San Francisco (about whom Aguilar wrote an article for "The Nation"), and their stories will be included as part of the project.

To support the creation of "Wall Ball," a new site-specific dance that celebrates the continuum between art and sport. The work will be created by artistic director Jo Kreiter and composer Beth Custer by conducting interviews with students, families, and staff from Sunnyside Elementary to get their perspectives on movement in daily life, which will inform the sound score and aerial movement.

To support the creation and presentation of a site specific collaborative work, Singing Praises: Centennial Dance for Women's Building, by choreographer Jo Kreiter. Collaborators will include composer Jewlia Eisenberg and lighting designer Elaine Buckholtz.

To support the creation and presentation of an evening-length dance called "The Ballad of Polly Ann," choreographed by artistic director Jo Kreiter. The dance and soundscape are inspired by the folksong lyrics of "The Legend of John Henry's Hammer."

Purpose: To support the publication and promotion of the literary journal Foglifter. Additional Project Description: With a focus on showcasing a wide range of contemporary LGBTQ+ writing, the journal will feature emerging writers alongside established authors. Intended Beneficiaries: The journal will benefit readers nationwide. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the publication and promotion of the literary journal Foglifter. Additional Project Description: With a focus on showcasing a wide range of contemporary LGBTQ+ writing, the journal features emerging writers alongside those who are well-known. Intended Beneficiaries: The journal will benefit readers nationwide. Intended Outcomes: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support an online convening for ensemble theater practitioners. The convening will feature workshops, artist performances, and panels around the themes of arts equity and new models of performance. In collaboration with the Literary Managers and Dramaturgs of America, dramaturgs will be paired with artists for a small-scope project and create a graphic deliverable for audience education, engagement, and discussion.

To support the 2018 FURY Factory Festival of Ensemble and Devised Theater. The biennial festival will bring innovative, cutting-edge work to Bay Area audiences and offer participating artists opportunities for artistic exchange and cross-pollination through performances, structured conversations, panels, and educational workshops. FURY Factory strives to fill a critical niche in the cultural ecosystem of the Bay Area, emphasizing works in progress and serving as a West Coast hub for the national ensemble theater movement. Audiences and presenters will be able to see artists whose work has outgrown the Fringe Festival, but who are not yet well known enough to appear at major presenting houses.

To support the FURY Factory Festival of Ensemble Theater. The biennial festival will bring innovative, cutting-edge work to Bay Area audiences and offer participating artists opportunities for artistic exchange and cross-pollination through performances, structured conversations, panels, and educational workshops. FURY Factory strives to fill a critical niche in the cultural ecosystem of the Bay Area. The festival emphasizes works in progress and serves as a West Coast hub for the national ensemble theater movement. Audiences and presenters will be able to see artists whose work has outgrown the Fringe Festival but who are not yet well known enough to appear at major presenting houses.

To support the FURY Factory, a festival of ensemble theater. The festival will bring innovative, cutting-edge work to Bay Area audiences and will offer opportunities for artistic exchange through performances, structured conversations, panels, and educational workshops. Since its inception in 2005, the FURY Factory has grown into a vibrant gathering of theater artists on the West Coast and has presented works by more than 75 ensembles from around globe.
