To support the FURY Factory Festival of Ensemble Theater. The biennial festival features performances of collaboratively-created works by ensemble companies, as well as public workshops, panel discussions, and opportunities for artists and audiences to interact.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support the creation of a ensemble theater piece in collaboration with playwright Sheila Callaghan and the Playwrights Foundation. Set within the opulent confines of a cruise ship, "Floating Uneasy" will explore the fine line between decadence and luxury in contemporary American culture.

Popular Name: aka Fort Mason Center for Arts & Culture
Project Description: To support the exhibition "Missing" by French conceptual artist Sophie Calle (b. 1953). The presentation will include selections of the artist's work exploring the fundamental concepts of the human condition, compassion, and memory through photography, sculpture, film, video, and site-specific installation. Deeply personal and honest, each of the works included will highlight concepts of loss and recovery and the artist's relationship to self and her environment. A discussion with the artist and curator Evelyn Jouanno will accompany the exhibition.

Purpose: To support the San Francisco International LGBTQ+ Film Festival, a free curated film series, and related activities. Additional Project Description: Feature-length and short films representing voices from the LGBTQ+ community will be screened throughout the festival, accompanied by discussion panels and question-and-answer sessions with filmmakers. The curated series will present public screenings throughout the Bay Area, followed by discussions with filmmakers, artists, critics, authors, educators, and community leaders. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve audiences in the San Francisco Bay Area, with a focus on the LGBTQ+ community, as well as participating artists, organizational partners, and venues. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support Frameline Voices, a free online platform for independent film. Additional Project Description: Frameline Voices will increase the visibility of diverse LGBTQ+ stories and provide greater access for global audiences to view films with narratives that are often underrepresented in mainstream media and unavailable for distribution. Intended Beneficiaries: Short films and episodic content will serve general audiences worldwide through virtual platforms, with a focus on the LGBTQ+ community. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the annual San Francisco International LGBTQ+ Film Festival and Frameline Encore, a free year-round film exhibition program. Feature-length and short films representing voices from the LGBTQ+ community will be screened throughout the festival, accompanied by discussion panels and question-and-answer sessions with filmmakers. In addition, the Frameline Encore series will present free public screenings throughout the Bay Area, followed by discussions with filmmakers, artists, critics, authors, educators, and community leaders. Programs will be presented virtually or at outdoor venues.

To support Frameline Voices, a free online platform for independent film. Frameline Voices will increase the visibility of diverse LGBTQ+ stories, and provide greater access for global audiences to view films with narratives that are often underrepresented in mainstream media and unavailable for distribution.

To support the annual San Francisco International LGBTQ+ Film Festival and Frameline Encore, a free year-round film exhibition program. Feature-length and short films representing voices from the LGBTQ+ community will be screened throughout the festival, accompanied by discussion panels and question-and-answer sessions with filmmakers. In addition, the Frameline Encore series will present free public screenings, followed by discussions with filmmakers, artists, critics, authors, educators, and community leaders. Some project activity will take place virtually.

To support filmmaker stipends, digital licensing fees, staff salaries, and associated costs for Frameline Voices, a free online platform for independent film. Frameline Voices will increase the visibility of diverse LGBTQ stories, and provide greater access for global audiences to view films with narratives that are often underrepresented in mainstream media and unavailable for distribution.

To support the 43rd San Francisco International LGBTQ Film Festival and Frameline Encore, a free year-round film exhibition program. Feature-length and short films representing voices from the LGBTQ community will be screened throughout the festival, accompanied by discussion panels and question-and-answer sessions with filmmakers. In addition, the Frameline Encore series will present free public screenings at venues throughout the Bay Area, followed by discussions with filmmakers, artists, critics, authors, educators, and community leaders.

To support filmmaker stipends, digital licensing fees, and associated costs for Frameline Voices, a free online platform for independent film. Frameline Voices will increase the visibility of diverse LGBTQ stories, and provide greater access for global audiences to view narratives that are often underrepresented in mainstream media and unavailable for distribution.

To support the 42nd San Francisco International LGBTQ Film Festival and Frameline Encore, a free year-round film exhibition program. Feature-length and short films representing the LGBTQ community will be screened throughout the festival, accompanied by industry forums, discussion panels, and question-and-answer sessions with filmmakers. In addition, the Frameline Encore series will present free public screenings at venues throughout the Bay Area, followed by discussions with filmmakers, artists, critics, authors, educators, and community members.

To support the presentation and expansion of Frameline Encore, a year-round film exhibition program. Feature-length and short films representing the LGBTQ community will be screened at each venue, followed by discussions with filmmakers, artists, critics, authors, educators, and community activists. In 2017, Frameline will continue its expansion to include Santa Clara, San Jose, and surrounding areas in the South Bay. All screenings are free and open to the public.

To support the presentation and expansion of Frameline Encore, a year-round film exhibition program. All screenings are free. This year, the screening series will include continued expansion to locations in Oakland, Berkeley, and surrounding areas in the East Bay. Feature-length and short film programs representing the LGBTQ community will be shown at each venue.

To support the presentation and expansion of "Frameline Encore," a film exhibition program. All screenings are free, and this year the program will expand to Oakland. Feature-length and/or short film programs representing the LGBT community will be shown at each venue.
To support a curated film series. To be presented during the San Francisco International LBGT Film Festival, the series will focus on early films of the New Queer Cinema Movement.
To support a retrospective of films by Andy Warhol. Warhol's better known works (Chelsea Girls, Sleep) will be exhibited alongside his less often seen films.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support a seminar series. The program will include panel discussions and interviews with film historians and artists, interspersed with film clips and culminating in question-and-answer sessions with audiences.
To support "Persistent Vision" a conference that will concentrate on strategies relating to exhibition, distribution, and support for filmmakers.
To support a curated film/video series, Open Screen. Open Screen will present short and feature-length work of all genres to an estimated audience of 2,000 people.
To support the presentation of a lecture series. Close-Up: Visionaries of Modern Cinema will feature the works of film professionals whose work has influenced lesbian and gay media over the years.

To support the presentation of a film series. Modern Masters of Lesbian and Gay Cinema will feature the works of filmmakers whose work has influenced lesbian and gay media for the past quarter-century.

To support the conference Persistent Vision. A series of panel discussions, round tables, keynote addresses, and public engagements will discuss and explore issues surrounding the past, present, and future of lesbian and gay film.
To support the planning of a conference. Entitled "Persistence of Vision," this event will address a variety of issues relevant to the past, present, and future of gay/lesbian film and video art.

To support production and editing of a multidisciplinary film and live performance work. Filmmakers Sam Green and Joe Bini will weave together a series of thirty-two vignettes exploring the universal influence of sound.

To support the creation and presentation of a multidisciplinary film and live performance work. Filmmaker Sam Green will collaborate with the Kronos Quartet to create a documentary film exploring the ensemble's 40-year history. Green will weave together interviews with the quartet and longtime collaborators, as well as archival footage and photos, to create the film. Presentations of the film will feature live narration by Green on-stage while Kronos performs the score. Green and Kronos will work with presenting partners to develop educational and outreach activities.

To support the creation and presentation of "The Measure of All Things," a multidisciplinary, live-cinema performance work by filmmaker Sam Green. Inspired by the "Guinness Book of World Records," the project will combine film, live music, and in-person narration to weave together a series of portraits of record-holding people, places, and things.

To support production and post production costs for "The Imagination of Jeremy Blake," an experimental non-fiction film about the young New York artist. Blake's "time-based paintings" that combine handmade art, photographs, film clips, sound effects, and pop imagery brought him fame in the late 1990s.

To support production and post-production costs for an experimental documentary film titled "Fog City" by Sam Green. Fog City will be a documentary about weather and landscape and will include a collage of moving images that illuminates and explores fog in the urban environment.
To support production and post-production costs for an experimental documentary by Samuel Green. The Universal Language will examine the rise and fall of Esperanto, an artificial language.

Purpose: To support a tour of Sean Dorsey Dance's work, The Lost Art of Dreaming, and related community engagement activities. Additional Project Description: The work imagines transgender and queer futures through contemporary dance, grand-scale costuming that will double as set and visual elements, and highly physical theater. Dorsey will host free community engagement activities such as trans-supportive writing and movement workshops. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit audiences in touring locations such as Maui, Hawaii; Seattle, Washington; Washington, D.C.; and Reston, Virginia. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organizations constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support the development and premiere of Sean Dorsey Dance's new work The Lost Art of Dreaming and related community engagement activities. The work will imagine transgender and queer futures through contemporary dance, grand-scale costuming that will double as set and visual elements, and highly physical theater. Dorsey will develop themes for the work in free community engagement activities such as online trans-supportive dance classes and participatory Dream Labs.

To support the research and creation phase of Sean Dorsey Dances new work The Lost Art of Dreaming. The work will imagine trans/gender-nonconforming/queer futures, challenging longtime fatalistic American rhetoric and constructs that deny these communities the space to dream about their own futures. During the research and creation phase, the company will conduct movement research and create films of works in progress.

To support a national tour of BOYS IN TROUBLE by choreographer Sean Dorsey and associated engagement activities. The work is about navigating masculinity and gender in contemporary America. Week-long community performance residencies will take place in five cities across the United States.

To support community forums, workshops, classes, and question-and-answer sessions during a national tour of BOYS IN TROUBLE by choreographer Sean Dorsey. The work is about navigating masculinity and gender in contemporary America. Week-long community residencies will take place in five cities across the United States as well as at various communities in the host city, including local youth, transgender, and LGBT communities. Residency activities include movement and writing workshops, inter-generational community forums and panels, master classes, and post-performance discussions.

To support the national tour of "The Missing Generation," an evening-length production by choreographer Sean Dorsey. The work will give voice to the early survivors of the AIDS epidemic, and explore the contemporary impact of the loss of much of an entire generation of gay and transgender people to AIDS in the 1980s. As part of the performance tour, residency activities may include movement and storytelling self-expression workshops, intergenerational community forums, master classes, workshops and classes at local universities, and post-performance discussions.

To support the national tour of "The Missing Generation," an evening-length production by choreographer Sean Dorsey. The work will give voice to the early survivors of the AIDS epidemic, and explore the contemporary impact of the loss of much of an entire generation of gay and transgender people to AIDS in the 1980s. The company will engage in a national tour. In each city, the company will offer performances and week-long residency activities such as master classes, movement and self-expression workshops, community panels exploring using the arts to promote HIV awareness and LGBT rights, and question-and-answer sessions, as well as community forums featuring Sean Dorsey, local activists, historians, and people with HIV/AIDS

To support the national tour of "The Missing Generation," an evening-length production by choreographer Sean Dorsey. The work will explore the contemporary impact of the loss of much of an entire generation of LGBT people to AIDS during the 1980s. The company will travel to Atlanta, Georgia; Boston, Massachusetts; Washington, D.C.; Lewiston, Maine; and Whitewater, Wisconsin. In each city, the company will offer performances and residency activities such as master classes; panel discussions featuring LGBT artists, activists, and historians; and community forums featuring LGBT seniors who experienced AIDS first-hand.

To support the creation and world premiere of Sean Dorsey Dance's new evening-length work, "The Missing Generation." The work will explore the contemporary impact of the loss of much of an entire generation of LGBT people to AIDS during the 1980s.

Organization Name: Friends & Foundation of the San Francisco Public Library
Category: National Arts and Humanities Youth Program Awards
Project Description: In recognition of San Francisco WritersCorps, a program which brings writers to after-school programs, community centers and juvenile halls to teach writing and help youths in San Francisco, California.

To support an exhibition featuring work by prominent California Latino artists from the late 20th century. The exhibition, with accompanying online catalogues and public programming, are planned to coincide with the 40th anniversary of Galeria de La Raza.

To support "Nighthawks (Remix)," in consortium with La Pocha Nostra. The project, commemorating Galeria's 40th anniversary, involves the development and premiere of a photo-based live performance work by Guillermo Gomez Pena and James Luna.

To support continued development of an online exhibition archive to include materials from Galeria's programming from 2001 to the present. The project involves uploading more than 1,000 images, documents, newspaper articles, and critical reviews.

To support continued development of an online exhibition archive to include materials from Galeria's programming between 1985-2000. The project involves uploading more than 1,500 images, documents, newspaper articles, and critical reviews.

To support expansion of an online exhibition archive to include materials from Galeria's earliest years of programming, 1970-1985. The project involves uploading more than 1,500 images, documents, newspaper articles, and critical reviews.

To support production of an online catalogue documenting exhibitions that commemorate Galeria's 35th anniversary. The exhibitions, organized in 2005, featured the work of approximately 75 Latino artists from California.

To support documentation of the Digital Mural Project, an archive of mural images on the organization's Web site. In just five years, Galeria has presented 25 public art pieces on a 24 foot by 10 foot billboard on its faade in San Francisco's Mission District.

To support development and presentation of an online record of Galeria de la Raza's exhibitions from its inception in 1970. The project is a major component of Galeria's 35th anniversary, celebrating its contributions to contemporary Latino art and culture.

To support Paradigms Lost. The project will explore Latino/Latin American artists' reflections on self and place in the digital age, and will comprise a visual art exhibition, performances, public art, and a youth arts component.

To support a community-based public art project that will commission artists and youth to develop computer-generated temporary murals. The project will include workshops and panel discussions to discuss how the works address the theme "Pervasive Forces: Globalization, Private Identities, and the Public Sphere."

To support the Digital Mural Project. The artists will be invited to explore issues related to the Digital Divide -- the cultural, economic, social, and political implications of new information technologies.

To support "Regeneration," a project designed to increase participation by young Latinos in the programs and exhibitions of Galeria Studio 24. "Regeneration" is designed to offer opportunities for young artists to gain the information and skills needed to launch careers in the arts.

To support (Re)Generation, a project designed to increase participation by young Latinos in the programs and exhibitions of Galeria Studio 24, providing a base from which young artists can gain the information and skills needed to launch careers in the arts. Participants may choose to be involved in the project at a number of different levels, including monthly meetings, exhibitions, performance opportunities, a writers' group, a quarterly magazine, career development workshops, and several special events. Planning will be guided by an advisory group of young artists working in various media. The project responds to the recognition that there is a need for intergenerational connections between the Galeria and an emerging generation of Latino artists who feel disconnected to the organization. This initiative represents faith in the organization's future and will ensure the artistic and cultural productivity of the community for years to come.

To support a consortium to develop an intercultural project which investigates and commemorates, through exhibitions, films and performing and literary arts events, the historical and contemporary connections among American communities affected by the Mexican American War (1848) and the Spanish American War (1898). At the 150 and 50 year juncture, respectively, 1998 offers the opportunity to consider historical and living connections among the Chicano, Cuban, Puerto Rican, Filipino, Samoan, and Hawaiian communities affected by these two wars. Galeria will work with consortium members Cine Accion, Kearny Street Workshop and La Pe a Cultural Center, and with other organizations such as the Philippine Resource Center, the American Indian Film Festival, and the Kapalakiko Hawaiian Band, to present a series of activities exploring issues related to the 1998 commemoration. Events include an opening conference bringing together community activitists, artists, and academics to illuminate the living influences of these wars on the various communities and to articulate the goals for the commemoration. Each of the consortium members plans a special event for the project and outreach activities to engage each other's audiences. For example, Galeria will present an installation by Amalia Mesa-Bains, Private Landscapes/Public Territories: The Re-Annexation Project, that will juxtapose stories of migration with the post-1848 land

Purpose: To support the translation from the Czech of Thousands of Plateaus by Sylva Fischerov Additional Project Description: Deborah Garfinkle will translate into English the work of Sylva Fischerov (b. 1963), the author of ten collections of poems, three volumes of short stories, two novels, and two children's books. Thousands of Plateaus is Fischerov's most recent collection, comprising 14 loosely interconnected short stories. One story, Its a Grub, Dude, is a philosophical argument about sauerkraut. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit fellowship recipient Deborah Garfinkle, a poet, translator, and adjunct instructor of English at College of San Mateo and De Anza Community College. The translation of this work also will benefit the public, who will have access to the English translation of this work for the first time. Intended Outcomes: Beneficiaries experience the international exchange of artists, artworks, and arts activities.
To support the translation of WORM-EATEN TIME, a collection of poems by Czech writer Pavel Srut.
To support the creation and presentation of a dance performance by choreographers Janice Garrett and Charles Moulton.

To support the creation and presentation of Hunting Gathering, by choreographers Janice Garrett and Charles Moulton. The new work will examine themes of cooperation, connection, and interdependence while investigating Ralph Waldo Emerson's concept of the "Oversoul" the life force which animates and connects all living beings. The cast will comprise dancers, musicians, and a movement choir whose nature will communicate a sense of collective human experience. The piece will feature an original score that will be composed and conducted by Musical Director Jonathan Russell. This production will help the company fulfill its mission of making large-scale, community-driven performances that celebrate our shared humanity.

To support the creation and presentation of an evening-length work, by Co-Artistic Directors Janice Garrett and Charles Moulton. Titled "Speak, Angels" the work will explore the themes of transcendence and hope, and will be a large-scale new work comprised of Garret + Moulton's six company dancers; an 18-dancer "movement choir;" a chorus of 12 singers who will be integrated into the stage action; and an ensemble of eight musicians. The work will premiere at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco and will include open rehearsals and post-show question-and-answer sessions.
To support the production of "The Archbishop's Ceiling" by Arthur Miller. The production will be presented in the theater's neo-gothic cathedral.

To support the development and production of a new music theater work. George Coates Performance Works will present The Blind Messenger, a musical theater work with a mixed voice chorus that will be based on an original score by Chinese American composer Forrest Fang with projected stage sets created by fine art photographer Steven Joseph.

To support actor and design team workshops, script development, rehearsal and production expenses for an original work, "Wittgenstein On Mars" to be produced in San Francisco Working with source material from the written works of two distinctly different writer/philosophers, Niccolo Machiavelli and Ludwig Wittgenstein, a workshop process will be employed by George Coates Performance Works (GCPW) to develop an original dramatic presentation investigating the ways in which language and context affect human behavior and cultural expression. Principal texts and script will be drawn from Machiavelli's lesser known plays and polemical works and from Wittgenstein's posthumously published tract "On Certainty" completed two months before his death in 1951. These works form a basis for dramatic examination of how culture and context shape language, assert meaning, and affect behavior. The production will make use of imaging systems developed for NASA's Pathfinder mission to Mars to create a realistic virtual Mars stage set. Audiences wearing 3-D glasses will experience a human scale 3-D illusion of an ancient Martian flood plain created from imagery produced with the stereographic cameras operating from the Sagan Memorial Station in the Aires Valley on Mars. This project is an outgrowth of GCPW's
To support the exhibition at Grace Cathedral of the Keiskamma Altarpiece, a commemoration of AIDS victims created by over 120 women from the East Cape Province of South Africa.

To support "New Music Festival in an Old Cathedral," a concert festival of contemporary music in consortium with the Center for New Music and Audio Technologies of the University of California at Berkeley. The concerts will take place at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco.

To support staff and administrative costs for production, post-production, and outreach for a short documentary film series directed by Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy. The series will explore the personal stories of women from around the world working towards women's rights in their communities, in such countries as Brazil, Nigeria, Turkey, and Kyrgyzstan. Once completed, the series will be available for online distribution, and presented to the public in community screenings and discussions internationally through partnerships with UN Women and the Women's Funding Network. Obaid-Chinoy has previously won Academy Awards for her films Girl in the River: The Price of Forgiveness (2015) and Saving Face (2011).

To support Ignite: Women Fueling Science and Technology, a transmedia project and online exhibition by the International Museum of Women. Exploring women's contributions to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), the Ignite Exhibition will show how the arts can both propel and express these achievements. The exhibition, which will be curated from an open call for submissions, will include art works, videos, photography, infographics, mixed-media pieces, and essays and stories.

Popular Name: aka San Francisco Gay Men's Chorus
Project Description: Purpose: To support the premiere of Songs of the Phoenix, a new multi-composer work performed by the San Francisco Gay Men's Chorus. Additional Project Description: The theme of the work will focus on the shared losses during the COVID-19 pandemic that has led toward a rising from the ashes. Composer Andrew Lippa will curate the work by as many as six other composers. Intended Beneficiaries: The performance will be promoted to audiences throughout the Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

Popular Name: aka San Francisco Gay Men's Chorus
Project Description: To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Popular Name: aka San Francisco Gay Men's Chorus
Project Description: To support RHYTHM (Reaching Youth Through Music), an education program for school students by the San Francisco Gay Men's Chorus. Activities may include master classes on vocal technique and musicianship, workshops, and performances. The program will be carried out virtually as necessary.

Popular Name: aka San Francisco Gay Men's Chorus
Project Description: To support RHYTHM (Reaching Youth Through Music), an education program for school students by the San Francisco Gay Men's Chorus. Activities at area high schools may include master classes on vocal technique and musicianship, workshops, and performances.

Purpose: To support the development of a new play by Tariq Hamami. Additional Project Description: The play will be based on Hamami's family history and will tell the story of members of the United States' Black Panther Party who lived in Algeria, following Algeria's independence from France in 1962. The theater will select a dramaturg for the playwright to inform additional drafts of the script. The development period will culminate in a design workshop and in a public staged reading of the final draft. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit theater artists and audiences in San Francisco. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organizations constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support a co-production of On The Periphery by Sedef Ecer, in a new translation by Evren Odcikin. Set in Istanbul and Paris, the play focuses on the stories of individuals and families who leave rural communities for large cities, in search of better lives. Golden Thread will partner with Crowded Fire Theater Company on the production.

To support the U.S. premiere production of Scenes from 71 Years by Irish-Palestinian playwright Hannah Khalil, directed by Michael Malek Najjar. The play presents stories of Palestinian life since 1948. Rather than attempting to make an overarching political statement about the conflict, the play tells stories of the day-to-day interactions of Israelis and Palestinians. The production will give the theater an opportunity to build on relationships with the Palestinian community and to honor its long and rich history in the Bay Area.

To support the premiere of "We Swim, We Talk, We go to War!" by Mona Mansour. Evren Odcikin will direct the production which is inspired by a conversation Mansour had with her nephew when she learned he had signed up to join the U.S. Army. The play is a literal conversation on stage between an aunt and a nephew about what it means to be American, Arab, and Arab-American.

To support the ReOrient Festival of Short Plays and Forum. The project will include a festival of short plays and a forum of panel discussions about theater and the Middle East. The festival will serve as a springboard for the careers of emerging Middle Eastern-American playwrights and will introduce audiences to significant dramatic works from the Middle East by authors rarely produced in the United States. Through the project, Golden Thread will create engagement opportunities for artists, academics, and both national and international audiences.

To support the premiere of "The Most Dangerous Highway in the World" by Kevin Artigue, and the West Coast premiere of "Our Enemies: Lively Scenes of Love and Combat" by Yussef El Guindi. Set on the Jalalabad-Kabul Highway in Afghanistan. Artigue's play portrays a precocious nine-year-old "business man" who survives by selling old fish to truck drivers and the random passersby. Through humor and with poignant honesty, the playwright creates a world that is both foreign and familiar. The production will introduce a new theatrical voice and will deepen the theater's relationship with the Bay Area's Afghan population. Golden Thread has served as an artistic home for Arab-American playwright El Guindi for more than 15 years. The theater will produce the second production of his play about the politics of representation in the publishing industry.

To support the ReOrient Theatre Festival and Forum. The theater's hallmark event will include a festival of short plays, a forum of panel discussions about theater and the Middle East, and a ReOrient Camp. The festival will serve as a springboard for the careers of emerging Middle Eastern-American playwrights and will introduce audiences to significant dramatic works from the Middle East by authors rarely produced in the United States. The project will create engagement opportunities for artists, academics, and both national and international audiences.

To support the development and premiere of "Isfahan Blues" by Torange Yeghiazarian with direction by Laura Hope. The story is inspired by the Duke Ellington Orchestra's 1963 tour to Iran that resulted in the album "The Far East Suite" and includes a track called Isfahan, named after a city in Iran. The creative team will include actors L. Peter Callender and Vida Ghahremani, Music Director Marcus Shelby, and Dramaturg Nakissa Etemad.

To support the development and premiere of "Urge for Going" by Mona Mansour with direction by Evren Odcikin. The story centers on Jamila, a young refugee girl preparing for her university exams--her ticket out of the refugee camp.

To support the ReOrient Festival, featuring short plays exploring the Middle East, a weekend forum of panels with leading experts, and presentations on theater and the Middle East. The four-week run of fully produced new short plays, as well as "ReOrient Forum," a weekend of talks, lectures, performances, showings, exhibitions, and other events, will take place at Theatre Artaud/Z Space in San Francisco.

To support a production of "Language Rooms" by Yussef El Guindi in consortium with the Asian-American Theatre Company. Artistic director Torange Yeghiazarian will partner with Asian American Theatre to reach new audiences and freelance director and dramaturge Mark Routhier will direct.
To support the annual ReOrient Festival of plays exploring the Middle East. The festival will feature full productions of new plays by Middle Eastern playwrights with post-play discussions.

To support a series of public programs, including demonstrations, lectures and exhibitions. The project will explore the connection between traditional bookmaking crafts and the work of writers and artists. A gallery and production room will house type foundry and letterpress printing operations where visitors may view all of the crafts of bookmaking, from start to finish.

To support a series of public programs, including demonstrations, lectures, and exhibitions. The project will explore the connections between traditional bookmaking crafts and the work of writers and artists. The project will take place in a unique historic working type foundry and letterpress-the nation's only remaining such operation. Examples of printed books will allow visitors the opportunity to familiarize and deepen technical knowledge. Tours, demonstrations, and readings by artists, writers, scholars, and publishers will be held in the institute's workshop facility.

To support Bookmaking, Writing, and Art, a series of demonstrations, lectures, and exhibitions. The programming will explore the connections between traditional bookmaking crafts and the work of writers and artists. The project will take place in a unique historic working type foundry and letterpress--the nation's only remaining such operation.

To support Bookmaking, Writing, and Art, a series of demonstrations, lectures, and exhibitions. The programming will explore the connections between traditional bookmaking crafts and the work of writers and artists.

To support Bookmaking, Writing, and Art, a series of demonstrations, lectures, and exhibitions. The programming will explore the connections between traditional bookmaking crafts and the work of writers and artists will take place in a unique historic working type foundry and letterpress, the nation's only remaining such operation.

To support "Bookmaking, Writing, and Art," a series of demonstrations, lectures, and exhibitions. Programs will explore connections between traditional bookmaking crafts and the work of contemporary artists and writers.

To support a series of public programs, including demonstrations, lectures, and exhibitions, titled Bookmaking, Writing, and Art. The project explores connections between traditional bookmaking crafts and the work of contemporary artists and writers.

To support a series of public programs, including demonstrations, lectures, and exhibitions, titled Bookmaking, Writing, and Art. The project explores connections between traditional bookmaking crafts and the work of contemporary artists and writers.

To support "Bookmaking, Writing, and Art," a series of public programs that includes demonstrations, lectures, and exhibitions. The project explores connections between traditional bookmaking crafts and the work of contemporary artists and writers.

To support "Bookmaking, Writing, and Art," a series of public programs that includes demonstrations, lectures, and exhibitions. The project explores connections between traditional bookmaking crafts and the work of artists and writers.

To support the restoration of vintage typecasting and letterpress printing equipment. This equipment forms the core of traditional bookmaking and the restoration will include an inventory of archive type as well as an operations/repair manual for the equipement in the foundry.

To support the restoration of stained glass windows created by the American master craftsman Charles J. Connick for the cathedral in 1930-45. Grace Cathedral is the third largest Episcopal cathedral in the country and provides the Bay Area with a wide variety of community services. The Cathedral has over 200,000 visitors each year and the stained glass windows are a signifcant feature to the architectural character wich attracts tourists.

Organization Name: Gray Area Foundation for the Arts
Project Description: Purpose: To support the Gray Area Festival and associated programming focused on arts at the intersection of technology. Additional Project Description: This in-person and online festival will include a conference, an exhibition of commissioned works, and creative code workshops focused on bringing together artists, technologists, and theorists working in diverse fields such as electronic music, expanded cinema, and virtual and augmented reality. Topics explored will include civic engagement, media arts education, human-computer interaction, creative coding practices, and digital culture. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival will engage audiences from across the country, with a focus on San Francisco-area residents and visitors, as well as participating artists, students, and community partners. Intended Outcome: Arts organizations support tech-centered creative practices and serve the public through digital or emergent technology.

Organization Name: Gray Area Foundation for the Arts
Project Description: Purpose: To support the Gray Area Festival and associated programming. Additional Project Description: Highlighting the intersection of art, technology, design, and culture, the hybrid in-person and online festival will bring together experimental audio and visual creatives working in diverse fields such as electronic music, expanded cinema, and virtual and augmented reality for an exchange of ideas, media arts exhibitions, and audiovisual performances. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival will engage audiences from across the country, with a focus on San Francisco-area residents and visitors, as well as participating artists, schools, and community partners. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Organization Name: Gray Area Foundation for the Arts
Project Description: Purpose: To support the creation and exhibition of immersive audio-visual works through a residency program for new media artists. Additional Project Description: In partnership with Recombinant Media Labs, artists selected from an open call will receive specialized training, facilities and equipment access, and stipends to develop audio and visual content for the CineChamber, a 360-degree theater for surround cinema presentations. The residency will culminate in a public exhibition. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit artists working in new media, as well as audiences attending the public performances in the San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

Organization Name: Gray Area Foundation for the Arts
Project Description: To support the Gray Area Festival and associated programming. Highlighting the intersection of art, technology, design, and culture, the festival will bring together experimental audio and visual creatives working in diverse fields such as electronic music, expanded cinema, and virtual and augmented reality for an exchange of ideas, media arts exhibitions, and audiovisual performances. Activities will take place virtually.

Organization Name: Gray Area Foundation for the Arts
Project Description: To support educational and professional development programming for emerging media artists, educators, and practitioners, with a focus on the intersections of art, technology, and science. Through artist-led online workshops, weekly group sessions, one-on-one meetings with instructors, and community events, participants will receive training on topics such as immersive media, projection mapping, physical computing, and how to teach creative coding.

Organization Name: Gray Area Foundation for the Arts
Project Description: To support the online Gray Area Festival and associated programming. Highlighting the intersection of art, technology, design, and culture, the festival will virtually bring together experimental audio and visual creatives working in diverse fields such as electronic music, expanded cinema, and virtual and augmented reality for an exchange of ideas about how technology development and artistic practice can engage broader audiences and create civic impact.

Organization Name: Gray Area Foundation for the Arts
Project Description: To support the "Free Art and Technology Lab Gold Project." Artists from different disciplines will be commissioned to create new site-specific media art works, which will then be exhibited with works created from previous labs. Commissioned artists also will hold workshops and other public events.

Organization Name: Gray Area Foundation for the Arts
Project Description: To support the development and implementation of a mobile immersive theater project. Images will be projected onto the CineChamber, a large (24' x 36') rectangular surround surface apparatus.

Organization Name: Gray Area Foundation for the Arts
Project Description: To support the development and implementation of a series of data-driven art works intended for the public. While much of our world is experiencing data overload, several artists are using the constant stream of digital information to engage the public.
In support of your significant impact on and your continuing contributions to the art form of jazz in the African-American tradition.

Purpose: To support the creation of a new dance work as part of the Dancing Distributed Leadership (DDL) project, with associated engagement activities. Additional Project Description: In 2020, choreographers Cherie Hill, Hope Mohr, and Karla Quintero co-stewarded the company's transition to an equity-driven model of distributed leadership. The DDL project will combine the three individual choreographic practices of these artists to create a dance that explores their different experiences of sharing power and moving into power as women. Public offerings will include live and virtual performances paired with audience dialogues, public workshops on shared leadership in dance, open rehearsals, writings, and an online project archive. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit the participating artists and general audiences in the San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support the creation and presentation of Ensemble for Non-Linear Time by visual artist Ranu Mukherjee and choreographer Hope Mohr. The work will consist of a video installation and live performances focused on refugees and people who have lost their homes due to wildfires. It will be presented as part of The Bridge Project, a program that facilitates cultural conversations that cross disciplines, geography, and perspectives.

To support the Bridge Project with repertory performances, workshops, and documentation to commemorate the 100th anniversary of choreographer Merce Cunningham's birth. Former Cunningham dancer Rashaun Mitchell will lead Cunningham technique and repertory workshops and work with selected dancers to perform excerpts of Cunningham works as part of the Bridge Project. The project is a collaboration with the Merce Cunningham Trust. Throughout and after the project, the public will receive free, online access to media that may include images, writings, commentary, performance videos, and reviews.

To support a series of workshops and performances as part of The Bridge Project. The Bridge Project will facilitate cultural conversations that cross disciplines, geography, and perspectives. Writers and performing artists in theater and dance will be paired based on their mutual interests to collaborate on an evening of performance and discussion. Prior to each performance, artists also will lead workshops open to the public.

To support "Ten Artists Respond to Locus," a bicoastal collaboration with the Trisha Brown Dance Company (TBDC). The presentation is part of Hope Mohr's The Bridge Project, a program that facilitates cultural conversations that cross disciplines, geography, and perspective. Bay Area artists will be commissioned to participate in movement and dance history workshops led by TBDC Associate Artistic Director Diane Madden. After the workshops, each artist will develop a new work in response to Trisha Brown's iconic 1975 solo, "Locus." Yerba Buena Center for the Arts will host each performance, followed by a moderated discussions with the artists about the topic of artistic lineage. All phases of the project will be documented and made available via social media.

To support the art and design phase of the Hilltop Park Renovation Project. Hunters Point Family will collaborate with state and city governments to spearhead a renovation and beautification project in Bayview Hunters Point, San Francisco's first and largest African-American community. The project activities will define the themes, media, and artists employed to provide the design and placement of artworks within the park. The community will have the opportunity not only to review the top proposals but also to work with the artists in the installation of the artwork.

To support the growth and maintenance of Design Kit, an online platform for teaching human-centered design. Formerly known as HCD Connect, the project focuses mainly on building media relationships, managing the design kit community, and conducting reviews and semi-annual surveys about user engagement with the website content. The Design Kit website highlights experienced designers from across the field through videos, provides the step-by-step process of more than 50 design methods, highlights case studies, and encourages readers to contribute their own stories.

To support the pilot, expanded content development, and community outreach for Design Kit. Design Kit is an online platform for designers and nonprofit practitioners working in underserved communities. Additional educational materials will be prepared to inform designers and social sector practitioners about human-centered design strategies, which focus on improving human life. A community manager will answer users' questions, spur conversations on social media, and connect members with one another to develop and encourage a sense of online community.

To support Human-Centered Design Connect, an online platform to support designers, nonprofit, and social enterprises working in underserved communities. This interactive platform enables practitioners and students to share their experiences, ask questions, and connect with others working on similarly-focused design projects with a social impact.

Discipline / Field: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support personnel costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support a new audience development and marketing initiative coinciding with the organization's 40th anniversary. The initiative will increase Cultural Odyssey's long-term ability to market its programs, facility, and services. The initiative includes implementation of a marketing plan and a new publicity campaign.

To support the tour of "Fully Awake, Facing Seventy: Heaven Betta Be a Honky-Tonk!" A cabaret with live music celebrates Cultural Odyssey Co-Artistic Director Rhodessa Jones' new status as a senior citizen and her career as a professional artist and community activist. It is written and performed by Jones with musical direction and performance by Co-Artistic Director Idris Ackamoor with a trio of musicians. The issues and experiences of the aging process for women are addressed through her writing and performance. The duo will celebrate their 40th anniversary as a performance ensemble and will tour the full-length autobiographical work to Washington D.C., and Knoxville, Tennessee.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work focusing on the issue of violence and its impact on women living with HIV. Cultural Odyssey Co-Artistic Director Rhodessa Jones, who is also the director of the Medea Project: Theater for Incarcerated Women, will collaborate with the Women's HIV Program at the University of San Francisco Medical Center to develop a musical theater work focusing on the issues of violence. The Medea Project uses the performing arts to work with female inmates and ex-inmates. Jones will utilize its longstanding method to empower women currently living in the community with HIV. Community forums will share information on HIV and encourage women living with the disease to develop supportive networks and overcome abusive relationships.

To support the creation of "Growing Up and Liking It in America" by Rhodessa Jones and Idris Ackamoor. The creative team will pay homage to their long creative partnership and will explore their artistic contributions to the performance field. Performance elements will include music, theater, film and video projections, spoken-word, and movement. The work will be accompanied by an archive including photographs, films, posters, and digital materials.

To support a production of "Birthright." The production will feature Rhodessa Jones and the Medea Project: Theater for Incarcerated Women. Using skills she has developed during the past 25 years through her work with incarcerated and formerly incarcerated women as well as HIV+ African-American women, Jones will collaborate with Planned Parenthood Shasta Pacific to lead residency and workshop activities exploring women's reproductive rights.

To support "Fully Awake  Facing Seventy: The End of Time Has Begun!" written and performed by Rhodessa Jones. In a solo piece with live music, Jones as a new senior citizen shares her "homegrown" wisdom regarding family, community, memory and spirit, and offers a treatise on the Baby Boom Generation confronting their last years with style, humor, and yoga.

To support the development and production of "The Resurrection of She," written and performed by Rhodessa Jones. Co-Artistic Directors Rhodessa Jones and Idris Ackamoor will collaborate on the project.

To support the development of a theatrical piece exploring the reasons behind the AIDS epidemic in the lives of African American women. "Dancing with the Clown of Love," will be created collaboratively with the Women's HIV Program at the University of California Medical Center, San Francisco.

To support the New Works Development Program of the African American Theater Alliance for Independence in consortium with the Afro Solo Theater. The project will inaugurate a development program to support the work of African American emerging and established performing artists.

To support the development and production of a new theater work, "The Breach" (working title), with community outreach activities. The artistic team of Rhodessa Jones and Idris Ackamoor will use music, theater, dance, and video production to examine the subject of reparations for African Americans.

To support the development, staged readings, workshop production, and world premiere of a new work. Co-artistic directors Rhodessa Jones and Idris Ackamoor will collaborate with writers Pearl Cleage and Zaron Burnett to create The Love Project.

To support the creation and production of "My Life in the Concrete Jungle," written and directed by Rhodessa Jones with music by Idris Ackamoor. Inspired by Amos Tutulola's "My Life in the Bush of Ghost," the piece will be a modern day musical myth that tells the story of lost souls in modern society.

To support the African American Theater Alliance for Independence (AATAIN!), a consortium project with AfroSolo Theatre Company. In partnership with the AfroSolo Theatre Company, the project will encourage self-empowerment through collective marketing, audience development, technical assistance, and aesthetic exploration.

To support the development and production of a new work by Rhodessa Jones and Idris Ackamoor to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the company. The performance will feature a unique interdisciplinary performance style, developed over nearly 25 years by Jones and Ackamoor, which combines music, theater, spoken-word, and movement.

To support a consortium project to preserve and document the theatrical works of two theater companies, including a retrospective performance showcase. Cultural Odyssey and Z Space Studio/AfroSolo will partner in an archival project to document, display, and publish the historic contributions of each organization to honor the groups' 25th and 10th anniversaries, respectively.

To support the "First Contact II" initiative. The program, lead by Artistic Directors Idris Ackamoor and Rhodessa Jones, will offer career development services for young emerging performance artists and the presentation of performances.
To support a consortium of African-American performance institutions to engage in collective marketing, audience development, technical assistance, and Web development.
To support the creation and production of a new theater work. Performing artists Rhodessa Jones and Idris Ackamoor will collaboratively create a theater performance exploring

To support a consortium of Black performance institutions in supporting and nurturing a performing arts community rooted in African-American artistic traditions. The consortium of Cultural Odyssey, Afro Solo Theater Company and the San Francisco Black Film Festival will encourage self-empowerment through collective marketing, audience development, technical assistance, web development and aesthetic exploration.

To support the enhancement of the theater's impact by developing new audiences, marketing strategies, and touring. Cultural Odyssey continues to expand its audiences by forming partnerships with the community and creating theater that speaks directly to its audiences.

To support the production of a video to document the Medea Project: Theater for Incarcerated Women. The video will focus on the realization of theater art as activism through the six Medea Project productions, resulting in a preserved documentary for future artists, scholars, and general audiences.

To support the establishment of a cash reserve, salary costs for a Program Administrator, and partial salary costs for a Co-Artistic Director for the Medea Project, theater for incarcerated women. Cultural Odyssey, in its eighteenth year, has established a history of creating, producing and presenting original interdisciplinary work rooted in African American music, dance and theatrical traditions. The company produces an average of two original works annually, and tours to venues throughout the nation and the world. The company conducts a number of community-based programs including the Medea Project, theater for incarcerated women. The project includes the creation of a cash reserve to secure organizational stability and artistic programming, and the augmentation of salary and expenses of a Program Administrator for the Medea Project. The Medea Project is an interdisciplinary performing ensemble comprised of professional actors, ex-offenders and current inmates who create and stage theater derived from the prisoners= own stories. The program=s four productions to date have confirmed the company=s belief that creating dramatic work can simultaneously transform members of a community and stretch the limits of theatrical possibilities.

Popular Name: aka The Imagine Bus Project; TIBP
Project Description: To support art making activities, including a large-scale mural project, for incarcerated youth at the San Francisco Juvenile Justice Center. The Youth Studio curriculum will offer skill building projects that incorporate art fundamentals such as design, composition, drawing, and painting.

Popular Name: aka The Imagine Bus Project; TIBP
Project Description: To support After School Studio, in consortium with the San Francisco School District. Targeted to children from under-resourced schools, After School Studio is a partnership with the San Francisco School District.

Purpose: To support promotion costs and community engagement activities for the public television series Independent Lens. Additional Project Description: The weekly PBS series provides the public with access to compelling, character-driven documentary films by independent media artists that are available for broadcast, streaming, and community screenings across the country. Additionally, ITVS will develop supplementary educational materials to deepen community engagement with the films. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve public audiences nationwide, as well as participating artists and producers in the independent film community. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support a community-based participatory, mixed-methods research study that documents and supports ethical and accountable filmmaking practices. Additional Project Description: Researchers will conduct a survey of diverse, independent, "nonfiction" filmmakersand a smaller set of focus groupsto examine ethical and accountable practices in filmmaking; how filmmakers implement these practices; the challenges faced in doing so; and the structural changes, resources, and support systems that might strengthen use of these practices. Researchers have partnered with multiple entities in the filmmaking community to develop data collection instruments, recruit filmmaker participants, and assist in interpreting the study's findings. Topics of interest will include power dynamics, interactions with nonfiction film subjects, the demographic characteristics of filmmakers, and participation in industry dialogues about ethical and accountable filmmaking. Intended Beneficiaries: This project has the potential to benefit the film community by elevating effective strategies for pursuing ethics and accountability in filmmaking. Intended Outcome: Research, statistics, and general information about the arts benefit the arts sector and other fields.

Purpose: To support promotion costs and community engagement activities for the public television series Independent Lens. Additional Project Description: The weekly PBS series provides the public with access to compelling, character-driven documentary films by independent media artists that are available for broadcast, streaming, and community screenings across the country. This season's selected programming also will include a focus on the criminal justice system. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve public audiences nationwide, as well as participating artists and producers in the independent film community. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the outreach for and promotion of films for the public television series Independent Lens. This weekly PBS series provides the public with access to compelling, character-driven documentary films by independent media artists that are available for broadcast, streaming, and community screenings across the country.

To support the selection, acquisition, packaging, and promotion of films for the public television series Independent Lens. This weekly PBS series provides the public with access to compelling, character-driven documentary films by independent media artists that are available for broadcast, streaming, and community screenings across the country.

To support the selection, acquisition, packaging, and promotion of films for the public television series Independent Lens. This weekly PBS series provides the public with access to compelling, character-driven documentary films by independent media artists. In addition to broadcast on PBS, the series will be made available for streaming access on pbs.org and through the Online Video Engagement Experience (OVEE) platform, and presented at community screenings across the country.

To support the selection, acquisition, packaging, and promotion of films for the public television series "Independent Lens." This weekly PBS series provides the public with access to compelling, character-driven documentary films by independent media artists. In addition to broadcast on PBS, the series also will be made available for streaming access on pbs.org and through the Online Video Engagement Experience (OVEE) platform, and presented at community screenings across the country.

To support staff and promotion costs for the public television series "Independent Lens." This weekly PBS series provides the public with access to documentaries, shorts, and experimental films by independent media artists. In addition to broadcast on PBS, the series also will be made available for streaming access through the Online Video Engagement Experience (OVEE) platform, and presented at community screenings across the country.

To support the Online Video Engagement Experience, a digital screening series that brings together audiences to watch and actively engage with the programs. OVEE is free and streams full-length films from multiple online sources to digital platforms with which audience members can interact in real time.

To support a 26-part television series titled "Global Voices." The series will present documentaries funded through the Independent Television Services' International Media Development Fund and will also showcase programs from the ITVS archive of more than 900 titles.

To support the selection, acquisition, and packaging of films for the public television series "Independent Lens." This weekly PBS series provides the public with access to innovative, dramatic, animated, and documentary works by independent filmmakers.

To support a television series titled "Global Voices. The series will present documentaries funded through the Independent Television Services's (ITVS) International Media Development Fund and will also showcase programs from ITVS's archive of more than 900 titles.

To support the public television series INDEPENDENT LENS, including acquisition, packaging, and promotion costs. This weekly PBS series provides the public with access to innovative, dramatic, animated, and documentary works by independent filmmakers.
To support the IndiesLab. The Independent Television Service is exploring revenue-generating partnership models for independent filmmakers and public television.

To support the selection, acquisition, and packaging of films for the public television series Independent Lens. This weekly primetime PBS series provides the public with access to innovative, dramatic, animated, and documentary works by independent filmmakers.
To support the second season of "Global Voices." The 26-part television series will air on the new digital channel PBS World to an estimated audience of 25 million people.

To support the selection, acquisition, and packaging of films for the public television series Independent Lens. This weekly primetime PBS series provides the public with access to innovative, dramatic, animated, and documentary works by independent filmmakers.

To support the selection, acquisition, and packaging of films for the public television series "Independent Lens." This weekly primetime PBS series provides the public with access to innovative dramatic, animated, and documentary works by independent filmmakers.
To support GLOBAL VOICES. Approximately 200 works will be broadcast to an estimated audience of 4.6 million people.

To support the selection, acquisition, and packaging of films for the public television series Independent Lens. This weekly primetime PBS series provides the public with access to innovative dramatic, animated, and documentary works by independent filmmakers.

To support the selection, acquisition, and packaging of films for the public television series Independent Lens. This anthology series provides the public with access to innovative dramatic, animated, and documentary works by independent filmmakers.

To support the selection, acquisition, and packaging of films for the public television series Independent Lens. This anthology series provides the public with access to innovative dramatic, animated, and documentary works by independent filmmakers.

To support the International Public Television (INPUT) Conference in 2005. The conference, to be held in San Francisco, will bring together media artists and public television professionals from around the world to view productions and exchange information.

To support the selection, acquisition, and packaging of films for the 2004-05 season of the public television series Independent Lens. The series will provide the public with access to innovative dramatic, animated, and documentary works by independent filmmakers.

To support the selection, acquisition, and packaging of films for the broadcast of the primetime public television series, INDEPENDENT LENS. In 2003-2004, the series will provide the public with access to innovative dramatic, animated, and documentary works by independent filmmakers.

To support the creation and presentation of "Beowulf" an Imagine Your Parks project. inkBoat will collaborate with the theater company We Players and the Rova Saxophone Quartet to create a new multidisciplinary work inspired by "Beowulf." Working in the San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park and adjacent Fort Mason, the artists will draw inspiration from the National Park Service sites, including Coast Miwok people settlements, U.S. military history, and historic ships. Workshop performances will be open to the public leading up to the premiere of the site-specific work.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work by Artistic Director Shinichi Iova-Koga in collaboration with Japanese Butoh master artist, Ko Murobushi. The work, titled Crazy Cloud, will be completed as part of a two-week residency at the Maggie Allesee National Center for Choreography at Florida State University.
To support the Center for Elders and Youth in the Arts program. Artists will provide instruction in painting, poetry, acting, movement, music composition, textiles, and oral history creation.
To support a series of workshops at senior centers throughout San Francisco. The workshops will bring together seniors and youth to create new works under the guidance of professional artists.

Popular Name: aka Coro Hispano de San Francisco
Project Description: To support performances of "Fandango!," a choral and instrumental program of the music of early California (1770-1870). Performances will take place in Oakland, San Francisco, and San Pablo.

Popular Name: aka Coro Hispano de San Francisco
Project Description: To support Dia de los Reyes (Epiphany) celebratory concerts featuring 18th-century Mexican music to be performed throughout Northern California and recorded for subsequent release. The project will involve the restoration to modern performance repertory and give present-day premieres of eight works by Mexican composers.

Popular Name: aka Coro Hispano de San Francisco
Project Description: To support the preservation, publishing, and performance of works by Mexican, Spanish, and Latin American baroque composers. In celebration of Corpus Christi, seven concerts are planned throughout California by the Coro Hispano de San Francisco, a community chorus, and Conjunto Nuevo Mundo, its professional component.

To support the annual SF Music Day of small ensemble performances. The annual free event will feature ensembles from the San Francisco Bay Area. Performances from a wide spectrum of musical genres, styles, and periods will be filmed at the San Francisco War Memorial and Performing Arts Center and streamed online.

To support the annual SF Music Day of small ensemble performances. The annual free event will feature ensembles from the San Francisco Bay Area. Performances from a wide spectrum of musical genres, styles, and periods will be presented concurrently on as many as four stages at the San Francisco War Memorial and Performing Arts Center.

To support the annual SFMusic Day of chamber music performances. The 11th annual free event will feature chamber ensembles from the San Francisco Bay Area. Performances by numerous ensembles will be presented concurrently on as many as four stages at the San Francisco War Memorial and Performing Arts Center.

To support SF Music Day Live + Free, the tenth annual chamber music festival. The free event will feature chamber ensembles from the San Francisco Bay Area. Programming will be curated by a committee led by Dr. Anthony Brown, founder and artistic director of Fifth Stream Music, and composer Paul Dresher, artistic director of the Paul Dresher Ensemble. Performances by numerous ensembles will be presented concurrently on multiple stages.

To support the annual chamber music festival. Titled SF Music Day, the free event will feature chamber ensembles from the San Francisco Bay Area. Programming curated by musicologist Kai Christiansen will explore an overarching theme of hybridity and innovation, celebrating the City of San Francisco's role as a port of call and cultural epicenter of the Pacific Rim. Performances by numerous ensembles will be presented concurrently on as many as three stages at the San Francisco War Memorial and Performing Arts Center.

To support the annual chamber music festival. Titled SF Music Day Live + Free, the free two-day event will feature chamber ensembles from the San Francisco Bay Area and will be directed by Lead Curator Kevin Chen, jazz program director at Intersection for the Arts. Programming will explore an overarching theme of hybridity and innovation, celebrating the City of San Francisco's role as a port of call and cultural epicenter of the Pacific Rim. Performances by numerous ensembles will be presented concurrently on as many as three stages at the San Francisco War Memorial and Performing Arts Center.

To support the annual chamber music festival. Titled SF Music Day Live + Free, the free day-long event will feature chamber ensembles from the San Francisco Bay Area and will be directed by Curators Kevin Chen, jazz program director at Intersection for the Arts, and Adam Fong, executive director of San Francisco's Center for New Music.

To support "SFMusic Day . Live + Free." A free day-long chamber music festival will be directed by Artistic Curator Martha Rodriquez-Salazar and will feature chamber ensembles from the San Francisco Bay Area.

To support Chamber Music Day, a free day-long chamber music festival. The festival will feature chamber ensembles from the San Francisco Bay Area in performances at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.
To support "Chamber Music Day," a free chamber music festival. Chamber ensembles from the San Francisco Bay Area will perform all day long at the San Francisco Conservatory of Music in Civic Center.

To support Chamber Music Day, a free chamber music festival, in consortium with the San Francisco Community Music Center. Chamber ensembles from the San Francisco Bay Area will perform all day long at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts and the adjacent Yerba Buena Gardens.

To support the Affiliates Program for chamber music ensembles. The project will include the presentation of concerts and Web site improvements, as well as services such as technical assistance workshops, educational outreach coaching, and the publication of a newsletter.
To support the International Latino Film Festival. Held in the fall, the festival presents more than 40 films to an audience of 14,000 people.
To support the International Latino Film Festival. The festival presents more than 40 films to an audience of up to 12,000 people.

To support The Circle. A series of multidisciplinary performances and engagement activities celebrating the organization's 50th Anniversary, activities will include visual art installations, communal storytelling events, music and theater performances, a mobile performance series, the creation of works with community members, and large public festivals. Intersection will engage with local community partners to provide educational workshops in storytelling, writing, and filmmaking.

To support the 2013 Triangle Lab. A partnership with the California Shakespeare Theater, the new program will place artists, arts organizations, and communities as equal partners in a "triangulated" relationship to create new theater works and will seek new development models for the field.

To support resident company Campo Santo's development of "Alleluia,The Road," a new play by Luis Alfaro, inspired by August Strindberg's "The Road to Damascus." The research and development process will engage urban and rural communities as a team of artists explore seven stops on California's Highway 99, reflecting on the state's history of economic, demographic, and cultural shifts.

To support the creation of "The River" by California playwrights Sean San Jose and Richard Montoya. Through a research and development process that will engage urban and rural communities, the project will explore California through the lens of the Southeast border towns of Calexico and Mexicali alongside the New River, a region that was once a resort destination and is now widely considered to be the most toxic river in North America.
To support the development and premiere of "Mirrors in Every Corner," a new play by Chinaka Hodge. The production will be directed by Marc Bamuthi Joseph.

To support the development and premiere of Fuku Americanus, based on The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao a new novel by Dominican American writer Junot Diaz. The play will be developed by Intersection for the Arts' resident ensemble member Campo Santo.

To support the development and premiere of "June in a Box" by playwright Octavio Solis and the Campo Santo resident theater ensemble with accompanying educational activities. Based on the Mexican ballad "El Corrido De June Robles," the play recounts the true story of the kidnapping of a young girl in Tucson.
To support the development and world premiere of a new play by Jessica Hagedorn with outreach and education activities. Danny Scheie will direct Fe in the Desert by playwright Jessica Hagedorn.
To support the development of a new play by Charles Randolph Wright. A Waiter by Charles Randolph Wright will be directed by Margo Hall and performed by the resident theater company Campo Santo.

To support the consortium project Independent Press Spotlight, a monthly series of events designed to highlight the work of independent presses and literary journals from the Bay area. In partnership with City Lights Foundation, the center will promote the series in its newsletter which is distributed to more than 11,500 individuals.
To support the presentation of the 12th annual summer series. The project will include work by Bay Area choreographers at the Cowell Theater.
To support the development and production of a new play written by Denis Johnson. "Soul of a Whore" is the third play in a triptych written specifically for Campo Santo by writer Denis Johnson.
To support the presentation and promotion of writers' residencies. Proposed artists include bell hooks, Jimmy Santiago Baca, Dave Eggers, and Ruben Martinez.

To support writers' residencies. Proposed artists include Jessica Hagedorn, Mike Davis, Kevin Powell, and Suzan Lori Parks. Each residency will include a public reading and at least one free outreach event tailored to the writer's interests and expertise.

To support the development and production of a new work by Octavio Solis. Written specifically for and with Campo Santo, the play will tell the story of San Francisco, exploring forgotten places and reclaiming the history, vitality, diversity, and beauty of a city in the midst of rapid change.
To support the presentation and promotion of writers' residencies in San Francisco. Proposed artists include Walter Mosley, Dave Hickey, Lucy Lippard, and Luis Rodriguez.
To support the development and world premiere of a play. "Hotel Angulo" by Luis Saguar will be preformed in April 2001.

To support the presentation and promotion of writers' residencies in San Francisco. Proposed artists include Benjamin Alire S enz, Luis Rodriguez, John Trudell, bell hooks, Lynne Tillman, and Christina Garcia.
To support the presentation and promotion of four writer's residencies, featuring Lynn Emmanuel, Martin Espada, Darcy Steinke, and Randall Kenan.

Organization Name: Japanese Cultural & Community Center of Northern California
Project Description: To support the Matsuri Project, a multi-event program focused on Japanese American heritage.
