Activities will include a residency by a minyo (folk song) and shamisen (three-string Japanese lute) master artist; performances at the Japan Center Obon Festival, Gen Taiko's 10th Anniversary Concert, and the fifth Annual Asian Pacific American Arts and Heritage Festival.

Purpose: To support the creation and presentation of an ensemble work directed by Jess Curtis. Additional Project Description: The work will focus on social and cultural experiences of darkness and light. Accessibility accommodations such as audio description, tactile floor markings, and touch-based navigation strategies will be utilized to allow performers to safely navigate the space and negotiate proximity to audiences given the literal use of extreme darkness and light. Digital documentation of the work will also be made available online. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit audiences, including people who are blind and visually impaired, in the San Francisco area and online. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support artist fees for the creation and presentation of a new dance work by choreographer Jess Curtis about sight and perception. The company will partner with LightHouse for the Blind and Visually Impaired to create work that addresses the prevalence of sight in our culture. Through this work, Curtis will research the intersections of movement, culture, sensory difference, and physical diversity in live performance. The work will embed access accommodations such as audio description, non-traditional seating arrangements, pre-show touch tours, and ASL interpretation.

To support the presentation of a new international choreographic research project, "Performance Research Experiment #2: Paradox of the Heart," by artistic director Jess Curtis. A collaboration with French-German dance and circus performer Jorg Muller, a full-length work will be created.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support the creation and presentation of culminating events as part of The Symmetry Project. The work is a three-year movement-based performance-installation/media project by choreographer and Artistic Director Jess Curtis, in collaboration with choreographer and performer Maria Francesca Scaroni.
To support the creation and presentation of "Under the Radar" by choreographer Jess Curtis. The work will be created for performers with and without disabilities.

Organization Name: Jewish Community Center of San Francisco
Project Description: Purpose: To support multidisciplinary arts programming. Additional Project Description: The series will focus on freedom as a basic human right. "Wander Woman III," a visual arts exhibition, will feature works created by female BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color) artists with immigrant backgrounds. A poetry reading with Guggenheim and 2019 NEA Creative Writing Fellow Reginald Dwayne Betts will highlight experiences with the criminal justice system and offer opportunities for change. Additional community engagement will include hands-on art making with exhibiting artists, panel discussions, and workshops. Intended Beneficiaries: The series will benefit Bay Area community members and visitors. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Organization Name: Jewish Community Center of San Francisco
Project Description: To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Organization Name: Jewish Community Center of San Francisco
Project Description: To support arts programming components of the Re-imagine Freedom series. Arts programming will include the What We Carry With Us multimedia installation by artist Sam Ball in collaboration with Citizen Film, and related public programs.

Organization Name: Jewish Community Center of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the production and presentation of the multidisciplinary performance "Mu." Theater artist Brenda Wong Aoki, composer Mark Izu, choreographer Kimi Okada, and director Jael Weisman will weave elements of Asian, African, and Hawaiian dance and music to create a multimedia pageant play.

Organization Name: Jewish Community Center of San Francisco
Project Description: To support the Back to the Garden series involving dance, film, and music. Activities will include performances, lectures, and documentary film screenings exploring environmental issues.

Organization Name: Jewish Community Center of San Francisco
Project Description: To support education and outreach activities related to the restoration and reinstallation of a WPA mural painted in 1933 by Bernard Zakheim. Once restored, the mural will be reinstalled at the Jewish Community Center's new 135,000-square-foot facility.

Purpose: To support the Jewish Film Institute's San Francisco Jewish Film Festival. Additional Project Description: Presented at venues throughout the Bay Area, the Academy Award-qualifying festival showcases short and feature-length narrative, documentary, animated, and experimental films. Additional programs may include virtual reality experiences, live performances, and panel discussions about contemporary Jewish culture. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival will serve San Francisco-area audiences, as well as participating artists. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the Jewish Film Institute's San Francisco Jewish Film Festival. Additional Project Description: Presented at venues throughout the Bay Area and online, the Academy Award-qualifying festival showcases short and feature-length narrative, documentary, animated, and experimental films. Additional programs may include virtual reality experiences, live performances, and panel discussions about contemporary Jewish culture. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival will serve San Francisco-area and virtual audiences, as well as participating artists, venues, community organizations, and schools. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts

To support the Jewish Film Institute's 41st San Francisco Jewish Film Festival. Presented virtually and at venues throughout the Bay Area, the Academy Award-qualifying festival showcases short and feature-length narrative, documentary, animated, and experimental films. Additional programs may include virtual reality experiences, live performances, and panel discussions about contemporary Jewish culture.

To support the Filmmaker Residency program for independent media artists at the Jewish Film Institute. Resident artists will have in-person and/or virtual access to stipends, feedback sessions, fundraising consultations, industry meetings, and mentorship opportunities to support their work on projects at all stages of development that explore Jewish themes, culture, and identity.

To support travel, theater rental, and staff costs for the Jewish Film Institute's 40th San Francisco Jewish Film Festival. Presented at venues throughout the Bay Area, the festival showcases short and feature-length narrative, documentary, animated, and experimental films. The festival also features virtual reality experiences, live music, and panel discussions in celebration of Jewish culture and tradition.

To support the Jewish Film Institute's 39th San Francisco Jewish Film Festival. Presented at venues throughout the Bay Area, the festival showcases short and feature-length narrative, documentary, animated, and experimental films. The festival also features virtual reality experiences, live music, and panel discussions in celebration of Jewish culture and tradition. Select performances and discussions are archived and available to stream on the festival's website and online platforms.

To support the Filmmaker Residency program for independent media artists. Resident artists will have access to facilities, studio space, equipment, stipends, and mentorship opportunities to support their work on projects at all stages of development that explore Jewish themes, culture, and identity.

To support the 37th San Francisco Jewish Film Festival. Held in the summer, the festival hosts film screenings, live music, and panel discussions in celebration of Jewish culture and tradition. Curatorial collaboration with media art organizations such as Frameline and the Center for Asian American Media will provide audiences with thematic programs that explore the ethnic, racial, and religious diversity of the Jewish experience.

To support the Jewish Film Institute's Online Film Forum, a quarterly online screening series. Utilizing the Online Viewer Engagement Experience (OVEE), a social-video sharing platform created by the Independent Television Service, the forum will provide U.S. audiences with access to films and filmmakers that reflect the global diversity of the Jewish experience. A hybrid of the festival's live and virtual offerings, the Forum will include a shared video viewing experience and real-time conversations with filmmakers and scholars. Additionally, the festival will partner with cultural organizations to host viewings of select screenings.

To support the San Francisco Jewish Film Festival and related activities. Held in the summer, the festival hosts film screenings, live music, and panel discussions in celebration of Jewish culture and tradition.

To support the 32nd San Francisco Jewish Film Festival and related activities. The festival, devoted to films on Jewish subjects, presents the premieres of films and videos by independent producers from around the world.

To support the 31st San Francisco Jewish Film Festival and related activities. The festival, devoted to films on Jewish subjects, presents the premieres of films and videos by independent producers from around the world.

To support the 30th San Francisco Jewish Film Festival and related activities. The festival, devoted to films on Jewish subjects, presents the premieres of films and videos by independent producers from around the world.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support the 29th San Francisco Jewish Film Festival and related activities. The festival, devoted to films on Jewish subjects, presents the premieres of films and videos by independent producers from around the world.

To support the 28th San Francisco Jewish Film Festival and related activities. The festival, devoted to films on Jewish subjects, presents the premieres of films and videos by independent producers from around the world.

To support the 27th San Francisco Jewish Film Festival and related activities. The festival, devoted to films on Jewish subjects, presents the premieres of films and videos by independent producers from around the world.

To support the 26th San Francisco Jewish Film Festival and related activities. The festival, devoted to films on Jewish subjects, premieres films and videos by independent producers from around the world.
To support the 2005 Jewish Film Festival and related activities. The festival, devoted to films on Jewish subjects, premieres films and videos by independent producers from around the world.
To support the 2004 Jewish Film Festival and related activities. The festival, devoted to films on Jewish subjects, premieres films and videos by independent producers from around the world.
To support the 2003 Jewish Film Festival and related activities. The festival, devoted to Jewish-subject films, premieres both films and videos by independent producers from around the world.

To support the 2002 Jewish Film Festival and related activities. The festival, devoted to Jewish-subject films, will be held in July and August of 2002 in San Francisco, Berkeley, Menlo Park, and Marin County.

To support the 2001 Jewish Film Festival and expansion of the organization's Web site. The festival, devoted to Jewish-subject films, will be held over a one-month period in San Francisco, Berkeley, Palo Alto, and Marin County; the Web site will serve as an information resource and include an image library and archive.

To support the 2000 Jewish Film Festival and expansion of the organization's Web site. The festival, devoted to Jewish-subject films, will be held over a one-month period in July and August in San Francisco, Berkeley, Palo Alto and Marin County; the Web site will serve as an information resource and include an image library and archive.

To support the 1999 Jewish Film Festival and expansion of the organization's Web site. The festival, devoted to Jewish-subject films, will be held over a one month period in July and August in San Francisco, Berkeley, Palo Alto, and Marin County; the Web site will serve as an information resource and include an image library and archive.

To support the establishment of a cash reserve. The San Francisco Jewish Film Festival is the leading exhibitor of Jewish-based film and video work in the country. Since 1981, it has held an annual festival and its current attendance figures surpass 34,000 people. The cash reserve will enable the festival to deal with cash flow crises during the time immediately preceding the event when many cash outlays must be made. Because bills have to paid, marketing and promotional efforts are curtailed due to lack of funds. However, with a cash reserve the festival staff will be able to afford publicity which will generate even more income which will repay the depletion of the cash reserve.

Purpose: To support a free, in-school and after-school dance education program for students. Additional Project Description: The Inspired Bodies program develops the artistic and creative abilities of students, leading them through the creation and performance of a piece of dance theater. Dance instruction will include technique, partnering, voice and song, and composition. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve high schools throughout San Jose and the San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

To support performances of Time of Change, a new site-specific work that will explore the history of the Haight-Ashbury neighborhood in San Francisco. Joe Goode, with a team of BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color) artistic collaborators, will invite Haight residents and workers to share experiences that will be woven into the show. The series of performances will attract audiences comprising followers of the company, local residents, and tourists interested in the historic neighborhood.

To support a free, virtual dance education program for students. The Inspired Bodies program develops the artistic and creative abilities of students, leading to the creation and performance of a piece of dance theater developed by the students. Dance instruction includes technique, partnering, embodying voice and song, and composition.

To support a free, in-school dance education program for students. The Inspired Bodies program develops the artistic and creative abilities of students, leading to the creation and performance of a piece of dance theater developed by the students. Dance instruction includes technique, partnering, embodying voice and song, and composition.

To support the creation and presentation of a new dance work about safe havens by choreographer Joe Goode. Performances will take place at the historic Haas-Lilienthal House, which is a cultural monument to the role Jewish immigrants played in the early development of San Francisco. The work will include elements of movement, text, song, architecture, sound, video, and audience interaction. Goode will work with composer and music director Ben Juodvalkis to create a master score, incorporating compositions from additional singers and songwriters.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work by choreographer Joe Goode. The work will be performed to an original score by French string quartet Quatuor. Goode's inspiration for the work is the French village Oradour-sur-Glane, which was completely demolished during the Nazi occupation of France. Goode and his company will interview residents of the village and their responses to the work will become verbatim text incorporated in the work. The work will premiere in San Francisco after its premiere in France during the Festival du Haut Limousin.

To support the creation and presentation of a walk-through dance theater installation choreographed by Joe Goode. Inspired by French philosopher Gaston Bachelard's book, "The Poetics of Space," Goode will create a series of installation rooms that the audience will navigate, creating their own narrative as they go. The project will explore ways to present audience members with choices, implicating them as active participants rather than passive observers.

To support the creation of a series of site specific performance work by choreographer Joe Goode. The project, titled The Human Kind Series, was inspired by the company's move to a newly acquired permanent studio at San Francisco's Project Artaud in the Mission Hill neighborhood.
To support the creation and presentation of a new piece by choreographer Joe Goode, in collaboration with architect Cass Calder Smith. The work will examine the relationship between house and body.

To support the creation and presentation of a new piece by choreographer Joe Goode. The new piece will be a performance/installation that will take place in the forum and outer lobby entrance at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.

To support the reconstruction and presentation of Joe Goode's seminal 1989 work, "29 Effeminate Gestures," on a national tour. The solo piece, set to music by Erik Ian Walker, will include related educational activities such as lectures, panel discussions, open rehearsals, and question and answer sessions after performances.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support the creation and presentation of "Traveling Light," a dance theater piece by choreographer and Artistic Director Joe Goode. The work will premiere at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.

To support creation of a new work by choreographer Joe Goode in collaboration with puppeteer Basil Twist. "Wonderboy" will receive its world premiere at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.
To support the creation and presentation of a dance theater work by choreographer Joe Goode, created in collaboration with composer Joan Jeanrenaud and videographer and filmmaker Austin Forbord.

To support the creation and world premiere of "Stay Together," choreographed by Joe Goode, and a retrospective of his works, during the company's 20th anniversary. Performances will take place at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.

To support the creation and presentation of a new dance theater work by choreographer and artistic director Joe Goode. The work will incorporate youth-produced videos and be presented at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work by Artistic Director Joe Goode. Folk will focus on the lives of rural Americans and will be set to music inspired by Celtic music and early blue grass.
To support the creation and presentation of a world premiere. Mythic, choreographed by Joe Goode, will be a large-scale work of dance theater.
To support collaboration with a composer to create a new piece of dance theater. Joe Goode and composer Beth Custer will create What the Body Knows, based on small incidents in people's lives.

To support artists fees and associated costs for the creation and presentation of a new work. The creation of this new piece, under the working title Gender Heroes, will involve the six company members and Artistic Director Joe Goode.

To support the planning and implementation of an experimental performance series, increased community outreach efforts to enlarge audiences, improved marketing, and staff development. In response to a changing national market for dance touring, the board and staff of the Joe Goode Performance Group have committed themselves to significantly increasing the company's visibility within the Bay Area over the next three years. A six-part strategy has been outlined: 1)plan and implement an annual fall experimental season; 2) increase the number of community outreach activities produced each year; 3) improve the effectiveness of current marketing efforts by collecting and analyzing existing market research; 4) conduct new market research targeting our current constituency and the constituencies of other Bay Area arts organizations 5) initiate a campaign to introduce, involve and solicit local corporations and their employees; 6) Hire a full-time outreach coordinator/marketing manager to assist staff in implementing these strategies.

To support the production and marketing of a series of media-literacy curriculum kits. The curriculum is designed for children in 3rd through 12th grade and will be marketed to teachers, parents, and community workers.

To support digital resources highlighting Asian Pacific American artists. Through research and interviews, staff will document the history and impact of the APAture Festival, as well as Kearny Street Workshops broader 50 year history. Related activities include a database of Asian Pacific American artists on Kearny Streets website, and a blog and podcast dedicated to providing opportunities for artists to speak on social justice issues. Project activity may take place virtually.

To support "APAture: A Spotlight on Asian Pacific American Art," a multidisciplinary arts festival. Project activities will include a visual arts exhibition, film screenings, literary readings, and music performances.

To support the "Unsung Opera Project," a multimedia visual arts exhibition about the legacy of Chinese Opera with associated readings and panel discussions. Robert Hsiang, a photographer; Genny Lim, a poet; and Nancy Hom, a visual artist, will present their perspectives on the role of Chinese Opera in sustaining the immigrant community.

To support the commissioning and exhibition of new work by the artist Flo Oy Wong exploring immigration issues. The project, entitled "made in usa: Angel Island Shhh," will explore the practice of falsifying identities by Chinese immigrants during the entry interrogation process at the Angel Island Immigration Station from 1910 to 1940. The exhibition will travel to several venues in California.

Purpose: To support production of The Keepers, a podcast and multimedia series exploring the work of archivists, librarians, collectors, and curators around the world. Additional Project Description: Created by producers Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva, this series incorporates audio storytelling, interviews, and archival recordings. This season will focus on those who record, interpret, and pass on history and cultural experiences through their art, featuring the work and stories of painters, poets, chefs, performing artists, and musicians. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit independent audio producers as well as general audiences, with the series made available for free via broadcast and podcast platforms nationwide. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support production of The Keepers, a podcast and multimedia series exploring the work of archivists, librarians, collectors, and curators around the world. Created by producers Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva, this series incorporates audio storytelling, interviews, and archival recordings and will be distributed on public radio, podcast platforms, and social media.

To support production of The Keepers, a podcast and multimedia series. Created by award-winning producers Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva, The Keepers explores the work of archivists, librarians, collectors, and curators around the world through the format of audio storytelling, incorporating interviews and archival recordings.

To support production of The Keepers, a podcast and multimedia series. Created by award-winning producers Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva, The Keepers explores the work of archivists, librarians, collectors, and curators around the world through the format of audio storytelling. Interviews and archival recordings will be used to uncover stories such as the history of mobile libraries in Kentucky delivered by women on horseback. Listeners will be invited to participate in the series by contributing their own stories of personal archiving and collecting through a phone call to The Keepers Hotline or via social media.

To support distribution and related costs for a podcast and multimedia series. "The Keepers" will explore the worlds of archivists, librarians, collectors, and curators around the world. Episodes will be distributed nationally through the Public Radio Exchange's Radiotopia network and broadcast on NPR's "Morning Edition." Additional project activities may include the production of promotional videos to be shared on social media platforms, Facebook Live videos from inside vaults and private archives, community events at universities and archival institutions, and the creation of behind-the-scenes content for the NPR and Kitchen Sisters websites.

To support distribution and promotion of the podcast Fugitive Waves. Incorporating a documentary archive of interviews, music, field recordings, and audio by producers Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva, the program is devoted to telling little-known stories of culture, ritual, and tradition. Archival works will be digitized, prepared for distribution, and made available for public access through the podcast and additional digital platforms.

To support distribution of the podcast Fugitive Waves. Incorporating a documentary archive of interviews, music, field recordings, and audio, the program is devoted to telling little-known stories of culture, ritual, and tradition. Archival works will be digitized, prepared for distribution, and public access to the program will offered through the podcast and additional digital platforms. In 2016, episodes will include features on the lives, history, tradition, food, music, and rituals of Native Americans, Alaskan Natives, and native Hawaiians.

To support the production of a series of audio documentaries produced by Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva. Hidden Kitchens World's "Kimchi Diplomacy - War and Peace and Food" will explore the creative use of food as a means of promoting cross-cultural understanding across the globe. The series will feature stories from around the world, such as the history of the 1863 "Egg War" outside San Francisco and "gastrodiplomacy" initiatives in Thailand, Taiwan, and South Korea. Hidden Kitchens World will be made available through radio broadcast and as a podcast available for online streaming and mobile devices.

To support the production and national distribution of a series of audio documentaries to be produced by Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva. Hidden Kitchens World will explore life and culture through food across the globe with stories ranging from the Quaker chocolate communities of England to honey hunters in India to bread bakeries in Morocco.

To support the production and national distribution of new programs for the audio documentary series, "The Hidden World of Girls," produced by Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva. Stories and podcasts procuded for the public radio series and Web site will focus on women and girls in the arts.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.
To support the production and national distribution of "The Hidden World of Girls" radio series. A series of audio documentaries to be produced by Davie Nelson and Nikki Silva.

To support the production of new stories for the Hidden Kitchens radio series. Produced by Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva in partnership with NPR's Morning Edition, the series looks into the worlds of kitchen visionaries, eating traditions, and local kitchen rituals as it explores how communities come together through food.
To support the production of the radio series HIDDEN KITCHENS by the Kitchen Sisters. HIDDEN KITHCENS will explore how communities come together through food.
To support the production of a radio series by Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva. Lost and Found Food will explore American life and culture through food.

To support the production of "Lost  Found Sound  Beyond," a collection of new radio stories by Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva (aka the Kitchen Sisters). Exploring American life through recorded sound, the works will be aired on National Public Radio's All Things Considered.

To support planning and development of "Lost and Found Film," a series of stories for television, created from rare, unusual, and little known moving image footage. Evolving from the Kitchen Sisters' Peabody Award-winning NPR series "Lost and Found Sound," the series will use personal and archival film, found footage, and "orphan films" to produce richly layered stories about daily life, culture, and the art and heritage of moving images.

To support the production of Lost  Found Sound  Beyond, a collection of new radio stories by Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva. Exploring American life through recorded sound, the works will be aired on National Public Radio's All Things Considered.

To support staff salaries for the production of If Cities Could Dance, a video series celebrating a variety of dance styles in cities across America. Dancers and videographers will co-produce episodes with site-specific choreography, highlighting each city's history and how it has informed a particular dance culture, while allowing dancers the platform to tell their individual stories. The series will be available on YouTube and on the KQED website, along with instructional videos from dancers.

To support the development of web-based resources to provide audiences with information about the Bay Area arts scene. The site will use a "responsive design" approach to provide content and coverage, along with user engagement opportunities and event listings.

To support the production of the television series and website SOUND TRACKS: MUSIC WITHOUT BORDERS that explores music from around the world. SOUND TRACKS will be a prime-time, public television mini-series that will present musical performances in the context of well-reported and well-crafted stories.

To support expansion of the SPARK Digital Library. Additional artist and organizational profiles and a new, two volume set of discipline-specific DVDs will be developed for inclusion in the library, along with an interactive Web site and companion to KQED's SPARK public television series, all of which provide access to information on local artists, exhibitions, performances, classes, and arts education in Northern California.

To support the production and distribution of Lost  Found Sound 2000, a national millennium series of radio programs that chronicle, reflect, and celebrate the 20th century through sound. The series will be made available to national audiences through regular features on NPR's All Things Considered in the year 2000, and as a free-standing anthology series created from the best of the Lost  Found Sound broadcasts.

To support "Lost and Found Sound: An American Record," a series of public radio programs which, through richly layered audio stories created by noted radio producers and other artists, will chronicle, reflect, and celebrate the 20th century through sound, intended for national broadcast. "Lost and Found Sound" will focus on some of the more personal profound, moving, eccentric, and everyday stories and audio captured in the 20th century--the century in which recorded sound developed. Some of our most gifted audio producers will create 10 hour-long programs which will include: endangered sounds, sounds on the verge of extinction, shifting accents, vanishing voices, the merging of languages, the memories of people 100 years and older, the stories of people obsessed by sound, home recordings, vintage audio, great orators and speeches, the music of new technologies, the soundtrack of the streets of the future--sounds that reveal a sense of place and mark the passage of time. The stories told throughout the series will explore the ways sound captured history, how sound changed the course of history, and how the sound of life has changed over the century. What were the sonic snapshots we took of ourselves, our rituals and events over the last 100 years? How does what we, as Americans, choose to capture in our radio broadcasts, home recordings, and sonic obsessions reveal about what we value,

Purpose: To support personnel costs, artist fees, and production expenses for performances that celebrate the Kronos Quartet's history. Additional Project Description: Kronos Quartet will commission two American composers to create new works. Performances of the new works will take place at the annual Kronos Festival in San Francisco and on tour. Educational activities may include Kronos Lab events for high school students as well as open rehearsals. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit the commissioned composers, as well as in-person audiences across the country and online audiences. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the Kronos Festival. Additional Project Description: Project plans include in-person performances during the Kronos Festival featuring works from the 50 for the Future collection of commissions. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit in-person audiences from the Bay Area of California. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel, facilities, and marketing expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organizations constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support a national tour by the Kronos Quartet with related educational activities. The tour will include multi-day residencies and concert performances in states such as California, South Carolina, Iowa, and Texas. The program, an evening-length song cycle for string quartet, chorus, and spoken-word, will explore issues including race relations, social justice, and civil rights.

To support the Kronos Festival. The festival will feature Kronos Quartet in collaboration with composer/performer Jacob Garchik and other guest artists. Related festival programming may include a family concert, world premieres, and highlights from Kronos' existing repertoire. The festival will take place entirely online.

To support the creation of a digital documentary work about composer John Cage by the Kronos Quartet and Academy Award-nominated filmmaker Sam Green. The documentary work, which will include Cage's own compositions, will feature audio, video, music, archival footage, and narration performed by the artists. The work will be premiered and distributed online.

To support the Kronos Festival. The festival will feature Kronos Quartetcelebrating its 45th anniversary seasonas the resident ensemble, in collaboration with an artist-in-residence and other guest artists from across the creative landscape. The festival will include mainstage evening performances, a family matinee, and a number of afternoon programs.

To support the creation of a new electronic media work by Willie Williams to accompany the Kronos Quartet's performance of One Earth, One People, One Love from the composition Sun Rings by Terry Riley. Drawing upon a video the artist created for Sun Rings when it originally premiered in 2002, Williams' new moving image work will incorporate electronic media, digital design, and found footage, and will be shown during performances across the country.

To support Fifty for the Future, a commissioning and education project by Kronos Quartet. The project will support five commissions for new string quartets created for multiple skill levels from beginner to pre-professional. Scores, individual parts, and an array of other project materials will be available online for free. Premieres of the new works will take place in conjunction with residencies across the country. Educational activities will include master classes and workshops.

To support the second phase of Kronos Quartet's development and implementation of free online resources for music education. The second phase of the project will include user testing and launch of the portal interface. Made in conjunction with an initiative to commission 50 new works for string quartets, the online platform will allow users to access the program's multimedia library and provide tools to support music education. The portal will feature responsive design that adapts content to the size of the screen on the device being used; the ability to search, sort, and filter the works; the ability to send push notifications about new content and news; access to interactive rehearsal and performance resources. Once the online portal is completed, the content will be available to the public free-of-charge.

To support a tour of a new work by composer Jonathan Berger and librettist Harriet Scott Chessman performed by the Kronos Quartet. The work, titled "My Lai" will mark the 50th anniversary of the My Lai Massacre in South Vietnam. The performances will feature tenor Rinde Eckert and Vietnamese musician Van-Anh Vanessa Vo. In addition to traditional instruments such as the dan Bau, a one-stringed zither, and a bamboo xylophone called the dan T'rung, Vo also will perform on a set of percussion instruments made from spent shell casings. Educational activities will include panel discussions, artist talks, and question-and-answer sessions.

To support the design of a web portal that will feature composer interviews, sheet music, and how-to videos, as part of a multi-year initiative. Features of the portal may also include a searchable, sortable media Created in conjunction with a five-year initiative to commission 50 new works for string quartets, the online platform will allow users to access the program's multimedia library and provide tools to support music education. Once the online portal has been completed, the content will be available to the public free-of-charge.

To support year one of Fifty for the Future, a commissioning project by the Kronos Quartet. Plans include the creation of five string quartets for players of multiple skill levels (ranging from beginner to pre-professional). Scores, individual parts, and an array of other project materials will be available online at no charge. Premieres of the new works will take place in conjunction with residencies across the country. Educational activities will include master classes and workshops.

To support the commission and premiere of a new work performed by the Kronos Quartet that will explore the My Lai Massacre in Vietnam in 1968. A copy of the libretto/score is the required product. The new work by composer Jonathan Berger and librettist Harriet Chessman will be scored for string quartet, voice, traditional Vietnamese percussion instruments, and digitally processed sounds. The featured soloists will be tenor Rinde Eckert and traditional Vietnamese musician Van-Anh Vo.

To support a national tour and residencies of a new work titled "Beyond Zero: 1914-1918" by composer Aleksandra Vrebalov with filmmaker Bill Morrison and visual artist Drew Cameron performed by Kronos Quartet. Plans include multi-day residencies in venues across the country. The previously commissioned work (in commemoration of the 100th anniversary of the beginning of World War I) will be accompanied by a film collage of archival footage. Educational activities will include workshops, panel discussions, and open rehearsals.

To support the commission, development, and rehearsal of a new work by Serbian American composer Aleksandra Vrebalov as part of Kronos Quartet's 40th anniversary season. The commissioned piece will mark the centennial of World War I and will be scored for string quartet, pre-recorded audio track, and video by filmmaker Bill Morrison.

To support the creation, planning, production, and rehearsal costs for 12 Stories, a collaboration with composer/performer Laurie Anderson and Kronos Quartet. The evening length work will comprise 12 short songs for processed (electronic) violin written by Anderson and arranged for string quartet interwoven with 12 stories written and spoken by Anderson.

To support performances and residency activities by the Kronos Quartet and the commissioning and national tour performances of a new work by composer Bryce Dessner. Four concerts and eight residency activities are planned at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts and the work by Dessner (b. 1976) will be on a program that will investigate works written early in the careers of composers such as John Cage, Morton Feldman, Conlon Nancarrow, and John Zorn programmed along with works previously commissioned by the quartet.

To support performances of American chamber works by composer Terry Riley performed by the Kronos Quartet including related educational activities. In honor of the composer's 75th birthday, two of the five quartets that make up Salome Dances for Peace will be revived in venues throughout the country.

To support a collaboration, commission, and performances by the Kronos Quartet. Plans include the commissioning and performances of a new work by composer J.G. Thirlwell for string quartet and audio tape based on the sounds of desert sands from Oman by sound artist Jacob Kirkegaard.

To support the Kronos Quartet's performances of Harry Partch's U.S. Highball: A Musical Account of Slim's Transcontinental Hobo Trip. Concerts and related educational activities will take place as part of the Los Angeles Philharmonic's California Festival.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support collaborations, commissions, and performances by the Kronos Quartet. Plans include a collaboration with pipa virtuoso Wu Man for a staged work and a commissioned work by jazz pianist Maria Schneider.

To support a re-staged production of George Crumb's "Black Angels (Thirteen Images from the Dark Land)" by the Kronos Quartet. Educational activities will include post-concert discussions, master classes, coaching sessions, school concerts, and open rehearsals.
To support commissioning of new works by composers Steve Reich and Hanna Kulenty to be performed by the Kronos Quartet.

To support commissions and residency activities. Plans include a residency at the Clarice Smith Performing Arts Center in College Park, MD, the creation and presentation of a new work by Tom Recchion, and the fourth round of the "Kronos Under 30" commission and residency program.

To support Kronos: Live Mix, featuring a celebration of the music of Steve Reich and collaborations with instrument creator and sound artist Walter Kitundu, the experimental duo Matmos, and sound artist Trimpin.
To support collaborations with women artists of diverse multi-national musical perspectives.
To support the Northern Lights Project. The series of activities will include commissioning, touring, and performances by composers and ensembles from the world's northern climates.

To support the development of a portble LED lighting system for music ensembles and performing arts events where mechanical equipment must operate silently. Kronos will collaborate with multimedia designer Willie Williams to employ new commercial LED systems that require no cooling fans.

To support commissioning and residency activities in celebration of Kronos Quartet's 30th anniversary season. Activities include a call for scores from composers under the age of 30, the commissioning of a new work by Michael Gordon in special tribute to the World Trade Center whose 30th anniversary occurs in 2003, and a collaboration with the Merce Cunningham Dance Company in their 50th anniversary season with music by John Cage.

To support the development and presentation of a new work by composer Terry Riley; including educational activities. Kronos Quartet will perform the work, which will include taped electronics based upon sounds of space.

To support VISUAL MUSIC and NUEVA COLLECTION--two presentation projects by the Kronos String Quartet that will tour in a number of different states. During 2001-02, Kronos will explore adventurous works and new ways to bridge associations between the string quartet and traditional instruments.

To support a tour of "Dracula: the Music and Film," a newly-composed work by Philip Glass performed simultaneously with the original 1931 film based on the classic by Bram Stoker, and "Kronos Caravan," commissions and arrangements of works based on the traditional music of several continents. The Kronos String Quartet will tour Dracula to 20 cities (in 15 states) during 2000-2001, and will commission 20 new works and arrangements.

To support an evening-length program of new arrangements for voice and string quartet comprised of works from a range of international women vocalists. The works will be performed in rural and urban sites nationwide.

To support phase two of the 25th Anniversary Commissioning and Performance Project involving collaborative residencies at the Hancher Auditorium (Iowa), University of Arizona (Tucson), and the University of Michigan (Ann Arbor)

Purpose: To support the development of Anting Anting Soul Dance, a site-specific, multidisciplinary ritual performance at the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco. Additional Project Description: Alleluia Panis, co-founder and director of KULARTS, and curators at the AAM will select works from the museum's Philippine and Pilipinx-American collection. Panis and her collaborators will conduct interviews and movement workshops exploring the community's connection to the selections. This process will inform a panel discussion in conjunction with the AAM's Carlos Villa and Bernice Bing exhibitions and will culminate in a ritual performance for the two artists, as well as a public performance in the museum's gallery spaces. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will engage the larger Pilipinx diasporic community of San Francisco. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support the development and production of Nursing These Wounds, led by choreographer Alleluia Panis. The large-scale, immersive dance performance and film project will investigate the impacts of colonization on health and caregiving, particularly through the histories and stories of Pilipinx nurses.

To support the creation and presentation of "Ba-e Makiling," a Filipino dance theater production. Filipino folkloric choreographer Jay Loyola and musician and composer Florante Aguilar will work with Kularts to develop the piece inspired by Philippine myths and native spirituality. In advance of the public performance, Loyola will present an advanced dance workshop for members of the folkloric dance community.

To support "Kodakan: Pilipinos in the City," an exhibition about Pilipino-American cultural changes, with related outreach activities. Photography and media art reflecting shifts in Pilipino identity and experience, and created by artists in collaboration with local residents, will be displayed. Residents contributed personal histories, poetry, and historical photos of their families to the creation of the works to be exhibited. Guest artists will also participate in multidisciplinary performances and panel discussions. The exhibition and related activities will take place at the I-Hotel Manilatown Center, a venue located in San Francisco that has historic ties to the Pilipino community.

To support a dance workshop and the creation and performance of "Maseg," a new dance work by Filipino folkloric choreographer Jay Loyola. Loyola will reinterpret Shakespeare's "The Tempest," incorporating traditional Pilipino dance, Palawan mysticism, and Tagbanua culture.

To support creation of a choreographed production of "Palau'an Bird Call--Huni Ng Tandikan." Using traditional Pilipino dance techniques and Pilipino mythology, the work will be performed by dancers and musicians from the Parangal Dance Company, fostering the development of a new generation of Pilipino American dance artists and expanding their knowledge of Pilipino tribal dances.

To support "You Will Gonna Go Crazy," a new dance-theater work created by choreographer Alleluia Panis, writer Jason Magabo, and composer Ronald Quesada. The piece will explore the life of a Filipino nurse who was accused of murdering patients in Ann Arbor, MI, in 1976. The performances will be held at the Bayanihan Community Center in the SOMA district.

To support the Parol Lantern Festival Project in consortium with the Filipino American Development Foundation. The project will consist of a residency by master artist Robert David, creation of several giant parol lanterns, and a community stroll lantern parade.

To support the production of Sons, Young Pilipino Men Speak, a multidisciplinary representation of stories about growing up in California. Lead artist Jaime Jacinto will oversee the writing and creative phase and Ellen Sebastian Chang will direct.

To support the commissioning of "Heroes," a performance work based on escrima (a style of Pilipino martial arts). The project will be presented as part of the Post-Modern American Pilipino Performance Project.

Purpose: To support creative storytelling workshops for high school students. Additional Project Description: The workshops will teach students interviewing skills, the importance of storytelling and oral history, and will incorporate examples of Filipino American heroes from the Bay Area in California. The students will create stories and podcasts, which will be made available for streaming on Spotify and YouTube. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit Bay Area high school students, including Filipino youth. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Organization Name: La Pocha Nostra Inter Cultural Performance & Community Arts
Project Description: To support a training workshop for national and international performance artists and activists at Cirque Roots, a community arts space in Tucson, Arizona, to culminate in an original public performance. Participants will train with artistic director Guillermo Gomez-Pena and resident artist/instructors, using a multicultural and multidisciplinary methodology that will include theater, dance, improvisation, and ritual performance.

Organization Name: La Pocha Nostra Inter Cultural Performance & Community Arts
Project Description: To support an arts training workshop and performance. The workshop will be designed for artists, scholars, and curators and will include professional development activities, instruction on the use of props and costumes, group discussions, shared meals, and salons.

Organization Name: La Pocha Nostra Inter Cultural Performance & Community Arts
Project Description: To support an international performance art winter school in consortium with Tucson's Museum of Contemporary Art. In partnership with the Tucsons Museum of Contemporary Art, the workshop is designed for artists, scholars, and curators and includes professional development activities, instruction on the use of props and costumes, group discussions, shared meals, and salons.

Organization Name: La Pocha Nostra Inter Cultural Performance & Community Arts
Project Description: To support the development of a new work, "La Nostalgia Remix: Best Hits and Outtakes for an Imaginary Bar." In collaboration with Native American multimedia artist James Luna, writer Guillermo Gomez-Pena will develop a theatrical production reflecting similarities between their Latin and Native American experiences.

Organization Name: La Pocha Nostra Inter Cultural Performance & Community Arts
Project Description: To support the creation and U.S. presentation of EX-CENTRIS. EX-CENTRIS will be directed by Guillermo Gomez-Pena at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.

Organization Name: La Pocha Nostra Inter Cultural Performance & Community Arts
Project Description: To support the "Museum of Fetish-ized Identity." This original performance/installation piece by Guillermo G mez-Pe a and Juan Ybarra will premiere in San Francisco in 2002.

To support a double-bill of Swipe! by composer Anthony R. Green and librettist Mark Labowskie and 4:30 Movie by composer Kurt Rohde and librettist Donna Masini. Swipe! will speculate on a future affected by today's dating apps by tracking the relationship trajectory of a number of characters whose intimacy is mediated through the use of futurist dating technology. 4:30 Movie is based on the librettist's funny, touching, and ruthless poems written about her sister's cancer diagnosis, treatment, and death. Each of the new micro-operas will be up to 35 minutes in length and will be created and performed with small groups to allow performances anywhere. The project also will include workshops and premiere performances.

To support the premiere of Artemisia by composer Laura Schwendinger and librettist Ginger Strand. Based on the life of Baroque painter Artemisia Gentileschi, the work is a dramatic opera of passion, betrayal, and art in 17th-century Italy. The production will incorporate projections of Gentileschi's paintings. Community engagement activities may include workshops for high school students, open rehearsals, and discussions with the composer and musicians at an area art gallery. Performances will take place in spring 2019 at Z Space in San Francisco and Doug Adams Gallery in Berkeley.

To support AMP (Artists Maximizing Potential), a program that seeks to innovate the single choreographer dance company model. Choreographer Sara Shelton Mann and her dancers will engage in an eight-week residency to create a new work with LEVYdance. The program will support the artistic process from the research and development phase, to production and touring, and will include a technical residency at ODC Theater. The program will culminate in a world premier.

To support AMP (Artists Maximizing Potential). A guest choreographer and several of his or her dancers will engage in a residency to collaborate with LEVYdance on the creation of a new work. The program will promote artistic exchange and resource-sharing while allowing the artists to hold onto their individual creative voices. The final phase of AMP will include the presentation of a new evening-length work and a national tour.

To support the company's 10th anniversary Oudoor Home Season. The company will restage and remount work from their history on custom built stages in a San Francisco alleyway, which will also be shared with other artists in the community for a week of free and subsidized performances.
To support the the Bay Area Contemporary Choreographer's Showcase. LEVYdance will partner with The Foundry, sharing resources to rent the performance space for an extended run.
To support AMP, in consortium with Headlands Center for the Arts. AMP is an innovative program that pools valuable resources to create an alternative to the single choreographer dance company model.

To support the presentation of COMFORT ZONE, a new dance installation by choreographer and artistic director Ben Levy that explores the intersection between technology and communication. The installation features motion-sensing webcams that trigger projected animations which are then manipulated through custom-computer programs to activate the space in response to the audience and dancers.

To support the design and construction of prototypes for a multimedia and live art installation conceptualized by choreographer Benjamin Levy, in consortium with The Exploratorium. The Exploratorium (San Francisco's museum of science, art, and human perception) will partner with Levy during the project's research and development phase to create the initial prototype installations in the museum's West Gallery.
To support the 2010 East Coast tour and San Francisco performances. The company will travel to New York City, Philadelphia, Washington, DC, Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, and Dover, Delaware.
To support the 2009 East Coast tour. The company is expected to tour to New York, Baltimore, Washington, DC, Philadelphia, Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania and Dover, Delaware.

Organization Name: Lighthouse for the Blind and Visually Impaired
Project Description: To support the annual Superfest Disability Film Festival. This multi-day event will include film screenings and panel discussions. The films will be juried by a group of individuals with disabilities. The films will be selected to highlight social issues within the disability community. The event will take place in mainstream venues to engage with the general public.

Organization Name: Lighthouse for the Blind and Visually Impaired
Project Description: To support Superfest, an international disability film festival. The festival will showcase multi-genre films complemented by panel discussions with filmmakers, actors, disability leaders, and audience members. The festival will provide assisted listening systems, live captioning, braille, large print programs, and audio description.

Organization Name: Lighthouse for the Blind and Visually Impaired
Project Description: To support Insights, an exhibition of work by contemporary artists who are blind or visually impaired. Featuring work by approximately 40 artists, the juried exhibition will be installed at the San Francisco Arts Commission Gallery in City Hall.

Purpose: To support the Litquake festival and year-round literary programming. Additional Project Description: The festival will feature events geared to both children and adults and include programming offered in collaboration with organizations such as museums and embassies. Litquake also will present public performances and readings throughout the year, such as its Elder Project, which will offer writing classes for individuals in low-income retirement communities. Intended Beneficiaries: Programming will serve writers and readers in the San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support staff salaries and administrative costs for the annual Litquake literary festival. With the goal of promoting community conversation and celebrating the written word, the ten-day online festival will feature readings, panel discussions, and themed events geared for both children and adults.

To support the annual literary festival Litquake. The San Francisco festival reaches book lovers of all ages and features readings, performances, film screenings, panel discussions, events for children and teens, staged readings, and the commission of original works of fiction. The nine-day festival is expected to attract an audience of thousands of adults and children.

To support Litquake, an annual literary festival in downtown San Francisco. The festival reaches book lovers of all ages and features readings, performances, film screenings, panel discussions, events for children and teens, staged readings, and the commission of original works of fiction.

To support the annual literary festival Litquake, featuring readings, performances, cross-media literary events, panel discussions, workshops, and the commissioning of original works of fiction. This youthful, non-traditional, week-long festival includes a "Lit Crawl," with 400 authors in 75 venues around the Bay area in a four-hour time period, as well as special events geared toward elementary school students ("Kidquake") and middle and high school students ("Teenquake").

Organization Name: Loco Bloco Drum and Dance Ensemble
Project Description: To support training and performances for the International Women's Day, the Carnaval Parade, and the Pride Parade. 2/16/11: unable to bring Caja Ludica to the States. Replacing with performances by own ensembles. DB

Purpose: To support the production of Monument, or Four Sisters (A Sloth Play) by Sam Chanse, directed by Giovanna Sardelli. Additional Project Description: The comedy chronicles the lives of three sistersConnie, Amy, and Macas they negotiate challenging life decisions, and the absence of their fourth sister, Lina. The play looks at the simultaneous impact of personal and ecological loss as Amy's study of the deterioration of coral reefs due to climate change parallels Lina's disappearance. Activities may take place virtually. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit artists and audiences in the San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support staff salaries for the development and world premiere production of The Kind Ones by Miranda Rose Hall. The play follows the story of Nellie, a farmer in Montana seeking anonymity and solitude. The theater will collaborate with the playwright to deliver education and community engagement opportunities to audience members and local college theater students.

To support the world premiere production of Don't Eat the Mangos, a new play by Ricardo Prez Gonzlez. The play addresses conflict and trauma within a Puerto Rican family. As a hurricane wreaks havoc, three sisters take turns caring for their ailing mother and father, and wrestle with what it means to be true to self, family, and homeland.

To support the premiere of Jessica Hagedorn's "The Gangster of Love." Playwright and novelist Hagedorn has adapted her second novel of the same title for the stage. It tells the story of Raquel "Rocky" Rivera and her troubled, eccentric family's emigration from Manila to San Francisco in 1970. The production will incorporate live music, poetry reading, and music video as narrative forms; and highlight the Filipino story within San Francisco's history.

To support the premiere of "Grandeur" by Han Ong. The play is inspired by the life of Gil Scott-Heron, frequently referred to as the "father" of hip-hop by the new generation of rappers. In 2010, a year before his death, Scott-Heron was profiled in "The New Yorker" magazine. He emerged from the article as an enigmatic subject, both astute and tragic, having succumbed to an addiction to crack cocaine in the 1990s. Ong portrays a young reporter who ruminates on his idol Scott-Heron, his pattern of self-destruction, Black masculinity, and the cultural legacy of Scott-Heron's life and music.

To support a residency with playwright Jessica Hagedorn. Hagedorn will be in residence to continue developing her seminal theater work "Dogeaters" and to create an adaptation for the stage of her novel, "Gangster of Love." She may revise the text of "Dogeaters" to incorporate additional dialogue in Tagalog to make the play bilingual. The play will be produced for a San Francisco premiere and may feature immersive and interactive design and staging that will allow audiences to access the play's exuberant and unpredictable world more closely. Community and student outreach efforts will accompany the production.

To support the world premiere of "This Golden State" by Luis Alfaro. An assimilated Chicano family comprising Protestants with a pastor father are grappling with the realities of being people of faith in a community that is struggling with an old world idea and new world expressions of Christianity. As the first play in a new trilogy, the work will explore themes of family, community, and culture. The trilogy is a co-commission with Oregon Shakespeare Festival.

To support the world premiere of "Hir" by Taylor Mac. Inspired from both Sophocles' "Antigone" and Sam Shepard's Pulitzer Prize-winning "Buried Child," the "kitchen sink" drama is about a mother's refusal to allow her children, Max and Isaac (a veteran recently returned from Afghanistan), to follow the same path as her abusive husband.

To support the development and world premiere of "Bruja," an original, contemporary adaptation of Euripedes' Medea, set in modern day Cuba, by playwright Luis Alfaro and producing artistic director Loretta Greco. Affairs of the heart take on intense theatrical dimension in this story of exile as people view Medea's choices in a contemporary light.

To support the San Francisco leg of the rolling premiere of Taylor Mac's THE LILY'S REVENGE. The five-hour, site-specific theatrical event in five acts tells the story of a flower that goes on a quest to become a man in order to wed his beloved bride.

To support the development and world premiere of "Oedipus El Rey" by Luis Alfaro. Artistic director Loretta Greco will lead the large cast to re-envision Sophocles' Oedipus as a contemporary Chicano story in California.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.
To support the world premiere of "Tir-Na-Nog (Land of Youth)" by Irish novelist and playwright Edna O'Brien. Artistic director Chris Smith will direct the play.

To support the world premiere of "Rust," a new play by Kirsten Greenidge directed by Raelle Myrick-Hodges. The production will be presented as part of the theater's annual "Hot House," a festival of world premieres performed in rotating repertory.
To support the commission, development, and workshop production of a new play by Victor Lodato.
To support the development and workshop production of ZACHARIA MOSLEY'S NEON BLUES, a new work by Neena Beber. The work will be presented in the fall of 2003.
To support the development of the play "Requiem for the Dead."
To support the Science on Stage Festival. The festival will feature a workshop and staged readings of new plays.

To support the continuation and expansion of the Young California Writers Project, an educational program designed to cultivate emerging playwrights. The first year of a two-year project would expand to include residencies in an additional school.

To support Magic Theatre's educational outreach and access activities. The objective of Magic Theatre's education and access efforts is to work with students and audiences, present and future, to explore the process and discipline of new play development.

To support the Ex Libris Project that adapts contemporary American literature for the stage. Since its founding in 1967, the Magic Theatre has been devoted to the primary voice of the theater - the playwright. The Ex Libris project continues that tradition by including a national solicitation of adaptations of contemporary American literature for the stage. It is planned that four new scripts will be identified, of which three will receive commissions to further develop the works.

To support partially-staged performances of Alessandro Stradella's comic opera IL TRESPOLO TUTORE. The project will feature a small ensemble of period instruments and singers under the artistic direction of Warren Stewart.

To support a series of regional touring performances and events in communities across the United States. Programming for the tour will center around the neglected works of a 17th-century Italian composer and cloistered nun, Chiara Margarita Cozzolani.

To support a tour of Circus Days 2003 to communities in the San Francisco Bay Area. The program offers free performances of a circus in which audience members learn basic circus skills and incorporate them into the performance.
To support Circus Days 2002. Make A Circus will tour a circus/theater musical play with audience participation to over 50 communities in California in summer 2002.
To support Circus Days 2001. Make A Circus will tour a circus/theater musical play with audience participation to over 50 communities in California in summer 2001.

To support the creation and presentation of an original circus theater piece as part of the Circus Days Program in the summer of 1998. Make A Circus is seeking support for the creation and development of an original circus theater piece as part of the Circus Days Program that includes workshops, training, and participation by community members in a final performance. Circus Days gives thousands of children and adults throughout the San Francisco Bay area an opportunity, sometimes their first, to see live, professional entertainment. An environment is created to encourage participation and learning. Through performing, participants gain self esteem and discover what it feels like to participate in a creative process.

Purpose: To support the Encounters Over 60 program, celebrating the voices of older dance artists Additional Project Description: With a focus on artists over the age of 60, a selection of artists will be highlighted during a festival in San Francisco, amplifying each artist's rich body of work and the lessons learned from a long career in dance. The project will include in-depth workshops, panels, mentorship opportunities, rehearsal practices, social gatherings, and performances of both works developed in community and solo repertoire performed by the artist. Intended Beneficiaries: Project activities will serve both dance professionals, dance enthusiasts, and general audiences in the San Francisco area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the creation, rehearsal, and artist fees for Global Moves, an evening-length work. The work will be created in collaboration with Tanusree Shankar Dance Company (Kolkata, India), Guangdong Modern Dance Company (Guangzhou, China), and Kolben Dance Company (Tel Aviv, Israel). Through a process of sharing and responding to movement prompts via video and livestream exchanges, the collaborators will develop the new work.

To support the creation of "Shadows and Embers." In 1988, Jenkins collaborated with Yoko Ono on a work which had, as its central metaphor, the cry for peace. The set consisted of 101 white pipes which hung from the ceiling; each string of 30+ pipes could lift or lower to create different images. With that as inspiration, the new work will be part of the company's 45th anniversary celebration in 2019.

To support the creation of "Skies Calling Skies Falling," a new work by Artistic Director Margaret Jenkins. The company will perform one part of the work in an intimate setting and the other part will take place in a traditional theatrical environment. After a four-decade history of performing mostly large-scale works in formal proscenium theaters, Jenkins' recent work, "Site Series (Inside Outside)" was created for living rooms, galleries, and more intimate spaces. "Skies Calling Skies Falling" will connect the two different ways of experiencing Jenkins' work in an atmosphere conducive to shifting one's perspectives to see dance differently. The company plans to offer several showings at their Lab.

To support the creation and presentation of "Site Series 2 (Inside Outside)." Propelled by the vagabond nature of being a performance artist, a metaphor for all of life's journeys, Margaret Jenkins and her company will choreograph small, site-specific works to be performed in non-traditional spaces, like churches, homes, and museums. The works can be presented as individual vignettes or as a complete evening-length work.

To support the creation and presentation of "Gallery of Rooms," a new site-specific work by Margaret Jenkins. Gallery of Rooms will be an audience-immersive installation fueled by Jenkins' interest in bringing the audience into the myriad of rooms in the building where she works. Along with her company, the building is also home to the Conservatory of Dance; the Prelinger Library, which is primarily a collection of 19th- and 20th-century historical ephemera, periodicals, maps, and books; and the Inner Research Institute, a Tai Chi studio. Jenkins will engage in a substantive collaboration with all these spaces that can be summarized as a walk-through landscape of ideas, allowing the spaces and their contents to inform the meaning of the dance.

To support the creation and presentation of "Prologue," a new dance-installation work by Margaret Jenkins. Audiences will travel through the work at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco, beginning in the Yerba Buena Forum, moving through the Yerba Buena Gardens, and ending in the Lam Research Theater.

To support the creation and presentation of "Barrier Winds," a new work by Margaret Jenkins. Jenkins will bring dancers from San Francisco to Israel for a residency that will foster the creation process, and then Israeli artists will come to San Francisco for the final rehearsal period leading up to the premiere.

To support the creation and presentation of "Times Bones," a new work by choreographer Margaret Jenkins. Time Bones, inspired by the myth of the scattered limbs of Osiris, will explore the "bones" of Margaret Jenkins' creative process throughout her 38-year career, and will be compiled from components of her 75 works.

To support the creation and presentation of "Light Moves" by choreographer Margaret Jenkins. A work based on the thematic weaving of parts of her earlier works (1973-93), the performance will premiere at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.

To support the creation and presentation of a site specific work by choreographer Margaret Jenkins in collaboration with multimedia visual artist Naomie Kremer. The work will be performed in the Jewish Community Center of San Francisco.
To support the continued development and presentation of OTHER SUNS by Margaret Jenkins. Excerpts from the work will be performed at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work by choreographer Margaret Jenkins. "Other Suns" is informed by Jenkins' investigations across cultures and her recent travels in foreign countries.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work by artistic director and choreographer Margaret Jenkins. Created in collaboration with choreographer Padma Menon from Kochi, India and dancers from the Tanusree Shankar Dance Company from Kolkata, India, the work will premiere in multiple sites at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Franciso, CA.
To support the creation and world premiere of "running with the land," a new work by Margaret Jenkins.
To support the presentation of a new work by Margaret Jenkins. Delay 2 will premiere during the company's 30th anniversary season.
To support creation and presentation of a new work choreographed by Margaret Jenkins. "Knot" will be created in collaboration with composer Alvin Curran and visual designer Alexander V. Nichols.

To support the creation, presentation, and national touring of a dance-theater collaboration titled "Time After" between the Margaret Jenkins Dance Company and actress Olympia Dukakis that will premiere in the company's 25th anniversary season at the Yerba Buena Garden Center for the Arts in San Francisco. Time After will be an exploration in movement and words of personal and public issues at the critical juncture in the life of a choreographer, performer and older woman. Ms. Jenkins wishes to take the stage again as a mature artist and find the language to express those concerns. It features a total of five principal characters of whom two are men. The roles will be performed by Margaret Jenkins, Olympia Dukakis, associate artistic director of the company Ellie Klopp and two male dancers. The work will be rehearsed and developed in residencies in Arizona, California, Illinois, and Hawaii. Following its premiere in San Francisco, the work will tour nationally.

Purpose: To support multidisciplinary arts festival. Additional Project Description: Arts programming will take place at a local park in honor of the Day of the Dead holiday. Community members will create personal altars to be displayed throughout the park. Local visual artists will help fabricate communal altars that will serve as backdrops for performances. Multidisciplinary Bay Area performing artists will be featured in music, dance, poetry, and ritual programming. The festival will be a free event, open to the public. Activities will take place in-person and online. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve audiences from the San Francisco area and the participating artists. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Organization Name: Marsh, a breeding ground for new performance
Popular Name: aka The Marsh and Marsh Youth Theater
Project Description: To support the remounting of Marsh Youth Theater's "Jip, His Story" with a cast of high school student actors from its theater arts program. Based on the Newbery Award-winning book by Katherine Paterson, the musical explores the pre-Civil War era in the United States.

Organization Name: Marsh, a breeding ground for new performance
Popular Name: aka The Marsh and Marsh Youth Theater
Project Description: To support a production of "Siddhartha: The Bright Path" with a cast of young actors from an affiliated theater arts program. The performance opportunity is designed to introduce the students to the rigors of a professional production experience.

Organization Name: Marsh, a breeding ground for new performance
Popular Name: aka The Marsh and Marsh Youth Theater
Project Description: To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

Organization Name: Marsh, a breeding ground for new performance
Popular Name: aka The Marsh and Marsh Youth Theater
Project Description: To support the Marsh Performance Initiative including the creation of new work, training, and the Festival of New Voices. The performance development program will focus on both creating performances and the production/business of theater.

Organization Name: Marsh, a breeding ground for new performance
Popular Name: aka The Marsh and Marsh Youth Theater
Project Description: To support the Marsh Youth Theater. The program will provide Bay Area children with in-depth drama instruction in areas such as playwriting, acting, costuming, and set design, while serving to strengthen each student's understanding of the dramatic arts and build self-esteem.

Purpose: To support staff salaries related to the publication of the literary journal McSweeney's Quarterly Concern. Additional Project Description: Championing adventurous and innovative writing, the organization fully reimagines the design of each issue in relation to planned content. Past issues have been tri-fold, vinyl-bound, foil-stamped, or disguised as a bag of balloons. The publication features fiction, art, nonfiction, and poetry. Intended Beneficiaries: The magazine benefits readers nationwide. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the presentation of multidisciplinary performances as a part of Soundwave NEXT. Additional Project Description: Curators, artists, producers, and artist collectives will present new performance-based works exploring the future of sound.
