Soundwave NEXT is a partnership between MEDIATE and Gray Area Foundation for the Arts. Intended Beneficiaries: The performances will benefit greater Bay Area artistic communities. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the Soundwave NEXT series. MEDIATE will consider the theme of Whats next? through the presentation of original sound art, music, media, and multidisciplinary performances. Artists selected through an open call will present new works at Gray Area Theater or through Gray Areas online platform Patch.

To support the Soundwave Biennial. The multidisciplinary media and sound art festival will explore the theme of time. Activities will include online and in-person performances of new and existing works, as well as discussions.

To support the Soundwave Biennial. The multidisciplinary media and sound art festival will take place in locations throughout the Bay Area. Exploring the theme of infrastructure, activities will include performances of new and existing works, exhibits, interactive installations, and discussions. Artists will explore globalized networks of physical and abstract spaces, supply chains, data and information networks, energy creation and distribution, and the foundations of cities with their work.

To support the Soundwave Biennial, an Imagine Your Parks Project. The multidisciplinary sound art festival will take place in locations throughout the Bay Area and include performances of new and existing works, exhibits, workshops, and discussions exploring the theme of architecture. A partnership with the National Parks Service will bring sound artists into regional national park spaces, where they will create site-specific works.

To support the Soundwave Biennial. The multidisciplinary sound art festival will take place in locations throughout the Bay Area and include performances, exhibits, workshops, and discussions exploring the theme of water.

To support performances of commissioned works by composers Gang Situ and Yuanlin Chen. The San Francisco Guitar Quartet will collaborate with Melody of China in the premiere performances at Herbst Theatre in San Francisco.

To support the commission and premiere of a new work by composer Duo Huang and the premiere performance of a new work by composer Kui Dong. The Del Sol String Quartet will collaborate with Melody of China in performances of the works at Herbst Theatre in San Francisco.

Purpose: To support a professional artist training program for emerging opera singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Additional Project Description: Through the 12-week training program, as many as 23 singers, five apprentice coaches, and a stage director will receive private coaching, attend master classes with veterans in the opera field, and perform in staged and costumed productions and concerts. Mozart's "Die Zauberflte" ("The Magic Flute") will be the featured production, with a summer concert of scenes from operas by Latinx composers, a cabaret-style song recital, and the Merola Finale concert with full orchestra. Intended Beneficiaries: Intended beneficiaries include emerging artists, Bay Area audience members attending the performances, and Bay Area middle school, junior high, and high school students who will observe the training program. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support a professional training program for opera singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants will receive private coaching, attend master classes with veterans in the opera field, and will perform in three concerts. Private coaching and master classes will be conducted both virtually and in person. Performances will be held live and recorded for streaming.

To support a virtual professional training program for opera singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants will receive four weeks of virtual learning, including intensive language study, acting classes, coaching by Alan Darling, Martin Katz, and Kevin Murphy, and seminars with industry leaders and opera luminaries.

To support a professional training program for opera singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants will receive private coaching, attend master classes with veterans in the opera field, and perform in staged and costumed productions and concerts.

To support a professional training program for singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants will receive private coaching and attend master classes with veterans in the opera field. Training will include language study, ensemble work, vocal technique, and stagecraft. Additional training for the apprentice coaches and apprentice stage director will focus on accompaniment, orchestral reduction, conducting for singers, and performing in a particular composer's style. All participants will rehearse with conductors and stage directors, and perform in staged and costumed productions and concerts in summer 2018. Participants will perform in Mozart's Il re pastore (The Shepherd King), Stravinsky's The Rake's Progress, the Schwabacher Summer Concert of extended opera scenes, and the Merola Grand Finale concert in the War Memorial Opera House.

To support a professional training program for singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants will receive private coaching and attend master classes with veterans in the opera field. The 12-week training program will include language study, ensemble work, vocal technique, and stagecraft. Additional training for the apprentice coaches and apprentice stage director will focus on accompaniment, orchestral reduction, conducting for singers, and performing in a particular composer's style. In 2017, participants will perform in Rossini's "La Cenerentola" and a triple bill of Pergolesi's "La Serva Padrona," Hoist's "Savitri," and Walton's "The Bear."

To support a professional training program for singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants will receive private coaching and attend master classes with veterans in the opera field. As many as 29 young artists will be selected from nearly 1,000 applicants to participate in the 12-week program. Training will include language study, ensemble work, vocal technique, and stagecraft. Additional training for the apprentice coaches and apprentice stage director will focus on accompaniment, orchestral reduction, conducting for singers, and performing in a particular composer's style. All participants will rehearse with conductors and stage directors, and perform in staged and costumed productions and concerts in summer 2016.

To support a professional training program for singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants will receive private coaching and attend master classes from veterans in the opera field. Training will include language study, ensemble work, vocal technique, and stagecraft. An additional week of training for the apprentice coaches and apprentice stage director will focus on accompaniment, orchestral reduction, conducting for singers, and performing in a particular composer's style. All participants will rehearse with conductors and stage directors, and perform in staged and costumed productions and concerts. Singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director will participate in as many as 12 weeks of summer training and performances.

To support master teachers and instructors at the professional training program for singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants will receive private coaching and attend master classes involving intergenerational exchange between veterans in the opera field and emerging newcomers. Training will revolve around language study, ensemble work, vocal technique, and stagecraft. All participants will rehearse with conductors and stage directors, and perform in staged and costumed productions and concerts.

To support a summer training program for singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants will be taught by master teachers and instructors and perform in fully staged productions and concerts.

To support master teachers and instructors at the professional level in a training program for singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants will receive private coaching and attend master classes for intergenerational exchange between veterans in the opera field and emerging newcomers.

To support master teachers and instructors at the professional training program for singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants will receive private coaching and attend master classes for intergenerational exchange between veterans in the opera field and emerging newcomers.

To support master teachers and instructors at the professional training program for singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants will receive private coaching and attend master classes for intergenerational exchange between veterans in the opera field and emerging newcomers.

To support master teachers and instructors at the professional training program for singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants will receive private coaching and attend master classes for intergenerational exchange between opera's veteran and emerging newcomers.

To support a professional training program for emerging opera artists. Singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director will receive private coaching and attend master classes that serve as forums for intergenerational exchange between opera's veterans and emerging newcomers.

To support a professional training program for singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants will receive private coaching and attend master classes that serve as forums for intergenerational exchange between opera's veterans and newcomers.

To support a professional training program for young opera artists. Participants will receive private coaching and attend master classes that serve as forums for intergenerational exchange between opera's veterans and newcomers.

To support a professional training program for singers, apprentice coaches, and an apprentice stage director. Participants receive private coaching and attend master classes that serve as forums for intergenerational exchange between opera's veterans and newcomers.
To support costs for the training program's visiting artists' workshops. The program offers advanced training and performance opportunities to young artists pursuing a professional operatic career.

To support curatorial research and planning for an exhibition titled "La Tercera Raiz (The Third Root): The African Presence in Mexico." Through visual, literary, media, and performing arts, the exhibition will expand scholarship and introduce the American public to a relatively unknown Afro-Mestizo component of Mexican cultural heritage.

To support part of "Chicanos en Mictlan: Dia de los Muertos en California," including an exhibition, catalogue, and educational activities. This is a multi-faceted project to recount, from a first-voice perspective, the development of Dia de los Muertos in California.

To support a planning project for restructuring the financial management systems of the museum in preparation for its move to a new, permanent downtown facility. The museum will work with a consultant to develop a plan to create a finance department and systems appropriate to the expansion of the museum's facilities and train the staff to implement the new financial management system. Relocation of the museum will expand its physical size five-fold and increase its operating budget three times, requiring the development of a financial management plan that will accommodate the growth of the organization and its need for increasingly sophisticated financial systems. Since 1994, when the San Francisco Redevelopment Agency awarded the museum a site and funding at Yerba Buena Gardens for a new facility, the organization has been evaluating all aspects of its programming and capacity for growth in preparation for the move in 1999. The San Francisco Foundation has supported this effort through grants for expanded marketing and staff development.
To support the Palabuniyan Kulintang Ensemble tour. The project will consist of a series of kulintang music and dance concerts and workshops.

Purpose: To support the completion and distribution of Heaven Through the Backdoor, a multimedia documentary film project by Anna Fitch and Banker White. Additional Project Description: The documentary tells the story of Yolanda Shae, an independent 88-year-old woman diagnosed with congestive heart failure, as she contemplates aging and death. Intended to initiate discussions about illness, grief, and loss, the feature-length film will broadcast on public television. The documentary also will be featured at community film screenings accompanied by an interactive art experience to be exhibited in galleries, museums, and public spaces in partnership with the Family Caregiver Alliance. Intended Beneficiaries: This project will benefit audiences nationwide, with a focus on caregivers and community groups serving aging populations and their families. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support production and post-production of a documentary film by Anna Fitch and Banker White. Incorporating documentary footage and artistic renderings, Heaven Through the Backdoor tells the story of Yolanda Shae, an independent 88-year-old woman contemplating aging and the universal human experience of death.

To support The Genius of Caring, a web-based public art project designed for both online screens and museum/gallery spaces. In conjunction with the film "The Genius of Marian," this interactive project will provide a space for people afflicted with Alzheimer's disease and their caregivers to share experiences through images, audio, video, and text.

Organization Name: Mission Cultural Center for Latino Arts
Project Description: To support the development and production of PLACAS by Paul S. Flores, in consortium with the Central American Resource Center.

Organization Name: Mission Cultural Center for Latino Arts
Project Description: To support the creation and presentation of "Representa!" in consortium with La Pena Cultural Center. Writer/performer Paul S. Flores, Cuban American rap artist Julio Cardenas, and writer/performer Danny Hoch will perform a bilingual work offering a new perspective on United States and Cuban relations.

Organization Name: Mission Cultural Center for Latino Arts
Project Description: To support exhibitions, catalogues, and related programming featuring the work of contemporary Latino artists.

Organization Name: Mission Cultural Center for Latino Arts
Project Description: To support an archival project to preserve a collection of posters and prints that document the Latino/Chicano Arts Movement of the San Francisco Bay area. Over 2,000 works on paper spanning 25 years will be archived, exhibited, and digitized.

To support the 30th Anniversary Carnaval San Francisco Festival and Parade. Numerous festival stages, including one stage entirely dedicated to young artists, will offer on-going, simultaneous performances by a variety of artists representing the cultural traditions of Latin America and the Caribbean.

To support the Carnaval San Francisco Festival and Parade. Seven festival stages, including one stage entirely dedicated to youth performances, will offer ongoing performances by a variety of artists representing the cultural traditions of Latin America and the Caribbean.

To support a Community Arts Development project in partnership with other community organizations. The project is a cultural tourism effort to market the "Carnaval San Francisco," a festival showcasing Latin American culture. Partnering organizations will include the San Francisco Convention and Visitors Bureau, San Francisco Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, Mission Street Merchants Association.

Purpose: To support "9/within the heart," a dance project that will include workshops and performances. Additional Project Description: Led by Artistic Director Sara Shelton Mann in collaboration with a group of multidisciplinary artists, the project will be developed through residencies in San Francisco, Northampton, and Dos Rios, and will culminate in a series of performances at Project Artaud's Space 124 in San Francisco. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit participating artists in California and Massachusetts and audiences in the San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the production of 8/the other side, an intensive workshop and residency program. Additional Project Description: The project will culminate in live and online performances choreographed and directed by Sara Shelton Mann. Using performance and experimental dance theater as a method of inquiry, transformation, and healing, the project will bring together emerging dancers, choreographers, and mixed media artists across the Bay Area and beyond. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit emerging BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color) and LGBTQ artists and their communities in the San Francisco area. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support the creation and presentation of 7 Excavations, a text-based movement performance choreographed and directed by Sara Shelton Mann. 7 Excavations is a legacy project seeking to codify Mann's performance and teaching methodologies and will be developed through a year-long workshop process at San Francisco's Joe Goode Annex, Djerassi Resident Artists Foundation in Woodside, California, and Dos Rios Retreat Center in rural northern California.

To support the creation and presentation of a new evening-length piece, "The Invitation," by Artistic Director Sara Shelton Mann. Made up of two intertwined duets, Mann will return to some earlier choreographic techniques to create the movement for this work-that of phrasing and complicated rhythms-placed within new research of how she may speak to the fast-paced information that surrounds us every day. "The Invitation" will premiere at ODC Theater in the Mission Neighborhood of San Francisco.

To support the creation and presentation of "Erasing Time," a new work by choreographer Sara Shelton Mann and digital archive of her work. The project will encompass the history of Mann's past work, including a live performance component featuring the restaging of seminal works, as well as the presentation of new material inspired by Mann's archive. In conjunction with the live events, Mixed Bag Productions will create an online archive of Mann's extensive body of work.

To support TRIBES OF THE FAMILIAL, a new dance work by Contraband choreographer/director Sara Shelton Mann. The project will focus on exploring the cultural roots of different artists, and how they chose their art forms.

To support up to eight workshop performances of "Monk at the Met." A site-specific, interdisciplinary performance installation, Monk at the Met will be created and staged by media, visual, literary, and design artists working under the direction of choreographer Sara Shelton Mann.

To support the continuing development and premiere of THE KEPLER PROJECT. Artistic Director Nina Wise in collaboration with Dr. Ralph Abraham, one of the pioneers of chaos theory, and Ryan J. Wyatt, Director of Morrison Planetarium, will integrate text, music, movement, and animated graphics to investigate events of the 1600s and cast light on the transformation that may occur in our own lifetimes.

To support Open(Art) a program to commission artists and technologists to collaborate in the creation and exhibition of digital art development platforms on the open Web. Open(Art), a joint venture between Mozilla and Eyebeam Art and Technology Center (Eyebeam) in New York City, is an invitational competition for teams of artists and technologist.
To support Folk Art in the Schools.

To support the exhibition "Fusing Traditions: Transformations in Glass by Native American Artists," with accompanying catalogue and education programs. The exhibition will bring together the work of the first generation of Native American studio glass artists for the first time.

To support a traveling exhibition of the work of American artist June Schwarcz, scheduled to travel to Honolulu and New York. The exhibition of 40 works will survey the sculptural aesthetics and technological innovations in metal enameling which have won Schwarcz the admiration of the American craft community for four decades. Long in the forefront of metal artists, Schwarcz was recently awarded the American Craft Council's Gold Medal for highest achievement in craftsmanship. Early in her career, in the mid-1950's, she became an expert in the basse taille technique in which she etched designs into copper and then enameled them over the entire surface. In her present work, she uses thin copper foil much like a textile, manipulating the pieces into sculptural forms by folding, creasing, and sewing seams with exposed stitches. The pieces are then enameled with transparent color allowing the textures below to show through, and then fired many times completing a process that is so complex and time consuming that Schwarcz may finish only 15 pieces a year. A full-color catalogue will accompany the exhibition and a video of the artist working in her studio will be produced, although they are not part of this proposal.

Purpose: To support an exhibition examining the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on Bay Area artists. Additional Project Description: The exhibition will feature more than 20 emerging and local artists, with a focus on communities which are historically underserved and underrepresented in museum exhibitions and collections, including BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color) and LGBTQIA artists. The exhibition will be accompanied by public programming such as a speaker series, hands-on artmaking activities, and in-person and virtual tours. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve artists and audiences from San Francisco and the Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support an exhibition and related programming featuring Bay Area artists with disabilities. Working with local artist groups and fashion houses, participating artists will receive individualized instruction from a diverse group of Bay Area designers. Each artist will create wearable works of art and incorporate their unique perspective into each piece.

Purpose: To support "ROOTS: The Power of African American and Black Dance in America," a national exhibition consisting of workshops, panel discussions and performances. Additional Project Description: Through individual residencies in host cities, resident artists Clyde Evans, Antwan Davis, and Jason Nious will trace the creation and evolution of African American step and hip-hop dance. Evans will host community workshops for Philadelphia police officers and the public and present performances. Nious and his company will complete an exhibition in body percussion history in Colorado Springs and community dance classes at Congo Square in New Orleans. Davis will explore the power of body percussion to heal mental and physical trauma in collaboration with doctors and somatic therapists in Oakland and teach dance therapy classes for individuals in San Francisco. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve audiences in Philadelphia, Colorado Springs, New Orleans, and the San Francisco Bay Area, with a focus on elementary schools, low-income communities, BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color) individuals, and seniors. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the preservation of personal papers of San Francisco Ballet prima ballerina Muriel Maffre, Stanford University dance scholar and critic Janice Ross, and the publicity and video archive of Oakland Ballet Company. Additional Project Description: Through this preservation project, original video recordings, photographs, documents, and press materials will be processed; finding aids and catalogue records will be created and shared on local and national publicly searchable databases. In addition, select videos and photographs will be digitized and made available online. Intended Beneficiaries: This preservation project will benefit the public, scholars, students, and artists. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support the cataloguing and digitization of original photographs, posters, scores, videos, and documents of dancer/choreographer Anna Halprin. Documents will be posted to the free, online Anna Halprin Digital Archive, both preserving and increasing public access to the personal papers of pioneering artist Anna Halprin.

To support the archiving, preservation, and dissemination of the personal papers of San Francisco Bay Area dancers and choreographers. Original video recordings, costumes, photographs, and press materials will be processed, finding aids and catalogue records will be created and shared on publicly searchable databases, and select videos and photographs documenting the work of these artists will be digitized and made available online for the public, scholars, students, and artists.

To support the digitization of videotapes of live theater performances documenting theater in the San Francisco Bay Area from 1976 to 2001. Productions to be preserved include the world premiere production of the Pulitzer Prize-winning Angels in America by Tony Kushner; the 1977 Eureka Theatre production of Sizwe Bansi Is Dead by Athol Fugard, starring a young Danny Glover; and dozens of productions from Tony Award-winning Bay Area theater companies. Recordings will be added to a public online catalogue that that will make them accessible to the general public, students, and artists via the museum's website, as well as through WorldCat, a global catalogue of library collections.

To support a digitization and archival engagement project. The museum will digitize, catalog, and make available online for broad public access dance images from photographers such as Katherine Kahrs, Chester Kessler, Henrietta McDowell, and Bob McLeod. More than 2000 images documenting dance in the San Francisco Bay Area from the 1940s to the 1990s will be scanned and uploaded onto the museum's online exhibitions website. Finding aids will be created or updated and added to the website and at-risk images will be preserved. The project will provide the general public, scholars, students, and artists open access to a new, extensive and significant exhibit of photographs on dance companies and individuals.

To support an archival and online access project. Music collections will be preserved and made accessible through the Preserving San Francisco's 20th-Century Musical Landscape project. Some of the materials to be archived are the personal papers of American composer Conrad Susa; Adrian Michaelis, program manager of classic radio program "The Standard Hour;" Robert Commanday, music critic for the "San Francisco Chronicle" and "San Francisco Examiner;" and jazz critic Phil Elwood. The museum also will archive the press and biographical files from the record label Fantasy Records. Key images and documents will populate a publicly available online exhibit. In addition, reel-to-reel recordings of incidental compositions by Susa will be digitized and added to the online exhibit. A searching aid, a detailed guide to the contents of a collection, and a collection-level catalogue record will be created for each of the collections.

To support the digitization of images and papers of California dance luminaries, Lew Christensen and Anna Halprin for online access. Key images from each collection will be digitized including photographs of Christensen's "Filling Station" and Halprin's "Parades and Changes."

To support phase II of Full Spectrum: Preserving Rare  Diverse Bay Area Dance Video, 1985-2000. The project will create archival-quality digital masters of 100 selected dance recordings which are currently housed in fragile and obsolete formats.

To support the inventory, digitization, and conservation services for the unidentified and at risk legacy materials, in consortium with Joe Goode Performance Group. The museum will gather the sizable collections of legacy materials and make them available via the Web sites of the museum, each company, and the Dance Heritage Coalition's "Secure Media Network."
To support Full Spectrum: Preserving Rare  Diverse Bay Area Dance Video, 1985-2000. The collection will be available to students, scholars, researchers, and the general public.

To support the Dance Stars of the West, an oral history project for three California dance artists. The artists include Jocelyn Vollmar (ballet), Naesio Paredes (Spanish dance), and Evelyn Cisneros (ballet).

To support Preserving the Dance Iconography of the West Before the Digital Era. A project that will preserve the early history of dance in the West, 400 images dating from 1850 and representing the wealth of dance history in the West will be preserved.

To support the preservation of the archives of San Francisco Ballet, LINES Ballet, and the San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. The outcome of the project will be a comprehensive visual record of the groups' historic achievements.

To support phase two of a project to preserve the archives of West Coast dance artists: Tandy Beal, Chitresh Das, Anna Halprin, and Michael Smuin. The Dance Icons of the West project will provide scholars and the community with four comprehensive collections of print and video materials.
To support the documentation and preservation of the dance collections of West Coast artists. These artists include Michael Smuin, Anna Halprin, Tandy Beal, and Chitresh Das.
To support the expansion of the LEGACY Oral History Project. Up to nine oral histories will be produced and two training workshops in the creation of oral histories will be offered.

To support the expansion of the LEGACY Oral History Project. LEGACY will train up to 32 volunteer interviewers to record, edit, and complete at least six research quality oral history documents of Bay Area dance community members.

To support "Legacy," a project to facilitate the training of volunteers in the production of oral histories that document the lives of significant dance artists and educators in Northern California. Over a period of 24 months, Legacy will train 24 volunteers to record edit, and complete six research quality oral history documents of local Bay Area dance community members who have contributed significantly to the national dance heritage. Legacy will also publish and distribute two educational pamphlets for K-12 school children based on excerpts from existing oral histories in the collection.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Music-Integrated Literacy Enhancement (MILE) Program. In collaboration with Oakland Unified School District, the program will provide opportunities for music teachers to co-teach with classroom teachers.

Purpose: To support teaching artist fees for after-school music education classes. Additional Project Description: Music Mission San Francisco will conduct free music classes for youth, where the majority of students are Latino and live in low-income communities. The teaching artists have close connections to the Latino community, and their classes will focus on classical music and music from Latin America. Intended Beneficiaries: Youth and musicians from the Mission District of San Francisco, California, will participate in the project. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Popular Name: aka Paul Dresher Ensemble/New Performance Tradtions
Project Description: Purpose: To support the Paul Dresher Ensemble Artist Residency program. Additional Project Description: The residencies will provide performing artists with access to rehearsal studio space, stipends, and paid performance opportunities, as well as mentorship consultations with ensemble staff. Residencies will be offered to artists who are exploring innovative aesthetic and cultural themes and multidisciplinary collaboration. Residency staff will consider diversity, equity, inclusivity, and access in the selection of panelists and artists in residence. Intended Beneficiaries: The residencies will benefit Northern California early to mid-career performing artists and Bay Area audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

Popular Name: aka Paul Dresher Ensemble/New Performance Tradtions
Project Description: To support an artist residency program of the Paul Dresher Ensemble. Early and mid-career artists working in multidisciplinary performing arts disciplines will receive artist fees, as well as access to rehearsal space, technical equipment, and mentorship opportunities. Each residency will culminate in a performance of the work developed during the residency. Activities will take place virtually as necessary.

Popular Name: aka Paul Dresher Ensemble/New Performance Tradtions
Project Description: To support an artist residency program of the Paul Dresher Ensemble. Early and mid-career artists working in multidisciplinary performing arts disciplines will receive access to rehearsal space, technical equipment, mentorship opportunities, and artist fees. Each residency will culminate in a performance of the work developed during the residency.

Popular Name: aka Paul Dresher Ensemble/New Performance Tradtions
Project Description: To produce the premiere of "Max Understood" by playwright Nancy Carlin and composer Michael Rasbury. The Paul Dresher Ensemble will present a musical drama about a seven-year-old autistic boy's magical odyssey and transformative journey out into the world beyond the confines of his parents' apartment. The project's focus on autism is expected to reach patrons for new music, individuals, and families having personal experience with autism, and to members of organizations that support the autism community.

Popular Name: aka Paul Dresher Ensemble/New Performance Tradtions
Project Description: To support presentations of Artistic Director Paul Dresher's seminal music theater work "Slow Fire;" a new music theater project by Rinde Eckert; and the touring of "The Tyrant," Dresher's new chamber opera.

Popular Name: aka Paul Dresher Ensemble/New Performance Tradtions
Project Description: To support a collaborative commissioning and performance project with the Russian ensemble Opus Posth. The Paul Dresher Ensemble and Opus Posth will participate in a 2003 mini-festival featuring the premiere of new works.

Popular Name: aka Paul Dresher Ensemble/New Performance Tradtions
Project Description: To support the completion of and multi-faceted activities evolving from SOUND STAGE, a musical theater work by Paul Dresher. The premiere and residency activities will take place at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.

Popular Name: aka Paul Dresher Ensemble/New Performance Tradtions
Project Description: To support a commissioning project of up to two concerti from composers Anthony Davis and Paul Dresher. These works will be developed and rehearsed in collaboration with cellist Joan Jenrenaud and the Musical Traditions' six-member Electro-Acoustic Band during 1999-2001.

Popular Name: aka Paul Dresher Ensemble/New Performance Tradtions
Project Description: To support the commission of works from composers Martin Bresnick and Terry Riley and the preparation for the premieres and touring of these works by the Musical Traditions' six-member Electro-Acoustic Band. This 20-month project, under the artistic direction of Paul Dresher, will take place from March 1999 through October 2000.

Popular Name: aka Paul Dresher Ensemble/New Performance Tradtions
Project Description: To support a statewide master-apprenticeship program, "Traditional Arts CA", a regionally-coordinated project featuring California's diverse artistic traditions, and a website featuring the informational publication entitled TRADITIONAL ARTS This innovative project will develop and administer a statewide master/apprenticeship program on a regional basis, with regional coordinators networking within traditional communities and arts orrganizations to solicit applications, convene a review panel, and document each apprenticeship's programm during the apprenticeship. A publication, "Traditional Arts CA" (TAC), will highlight samplings of the works of the traditional artists, including descriptions and analyses of techniques. It will be informational, announcing and critiquing traditional arts events and festivals in an effort to build and serve a broader traditional arts community.

Popular Name: aka Paul Dresher Ensemble/New Performance Tradtions
Project Description: To support the premiere of "Ravenshead" by composer Steve Mackey and librettist/singer Rinde Eckert, co-commissioned with Penn State University and co-produced by the Berkeley Repertory Theater.

Organization Name: Na Lei Hulu I Ka Wekiu Hula Halau
Project Description: To support the presentation of MAHU, a multi-media hula dance theater work. Based on traditional Hula dance forms, new dances will be choreographed to celebrate transgendered Hawaiian artists. This performance will reclaim the traditional understanding of mahu (third-person gender), and re-establish its original meaning. Hawaiian culture traditionally considered transgendered individuals as valued artisans and healers.
To support the translation from Japanese of THE COLLECTED POEMS OF SAGAWA CHIKA.
To support artist fees and upgrades for the free online magazine NARRATIVE. The journal publishes more than 350 authors and artists each year and has more than 170,000 subscribers.

To support the publication and promotion of "Narrative Magazine," a free online journal of new literature. In 2011, Narrative's Web site will be upgraded to include community-building modules and allow readers to personally customize their onsite experience with features such as individual bookshelves.

To support the publication and promotion of "Narrative Magazine," a free online journal of new literature. In 2008, Narrative became the first literary magazine available on the Kindle, Amazon's wireless reading device; in early 2010, the journal launched its iPhone application.
To support artist fees for Narrative Magazine, a free online journal of new literature. Recent contributors have included Joyce Carol Oates, E.L. Doctorow, Amy Tan, and T. C. Boyle.

To support the production and promotion of LOST AND FOUND: American Treasures from the New Zealand Archive. This three-hour collection will draw from up to 176 American films repatriated from the New Zealand Film Archive, including films by notable directors John Ford and Alfred Hitchcock, and preserve the films through a partnership among five American archives.

To support the production of "Treasures 6: Next Wave Avant-Garde, 1960-1988," a DVD anthology. Treasures 6: New Wave Avant-Garde, 1960-1988 will include experimental films by artists such as Bruce Conner, Marjorie Keller, Willie Varela, and Ernie Gehr.
To support conservation of repatriated silent-era films. American distribution prints thought to be destroyed but kept in storage by the New Zealand Film Archive will be preserved and duplicated.
To support the first-year of production of a DVD anthology, "Treasures V: The West." A selection will be screened with live accompaniment by music curator Martin Marks at NYU's Orphan Film Symposium.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.
To support the production of a DVD anthology. The American Avant-Garde, 1945-1985, will include films from four decades of experimental cinema.
To support a national initiative to make preservation masters and public viewing copies of surviving American Silent Fiction Film in three major non-profit collections.

To support the research and development of a sustainable product design approach and toolkit. Case studies for sustainable product design will be documented and disseminated through a publication and articles in appropriate design journals.

Purpose: To support the creation and production of Rogue Gestures/Foreign Bodies, a bharatanatyam dance work. Additional Project Description: The work will feature choreography by Nadhi Thekkek, collaborations with modern dancer Randee Paufve, and original music compositions by G.S. Rajan and Chris Evans. The project will take place at ODC Theatre in San Francisco. Intended Beneficiaries: The production will serve San Francisco Bay Area audiences, including the South Asian American community. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support the creation of a multimedia Bharatanatyam and visual arts production exploring class and caste constructs in the South Asian diaspora. Choreographer Nadhi Thekkek's work diverges from traditional Bharatanatyam by using current events rather than traditional Hindu mythology to inspire the movement with elements of mime, satire, and calligraphy.

To support Atlantic Crossing, a performance project with San Francisco Chanticleer, the male a cappella vocal chorus. Programming under the direction of Music Director Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg will focus on music by European composers living and working in America during the years between the two world wars, as well as works from the great American Songbook canon by composers Cole Porter, George Gershwin, and Duke Ellington.

To support the Featured Composer Residency by American composer Mark O'Connor. A commissioned new work and its premiere performances will take place in San Francisco, Berkeley, Palo Alto, and San Rafael, and will include two of his other works: Appalachia Waltz, Song of the Liberty Bell, and Strings and Threads (with the composer on the violin).

To support the Featured Composer Residency by American composer William Bolcom. Activities will include the commissioning of a new work for the chamber orchestra and its premiere performances in San Francisco, Palo Alto, and San Rafael.
To support a multi-state chamber orchestra tour. Concerts will take place in California, Ohio, Michigan, and Illinois.

To support the premiere performances of a string-orchestra transcription of Aaron Jay Kernis' "100 Greatest Dance Hits," originally written as a guitar quintet. This year 2000 project will feature guitarist David Tanenbaum and the New Century Chamber Orchestra.

To support the development of Unpacking in P'town, a new play by Jewelle Gomez. Based on the true-life experiences of the playwright's grandmother who worked as a chorus girl in America during the 1950s, the play will explore the ability of art to foster intergenerational connections. Activities may take place virtually.

To support a production and tour of "From White Plains" by Michael Perlman. This new play examines the lives of four adult men grappling with the effects of teen bullying, and the need for healing and forgiveness. Following initial performances at San Francisco's Walker Theatre, the play will be toured to Modesto.

To support the Bay Area premiere and touring of "Standing On Ceremony: The Gay Marriage Plays," a collection of short plays on the topic of marriage equality, directed by Sara Staley. Conceived by Brian Shnipper, the project is a collection of plays by established playwrights created in response to the ongoing battle for marriage equality throughout the United States.

To support the New Conservatory Theatre Center's "YouthAware Educational Theatre" program. YouthAware travels to schools to perform professional theatrical productions with an educational component that feature characters and story lines addressing diversity, substance abuse, school safety, body image, and HIV prevention.

To support the creation, development, and production of a new play by Terrence McNally. The project will be commissioned and developed through the Playwrights Commission  Residency Program, which is devoted to developing and producing new works.

To support a survey exhibition of the art of San Francisco artist Tony Labat. The exhibition will include a new public artwork, a catalogue, a Web component, and screenings documenting his contributions to the emerging genres of video, installation, and performance art.

To support the commission of a new work by artist Anna Gaskell. The exhibition, to be held during New Langton's year-long 25th anniversary celebration, will have its West Coast premiere and travel nationally.

To support development of a traveling retrospective exhibition of the work of artist Jim Pomeroy (1945-1992) to coincide with 25th anniversary activities for New Langton Arts. During his 20-year career, Pomeroy made important contributions to sculpture, performance art, new music, video and digital media, criticism and theory, stereo and anamorphic photography. An artist whose work resonates worldwide, Pomeroy combined his interests in technology, politics, and popular culture to make work that demonstrates an amalgam of humor, irony, and serious play. The exhibition will include significant installation and sculptural works, a catalogue, Web site, and public programs. The catalogue will include original essays by and about Jim Pomeroy, photography of his work, biographical information, and an index of works produced in his short life-time. An initial printing of 2,000 copies will be distributed nationally through bookstores, libraries, museums, schools, universities, and artists' spaces. The Exploratorium has offered to host the Web site, enabling the presentation of video and audio. New Langton will work closely with the Center for Creative Photography at the University of Arizona which houses a significant portion of the artist's archive.

Purpose: To support the translation from the Danish of the novella "Natalja's Stories" by Inger Christensen Additional Project Description: Christensen (1935-2009) remains one of Denmark's most distinguished and original writers of poetry and prose. She wrote "Natalja's Stories" in the late 1980s as part of a collective project with seven writers who each wrote stories from the perspective of someone fleeing a fictive explosion at a Swedish nuclear reactor. The seven people tell their stories on seven specific themes over seven days. Modeled after Boccaccio's 14th-century "Decameron," all seven narratives by the seven writers were published together as "September Stories." Christensens contribution is about Natalja Valdon, who tells the story of her life and the lives of her foremothers. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit fellowship recipient Denise Newman, a poet, translator, and professor of creative writing at California College of the Arts. The project also will benefit the public, who will have access to the English translation of this work for the first time. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries experience the international exchange of artists, arts, and cultural traditions.

To support the translation from the Danish of a collection of short stories, "Baboon," by Danish author Naja Marie Aidt. The stories in "Baboon" are set in Denmark and focused on characters that experience extreme psychological strain. Aidt's work is well regarded throughout Europe and has been compared to that of Anton Chekov, James Joyce, and Jhumpa Lahiri; however, she is relatively unknown in America. In 2008, Aidt received the Nordic Council's Literature Award for "Baboon," the highest honor available for a book published in the Nordic countries. Denise Newman is a Senior Adjunct Professor in the MFA Writing and Undergraduate Writing and Literature Programs at the California College of the Arts. She is the translator of two novels by Danish writer Inger Christensen, "Azorno" and "The Painted Room." Newman has received awards for her translation work from the Danish Arts Council and the Danish Ministry of Culture.

Popular Name: aka Ninth Street Independent Film Center
Project Description: To support a programmatic collaboration at the Ninth Street Independent Film Center which is a consortium of eight media arts organizations, all housed in one building. "The Collaborative Connections Initiative includes a residency program, a media education program for youth, and access for filmmakers and other non-profits to a state-of-the-art screening room.

Popular Name: aka Ninth Street Independent Film Center
Project Description: To support a programmatic collaboration at the Ninth Street Independent Film Center which is a consortium of eight media arts organizations, all housed in one building. The collaboration involves the continuing implementation of a shared information technology department for the occupants and a facilities department.

Popular Name: aka Ninth Street Independent Film Center
Project Description: To support a programmatic collaboration at the Ninth Street Independent Film Center. The center is a consortium of eight media arts organizations, all housed in one building.

Popular Name: aka Ninth Street Independent Film Center
Project Description: To support a programmatic collaboration at the Ninth Street Independent Film Center. The center is a consortium of seven media arts organizations, all housed in one building.

Popular Name: aka Ninth Street Independent Film Center
Project Description: To support a shared information technology department for the Ninth Street Independent Film Center. The center is a consortium of seven media arts organizations all housed in one building.

Popular Name: aka Ninth Street Independent Film Center
Project Description: To support programmatic collaborations at the Ninth Street Independent Film Center. The Center is a consortium of eight media arts organizations all housed in one building.

Popular Name: aka Ninth Street Independent Film Center
Project Description: To support the programmatic collaboration of the Ninth Street Independent Film Center. The collaboration will include the continuation of a new film forum series, expansion of exhibition programs, and strengthening of collaborative youth program initiatives.

Popular Name: aka Ninth Street Independent Film Center
Project Description: To support a forum series and the continuation of the Knowledge Sharing Project, a technology initiative. The Ninth Street Independent Film Center houses multiple non-profit media arts organizations, each with its own identity.
To support the 13th annual October "Russian Music Festival." Free noontime solo and chamber ensemble performances will survey Russian musical traditions.

Purpose: To support the creation and presentation of dance works from Artistic Director Brenda Way and guest choreographer Dexandro Montalvo. Additional Project Description: Way's "Collision, Collapse and a Coda" will continue her reflection on how communities face our most challenging communal moments, while Montalvo's "A Commitment to Consciousness" will investigate society's current consciousness of barriers and confinement. Both dance works will be part of the Company's Dance Downtown Season. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit diverse audiences in the San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support dancer salaries for the creation and presention of dance works as part of the Dance Downtown series. Additional Project Description: The company will work with Artistic Director Brenda Way as well as guest choreographers Dexandro Montalvo and Amy Seiwert as they create new works and stage two revivals.. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances will benefit a broad and diverse Bay Area audience. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support dancer salaries to develop a new dance film based on the stage work Up for Air (Decameron) by choreographers Brenda Way, KT Nelson, Kimi Okada, and Kate Weare. The film will be featured in the company's 50th anniversary season, first as a part of the digital program offerings and then shared with major film festivals around the country.

To support the creation of Decameron, Up for Air, a new dance work by ODC/Dance. Based on Boccaccio's Decameron, the evening-length work will be a collaboration between ODC's three founding choreographers Brenda Way, KT Nelson, and Kimi Okada, and ODC's resident New York choreographer, Kate Weare.

To support the creation and presentation of World's on Fire, a new work by Brenda Way and Kate Weare. Centered on universal themes of kinship, belief, suffering, and love that connect generations, this milestone work will signal a changing of the guard in artistic leadership in anticipation of ODC's 50th anniversary in 2020-21. Way and Weare will team up for the first time to create a full-length piece for the ten-dancer and four-musician ensembles. Way and Weare both have a history of collaborating across disciplines with composers, painters, and musicians, and both find great value in being challenged by outside perspectives. Community engagement activities such as open rehearsals, informal artist talks, and behind-the-scenes tours will accompany the performances.

To support the creation and presentation of new dance works. Co-Artistic Director KT Nelson will choreograph "Path of Miracles," a collaboration between ODC/Dance and the SF choral group, Volti. ODC Artistic Director Brenda Way will premiere "News of the World," the latest in her ongoing efforts to realize and reveal the artistic process onstage and to explore the aesthetic possibilities of bringing visual artists into the dance realm. Kimi Okada will present "Head in the Sand." The company will work with presenters and local organizations to develop outreach activities to increase engagement, such as lecture-demonstrations and balcony talks.

To support the creation and presentation of new dance works. Co-Artistic Director KT Nelson will choreograph the first phase of a new work, titled,"Blink of an Eye." Founder and Artistic Director Brenda Way will create a new chamber work with music drawn from the David Lang catalogue. ODC will work with presenters and local organizations to develop outreach activities to increase engagement, such as lecture-demonstrations and balcony talks. These new works will premiere in ODC's annual Dance Downtown season at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.

To support the creation and presentation of new dance works. Artistic Director Brenda Way will choreograph, "Walk Back the Cat," to a commissioned score by composer Paul Drescher. Guest artist Kate Weare will choreograph "Giant." The works will premiere at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.

To support the creation and presentation of a new dance works by Co-Artistic Director KT Nelson. "Dead Reckoning" will explore the human relationship to nature. Composer Joan Jeanrenaud will be commissioned to write a score that draws on the more primal elements of rock-and-roll.

To support the creation and presentation of "Boulders and Bones," a new work by Artistic Directors Brenda Way and KT Nelson. The piece, danced by the members of ODC/Dance to an original score by Zoe Keating, concerns itself with the physical materials and creative process for a work of art, specifically, a landscape installation being created by British artist Andy Goldsworthy.

To support the creation and presentation of new works by resident choreographers Brenda Way and KT Nelson. Way, ODC founder and artistic director, will create "Lifesaving Maneuvers" with set designer Alexander V. Nichols and composer Jay Cloidt; co-artistic director Nelson will create "Transit: Next Stop" with designer/craftsman welder Max Chen and lighting and set designer Barry Steele.

To support the creation and presentation of new works including "Breathing Underwater" by Brenda Way and "Transit" by KT Nelson. Artistic director Way's "Breathing Underwater" will include a set by Alexander Nichols, and music by composer/cellist Zoe Keating; co-artistic director Nelson's "Transit" will be presented in collaboration with composer Hyo-shin Na, set designer Matt Antaky, and designer/welder Max Chen.

To support the ODC/Dance's creation and presentation of two world premieres by artistic directors Brenda Way and KT Nelson in celebration of the company's 40th anniversary. In addition to performances, the company will reach out to underserved audiences through its "Educational Outreach Program" that directly serves more than 400 students in San Francisco's public elementary and middle schools, and numerous communities on tour.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work by Artistic Director and choreographer Brenda Way with related outreach activities. In the Memory of the Forest, will be created in collaboration with video artists David and Hi-jin Hodge, composer Jay Cloidt, and lighting/set designer Elaine Buckholtz, and will be presented at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts Theater in San Francisco.

To support the creation and presentation of LIFE IS A HOUSE, a new work by artistic director and choreographer Brenda Way. The work will be created with the San Francisco Girls Chorus and presented at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work by artistic director and choreographer Brenda Way. The work will be created in collaboration with composer David Lang, Japanese video artist Hiraki Sawa, and lighting/stage designer Alex Nichols, and will be performed at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.
To support the creation of a site-specific work by co-artistic director KT Nelson. The project will celebrate the opening year of the company's new dance center.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work entitled "On A Train Heading South," by choreographer Brenda Way. Titled On a Train Heading South, the work will be created in collaboration with composer Jack Perla and video artist Jim Campbell.

To support a Community Arts Development project in partnership with other community organizations. The project is a cultural tourism effort to support design refinements associated with the renovation of the facility that houses the Oberlin Dance Collective. Partnering organizations will include Architecture + Light and Summerfest/Dance.

To support a new Community Outreach Initiative. ODC Theater will work with area cultural organizations and/or curators to program events throughout the year; components of the project will include a jazz festival and the Mission Matinees Series.

To support the Artists in Residence series. The Oberlin Dance Collective (ODC) Theater's goal is to facilitate and promote artistic excellence in the creation and presentation of new performance work by predominantly Bay Area artists.

Purpose: To support the presentation of performance artists as part of the State of Play Festival. Additional Project Description: Creative Director Chlo Zimberg has invited Degenerate Art Ensemble (Seattle) and Resident Island Dance Theatre Ensemble (Pingtung County, Taiwan) to be visiting artists, while two California-based dance artists will curate ODC Theater's State of Play Festival. The festival will highlight movement artists at different stages in their careers, with a focus on the creative process. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit participating artists and general audiences in the San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support artist and guest curator fees for the presentation of visiting and San Francisco Bay Area dance and contemporary dance artists. Additional Project Description: Guest curators Charles Slender-White and Amara Tabor-Smith will program ODC Theater's annual summer festival, which will include works in various stages of development, from works-in-process to fully produced programs. Featured festival artists will include MK Abadoo and Sammay Dizon. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve a diverse San Francisco Bay Area audience, including visitors to the area, dance artists, and culture workers. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support artist fees and staff costs for the virtual presentation of new works by local choreographers. The online festival will present works by Jos Navarrete and Debby Kajiyama, Catherine Galasso, Margaret Jenkins and Rinde Eckert, Robert Moses and Hope Mohr.
To support the creation and presentation of a new dance work. Larry Arrington will examine western dance as a series of folk dances in his work No Quarter.

To support the presentation of Tere O'Connor Dance's Long Run with related public activities. In addition to presenting dance performances, ODC Theater will hold public engagement initiatives including workshops, their resident writer's blog, lobby exhibitions, public programs, and civic dialogue.
To support the presentation of dance works by Rashaun Mitchell, Cori Olinghouse, and Bobbi Jene Smith.

To support the presentation of dance works by local and national artists. ODC Theater will expand the Walking Distance Dance Festival-SF to feature an increased number of performances in a fringe-format. Additional performance highlights will include the world premiere of Monique Jenkinson's "Delicate Material," which questions how society views gender and misogyny, and performances by Joanna Haigood/Zaccho Dance Theater in partnership with the African American Performing Arts Coaltion and the Joe Goode Annex. ODC Theater will take these dance experiences beyond performance by offering master classes, pre- and post-performance talks, and a performance docent program.

To support the ODC Theater Presents program. The project will include The Walking Distance Dance Festival-SF, as well as presentations of French-Algerian Compagnie Herve Koubi's "What the Day Owes to The Night," RAWdance's "Double Exposure," and Hope Mohr Dance's "Manifesting." ODC Theater's primary mission is to be the West Coast's premier venue for the contemporary performing arts and a home to nurture artists.
To support the ODC Theater Presents program. The project will include the Walking Distance Dance Festival, and a presentation of Rosanna Gamson's "Layla Means Night."

To support the presentation of a new work by choreographer Sarah Michelson, in collaboration with playwright Richard Maxwell, visual artist TM Davy, and composer Peter Drungle. The work will launch the opening season of the newly renovated and expanded Oberlin Dance Collective Theater.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support "Intimate Reveal", a series of theater, dance, and music performances. In celebration the opening of the new theater, programming will present artists who have had a long relationship with ODC Theater and the community.
To support the Artist-in-Residence Program. The theater will provide rehearsal space, technical support, production assistance, and performance opportunities.
To support residencies for established and emerging performing artists. The theater will provide rehearsal space, technical support, production assistance, and performance opportunities.

To support residencies for Chris Black and the Black Choreographers Festival. The theater will provide rehearsal space, technical support, and production assistance to performing artists and companies who will create site-specific works during their residencies.
To support the Verge and Artists-in-Residence programs. The project will provide professional development training, technical support, and space subsidies to dance and music artist/companies.
To support the presentation of a series of local and international dance. The performances will take place at the ODC Theater and Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.

To support an artist-in-residence program. Based on artistic quality and the opportunity for the residency to invigorate community, three residencies will be organized during 2002. The ODC Theater, located in San Francisco's Mission District, has for twenty years provided affordable theater access for local and touring performing arts companies. This project will support work by choreographer Jess Curtis and an international team of artists; composer Wayne Wallace to create a series of jazz-based compositions; and traditional Cuban dance and music company Ban Rarra.

Purpose: To support the production of "The Shining" in a new orchestration by composer Paul Moravec and librettist Mark Campbell. Additional Project Description: Based on the novel by Stephen King and premiered in 2016 by the Minnesota Opera, the full-scale opera will be orchestrated for chamber ensemble by the composer to make it accessible to small and mid-sized opera companies. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances will benefit audiences in San Francisco and the surrounding region. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the world premiere of "Sophia's Forest" by composer Lembit Beecher and librettist Hannah Moskovitch. Additional Project Description: Inspired by the composer's grandmother and infant mother's escape from Estonia during World War II having survived the Nazi and Soviet occupations of their country, the libretto unfolds during the 1990s war in the Balkans. The opera focuses on a nine-year old's recent immigration to the United States, and how she uses her imagination to survive the traumatic journey and civil war in her homeland. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances will benefit audiences in San Francisco and the surrounding region. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support an animated filmed production of the opera Everest  a Graphic Novel Opera by composer Joby Talbot and librettist Gene Scheer, based on the events of the 1996 Mt. Everest disaster. Using a unique graphic novel opera approach to producing the film, activities include studio recordings of the singers and a motion capture process to animate characters in the film. The singers own movements control the animated expressions of their characters, creating an authentic emotional experience for the audience. Everest follows the fates of three climbers and is told in a non-linear fashion, jumping between the climbers and their families at home. At its emotional core, this is a story about the value of each breath and step we take as humans.

To support production costs for a revised and re-orchestrated version of Harvey Milk by composer Stewart Wallace and librettist Michael Korie. An activist and the first openly gay elected official in California, Milk served only 11 months before being assassinated. The production will integrate archival footage of Milk, the late 1970s, and the dynamically emerging gay movement in San Francisco.

To support a new production of "Les Enfants Terribles" by composer and NEA Opera Honoree Philip Glass at Opera Parallele. Based on novel of the same name by Jean Cocteau (1929), this tragic story follows siblings Paul and Elisabeth through what began as a childhood game and ends in death and destruction. The third installment of the composer's trilogy of works based on Cocteau, with this work Glass invented a hybrid dance-opera form in which the dance element is not secondary or decorative, but rather contributes to the narrative flow and sound-scape of the opera. The creative team will include director Brian Staufenbiel, conductor Nicole Paiement, media designer David Murakami, and choreographer Amy Seiwert. Performances will take place at the Caroline H. Hume Concert Hall in San Francisco.

To support performances of "Flight" by composer Jonathan Dove and librettist April De Angelis at Opera Parallele. Based on the actual events surrounding the forced residence of Iranian refugee Mehran Karimi Nasseri at Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris, the opera is a cynical comedy about what it means to be stranded in an airport for 17 years. The refugee is tailed by an immigration officer and comes in contact with a variety of colorful characters: a couple on vacation, Eastern European diplomats, airline attendants, an enigmatic older woman, and an air traffic controller. The creative team will include conductor Nicole Paiement and director Brian Staufenbiel, and the artistic team will include counter-tenor Tai Oney, soprano Nikki Einfeld, bass-baritone Hadleigh Adams, and baritones Eugene Brancoveanu and Phillip Skinner.

To support the American premiere of "Heart of Darkness" by composer Tarik O'Regan and librettist Tom Phillips. Based on the novel by Joseph Conrad, the production will showcase a number of technical and artistic innovations, such as the use of multidimensional video projections onto audience members wearing white garments turning them into virtual scenery, as well as video mapping to infuse life into inert props and set pieces, thereby transforming the stage. An educational component will involve partnerships with area high schools where the students will be studying the Conrad novel and to whom the company's artistic team will make a presentation before the students see the opera.

To support the American premiere of "Anya 17," a recently commissioned opera by composer Adam Gorb and librettist Ben Kaye. The opera portrays human trafficking as experienced by the central character, Anya. The plot unfolds through a series of short, fast-paced flashbacks that detail how Anya is deceived into traveling abroad, sold as a prostitute, and held against her will through repeated threats of violence.

To support the 25th annual Other Minds new music festival. Other Minds Festival 25 programming will feature artists working in the fields of avant-garde jazz and improvised music, including NEA Jazz Masters Anthony Braxton and Roscoe Mitchell, composer and jazz pianist Myra Melford, guitarist Mary Halvorson, and trumpeter Wadada Leo Smith.

To support a performance project celebrating the life and music of American composer Lou Harrison. Titled Just 100: Homage to Lou Harrison, the project activities will include performances, panel discussions, and exhibitions. Participating in the centenary celebration will be artists Dennis Russell Davies, pianist Maki Namekawa, violinist Yumi Hwang-Williams, percussion ensemble William Winant Ensemble, harpist Meredith Clark, cellist Emil Miland, and the Mission Dolores, and Resound choruses.

To support the Other Minds New Music Preservation Project/www.radiom.org. The organization will convert archival live recordings of performances, interviews, and conversations with innovative composers and artists of 20th-century American music into digital media and make them available worldwide, via www.radiOM.org. In partnership with Internet Archive, Other Minds will focus on digitizing approximately 125 hours of audio from a collection donated by Joseph Franklin, founder of the Relache Ensemble, which has commissioned and performed works by composers such as Robert Ashley, Kitty Brazelton, John Cage, Philip Glass, Fred Ho, and George Russell. In addition, several hours of video and other materials from OM 11 and OM 12 festivals will be digitized and added to the online archive, featuring artists such as John Luther Adams, Billy Bang, Per Norgard, and the late Peter Sculthorpe.

To support the Other Minds New Music Preservation Project/www.radiOM.org. The organization will convert archival live recordings of performances, interviews, and conversations with innovative composers and artists of 20th-century American music into digital media and make them available worldwide, via www.radiOM.org.

To support the Other Minds New Music Preservation Project/radiOM.org. The organization will convert archival live recordings of performances, interviews, and conversations with innovative composers and artists of 20th-century American music into digital media and make them available worldwide, via www.radiOM.org.

To support the Other Minds New Music Preservation Project/radiOM.org, in consortium with Internet Archive. This project will convert archival live recordings of performances, interviews, and conversations with innovative composers and artists of 20th century American music into digital media and make available worldwide, via Internet at www.radiOM.org for free public access. Other Minds will select and prepare the materials featuring leading American artists, such as Lou Harrison, Pauline Oliveros, Rainer Schulte, Brian Eno, and Frank Zappa.

To support OM16, the 16th annual new music festival, including composer residencies, a panel discussion, free workshop, and lecture-demonstration session. Participting composers include Jason Moran, Ken Ueno, Janice Giteck, Michael Gordon, and John Zorn (United States); Louis Andriessen and Han Bennink (Netherlands); Agata Zubel (Poland); and Howard Skempton (United Kingdom).

To support the New Music Preservation Project, in consortium with the Internet Archive. Other Minds will convert archival recordings of performances, interviews, and conversations with leading composers and artists of 20th-century American music and make them available for a worldwide audience via radiOM.org.
To support "Dane Rudhyar: The Magic of Tone." Chamber music concerts of Rudhyar's compositions will be performed in San Francisco and in Portola Valley, California.

To support OM15, the 15th annual new music festival. Activities will be held at the Jewish Community Center in San Francisco, with guest composers participating in a four-day residency that will include a panel discussion, free workshop, and lecture-demonstration session.

To support a project to convert archival recordings for free public access via the Internet, in consortium with Internet Archive. Other Minds will select and prepare the materials featuring performances, interviews, and conversations recorded live by leading composers and artists of 20th-century American music.
To support "Henry Cowell: The Whole World of Music." Chamber music concerts of Cowell's compositions will be performed in Tateuchi Hall at the Finn Center in Mountain View, California.

To support OM14, the 14th annual new music festival. Activities will be held at the Jewish Community Center of San Francisco, with guest composers participating in a four-day residency that will include a panel discussion, free workshop, and lecture-demonstration session.
To support a celebration of the life and works of American composer Ruth Crawford Seeger and her contemporaries. Performances will be held at the Swedenborgian Church in San Francisco.

To support a CD recording project featuring works of rarely heard historical American music for violin and piano performed by violinist Kate Stenberg and pianist Eva-Maria Zimmermann. The SCENES FROM A SEANCE CD recording will be released on the Other Minds label.

To support OM13, the 13th annual new music festival. The festival will be held at the Jewish Community Center of San Francisco, with guest composers participating in a residency that will include a panel discussion, free workshop, and lecture-demonstration session.

To support a project to convert archival recordings for free public access via the internet in consortium with Internet Archive. Other Minds will select and prepare the materials featuring performances, interviews, and conversation recorded live by leading composers and artists of 20th-century American music.
To support the "Other Minds Festival 12." Guest composers will also participate in a four-day residency that will include a panel discussion, free workshop, and lecture-demonstration session.
To support "The History of New Music Preservation Project" in preserving recordings of performances and interviews by leading figures in new music.

To support the conversion of archival recordings for free public access in consortium with Internet Archive. Consortium partner Internet Archive will select and prepare the materials featuring performances, interviews, and conversation recorded live by leading composers and artists of 20th-century American music.

To support, in consortium with Internet Archive, the digital conversion of archival recordings for free public access via the Internet. Other Minds and consortium partner Internet Archive will select and prepare the materials featuring performances, interviews, and conversation recorded live by leading composers and artists of 20th-century American music.

To support OM11, an annual new music festival performed at Yerba Buena Center. Composers will participate in a four-day residency that will include concerts, a panel discussion and a free workshop and lecture-demonstration.
To support OM10, the 10th annual Other Minds new music festival. At least two new works will be premiered by virtuoso musicians during the festival.

To support the commissioning and presentation of a new work by Rova Saxophone Quartet member Jon Raskin. The work will be premiered by the quartet and an ensemble of virtuoso musicians at the Other Minds Festival.

To support a consortium project, "New Music in America," that will preserve more than 3,500 hours of original live conversations, interviews, and performances by leading American composers and artists of the 20th and early 21st centuries. The San Francisco Performing Arts Library and Museum will collaborate on the project to convert the aging analog archive into a digital medium.
To support the commission and presentation of a new work by Randy Weston. It will be premiered by the composer and the African Rhythms ensemble at the Other Minds Festival in San Francisco.

To support artists' fees and expenses related to the fifth Other Minds Festival. This week-long international contemporary music festival will take place in the spring of 1999 in the San Francisco Bay area.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work. The project will consist of a collaboration between Filipino American choreographer Pearl Ubungen and Filipino composer Joey Ayala, and take place in San Francisco, CA and St. Paul, MN.

Purpose: To support spoken-word poetry residencies for youth from underserved communities. Additional Project Description: Professional teaching artists will lead high school students through year-long residencies aligned with their schools' curriculum. In addition to instruction in writing and poetry performance, students will study this multidisciplinary performance art forms' language, history, and cultural context. Students will attend performances by a diverse roster of spoken-word artists and perform at an annual student showcase for their peers, families, and the general public.
