Intended Beneficiaries: High school students from underserved communities will benefit from the project. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the teaching of capoeira as part of the Artists-in-Schools program. Capoeira, a traditional art form originating in Afro-Brazilian culture and rooted in West African tribal traditions, brings together dance, music, cultural heritage, martial arts, history, and the Portuguese language. Students will learn creative thinking, concentration, leadership, communication skills, and respect for self and others. They also will be able to apply the discipline required for Capoeira to their classroom studies and community involvement.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Artists-in-Schools program. Professional artists will provide standards-aligned learning opportunities in creative movement, theater arts, creative writing, world dance, and music to youth in schools and child development centers.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Artists-in-Schools program. Artists-in-residence will provide schools with a combination of world dance, theater, music, and creative writing including eight, 30-week intensive residencies and eight, 15-week moderate residencies, totaling 360 hours of direct arts instruction.

To support continuation of the Artists in Schools evaluation. The research study of student learning in and through the arts will focus on student performance at up to 10 elementary schools in San Francisco, San Mateo, and Marin County.

Category: Challenge America Positive Alternatives for Youth
Project Description: To support a partnership project of artist-led activities that provides positive alternatives for youth. The partnership with Hamilton Family Center will provide 10 artist residencies serving more than 150 students living in two San Francisco homeless shelters. Professional artists will lead multiple, one-hour classes in dance, theater, and creative writing over a 12-month period.

To support the "Artists-in-Schools (AIS)" program. The project places professional artists in schools to conduct 15-week, process-oriented residencies in creative movement, theater, and world dance to enhance the academic experience of educationally and economically disadvantaged students.

To support the production of an experimental narrative film script by Paul Kwan and Arnold Iger. Agnosia: Confessions of a Tasteless Critic will take an offbeat look at the relationship between food, culture, and memory.

To support Let's Play the Kulintang, an instructional video. The compact disc will consist of 12 musical compositions and rituals of southern Philippine culture to be taught by National Heritage Fellow and kulintang master Danongan S. Kalanduyan.

To support the tour of the play peregriNasyon to cities throughout the state of California. The Philippine Information Education Resource Center's tour of peregriNasyon will create access for Filipino populations and multicultural audiences to a play based upon the Filipino American experience.

To support the Palabuniyan Kulintang Music  Dance Ensemble's outreach program, featuring Danongan Kalanduyan, a National Heritage Fellow, with concerts and presentations in cities with significant Filipino populations, such as Oakland, Sacramento, San Francisco, and Los Angeles. The Palabuniyan Music  Dance Ensemble uses some instruments that are rarely seen in the U.S., and present the artform in context with its origins in the Philippines. Targeted audiences are new immigrants and the Filipino-American children residing in the U.S. Teacher kits with maps, cultural background, and specific information about the instruments and repertory, as well as the changing aspect of culture in the U.S. will be an important aspect of the project.

Purpose: To support the Bay Area Playwrights Festival. Additional Project Description: The festival will provide emerging playwrights with a nurturing and rigorous environment to advance their new plays toward completion including a weekend artist retreat, access to a professional creative team, time and space for rewriting and rehearsal, panel discussions with topic experts, and staged readings for the public. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival will support playwrights from across the nation and residents in the San Francisco Bay Area interested in new dramatic literature and the new work development process. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the Bay Area Playwrights Festival. Additional Project Description: The festival will provide emerging playwrights with a nurturing and rigorous environment to advance their new plays toward completion including a weekend artist retreat, a professional creative team, time and space for rewriting and rehearsal, panel discussions with topic experts, and staged readings for the public. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival will support playwrights from across the nation and residents in the San Francisco Bay Area interested in new dramatic literature and the new work development process. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support readings of plays in development during the Bay Area Playwrights Festival. The project will include an artists' retreat, studio development time, and public staged readings of full-length, unproduced plays by emerging playwrights, some of which may be offered virtually. The festival is designed to support new theatrical works by Bay Area and national playwrights and showcase their work to audiences.

To support the annual Bay Area Playwrights Festival. The project will include an artists' retreat, studio development time, and two weekends of public staged readings of full-length, unproduced plays by emerging and mid-career playwrights. Plays will be selected from an open submission process. The festival is designed to support the new theatrical works by Bay Area and national playwrights as they experiment with new ideas, develop and nurture collaborative relationships, push the boundaries of the form, and showcase their work to audiences.

To support educational activities associated with the Bay Area Playwrights Festival. Activities will include a young theater-makers event, panels and lectures associated with Festival plays, and an industry weekend during which national new play producers will be invited to San Francisco to see staged readings of plays presented in the Festival. Young artists will be selected to be mentored by participating Festival playwrights, and will participate in all Festival activities.

To support the Bay Area Playwrights Festival. The festival will include an artistic retreat, studio development of new plays, and publicly staged readings of full-length plays. Plays for staged readings will be selected through a competitive submission process. The festival also will present a workshop production of a play in development at a partner theater.

To support the Bay Area Playwrights Festival. The festival will include an artistic retreat, studio development of new plays, and publicly staged showings of full-length plays. Festival plays for staged readings will be selected through a competitive submission process. The festival also will present a workshop production of a play in development at a partner theater. Other festival activities will include a young theater-makers event, mentorship for emerging scenic designers, and an industry weekend, during which national new play producers are invited to San Francisco to see the plays.

To support the Bay Area Playwrights Festival. The festival will include an artistic retreat, studio development of new plays, and publicly staged showings of full-length plays. Festival plays for staged readings will be selected through a competitive submission process. The festival also will present workshop productions of plays in development at partner theaters, including an in-depth workshop of "A Wonderverse," a new experimental play by Geetha Reddy.

To support the Bay Area Playwrights Festival. The festival will include a three-day artistic retreat, studio development of new plays, and two weekends of public staged showings of full-length plays. Festival plays for staged readings will be selected through a competitive submission process. The festival will also present workshop productions of plays in development at partner theaters, including an in-depth workshop of "Ozma of Oz," a new musical by Rob Melrose, artistic director of Cutting Ball Theater.

To support the 36th anniversary presentation of the Bay Area Playwrights Festival, a new play development event that serves as a laboratory and showcase for Bay Area playwrights. The festival includes a week of studio work and two weekends of staged readings of eight new plays.
To support the 35th anniversary presentation of the Bay Area Playwrights Festival. The festival includes studio work and publically-staged readings of up to eight new plays.

To support the development and premiere of THE HUNDRED FLOWERS PROJECT, a new play by Asian American playwright Christopher Chen, in consortium with Crowded Fire Theater Company. With participation by the Lark Play Development Center, a new model for a multistep development process will emerge, involving a national community of participating theaters that will provide workshop performances, table readings, and public showcases, as the project investigates the reign of Mao Tse-tung's "cult of personality" and its powerful impact on the modern world.

To support the "Bay Area Playwrights Festival." Professional and emerging playwrights collaborate with other arts professionals in an intensive creative process to develop new work during a week in the studio and two weekends of public staged readings of eight new works presented at The Thick House in San Francisco.

To support the "Bay Area Playwrights Festival." The festival brings professional and emerging playwrights from diverse aesthetic and cultural backgrounds together with other arts professionals in an intensive creative process to develop new work.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support the 30th Annual Bay Area Playwrights Festival. The festival includes an artists' retreat, artistic collaborations, development of new theater works, a commissioning program, symposia, outreach activities, and a series of staged readings of new work by emerging and established writers.

To support the 28th Annual Bay Area Playwrights Festival. The festival includes an artists' retreat, artistic collaborations, development of short plays, a commissioning program, symposia, outreach activities, and a series of staged readings of new work by vanguard regional and national writers.

To support the 27th Annual Bay Area Playwrights Festival. The festival includes staged readings of new works by regional and national writers, a commissioning project, an Annual Artists Retreat, a playwright fellowship, and artists' collaborations.
To support the 26th annual Bay Area Playwrights Festival. The festival is a series of staged readings of new work by vanguard regional and national writers.
To support the Bay Area Playwrights Festival. The festival supports the development and presentation of new works by emerging playwrights.

To support planning for the New Play Resources initiative designed to formalize and expand the foundation's role as a catalyst between playwrights and theater companies. The Playwrights Foundation, founded in 1976, is dedicated to new play development and to providing playwrights with opportunities to refine their craft and present new work through the Bay Area Playwrights Festival, an annual series of staged readings. The roster of Bay Area Playwright festival participants includes some of the most acclaimed and innovative playwrights working today including Sam Shepard, Maria Irene Fornes, David Henry Hwang, and Anna Deavere Smith. The goals of the project include structural development in keeping with the organization's plans for future growth and extension of existing services provided to playwrights and theater companies. The company plans to increase Artistic Director responsibilities to year-round, create a library of selected new plays including exceptional works by Bay Area playwrights, purchase computer equipment and software for database management, hire a part-time administrative assistant to maintain the company's script repository, and conduct targeted marketing to inform theaters and playwrights of these new services.

Purpose: To support personnel costs for the creation of A Pocket Magic Flute, in which the Mozart opera will be condensed into a 45-minute animated and live-action film version for children. Additional Project Description: The company will create A Pocket Magic Flute, a children's version of Mozart's The Magic Flute featuring a primarily African-American cast and creative team. The singing portions of the opera will be showcased by singers set to animation, and the speaking portions of the opera will be live action, with animation background, casting actors from the Lorraine Hansberry Theatre. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances will benefit San Francisco Bay Area audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.
To support the translation and performance of Stanislaw Moniuszko's opera THE HAUNTED MANOR.
To support the creation of the mural "Making Friends Across Diverse Cultures" at the Bret Harte Elementary School. Artists Brenda Miller and Susan Cervantes will lead the visual arts project.

To support the creation of murals in community settings. Sites include Leonard R. Flynn Elementary School, Bret Harte Elementary School,the Silver Avenue Health Center, and the St. Vincent De Paul homeless shelter.

To support research and development of a book documenting the murals of San Franciso's Mission District. To be published and distributed by the University of California Press, the volume will present the murals in full-color photographs.

To support a mural project in the economically disadvantaged neighborhood of Bayview/Hunters Point. Led by muralists Susan Cervantes, Keith Lewis, and Mary Newson, the project will involve members of the community in the planning, design, and execution of the mural.

To support "Sister Spaces," a collaborative exhibition project among alternative artists organizations in different countries, with an accompanying catalogue. IT Park in Taipei, Taiwan; The Physics Room in Christchurch, New Zealand; and Ze dos Bois in Lisbon, Portugal will collaborate with Southern Exposure on an exhibition highlighting artists' work from each country.

To support Race, Representation and Youth, Southern Exposure's media literacy program to promote greater understanding of cultural representation in mass media. The project, which is integrated into the curriculum of a San jFrancisco high school, is a collaborative endeavor between artists and teachers.

To support a consortium project entitled, "Mission Voices," an arts education program for Mission District youth organized in collaboration with social service organizations in San Francisco to encourage creative expression. A combined effort between Southern Exposure, Horizons Unlimited, La Casa de los Jovenes, and Youth in Action, the program draws upon the experience and expertise of artists, youth workers, counselors, and community workers. Called "Mission Voices," the program emphasizes the importance of creativity for young people, taking into account a few simple elements: self-esteem, cultural and vocational opportunities, community pride, and developing a voice through art. One artist is paired with a dozen or so students from each organization and one youth supervisor. Each group meets twice a week for three-hour sessions. The three groups come together periodically for collective activities and projects, facilitated by a guest artist. The program culminates in a performance and exhibition at Southern Exposure, and all of the program participants will be involved in assessment and evaluation.

To support the "1% Program," which connects nonprofits with pro bono services from architecture and design firms. Project activities include the engagement of national, high impact nonprofits to expand the "1% Program" to specifically meet the design needs of national nonprofits and their local affiliates.

To support the global coalition of designers, educators, and business leaders to Public Design Studio's 1% Program, in consortium with The Designers Accord. The amalgam will expand the variety of pro bono design services available to nonprofit organizations through the 1% Program.

To support the design and distribution of a pro-bono design innovation book by Public Architecture. The book will explore the impact of architecture and pro-bono design services on nonprofit organizations and communities.

To support the Pro Bono Road Show. The traveling exhibition will showcase excellence in pro bono design, inspiring both architects and nonprofits organizations by raising collective awareness about the potential of pro-bono design including its importance in improving public life.

To support The 1% Design Advocates program, in consortium with the Taproot Foundation. Public Architecture will create a network of design firms to promote the power of architecture and pro bono design services to nonprofit organizations.

To support the 1% Solution, a network for architecture professionals to pledge one percent of their billable hours to pro bono work. Public Architecture's interactive Web site, along with training sessions, will connect willing architects with nonprofit organizations and communities seeking design services.

To support the creation of online documentation of pro bono design services for nonprofit organizations in consortium with Taproot Foundation. They will collaboarate to identify pro bono design projects that exemplify excellence in architectural design, experimental use of space or materials, significant empowerment of a community or population, and a uniquely collaborative design process.

To support the 1% Solution, a network for architecture professionals to pledge one percent of their billable hours to pro bono work. The next phase of the project, the 1% Matching Program, will include developing and implementing an interactive website that will match willing architects with not-for-profit organizations and communities seeking design services.

To support a publication about library design, a consortium project with Robin Hood Foundation. The publication will document the Robin Hood Foundation's L!brary Initiative, which provides new libraries for New York public schools.

To support the development of a network for architecture professionals to pledge one percent of their billable hours to pro bono work. Using an interactive website, willing architects will be connected with not-for-profit organizations and communities seeking design services.

Organization Name: QCC-The Center for Lesbian Gay Bisexual Transgender Art & Culture
Project Description: Purpose: To support the presentation of the 25th anniversary National Queer Arts Festival. Additional Project Description: QCC will present new works by emerging and mid-career LGBTQ+ artists of color from the Bay Area. Artists in disciplines including storytelling, theater, and multidisciplinary performance will receive commissioning fees and production assistance. Productions will reflect the lives and experiences of marginalized LGBTQ+ and BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color) artists. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival will benefit San Francisco Bay Area audiences and BIPOC and LGBTQ+ artists. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Organization Name: QCC-The Center for Lesbian Gay Bisexual Transgender Art & Culture
Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organizations constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

Organization Name: QCC-The Center for Lesbian Gay Bisexual Transgender Art & Culture
Project Description: To support the virtual presentation of the National Queer Arts Festival. The Queer Cultural Center will present in a virtual format new works by artists from the Bay Area. Artists in disciplines including storytelling, dance, theater, music, and multidisciplinary performance will receive commissioning fees and production assistance.

Organization Name: QCC-The Center for Lesbian Gay Bisexual Transgender Art & Culture
Project Description: To support planning costs for the National Queer Arts Festival. Staff will collaborate on planning for a multidisciplinary festival featuring LGBTQ artists in disciplines including storytelling, dance, theater, music, and multidisciplinary performance.

Organization Name: QCC-The Center for Lesbian Gay Bisexual Transgender Art & Culture
Project Description: To support the presentation of new work at the National Queer Arts Festival. QCC will present new works by commissioned LGBTQ artists of color from the Bay Area. Artists in disciplines including storytelling, theater, and multidisciplinary performance will receive commissioning fees and production assistance.

Organization Name: QCC-The Center for Lesbian Gay Bisexual Transgender Art & Culture
Project Description: To support the presentation of new work at the National Queer Arts Festival. QCC will present new works by commissioned LGBT artists of color from the Bay Area. Artists in disciplines including storytelling, theater, and multidisciplinary performance will receive commissioning fees and production assistance.

Organization Name: QCC-The Center for Lesbian Gay Bisexual Transgender Art & Culture
Project Description: To support National Queer Arts Festival presentations. Events featuring and focusing on LGBT artists of color, will include a photography exhibition, performances, and documentary screenings. All activities will take place in Oakland, California.

Organization Name: QCC-The Center for Lesbian Gay Bisexual Transgender Art & Culture
Project Description: To support the 2012 East Bay Queer Arts Festival, in consortium with La Pena Cultural Center. The festival will include literary and stage readings, film screenings, and performing arts presentations.

Organization Name: QCC-The Center for Lesbian Gay Bisexual Transgender Art & Culture
Project Description: To support a capacity-building professional development program for emerging Bay Area lesbian, bisexual, and transgender arts organizations and artists. The Center will offer workshops for artists and organizations proposing to present works at the annual National Queer Arts Festival.

Organization Name: Queer Women of Color Media Arts Project - QWOCMAP
Project Description: Purpose: To support staff salaries for the Queer Women of Color Film Festival and associated public programming. Additional Project Description: The virtual and in-person festival will feature films from around the world highlighting the experience of LGBTQ and gender nonconforming people of color, accompanied by moderated discussions with filmmakers, academics, and community leaders. Presented with partnering organizations, the curated programming will connect audiences with social issues featured in presented films, as well as increase accessibility for people with disabilities. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival will benefit audiences online and in the Bay Area, as well as participating artists and community partners, with a focus on individuals that identify as queer women of color. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Organization Name: Queer Women of Color Media Arts Project - QWOCMAP
Project Description: Purpose: To support an artistic and professional development program for underrepresented filmmakers. Additional Project Description: Intended to advance gender and racial equity in the film industry, QWOCMAP will provide emerging and early-career filmmakers with master classes, regular mentorship from film industry professionals, work-in-progress screenings and feedback, as well as access to equipment. Activities may take place virtually as necessary. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit emerging and early-career filmmakers, with a focus on artists that identify as queer women of color. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

Organization Name: Queer Women of Color Media Arts Project - QWOCMAP
Project Description: To support staffing costs for the annual Queer Women of Color Film festival and associated public programming. Presenting films from around the world highlighting the experience of LGBTQ and gender nonconforming people of color, this year's free, public festival will include a focus on disabled communities, disaster preparedness, and the environment. In partnership with community organizations, festival screenings will be accompanied by panels and public discussions with filmmakers, artists, academics, and community leaders. Some project activity may take place virtually.

Organization Name: Queer Women of Color Media Arts Project - QWOCMAP
Project Description: To support the Filmmaker Training Program. Online workshops will provide students with skills in scripting, storyboarding, production planning, cinematography, directing, and editing, making filmmaking financially accessible and equipping participants with tools to develop professional careers.

Organization Name: Queer Women of Color Media Arts Project - QWOCMAP
Project Description: To support the public exhibition of commissioned films made by local residents that explore the contributions of LGBTQ people of color to the history and culture of San Francisco. Commissioned in collaboration with local human services agencies, cultural institutions, and community organizations, the online screenings will take place during the Queer Women of Color Film Festival.

Organization Name: Queer Women of Color Media Arts Project - QWOCMAP
Project Description: To support the Filmmaker Training Program. Workshops will provide students with skills in scripting, storyboarding, production planning, cinematography, directing, and editing. The free workshops make filmmaking financially accessible and equip participants with the skills and tools to develop professional careers. Focusing on Two Spirits - queer women, gender nonconforming and transgender people who are First Nations, Native American, American Indian and Indigenous - workshop participants will be encouraged to create films that explore their unique history, dispel stereotypes, and examine the spiritual and societal roles of their culture.

Organization Name: Queer Women of Color Media Arts Project - QWOCMAP
Project Description: To support the Filmmaker Training Program. Workshops provide students with skills in scripting, storyboarding, production planning, cinematography, directing, and editing. The free workshops make filmmaking financially accessible and equip participants with the skills and tools to develop professional careers.

Organization Name: Queer Women of Color Media Arts Project - QWOCMAP
Project Description: To support the Filmmaker Training Program The workshops provide adult students from underserved communities with skills in scripting, storyboarding, production planning, cinematography, directing, and editing. The free workshops make filmmaking financially accessible and equip the participants with the skills and tools to develop professional careers.

Organization Name: Queer Women of Color Media Arts Project - QWOCMAP
Project Description: To support the Filmmaker Training Program. The 16-week hands-on workshops provide underserved students with skills in scripting, storyboarding, production planning, cinematography, directing and editing.
To support "RADAR Lab," a writer's retreat targeting lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender writers. Scheduled faculty includes Michelle Tea, Eileen Myles, and Jewelle Gomez.

To support the creation of a new dance, "Double Exposure." Comprising 12 duets and created by multiple choreographers, the duets will be constructed into an evening-length work and will be performed by Co-Artistic Directors Ryan Smith and Wendy Rein. Smith and Rein will work with artists Joe Goode, KT Nelson (ODC/Dance), Shinichi and Dana Iova-Koga (InkBoat), and Ann Carlson. The company is approaching the work like museum curation, seeking diverse points of view and applications of the form (including dance film) to make a complete exhibition.

Organization Name: Regents of the University of California, San Francisco
Project Description: Purpose: To support a research agenda and associated studies that will be designed and implemented by the Sound and Music Perception Lab. Additional Project Description: This NEA Research Lab in the Arts, Creativity, Cognition, and Learning will build on work completed through two prior NEA Research Lab awards, which supported a series of studies identifying biological/neural bases for creativity across a range of art forms such as music, comedic improvisation, and visual arts. Accomplishments to date include the completion of separate studies on these three different art forms, and research publications in outlets such as "Current Opinions in Behavioral Sciences," "NeuroImage," and the "Encyclopedia of Creativity." The lab's projects also have garnered media coverage from "60 Minutes" and "Wired" magazine, and resulted in presentations at venues such as the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and the Juilliard School. Activities during the renewal phase will include continuing to test eminent artists as case studies, recruiting new participants, running additional models on past participants, and writing research publications and disseminating those materials to artists, scientists, and the general public. Under the lab's renewal, researchers will complete case studies of a select group of NEA Jazz Masters honorees. This effort will involve surveying and interviewing the honorees to document the artists' daily habits and creative processes and rituals. Further activities will include developing instruments that can be used in an fMRI machine to allow for brain imaging of case-study participants who use a range of different arts materials and instruments. Intended Beneficiaries: The project has the potential to benefit researchers and educators studying the scientific basis of artists' creativity. Intended Outcome: Research, statistics, and general information about the arts benefit the arts sector and other fields.

To support AFRICA IN THE PICTURE . Resolution will acquire eight recent African feature films, documentaries, experimental videos and television programs to distribute to institutional venues (universities, libraries, etc.), semi-theatrical exhibitors (film festivals, media arts centers), and public television stations.

To support "African Cinema 2000: A Celebration of Ubuntu," a circulating tour of recently produced African films. After the films are subtitled and distributed on 35mm prints, Resolution will make video tapes of the works, write a catalog to accompany the collection, and offer the package to audiences via its Library of African Cinema.

Discipline / Field: Creative Links: Positive Alternatives for Youth
Project Description: To support a Creative Links project to provide positive alternatives for youth. The partnership brings together the Neighborhood Center, California Poets in the Schools, and the San Francisco Arts Education Project to allow a lead artist to work with ten to 15 middle-school students in the Richmond District where English is a second language in 50% of the households. Students will take classes in writing poetry, computer design and layout, and will publish an anthology of their work.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Discipline / Field: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support personnel and facilities costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the creation and presentation of "Trick Bags/Trap Doors/Painted Corners," a series of new works by Artistic Director Robert Moses. The piece will explore the parallel paths taken from childhood to adulthood, based on race and possibility, and will look at the displacement, disconnection, and lifetime of personal disparity that results from these separate paths. "Trick Bags/Trap Doors/Painted Corners" will be a triptych and premiere in three parts: onstage at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts; outside at the famous Powell Street cable car turn-around; and in the historically African-American and now changing Bayview neighborhood of San Francisco.

To support the creation and presentation of "Fable and Faith" by artistic director and choreographer Robert Moses. In collaboration with playwright Anne Galjour, Bay Area vocal musicians Bay City Luv, and the San Francisco Boys Chorus, Moses will create the work and it will premiere as the centerpiece of the company's 16th anniversary home season at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.

To support the creation and premiere of THE CINDERELLA PRINCIPLE, a new work by artistic director Robert Moses. The work will premiere as the centerpiece of Robert Moses' Kin's 15th Anniversary home series at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, San Francisco.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work by artistic director and choreographer Robert Moses. The work, tentatively titled Redline, will premiere at The Jewish Community Center of San Francisco.

To support phase two of the creation and presentation of THE LOST PARADE, a new work by artistic director and choreographer Robert Moses. THE LOST PARADE will premiere at the Jewish Community Center in San Francisco, California.
To support the creation of a new work by choreographer Robert Moses. The President's Daughter will premiere as the centerpiece of the company's 10th anniversary.

Purpose: To support a series of exhibitions, accompanying catalogues, and public programming featuring work by contemporary artists. Additional Project Description: Bay Area artists will present works that explore contemporary ideas and issues in a variety of media including painting, drawing, sculpture, photography, installation, video, film, new media, and performance art. The series will include as many as 350 artists and will engage the public through panel discussions and related public programming. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit emerging artists as well as a diverse audience including curators, arts professionals, and educators, with a focus on outreach to youth participants and families. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support a series of exhibitions and accompanying catalogues featuring work by contemporary artists, with associated public programming. Additional Project Description: Bay Area artists will present works that explore contemporary ideas and issues in a variety of mediums including painting, drawing, sculpture, photography, installation, video, film, new media, and performance art. The series will include as many as 350 artists and will engage the public through artist panel discussions and related public programming. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit a diverse audience including emerging artists, curators, arts professionals, and educators with a focus on outreach to youth participants and families. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the Second Saturday Exhibition Series and accompanying catalogs. Bay Area artists will present works that explore contemporary ideas and issues in a variety of media including painting, drawing, sculpture, photography, installation, video, film, new media, and performance art. The series will include as many as 350 artists and will engage the public through artist panel discussions and related public programming. Exhibitions will be presented both in-person and online, with programming taking place virtually as necessary.

To support the Second Saturday Exhibition Series, a collection of visual arts events and presentations of work by Bay Area artists. Local artists will present works that explore contemporary ideas and issues in a variety of media including painting, drawing, sculpture, photography, installation, video, film, new media, and performance work. The series will include as many as 350 artists, and will engage the public through open gallery hours, artist panels, and related public programming. Some project activities may take place virtually.

To support the Second Saturday Exhibition Series, a collection of visual arts events and presentations of work by Bay Area artists. Local artists will present works that explore contemporary ideas and issues in a variety of media including painting, drawing, sculpture, photography, installation, video, film, new media, and performance work. The series will include as many as 350 artists, and will engage the public through open gallery hours, artist panels, and related public programming.

To support the Second Saturday Exhibition Series, a collection of visual arts events and presentations of work by Bay Area artists. Local artists will present works that explore contemporary ideas and current social concerns in a variety of media including painting, drawing, sculpture, photography, installation, video, film, new media, and performance work. The series will engage the public through open gallery hours, artist panels, and related public programming.

To support the Second Saturday Exhibition Series. The project is a collection of visual arts events and presentations of work by Bay Area artists. Local artists will present works that explore contemporary ideas and current social concerns in a variety of media including painting, drawing, sculpture, photography, installation, video, film, new media, and performance work. The series will include more than 350 artists, and will engage the public through open gallery hours, artist panels, and related public programming.

To support the Second Saturday Exhibition Series and accompanying catalogues. The series will present a unique event or exhibition on the second Saturday of each month highlighting the painting, drawing, sculpture, photography, installation, video, film, new media, and performance work of Bay Area visual artists. Hundreds of artists are expected to participate in the series and commissions of new work will be presented.

To support the Second Saturday Exhibition Series, a collection of visual art events taking place in San Francisco's Mission District. The series will present a unique event or exhibition opening on the second Saturday of each month highlighting the painting, drawing, sculpture, photography, installation, video, film, new media, and performance work of Bay Area visual art artists.

To support the creation and presentation of "Grand Electric Skull." The multimedia work will be created by the Rova Saxophone Quartet, artist Ikue Mori, and composer/conductor Gino Robair and will culminate in a performance at San Francisco's Jewish Community Center.

To support "Cleaning the Mirror", a documentary film focused on the re-envisioning of John Coltrane's 1965 work Ascension. The work has been re-envisioned as Electric Ascension by the Rova Saxophone Quartet.

To support "Fissures, Futures," a series of performances and lecture-demonstrations on music improvisation by the Rova Saxophone Quartet. Programming will feature guest artists and composers and focus on the ideas of R. Buckminster Fuller, the visionary American architect.
To support Improv:21, a series of lecture-demonstrations on music improvisation. The programs will feature guest artists and composers with the Rova Saxophone Quartet in San Francisco.

To support "Rovate IV: An Improviser's Festival," Rova Saxophone Quartet's collaborative project and festival. This 2001 project will feature premieres of new works by Wadada Leo Smith, Graham Connah, and John Schott.
To support "Rovate III," a collaborative project and festival. This 1999-2000 project will feature drummer/composer Gerry Hemingway and a premiere of a new work by Graham Connah.

To support artists' fees and related expenses for a collaborative project and festival. This 1999 project will involve Sam Rivers and Orkestrova--a large ensemble of Bay area musicians organized by Rova Saxophone Quartet.
To support the Bay Area Emerging Composers Project, the Rova Saxophone Quartet's new initiative of commissioning and performing the works of promising young composers.

Purpose: To support a curated series of Spanish-language films and associated public programming. Additional Project Description: The film series will showcase international narrative, documentary, and independent cinema featuring underrepresented stories from Spanish-speaking countries and filmmakers. Select events will include post-screening discussions with visiting filmmakers and community partners. Project activities may take place virtually as necessary. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve filmmakers and partner organizations, as well as local audiences in the San Francisco Bay Area and streaming audiences nationwide, with a focus on Spanish-speaking communities. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support a year-round curated series of Spanish-language films and associated public programming. Additional Project Description: Showcasing international narrative, documentary, and independent cinema featuring underrepresented stories from Spanish-speaking countries and film artists, screenings are complemented by discussions and presentations from visiting filmmakers about their work. Intended Beneficiaries: Programs will serve participating artists, partner organizations, and public audiences, with a focus on Spanish-speaking communities in the San Francisco area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Mud Bus, a mobile ceramic studio equipped with materials and tools needed to teach ceramic classes to youth in underserved communities in San Francisco. Families are invited to attend an opening reception for the professionally presented display of the students' work at Ruby's Gallery at the end of the program.

Organization Name: San Francisco Art and Film Program
Project Description: To support the Teen Film Workshop. The media arts education project will prepare students for film school and train them for careers in the film industry. Students will participate in lectures and film viewings, which will provide them with a foundation in theory; they then will apply what they have learned as they design and produce individual films and a group film. The program will culminate in the presentation of student work at the San Francisco Art Institute.

Organization Name: San Francisco Art and Film Program
Project Description: To support the Teen Film Workshop, an arts education project designed to prepare students for film school and train them for careers in the film industry. Students will participate in lectures and film viewings, which will provide them with a foundation in theory; they then apply what they have learned as they design and produce individual films and a group film.

Organization Name: San Francisco Art and Film Program
Project Description: To support the Teen Film Workshop, an arts education project designed to prepare students for film school and train them for careers in the film industry. Students will participate in lectures and film viewings, which will provide them with a foundation in theory; they then apply what they have learned as they design and produce individual films and a group film.

Organization Name: San Francisco Art and Film Program
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Teen Film Workshop. Students will attend lectures and films, learn a foundation in theory; they then will design and produce individual films and a group film.

Organization Name: San Francisco Art and Film Program
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Teen Film Workshop. The project is designed to prepare students for film school and train them for future careers in the film industry.

Organization Name: San Francisco Art and Film Program
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Teen Film Workshop. The project is designed to prepare students for film school and train them for future careers in the film industry.

Organization Name: San Francisco Art and Film Program
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Teen Film Workshop. The project is designed to prepare students for film school and train them for future careers in the film industry.

Organization Name: San Francisco Art and Film Program
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support continuation of the Teen Film Workshop. The project is designed to prepare students for film school and train them for future careers in the film industry.

Organization Name: San Francisco Art and Film Program
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support continuation of the Teen Film Workshop. The project is designed to prepare students for film school and train them for future careers in the film industry.

Organization Name: San Francisco Art and Film Program
Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support continuation of the "Teen Film Workshop." The project is designed introduce students to the film production process and provide them with the skills, knowledge and understanding that will help them pursue a future in filmmaking.

Organization Name: San Francisco Art and Film Program
Project Description: To support continuation of the Teen Film Workshop. The film workshop is designed to prepare high school juniors and seniors aged 16 to 18 for film school and train them for future careers in the film industry.

To support programming to examine the San Francisco Art Institute's influence on American art in its 150-year history. The SFAI will mount exhibitions examining the legacy of artists, introduce a podcast series exploring its 150-year history and post an online presentation of exhibits.

To support the traveling exhibition and catalogue Carlos Villa: Rituals and Actions. The exhibition will feature works of Filipino-American artist Carlos Villa (1936-2013), alongside ethnographic objects from the Philippines. The exhibition will be presented at the Newark Museum in New Jersey and the San Francisco Arts Commission in California.

To support the conservation of Frederick Olmsted, Jr.'s New Deal-era fresco "Marble Workers at Fisherman's Wharf." The fresco "Marble Workers at Fisherman's Wharf" by Frederick Olmsted, Jr., is part of a larger group of works dating back to the 1930s under restoration inside the school's main building, which includes frescos by Diego Rivera and Marjorie Eakin. Conservation will include removal of paint and urethane and the restoration of previous in-painting and fills. Free and open to the public seven days a week, the school will use the frescos as teaching tools, exposing students to the art of the fresco and the science of conservation.

To support a digital engagement project to enhance audience participation in public programming. Artists will integrate content from exhibitions, lectures, performances, symposia, and other public events in an effort to connect visitors to the organization's programs via mobile phone applications.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support City Studio Programs. Students (ages 13 to 19) will receive free arts instruction on-campus at the San Francisco Art Institute (SFAI) and at various locations encompassing three Bay Area counties.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support City Studio. At each of three sites, an SFAI faculty member and a group of approximately 15 students will work with professional artists to study photography, digital media, game design, and architecture.

Purpose: To support a visiting artist-in-residence, commissioning, and community engagement program. Additional Project Description: During the residency, California-based, multidisciplinary artist Agelio Batle will develop and present new commissions and exhibitions, and will produce multigenerational and interdisciplinary collaborative activities for artists and the community. Batle also will design physical and virtual engagement programs that will unify young people, their families, and neighborhoods, such as live performances, art classes, workshops, pop-up arts events, neighborhood walking tours, gallery tours, and field trips to local artist studios. Intended Beneficiaries: Programming will serve local young people from underserved communities (primarily in grades K-8), as well as their families, neighbors, and communities. The project also will benefit the artist-in-residence. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support a visiting artist-in-residence, commissioning, and community engagement program. San Francisco-based artist Taraneh Hemami (b. 1960) will be invited to further develop her project Green Parcels at the Minnesota Street Project campus, a warehouse district for economically sustainable artist spaces, art galleries, and related nonprofits. Hemami will work with the community during her residency, where she will continue her work on an installation that addresses the geography, ecology, and history of nearby neighborhoods. Project activity may take place virtually.

To support an artist-in-residence program for visual artist Zoe Farmer. Farmer will create a new body of work in collaboration with residents from underserved San Francisco neighborhoods. Exhibitions and programming curated by the participants will include theme-driven presentations that connect artist and community through tactile 3D objects, multimedia storytelling, artist talks, tours, and didactic graphics.

To support an exhibition exploring the legacy of artist and educator Ruth Asawa (1926-2013). The exhibition, guest curated by Larry Rinder, Director of the Berkeley Art Museum, will include original sculptural works illustrating the influence of the minimalist tendencies of American art in the 1960s alongside selected facsimiles from the artist's archives held at Stanford Libraries. Born in rural California to Japanese immigrants, the artist, perhaps best known for her wire sculptures, was deeply influenced by her family's detainment in Japanese internment camps during the Second World War. The exhibition will highlight Asawa's significant artistic contributions and ongoing influences in shaping educational pedagogy.

To support the creation and presention of "Inspired Bodies," a site-specific dance theater work. The work will honor the organization's 50th year and its legacy of participatory experiences in the arts for the children of San Francisco, their families, schools, and neighborhoods. "Inspired Bodies" will be developed and performed by SFArtsED's company of teen-aged players and young adult alums in collaboration with and engineered by core artists of the Joe Goode Performance Group. After roughly nine months of community engagement and production, "Inspired Bodies" will be presented over a series of public performances at the new Minnesota Street Project campus and the Joe Goode Annex in San Francisco. SFArtsED's veteran Artistic Director Emily Keeler will mentor throughout the creative process.

To support Give and Take: Artists and Youth in Dialogue, an artist-in-residence program which matches Bay Area artists with students for workshops and studio visits, culminating in a public exhibition with an accompanying catalogue This project will augment the San Francisco Arts Education Project's Visual Artist-in-Residence programs at 16 elementary and middle schools and community after-school sites. It will pair a set of diverse, mid- to late-career artists with students to engage in the processes of creative exchange and problem solving and to mutually produce a body of work that will be exhibited at an off-school site. Plans include a one-month installation at the Cowell Theater and Bayfront Gallery in Fort Mason. Most of this project will take place in the schools and centers, although students will participate in at least 20 field-trip visits to the artists' studios. The exhibition will be curated by Larry Rinder, the Twentieth-Century Art Curator at the University Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive at the University of California at Berkeley. The project will be evaluated in a number of formal and informal ways; the artists will document the students' process and progress with photographs and individual portfolios of student work, and a photographer and videographer will document different stages of the project.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVD-19 pandemic.

To support the creation and presentation of a new ballet. Alongside the performances, the company will offer a range of educational opportunities to the community related to the new works, allowing participants to explore the process of creating a new ballet and deepening their knowledge of ballet as an art form.

To support staff salaries for year-round, dance education programs at the San Francisco Ballet School. Kindergarten through high school age students from underserved neighborhoods will participate in tuition-free ballet and dance programs both in-person and/or virtually. Programs, led by professional dancers, will take place during the school year and in summer.
To support the creation and presentation of a new work by choreographer Cathy Marston. The work will be presented to the public at the War Memorial Opera House in San Francisco.

To support the creation and presentation of new ballets and a company premiere. Liam Scarlett and Yuri Possokhov will create two new repertory ballets. In addition, Benjamin Millepied will work with company dancers to present the company premiere of his ballet, Appassionata. The works will be presented to the public at the War Memorial Opera House in San Francisco.

To support the creation and presentation of dances as part of Unbound: A Festival of New Works. The goal of the festival is to advance contemporary ballet and encourage emerging choreographers to make new work. New works will be commissioned from a diverse group of 12 choreographers. The new dances will premiere at the War Memorial Opera House in San Francisco. Alongside the performances, the company will offer a range of educational opportunities to the community.

To support the creation and presentation of new ballets. Liam Scarlett, artist-in-residence at the Royal Ballet, will create a full-length story ballet based on "Frankenstein." Choreographers Christopher Wheeldon and Yuri Possokhov will develop new repertory works. Complementing the performances, there will be a range of educational opportunities offered to the community, such as lectures and interviews with the artists. The ballets will be presented at the War Memorial House in San Francisco.

To support the creation and presentation of several new ballets. The choreographers are yet to be determined, but leading up to the premieres, the artists and their works will be highlighted on the company's various digital media platforms. They also will be documented in video through San Francisco Ballet programs such as Artist Spotlight, Behind the Scenes, and Instant Expert. All works will be performed at the San Francisco War Memorial Opera House.

To support the creation and presentation of several new ballets. New works are tentatively scheduled to include commissions by Artistic Director Helgi Tomasson, choreographer-in-residence Yuri Possokhov, and Alexei Ratmanksy. The project will include audience engagement activities such as community matinees for students and seniors, lecture-demonstrations, a docent training program. Additionally, Meet the Artist Interviews and Pointes of View lectures will be heard as podcasts on the ballet's website.

To support the creation and presentation of new ballets by several choreographers. Choreographers such as artistic director Helgi Tomasson and Alexei Ratmanksy as well as others will be commissioned to create new works.

To support the creation and presentation of new works by several choreographers. Choreographers such as artistic director Helgi Tomasson, choreographer-in-residence Yuri Possokhov, Wayne McGregor, Mark Morris, and Christopher Wheeldon will be commissioned to create new dance works. The project includes engagement activities such as community matinees for students and seniors, reduced-price tickets, pre-performance discussions, a docent-training program, and podcasts of "Meet the Artist" interviews and "Pointes of View" lectures.

To support the creation and presentation of new works by several choreographers, including choreographer-in-residence Yuri Possokhov. The project includes audience-engagement activities, such as community matinees for students and seniors, reduced-priced tickets, pre-performance discussions, a docent-training program, and podcasts of "Meet the Artist" interviews and "Pointes of View" lectures.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support an interactive dance and music education program in consortium with the San Francisco Unified School District. Master teacher Charles McNeal and additional dancer instructors, musicians and an ethnomusicologist will introduce students in grades two through seven to the universal dance concepts of space, time, energy, force and traditional music from Latin and Central America, Africa, the United States and Europe.
To support the creation and presentation of new works. Performances will take place at San Francisco's War Memorial Opera House.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Dance in Schools and Communities, in consortium with the San Francisco Unified School District. Teaching artists will provide ten weeks of free, interactive movement and music instruction to students in the second- through fourth-grade and their teachers.

To support the creation and presentation of new works, including commissions by Artistic Director Helgi Tomasson and Choreographer in Residence Yuri Possokhov. Performances and related education programs will take place at San Francisco's War Memorial Opera House.

To support the creation and presentation of new works, including commissions by Artistic Director Helgi Tomasson and Choreographer-in-Residence Yuri Possokhov. Performances will take place at San Francisco's War Memorial Opera House.
To support the creation and presentation of world premieres during the company's 75th Anniversary festival. Performances will take place at San Francisco's War Memorial Opera House.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Dance in Schools and Communities in consortium with the San Francisco Unified School District. Implemented with its partner the San Francisco Unified School District, the residency program will provide free, interactive movement and music instruction to as many as 3,500 students in the second through fourth grades and their teachers.

To support the creation and presentation of new works. Performances will take place at San Francisco's War Memorial Opera House, and will be supplemented with a variety of education and outreach activities organized by the company's Center for Dance Education.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Dance in Schools and Communities, in consortium with the San Francisco Unified School District. The residency program, implemented with the San Francisco Unified School District, will provide interactive movement and music instruction at no charge to as many as 3,500 students and teachers in the 2nd to 4th grades.
To support the creation and presentation of new works. Paul Taylor, Christopher Wheeldon, and Lar Lubovitch will create world premieres for the company.
To support the creation and presentation of new works. The works will include the acquisition of Jerome Robbins' The Dybbuk Variations.
To support Dance in Schools and Communities, a consortium project. The project will provide free, interactive movement and music activities for students.
To support the presentation of work by George Balanchine and Frederick Ashton.
To support the creation and presentation of works by emerging and established choreographers. The company will commission works by choreographers Stanton Welch, Julia Adam, and Alexei Ratmansky.

To support commissions and presentations by emerging and established choreographers. Choreographers Christopher Wheeldon, Stanton Welch, and Artistic Director Helgi Tomasson will create new works for the company that will be performed at the War Memorial Opera House.

To support the acquisition, commission, and presentation of classical and contemporary ballets; and associated educational outreach programs. New choreography by Mark Morris, Lar Lubovitch, Val Caniparoli, and Helgi Tomasson will be commissioned.

To support the commission and acquisition of ballets for an American Works Program as part of San Francisco Ballet's 67th repertory season. The program will focus on ballets by the country's leading classical and contemporary ballet choreographic talent.

To support the creation and presentation of ballets by choreographers Helgi Tomasson and Mark Morris, acquisition of repertory by Kenneth MacMillan, and encore performances of new works premiered in 1997-98. This project has three components: Performance of works from the classical repertory with the addition to the repertory of Helgi Tomasson's version of Giselle; performance of works that have been commissioned by San Francisco Ballet by such contemporary masters as Mark Morris; and performance of ballets acknowledged to be masterworks of 20th century choreographers such as Jerome Robbins, George Balanchine, Kenneth MacMillan, Lar Lubovitch, and James Kudelka.

Organization Name: San Francisco Bay Area Theatre Company
Project Description: Purpose: To support the development of Sign My Name to Freedom: The Unheard Songs of Betty Reid Soskin by Jamie Zee and Michael Gene Sullivan. Additional Project Description: Featuring the music of Betty Reid Soskin, the musical explores the life of Soskin in the Bay Area, her lifelong community service, and advocacy for the inclusion of women and Black Americans in national memorials. Soskin, who turned 100 years old in 2021, was the U.S. National Park Services' oldest park ranger in residence at the Rosie the Riveter World War II Home Front National Historical Park in Port Richmond, California. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve theater artists in the San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Organization Name: San Francisco Bay Area Theatre Company
Project Description: Purpose: To support a production of "I, Too, Sing America." Additional Project Description: Featuring approximately poems by Langston Hughes, Jean Toomer, Frances Chung, Gwendolyn Brooks, and others, and set to music by composer Othello Jefferson, the production honors the work of American artists of color while exploring issues of identity and representation. Facilitated conversation about the production's themes will follow performances. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances of the production will serve residents in the San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Organization Name: San Francisco Bay Area Theatre Company
Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organizations constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support two publications in a series by emerging and underrepresented national and international artists. Artists Sanaz Mazinani, McNair Evans, Amanda Boe, and Kevin Kunishi will receive conceptual, logistical, financial, and administrative support to develop their work. The publication series is part of San Fransisco Camerawork's historical publication program and will include essays, reproductions, and documentation.

To support the "New Works Initiative" with accompanying public programs, and a publication featuring the work of artist Gerald Slota. The "New Works Initiative" will result in at least five interrelated solo exhibitions, featuring emerging and mid-career artists whose work engages the complexities of photographic representation.
To support "New Narrative Collaborations," an exhibition, publication and related activities that explore the relationship between photography and the literary arts.

To support a 35th anniversary project "The Autobiography of the San Francisco Bay Area Since 1974." The multi-faceted project will include three exhibitions, commission of new work, and a publication.

To support the photography exhibition I FEEL THAT I AM FREE BUT I KNOW THAT I AM NOT, including related programming and journal. The project will examine the relationships between photography, performance, artist, and viewer.
To support the development and exhibition of "The Kaiten Project." The project will feature new work by Japanese artist Katsushige Nakahashi.

To support the photography exhibition, Ghost in the Machine. The project will feature work by artists who have explored inventive uses of photography, video, installation, digital media, and performance to reclaim lost histories and respond to personal, national, and cultural memories.

To support AGITATE: NEGOTIATING THE PHOTOGRAPHIC PROCESS, a group exhibition and publication featuring the work of artists who reexamine, rebuild, or dispense entirely with standard photographic techniques. An entire issue of Camerawork: A Journal of Photographic Arts will document the exhibition.

To support an exhibition of work by Daniel Joseph Martinez entitled WITHOUT ANESTHESIA, OR, THIS ISN'T A NICE NEIGHBORHOOD: RECENT WORK BY DANIEL JOSEPH MARTINEZ, accompanied by the publication CAMERAWORK: A JOURNAL OF PHOTOGRAPHIC ARTS. This project will attempt to further conversations about contemporary cultural issues instigated by artists utilizing photography and related technologies.

To support the exhibition "Timekeepers" and an accompanying issue of the journal "Camerawork." Work in the exhibition, which will be predominantly new media, will question and expand the ways in which we conceive of time.

To support an exhibition and an accompanying issue of the journal CAMERAWORK. To commemorate San Francisco Camerawork's 25th anniversary, the project will present the work of photographers who have made seminal contributions to the medium.

To support the exhibition "Cocktail Hour: New Imagery in the AIDS Era" and an accompanying issue of CAMERAWORK: A JOURNAL OF PHOTOGRAPHIC ARTS. The exhibition will examine the way AIDS inspired work has evolved in recent years and will provide a critical context for examining the changes in AIDS related imagery and our culture's understanding of the disease. The curatorial approach will examine developments in current AIDS-related photographic work away from the documentary style of the 1980's toward work with an experimental, often metaphoric thrust, which encompasses the role of memory, humor, irony, and mortality in a wide cultural context. The exhibition will be documented by an issue of Camerawork: A Journal of Photographic Arts, a magazine devoted to presenting new writing and high quality reproductions of work that interpret and reflect contemporary issues in photography and related media. Three thousand copies are produced; 1,000 of which are sold by bookstores, photographic supply stores, and photography museums. The remaining copies are sent to subscribers -- museums, libraries, galleries, and other artists organizations.

Organization Name: San Francisco Center for the Book
Project Description: To support the Art of the Book in the Classroom Initiative. Artist-led, book arts activities with teachers and students will be designed to develop artistic expression and literacy skills.

Purpose: To support salaries and travel costs for Chanticleer's national tour and residency program. Additional Project Description: In addition to concert performances, all ensemble singers of the residency program will participate in educational programs such as workshops, master classes, and youth choral festivals. The tour will include as many as 25 states and some events will be livestreamed on multiple platforms and offered online on Chanticleer's website. Intended Beneficiaries: Audiences of all ages, including singers, will be served by the project. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support salaries and travel costs for Chanticleer's national concert tour and residency program. In addition to concert performances, all ensemble singers of the residency program will participate in the educational programs such as workshops, master classes, and youth choral festivals. The tour will include as many as 25 states, and due to the pandemic, some events will be livestreamed on multiple platforms and offered online on Chanticleer's website.

To support the salaries and travel costs for Chanticleer's national concert tour and residency program. In addition to concert performances, all ensemble singers of the residency program will participate in the educational programs such as workshops, master classes, and youth choral festivals. The tour will include as many as ten states in the continental United States.

To support Chanticleer's national concert tour and residency program. In addition to concert performances, all ensemble singers of the residency program will participate in the educational programs such as workshops, master classes, and youth choral festivals. The tour will include as many as 25 states in the continental United States.

To support Chanticleer's national concert tour and residency program. In addition to concert performances, all ensemble singers of the residency program will participate in the educational programs such as workshops, master classes, and youth choral festivals. Celebrating its 40th anniversary, Chanticleer will perform diverse programming that will include early music, sacred music, and new work by American composer Peter Bloesch. Programming also will comprise repertoire spanning 700 years of the Christmas narrative, from chant to gospel to contemporary works. The tour will include as many as 25 states in the continental United States.

To support Chanticleer's national concert tour and residency program. In addition to concert performances, all ensemble singers of the residency program will participate in the educational programs such as workshops, master classes, and youth choral festivals. The diverse programming will include early music, sacred music, and commissioned works by American composers. Programming also will comprise repertoire spanning 700 years of the Christmas narrative, from chant to gospel to contemporary works.

To support a national concert tour and residency program. In addition to concert performances, all ensemble singers of the residency program will participate in the educational programs such as workshops, master classes, and youth choral festivals. The diverse programming will include early music, sacred music from the Venetian School, and newly commissioned works by American composers Mason Bates and John Harbison. Programming also will comprise repertoire spanning 700 years of the Christmas narrative, from chant to gospel to contemporary works.

To support a national concert tour and residency program. In addition to concert performances, all of the ensemble singers will participate in the educational programs such as workshops, master classes, and youth choral festivals, as part of the residency activities. The diverse programming will include vocal music of ethnic Gypsy origin, early music, sacred music from the Venetian School, as well as repertoire spanning 700 years of the Christmas narrative, from chant to gospel to contemporary works.

To support a national concert tour and residency program. Repertoire will be selected by Interim Music Director Jace Wittig and all of the ensemble singers will participate in the educational programs, such as workshops, master classes, and youth choral festivals, as part of the residency activities. Programming will include music of ethnic Gypsy origin, early music, sacred music from the Venetian School, as well as repertoire spanning 700 years of the Christmas narrative, from chant to gospel to contemporary works.

To support a national concert tour and related educational activities. Repertoire will be selected by the interim Music Director Jace Wittig, and all of the ensemble singers will participate in the educational programs as part of the residency activities.

To support a national concert tour and residency program. Programming will be directed by Jace Wittig, and all of the ensemble singers will participate in the educational programs, featuring contemporary and traditional repertoire, as part of the residency activities.

To support a national concert tour and residency program. Repertoire will be selected by Music Director Matthew Oltman, and all of the ensemble singers will participate in the educational programs as part of the residency activities.

To support youth and adult choral workshops and "Mission Road II," a California-wide musical history project, in consortium with the Paso Robles Joint Unified School District. San Francisco Chanticleer will offer choral coaching and present youth choral festivals.

To support residency activities that include youth choral festivals, workshops and master classes in consortium with the American Choral Directors Association-Western Division (Tucson). Along with other national educational residency collaborators, Chanticleer will present a series of day-long workshops and festivals for high school choruses and adult singers and will be guest artists at ACDA conferences.
To support a national concert tour and residency program. Activities will include choral coaching, youth choral festivals, and advanced choral training for adult singers.

To support a residency project of choral workshops and youth choral festivals, in consortium with the Hibbling Independent School District #701. Along with other national educational residency collaborators, Chanticleer will present a series of day-long workshops and festivals for high school choruses and adult singers.
To support a national concert tour and residency program. Activities will include choral coaching, youth choral festivals, and advanced choral training for adult singers.

To support a residency project of choral workshops, youth choral festivals, and a symposium in consortium with North Dakota State University. Chanticleer will present a series of day-long workshops and festivals for high school choruses and adult singers in California, Connecticut, and North Dakota.
To support a national concert tour and educational residency project. Activities will include choral coaching, youth choral festivals, and advanced choral training for adult singers.
To support a national concert tour and educational residency project. Activities will include choral coaching, youth choral festivals, and advanced choral training for adult singers.

To support choral workshops, youth choral festivals, and a symposium in consortium with the National Education Residency Partners. With the MacPhail Center for the Music and other national educational residency partners, Chanticleer will present a series of day-long workshops and festivals for high school choruses and adult singers.
To support a national concert tour and educational residency project. Activities will include choral coaching, youth choral festivals, and advanced choral training for adult singers.
To support a national concert and educational residency project. Activities will include choral coaching, master classes, and workshops.

To support the commission and presentation of a concert-length choral music and theater work based on 12th-century composer and spiritual leader Hildegard von Bingen. Composers Steven Stucky, Regis Campo, and Jeeyoung Kim will collaborate with Chanticleer and music director Joseph Jennings in creating the new work.
To support the "New Music Advisor" project, during which composer Jeeyoung Kim will create a new work and collaborate with Chanticleer's artistic staff.

To support "Chanticleer: An American Journey," a 25th anniversary celebration. The project includes commissions, concerts, a compact disc recording, a composers' symposium, and multiple education residencies.
To support the expansion of the music Education Program. Chanticleer will add a school residency program, youth ensembles, and a youth chorus festival for students in up to eight Bay Area schools.

To support "How Sweet the Sound," the presentation of gospel concerts in the San Francisco Bay Area. The Reverend Yvette A. Flunder, a recipient of the Gospel Academy Awards Soloist of the Year honor, will participate as guest artist in this year 2000 project.

To support the commissioning of new vocal works from up to five composers for San Francisco Chanticleer. This 1998-99 project will include these works in Chanticleer's New Music for a New Century program, scheduled for March 1999, and will become a permanent part of its contemporary repertoire.
