To support production and presentation costs associated with the restaging of Benjamin Britten's chamber opera "Curlew River" at Theater Artaud.

Purpose: To support presentations of experimental film, video and performance art. Additional Project Description: Presented in-person and online, the Crossroads (XRDS) festival will represent the diversity of contemporary cinema techniques and forms, including live multimedia performances and avant-garde film that expands the boundaries of conventional narratives. Curated through an international open call process, the programs will be presented with community partners and accompanied by opportunities for audiences to engage with film artists. Intended Beneficiaries: This program will serve audiences in San Francisco and online, as well as artists working in experimental cinema. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support Crossroads, a festival dedicated to experimental film, video, and performance-based cinema. Additional Project Description: Presented in-person and online, the festival will showcase contemporary experimental work including live multi-screen and mixed-media performances. Additionally, Crossroads will show non-commercial feature-length films and offer opportunities for audiences to engage with film artists. Intended Beneficiaries: This program will serve participating artists, as well as San Francisco residents and visitors interested in alternative forms of cinema. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Purpose: To support presentations of experimental film, video and performance art. Additional Project Description: Presented in-person and online, the series of curated events will showcase works by emerging and established artists from around the world. In-person programs held in partnership with theatrical venues will feature live curatorial introductions and artist presentations. Online programs will consist of a mix of on-demand programs and livestreams. Intended Beneficiaries: This program will benefit media artists, as well as San Francisco residents and visitors interested in alternative forms of cinema and audiences online. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support Crossroads 2020, an online festival dedicated to experimental film, video, and performance-based cinema. The festival will show new works highlighting the contemporary avant-garde and experimental arts field.

To support the creation of Craig Baldwin: Science in Action, a print publication documenting the work of American experimental filmmaker Craig Baldwin. This publication will be the first full-length, critical compendium of original commissioned writings, interviews, curated historical texts, images, and ephemera documenting the work of Baldwin, a key figure in contemporary media arts.

To support public engagement activities for Crossroads 2019, a festival dedicated to experimental film, video, and performance-based cinema. Primarily taking place at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, the festival will present new work made within the last two years, highlighting contemporary artistic and curatorial trends within the avant-garde and experimental landscape, including live multi-screen and mixed-media performance experiences that exist beyond the screen. Community members, curators, and industry professionals will have the opportunity to engage directly with participating filmmakers through networking activities and question-and-answer sessions.

To support Crossroads 2018, a festival dedicated to experimental media arts. The festival presents avant-garde and experimental works, including film, video, moving image installations, and live expanded-cinema performance experiences that exist beyond the screen. Crossroads generally showcases new work made within the last two years, highlighting contemporary artistic and curatorial trends within the avant-garde and experimental landscape.

To support the Crossroads festival. Held in the spring, the festival presents avant-garde and experimental works, including film, video, live cinema performance, and media art installation. Crossroads generally showcases new work made within the last two years, highlighting contemporary artistic and curatorial trends within the avant-garde and experimental landscape.

To support curated film series of experimental and avant garde film and video. Programs to be included range from forgotten masterpieces by artists such as Stan Brakhage and Chick Strand, to retrospectives of Canadian filmmaker Etienne O'Leary and France's Helga Fanderl.

To support the production and publication of "Speaking Directly: Oral Histories of the Moving Image." The journal will bring together discussions with noted filmmakers (Stan Brakhage, Hollis Frampton, Trinh Minh-ha) recorded at San Francisco Cinematheque events over the past several decades along with newly commissioned interviews with emerging filmmakers.
To support a curated film series. International Perspectives will feature contemporary international experimental film and video work.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.
To support "Immersive Cinema," a curated film series. "Immersive Cinema" is a series of up to four week-long residencies for artists, scholars, and curators focusing on experimental cinema.
To support a curated film and video series. Bay Area Cinematic Roots and Reiteration will showcase artists who have been involved in Bay Area filmmaking during the last 40 years.

To support a curated film/video series, "Around the (Pacific) Rim." The series will feature experimental and personal work by media artists from the west coast of the United States, Canada, and Mexico, as well as from Asian countries of the Pacific Rim.
To support a curated film/video series. PROMISCUOUS CINEMA will feature media artists who combine film and video projection with live performance.

To support "Dialogues in the Dark: The Pleasures and Anxieties of Influence," a curated film and video series. Dialogues will feature contemporary media artists screening their own works paired with influential works by their avant-garde forebears.
To support a curated film/video series that focuses on experimental work by young and emerging artists from across the United States. "Fresh Eyes" will focus on experimental work by

To support Home Away From Home: Cinema Visionaries in Residence, a series of residencies for artists, scholars, and curators focusing on experimental cinema. Each residency will be one week long, with lectures, workshops, panels, and screenings.

To support the curated film series San Francisco Cinematheque: 40 Years in Focus. For four decades, the San Francisco Cinematheque has dedicated itself to, and premiered the work of, experimental film and video artists.
To support Media Migrations, a curated film/video series which includes gallery installations and a symposium. The 25 screenings will feature classic and contemporary works of avant-garde cinema.
To support "From the Bay and Beyond," a film and video exhibition series that will premiere new work in San Francisco, and the mentoring of a new generation of media arts curators.

To support "New Work, New Artists," an exhibition series of experimental film, video, and new media work by new and emerging artists which is estimated to draw an audience of over 7,000 people. The series is intended to bring new faces to the Cinematheque's exhibition program. "New Work and New Artists" will demonstrate to audiences a continued vitality in the field and will provide an important reflection of film and video practice in the larger art world. Approximately 120 artists will be included in the series and the specific programs will be curated thematically, i.e., "Revisiting the Film Installation" or "Challenges Facing New Media Artists Today." Some of the better-known artists who may be part of "New Work, New Artists" are Janice Tanaka, Wendy Clarke, and Lourdes Portillo. Whenever possible, artists are asked to introduce their work and participate in question-and-answer sessions. Extensive program notes accompany each exhibition.

To support a music engagement program through arts journalism. The WriteOn! music educational program will engage young people with performances in the Bay Area. Students at partner high schools will attend concerts free of charge and then, under the guidance of professional writers, will write about their experience for the organization's website SFCV.org.

To support an expansion of SFCV.org, an arts-focused website. San Francisco Classical Voice (SFCV) will present the works of arts organizations in the San Francisco Bay area to a wider audience, including ethnic minorities who may not have traditionally engaged with classical music.

To support technical enhancements of the organization's Web site through the addition of podcasting and videocasting features. The project will promote deeper knowledge and experience of listeners through the online music resource beyond the Bay Area.

Purpose: To support a commissioning and performance project featuring a new work for chamber orchestra by composer Brian Baumbusch. Additional Project Description: The project will result in a new 45-minute work that explores the development of complex musical time under circumstances of isolation, experienced live or through virtual reality (VR). The ensemble will collaborate with the composer in the development of the work. Expanding on Baumbusch's previous works that use polytempo structures, which are multiple simultaneously-divergent tempo streams conveyed via click tracks, his composition will allow performers to collaborate remotely, as well as perform the work live. The project will include a partnership with the Film and Media Department at University of California, Santa Cruz to create a 25-minute VR production of an excerpt of the work. The work will also be performed live. Intended Beneficiaries: Virtual and live performances will engage audiences of all ages. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support a virtual performance project featuring a new work for chamber orchestra by composer Tyshawn Sorey. A co-commission by the ensemble and Paris-based Ensemble InterContemporain, the work is dedicated to the life and legacy of late composer Olly Wilson. The concert program, one in a series exploring cross-genre connections, will include works by Wilson and composer and jazz cellist Tomeka Reid (who will join the ensemble in performance).

To support staff salaries, artist fees, and cartage costs for performances of a new work by composer Michael Gordon inspired by Angel Island in the San Francisco Bay. The 24-member ensemble will be joined by reed quintet Splinter Reeds and vocal ensemble Roomful of Teeth in the premiere performance of the previously commissioned work. From January 21, 1910, to November 5, 1940, Angel Island Immigration Station, sometimes known as "Ellis Island of the West," was an immigrant station where people entering the United States were either passed through immigration or detained.

To support a performance project celebrating the legacy of American composer Lou Harrison. The project, titled A Lou Harrison Centennial Celebration, will comprise tributes to Harrison, composer talks, and concerts featuring the works of Harrison. Programming will include the participation of composers Jimmy Lopez and Natacha Diels. Activities will take place at Z Space in San Francisco.

To support an artist residency project. The ensemble will present a residency, titled X-SCAPE: New Spaces for New Music, which will explore space in the physical, metaphorical, and poetic sense, at the Z-Space Theater Artaud, in the Mission District of San Francisco. Programming will include works by composers such as David Lang, Gerard Grisey, Marianthi Papalexandri-Alexadri, Zosha DiCastri, Louis Andreissen, and Morton Feldman. Project activities will include educational events.

To support "Sweet Thunder", a festival of electro-acoustic music. Artistic Director Steven Schick will direct the programming that will juxtapose iconic works of the past 50 years with new and recent works by composers Ed Campion, Kevin Ernste, Natacha Diels, and Matt Ingalls, among others.

To support commissioning and performance of Pointing Twice, a new chamber work by intermedia composer Jaroslaw Kapuscinski. Inspired by Anton Webern's Concerto for Nine Instruments, Opus 24, the composition will integrate community-created intermedia works into the performance.
To support concerts of chamber music by American composers. The ensemble will perform contemporary works by John Cage and Du Yan at the Herbst Theatre in San Francisco.

To support world premieres of chamber works by composers Brian Current, Manolis Manousakis, Ronald Bruce Smith and Charles Boone. The concerts will take place at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.

To support concerts of chamber music by American composers of diverse origins. The ensemble will perform contemporary music written by John Harbison, Tan Dun, and Brian Ferneyhough at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts and related educational events at the School of the Arts in San Francisco.

To support performances of contemporary chamber works. Composers Lee Hyla, Roscoe Mitchell, Cindy Cox, Terry Riley, Philippe Leroux, Ken Ueno, and Donnach Dennehy and their works will be featured in performances at the Herbst Theatre in San Francisco.

To support Four Dreams: Recent American Chamber Music, featuring works by American composers Elliott Carter, Mario Davidovsky, Reynold Tharp, Lei Liang, Mario Diaz de Leon, and Dmitri Tymoczko. The concert will take place at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts and related educational events will occur at the School of the Arts, Lowell High School, local universities in San Francisco, and other venues.
To support performances of chamber works at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, as well as related educational activities.

To support performances of works by composers Edmund Campion, Ellen Harrison, Brian Ferneyhough, Marco Stroppa, Manolis Manousakis, and James Matheson. The chamber works will be performed at the Yuerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.

To support the world premiere of a commissioned work by composer Wendell Logan and performances of works by American composers. The chamber works will be performed at the Yuerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.

To support a compact disc recording of music by composer Pablo Ortiz. The recording will include Ortiz works composed between 1996 and 2003, performed by musicians from the ensemble and conducted by music director David Milnes.
To support world premieres of commissioned works by composers Kui Dong, Betty Olivero, and David Soley. The chamber works will be featured in three concert programs.

To support a concert of contemporary chamber music titled "30th Anniversary Celebration." The March 2001 concert, celebrating the 30th anniversary of the ensemble, will consist of previously commissioned works by composers Steven Mackey and Pablo Ortiz, and music by composers Kui Dong and Ellen Harrison.
To support "American Originals," a performance project. During 1999-2000, the Ensemble will perform works by American composers Edgar Varese, Seymour Shifrin, Ralph Shapey, and Gunther Schuller.

To support the recording and production of a compact disc of previously unrecorded chamber works of University of California-Berkeley composition faculty member Andrew Imbrie. The performance and recording is in honor of Mr. Imbrie's 80th birthday.

To support a recording of chamber music compositions written by noted flutist James Newton, featuring the San Francisco Contemporary Music Players and James Newton, to be released in July, 2000 on New World Records to libraries and retail/wholesale outlets in the U.S. and abroad.

Purpose: To support the San Francisco International Film Festival. Additional Project Description: The film festival will present narrative, documentary, and short films from around the world, accompanied by panel discussions, visiting filmmakers, and live music performances. Intended Beneficiaries: The film exhibition programming will serve local Bay Area audiences including community partners, educators, students, and participating artists. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support curated film series, including the San Francisco International Film Festival, and related activities. Additional Project Description: The festival presents narrative, documentary, and short films from around the world, accompanied by live performances and educational programs, presented in person and online. Throughout the year, additional programs will include contemporary works from Hong Kong, works exploring science through film, and the Screenings for Schools program, in which students view films and engage directly with filmmakers. Intended Beneficiaries: The film exhibition programming will serve local Bay Area audiences and visitors, as well as artists and students. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support several year-round curated film series and planning costs for the San Francisco International Film Festival. Held in the spring, the festival presents narrative, documentary, and short films from around the world, accompanied by live performances and educational programs. Throughout the year, additional programs will include contemporary works from Hong Kong, and the Screenings for Schools program, in which students view films and engage directly with filmmakers.

To support the San Francisco International Film Festival and related public programming. Held in the spring, the festival screens short and feature-length narrative and documentary films from around the world, accompanied by live performances and educational programs. Throughout the year, the San Francisco Film Society (SFFILM) presents several curated series, including contemporary works from Hong Kong, a documentary showcase connecting emerging and established filmmakers, and Screenings for Schools, a free program in which students view films and engage directly with filmmakers. Additionally, SFFILM offers its members access to an online screening room featuring select feature films, shorts, and events from the festival, many of which have not received U.S. distribution.

To support the 61st San Francisco International Film Festival and related public programming. Held in the spring, the festival presents narrative, documentary, and virtual reality films from around the world, accompanied by live performances and educational programs. Throughout the year, the San Francisco Film Society (SFFS) will present several curated series, including contemporary works from Hong Kong, a documentary showcase for emerging and established filmmakers, and Screenings for Schools, a free program in which students view films and engage directly with filmmakers.

To support the San Francisco International Film Festival, and other curated film series. Held in the spring, the festival includes films from around the world, accompanied by live performances and educational programs. Throughout the year, additional presentations will include contemporary works from Hong Kong and the Screenings for Schools program, in which students view films and engage directly with filmmakers.

To support the annual San Francisco International Film Festival, and other curated film series. Held in the spring, the festival includes films from around the world, educational programs, and live performances. Additional programming throughout the year will include a series devoted to cinema from Hong Kong, and Screenings in Schools, in which students view films and engage with the filmmakers in person or via Skype. In partnership with the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, SFFS presents a year-round series celebrating established and emerging masters of cinema.

To support the annual San Francisco International Film Festival and other related exhibition programs. The San Francisco International Film Festival will showcase more than 260 films; through its year-round programming, the SFFS will present current American independent and international feature films as well as programs devoted to French film, Italian film, animation, and documentaries.

To support the 55th San Francisco International Film Festival and other related exhibition programs. The San Francisco International Film Festival will showcase more than 250 films; through its year-round programming, the SFFS will present current American independent and international feature films as well as programs devoted to French film, Italian film, animation, and documentaries.

To support the 54th San Francisco International Film Festival and other related exhibition programs. The San Francisco International Film Festival will showcase more than 250 films; through its year-round programming, the SFFS will present current American independent and international feature films as well as programs devoted to French film, Italian film, animation, and documentaries.
To support the 53rd San Francisco International Film Festival and other related exhibition programs. Approximately 400 films will be shown to an estimated audience of 116,000 people.
To support the 52nd annual San Francisco International Film Festival. The festival presents more than 100 films from 40 countries to an audience of 75,000 people.
To support the 51st San Francisco International Film Festival. The festival presents more than 300 films from 54 countries to an audience of 85,000 people.
To support the 50th San Francisco International Film Festival. The festival presents more than 200 films from 50 countries to an audience of 90,000 people.
To support the 49th San Francisco International Film Festival. The festival presents more than 200 films from 50 countries to an audience of 85,000 people.
To support the San Francisco International Film Festival. The festival presents more than 200 films from 50 countries to an audience of 95,000 people.
To support the 47th San Francisco International Film Festival. The event presents over 200 films from 50 countries to an audience of 90,000 people.
To support the 46th annual San Francisco International Film Festival. The event presents over 200 films from 50 countries to an audience of 87,000 people.

Organization Name: San Francisco Foundation Community Initiative Funds
Project Description: To support Phase II-Cycle I of a consortium effort among the San Francisco Art Commission, the Arts Education Funders' Collaborative, the Arts Providers Alliance, the San Francisco Foundation, and the San Francisco Unified School District, to strengthen arts education development in San Francisco public elementary schools and pre-K child development centers For 76 San Francisco elementary schools there are currently only 16 music teachers and no visual or performing arts teachers. The Board of Education has recently passed a resolution to bring the arts back into the curriculum, so the timing for this project is ideal. It is part of a larger initiative that occurs in 3 overlapping 22-month cycles, involving one-third of the 91 schools and centers in each cycle. The philosophy is to advance arts education without promoting a specific aesthetic or educational methodology. Each school will develop a plan and carry out activities to suit the character and needs of its stakeholders, and to strengthen its curriculum in accordance with state- and district-level arts education guidelines. Project-directed activities will include: an orientation for school principals; a professional development day for over 200 educators; financial support and technical assistance to the schools; and an arts education workshop series for interested teachers. An outside evaluator will develop and carry out a "best practices" case study report, which will be widely disseminated.

Purpose: To support the presentation of a modernized, re-orchestrated, and fully-staged version of the opera Juditha Triumphans by composer Antonio Vivaldi, with virtual and augmented reality elements. Additional Project Description: The 1716 oratorio was written for the orphaned young girls of Venice's Ospedale della Pietan unusual school and convent where girls were given extraordinary musical education and performance opportunities. A timeless story of female determination, independence, and empowerment, the opera tells the biblical story of Judith, a woman who saved her own city by beheading the invading Assyrian general Holofernes. The company will debut a modern version of the oratorio, in partnership with Ars Minerva, a local institution dedicated to reviving Baroque operas. The company also will create a re-orchestrated edition of the work that reduces the instrumentation from 30 to 12 musicians. Unique to this production, the work will be performed by trained singers the same age as those for whom it was originally written, as the ensemble consists of young women and non-binary youth ages 13-18. Artistic directors Valerie Sainte-Agathe and Cline Ricci and musician Lionel Renoux form the creative team. Intended Beneficiaries: San Francisco-area audiences will benefit from the performances, as will the young singers engaged to perform the work. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support the premiere of the fully staged choral opera Tomorrow's Memories: A Little Manila Diary by composer Matthew Welch. Based on the 1920s diary of a young Filipina immigrant, Angeles Monrayo, the core themes of the diary include race, gender, and class issues in early 20th-century America. These themes resonate today, as immigrants grapple with family separation, worker's rights, women's rights, and economic struggle. The choral operascored for a girls' chorus, violin, guitar, and percussionwill be created and produced in an effort to elevate the experiences of the Filipino-American community and to empower young women.

To support a recording project featuring choral and orchestral works. In a collaboration with The Knights orchestra, the chorus will make premiere recordings of repertoire by American composers including Pulitzer Prize-winner Aaron Jay Kernis, Rome Prize and American Academy of Arts and Letters Award winner Lisa Bielawa, and Colin Jacobsen, co-founder and co-artistic director of The Knights and member of the Silk Road Ensemble. The works will be settings of American texts examining social and historical issues, from anger and grief prompted by rising violence in American and world communities (for "Remembering the Sea" by Kernis) to writings of child genius Mary MacLane from Butte, Montana, whose memoir dates from 1901 (for "My Outstretched Hand" by Bielawa, with participation by Trinity Youth Chorus) and New England's "flash fiction" writer Lydia Davis (for "If I Were Not Me" by Jacobsen). The recordings will be available on CD and iTunes.

To support Creating Choral Music (CCM). A free, in-school choral music program for students in Bay Area elementary schools, the program will provide young elementary school students with beginning music skills. Teaching artists will provide weekly music instruction throughout the school year, as well as guide partnering school staff in integrating music into core subjects. The program will offer cross-curricular connections, includes a variety of music genres, and will culminate in school performances featuring CCM students with members of the San Francisco Girls Chorus at each school site.

To support the Music Education and Performance Program. The program will provide instruction in choral singing, as well as summer camps and opportunities for concert performance, using a five-level graduated curriculum.

To support the Music Education and Performance Program. The program will provide nine months of instruction in choral singing and opportunities for concert performance, using a five-level graduated curriculum and repertoire that spans six centuries and includes 14 languages.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Music Education and Performance Program. The program will provide nine months of instruction in choral singing and opportunities for concert performance, using a five-level graduated curriculum and repertoire that spans six centuries and includes 14 languages.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Music Education and Performance Program. The project will provide year-round instruction in choral singing and opportunities for concert performance.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Music Education and Performance Program. The project will provide year-round instruction in choral singing and opportunities for concert performance touring.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Music Education and Performance Program. The project will provide an introduction to choral singing and will serve as the foundation for the concert performance and touring ensembles.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Music Education and Outreach Program. The project will provide an introduction to choral singing and serve as the foundation for the concert performance and touring ensembles.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Music Education and Outreach Program. The project will provide an introduction to choral singing and will serve as the foundation for the concert performance and touring ensembles.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Music Education and Outreach Program. The project will provide an introduction to choral singing and will serve as the foundation for the performance concert and touring ensembles.

To support a choral music education and performance program for talented Bay-area girls. The program provides a graduated curriculum and serves as a training ground for the Performance Program's two concert and touring ensembles.

To support the Music Education and Outreach Program. The program provides need-based scholarships targeted for female youth in up to 160 schools in the Bay area to participate in choral training and performances.
To support the Music Education and Outreach Program. This project will provide a graduated curriculum for young singers in the beginning level training choruses.
To support the Music Education and Outreach Program. During 2000-01, this project will provide a graduated curriculum for the singers in the beginning level training choruses.

To support the Master Teacher Program. During 1999-2000, this program will provide specialized vocal training, language exposure, and performance opportunities for the young concert and touring ensemble singers (Chorissima and Virtuose Choruses) and continued professional development for the artistic staff, including conductor/vocal workshops and coaching invocal development, conducting styles, and performance practices.

To support the Master Teacher Program, providing sequential vocal training, language exposure, and performance opportunities for the young concert and touring ensemble singers (Chorissima and Virtuose Choruses) and continued professional development for the artistic staff, including conductor/vocal workshops and coaching.

To support the Impact Film program at the San Francisco Green Film Festival. Free and open to the public, the two-day forum will convene film professionals and industry experts in panels, discussions, and interactive/new media workshops to advance the field of documentary storytelling and its impact on social issue and environmental filmmaking.

To support filmmaking workshops and screenings. In partnership with the Ninth Street Independent Film Center, San Francisco Public Libraries, and the San Francisco Department of the Environment, this program will pair two teams of local filmmakers with a team of environmental scientists to engage in collaborative workshops and produce a series of short films during an immersive filmmaking lab. The program will culminate in free community screenings and discussions with the filmmakers and scientists in locations throughout San Francisco.

Purpose: To support multidisciplinary programming. Additional Project Description: Programming will include a visual arts exhibition, music performances, and multidisciplinary arts workshops all hosted at the River's Edge Art Park. Art works will focus on water usage, climate conditions, and local foodways. Intended Beneficiaries: The programming will serve Bay Area artists and audiences and featured artists. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Organization Name: San Francisco International Arts Festival, Inc.
Project Description: To support production and marketing costs for multidisciplinary performances at the San Francisco International Arts Festival. The festival will feature performances by artists from the Bay Area in disciplines including dance, music, spoken word, and theater.

Organization Name: San Francisco International Arts Festival, Inc.
Project Description: To support the presentation of the international collaborative project "Beyond the Mirror" in consortium with the Bond Street Theatre. The play, developed by Bond Street Theatre in collaboration with The Exile Theatre of Kabul, will be presented as part of the 2009 San Francisco International Arts Festival.

Organization Name: San Francisco International Arts Festival, Inc.
Project Description: To support the presentation of a contemporary dance program in consortium with Epiphany Productions Sonic Dance Theater. The program will feature Kim Epifano's "Speaking Chinese," a co-production with Creative Futures Company, based in Shanghai, and "Oust," a collaboration between Dandelion Dance Theater and Compania Y from Spain. The program, in

Organization Name: San Francisco International Arts Festival, Inc.
Project Description: To support performances and residency activities by Spanish jazz pianist Omar Sosa and his Sextet. The Sextet also will perform at the Yerba Buena Arts and Events Festival.

Purpose: To support SFJAZZ Collective national touring and outreach activities. Additional Project Description: The ensemble will perform in concerts across the country in a national tour. The featured musical repertoire will include premieres of works by each collective member, as well as new arrangements of works by other composers. In addition to public performances, the tour will include educational programs and outreach events such as master classes for emerging musicians. Ensemble members will include jazz artists Matt Brewer, Etienne Charles, Chris Potter, David Sanchez, Kendrick A.D. Scott, Edward Simon, and Warren Wolf. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit general audiences across the country, including university students. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the SFJAZZ Collective's commissioning and touring performances of new original works by ensemble members and arrangements of works by singer-songwriter Joni Mitchell. Additional Project Description: During its 2022 national tour, the ensemble will engage in public performances and deliver educational and outreach events such as master classes for young musicians. The featured musical repertoire will include premieres of works by each Collective membercommissioned by SFJAZZ as well as new arrangements of works by singer-songwriter Joni Mitchell. In addition to public performances, the tour will include educational programs at concert venues across the nation with large student populations nearby. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve general audiences across the country, including students. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the SFJAZZ Collective's commissioning and development of new original works, and planning for a national tour. The musical repertoire will include premieres of works by each Collective member, commissioned by SFJAZZ, as well as new arrangements of two classic recordings: Miles Davis' In a Silent Way, and Sly and the Family Stone's Stand! Additional activities will include an intensive clinic for the SFJAZZ High School All-Stars band..

To support the SFJAZZ Collective's commissioning, development, and performance of new original works by ensemble members and arrangements of works by Brazilian composer Antnio Carlos Jobim. During its 2019 national tour, the ensemble will perform and engage in educational and outreach events including master classes for young musicians. Confirmed tour stops include a performance at the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles and a multi-day engagement at the SFJazz Center's Miner Auditorium, which will include a family matinee performance and a pre-concert talk.

To support the SFJAZZ Collective's commissioning, development, and performance of new original works by octet members and arrangements of music by Miles Davis. During its 2017 national tour, the ensemble will perform and engage in outreach events including master classes for young musicians. Confirmed tour stops include the Ferst Center for the Arts in Atlanta, Georgia; Chicago Symphony Center in Chicago, Illinois; Ferring Jazz Bistro, in St. Louis, Missouri; Miller Theatre at Columbia University in New York, New York; Annenberg Center for the Performing Arts in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; and Brooks Center for the Arts at Clemson University in Clemson, South Carolina.

To support the SFJAZZ Collective's performance of new original works by each member and arrangements of music by Michael Jackson. The ensemble will play as many as 18 live concerts on its 2016 national tour and present pre-concert talks, engage in master classes, workshops, school programs, and outreach events in tour cities throughout the United States. The SFJAZZ Collective members are Obed Calvaire, Robin Eubanks, Sean Jones, Matt Penman, Davis Sanchez, Edward Simon, Warren Wolf, and Miguel Zenon.

To support the SFJAZZ Collective's Spring 2015 tour and recording of original works and new arrangements of music by NEA Jazz Master Joe Henderson and the required product of copies of the recordings. During its spring 2015 tour, the ensemble will perform as many as ten concerts and engage in master classes, educational sessions, and outreach events. The Collective intends to record both the new works created by its ensemble members and the arrangements of Henderson's music, for the SFJAZZ label.

To support the SFJAZZ Collective's 10th anniversary retrospective tour and outreach. During its tour, the ensemble will present a retrospective of original works by Collective members and reinterpretations of jazz masterworks. Other project components include school concerts, residencies, workshops, and master classes for young musicians. Project activities also will consist of open rehearsals and pre- and post-concert talks.

To support the 2013 SFJAZZ Collective Tour and Outreach Project, a residency and touring ensemble. Components include the creation and public presentation of new and re-interpreted works by Collective members, residencies, workshops and master classes for young musicians, open rehearsals, and pre-concert talks.

To support the 2012 SFJazz Collective Tour and Outreach Project. The Collective is a residency and touring ensemble of all-star musicians; project components include the creation and public presentation of new works by Collective members and reinterpreted masterworks by Stevie Wonder as well as residencies for high school and college students.

To support the 2011 "SFJazz Collective Residency and Tour," a residency and touring ensemble of all-star musicians. Project components include the creation of eight new works and eight new arrangements by each collective member, residency activities, and a public performance in San Francisco followed by a tour tentatively to the states of AL, FL, GA, TN, and TX.

To support the Discover Jazz lecture series, in consortium with the Museum of the African Diaspora. Additional partner Yerba Buena Gardens Festival, the six-course interactive lecture series at the Museum of the African Diaspora, is led by musician and ethnomusicologist John Santos who invites participants to a multimedia educational experience that includes jazz video, classic and new jazz audio recordings, and lecture-demonstrations.
To support the residency and touring of the SF JAZZ Collective ensemble. Activities will encompass open rehearsals, world premieres of new work, educational outreach activities, and a national tour.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support the residency and touring activities of the SFJAZZ Collective ensemble. Events will include open rehearsals, world premieres of new work, educational outreach activities, and a national tour.

To support the residency and touring activities of the SFJAZZ Collective ensemble. Events will include open rehearsals, world premieres of new work, educational outreach activities, and a national tour.

To support the residency and touring activities of the SFJAZZ Collective ensemble. Events will include open rehearsals, world premieres of new work, educational outreach activities, and a national tour.

To support the residency and touring activities of the SF Jazz Collective ensemble. Events will include open rehearsals, world premieres of new work, educational outreach activities, and a national tour.
To support the presentation of NEA Jazz Masters as part of the national tour program.
To support the presentation of NEA Jazz Masters as part of the national tour program.

To support the residency and touring activities of the SF Jazz Collective ensemble. Events will include open rehearsals, world premieres of new work, educational outreach activities, and a national tour.
To support the presentation of Ornette Coleman, Wayne Shorter, Hank Jones, Clark Terry, Sonny Rollins, Jay McShann, and Herbie Hancock as part of the NEA Jazz Masters on Tour program.
To support the 22nd Annual San Francisco Jazz Festival. Events will take place in multiple performance spaces throughout San Francisco during the festival.
To support the NEA/Doris Duke Charitable Foundation's JazzNet Initiative to increase programming by jazz artists.
To support the 21st Annual San Francisco Jazz Festival. Executive Director Randall Kline will direct the programming of more than 24 events during the two-week festival.
To support the NEA/Doris Duke Charitable Foundation's JazzNet Initiative to increase programming by jazz artists.

To support "Sonny Rollins: Living Legend," a presentation project Artistic director Joshua Redman will program and participate in a weekend festival celebrating the artistry of saxophonist Sonny Rollins.
To support "The Legacy of Jazz Trumpet," a weekend of concerts and related activities. Artistic director Joshua Redman will participate in one weekend festival during 2001.

To support the NEA/Doris Duke Charitable Foundation's JazzNet initiative to increase commissioning and urban residency programs by jazz artists, including educational activities for youth and adults, and a jazz festival in the fall.

To support the San Francisco Jazz Festival. The 18th annual, two-week festival will produce more than 30 jazz concert performances featuring emerging and world-renowned artists in numerous Bay Area venues during fall 2000.

To support the 1999 San Francisco Jazz Festival. A jazz celebration which includes concerts in numersous Bay Area venues, the two-week fall Festival comprises of more than 20 jazz concerts performed by both emerging artists and world-renowned musicians, in total attracting more than 50,000 patrons.

To support the 1998 San Francisco Jazz Festival which includes concerts in numerous Bay Area venues; a Youth in Jazz concert, featuring high school jazz musicians; and Jazz Dialogues lectures for adults.

Purpose: To support a production of A Red Carol by Michael Gene Sullivan, and related engagement activities. Additional Project Description: In an adaptation faithful to Charles Dickens' original, which includes all characters found in the source material, this version of A Christmas Carol allows the characters to speak for themselves and to put their lives into context as part of the popular, and often edited, narrative. Engagement activities will include the creation of historical dioramas with facts and statistics from the Victorian era, the development of a study guide for high school students, panel discussions, and post-show conversations with the artists. The play will be made available via streaming. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve theater artists and the residents of San Francisco and the greater Bay Area region. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the audio play adaptation of Seeing Red: A Time Traveling Musical, the creation of accompanying educational material, and related engagement activities. Originally written by the troupe, the play is a time-traveling satire with music that explores the history of early 20th-century politics and invites dialogue that fosters a mutual respect for diverse beliefs and values. The production will be shortened to accommodate class schedules of the high schools and colleges throughout the Bay Area and in rural California, the intended audience for the adaptation.

To support the creation and production of "WALLS!," a satirical new musical theater work. Using the Mime Troupe's signature style of broad, physical theater, the work will explore immigration, gun violence, depression, the public education system, and racial tensions.

To support the tour of "Freedomland," an original musical theater political satire exploring concepts of citizenship. The work grapples with challenging themes using its signature style rooted in the popular theater traditions of Commedia dell'Arte, American Melodrama, and broad physicality. During the tour, workshops will be offered in the Troupe's unique style of collaborative playmaking.

To support "FreedomLand," a musical theater work that will examine the Bill of Rights. The work will be performed admission-free in public parks for socioeconomically diverse audiences. The piece will be developed with audience input on the issue of rights through social media, in-person story sessions, and educational forums. The production will employ the company's trademark style, drawing from many genres with an emphasis on highly physical commedia dell'arte, and incorporating larger-than-life characters, fantasy, and live music.

To support the development and production of "Ripple Effects." Based on real stories of people taking direct action to improve their environments, the production will illuminate the collective impact that individual actions can have in bettering local communities. With its roots in Commedia dell'Arte, the company has created more than 70 original productions using physicality and musical comedy to explore political and social issues in its 54-year history.

To support the creation, production, and Bay Area parks tour of "The Last Election." The musical will tell the story of a group of corporate power brokers on Capitol Hill that plots to postpone an election to make an assault on democracy.

To support the development and tour of a musical comedy titled "2012 - The Musical." The work will examine the destruction of the planet as seen through the eyes of a small group of time travelers who witness the future and return to the present day to demand change before it is too late.

To support the development and tour of a musical comedy titled "Posibilidad, or Death of the Worker." The Tony Award-winning company will develop and produce an entertaining comedy that explores the parallels between American and South American job security and workers rights framed against the ongoing recession.

To support the development and tour of a musical comedy titled "Too Big to Fail ." During its 50th anniversary season, the Tony award winning company will develop and produce an entertaining comedy that explores the ongoing national and international economic crisis.

To support the development and tour of a musical comedy entitled Red State. Developed and produced by the Tony Award-winning troupe, the musical will create an entertaining examination of electoral politics and the voting process.
To support the creation and tour of a new musical theater work, "Making a Killing." The work will tour in Bay Area parks and to rural communities in northern and central California.
To support the creation and tour of a new musical theater work, "GodFellas." The play will tour in Bay Area parks and to rural communities in northern and central California.

To support the development, production, and tour of an original musical comedy. As the centerpiece of its annual summer tour of free shows, DOING GOOD will be created and will tour to parks and venues throughout California including underserved rural communities.

To support the development, production, and tour of an original musical comedy. San Francisco Mime Troupe will premiere a new work that focuses on national or community events, touring it to Bay Area parks and venues throughout California, including underserved rural communities, then nationwide in fall.

To support the development, production, and national tour of an original musical comedy. San Francisco Mime Troupe will premiere a new work that focuses on national or community events in San Francisco and will tour Bay Area parks and venues throughout California.

To support the development, production, and tour of an original musical comedy. The new work will focus on national or community events in San Francisco and will tour Bay Area parks and venues throughout California.

To support the development, production, and national tour of an original musical comedy. San Francisco Mime Troupe will premiere a new work that focuses on national or community events in San Francisco and will tour Bay Area parks and venues throughout California.

To support the development and production of an original musical comedy. San Francisco Mime Troupe will premiere a new work that focuses on national or community events in San Francisco and will tour Bay Area parks and venues throughout California.

To support the development and production of an original musical comedy. The San Francisco Mime Troupe will develop a new work to premiere in San Francisco and tour Bay Area parks and venues throughout California.

To support the establishment of a cash reserve. The San Francisco Mime Troupe, which creates and performs original music theater, is seeking support for the establishment of a $100,000 cash reserve to provide the theater the means to effectively manage its cash flow, resulting in savings on annual interest expenses and loan fees. This reserve will afford the opportunity for the Mime Troupe=s staff to direct its attention to the creation of work and to the theater=s artistry, which will in turn contribute directly to long-term stability through earned and contributed funds, rather than a focus on cash shortages at the beginning of the production period

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support a retrospective exhibition featuring Nam June Paik (1932-2006). Co-organized in partnership with the Tate Modern in London, the exhibition will include as many as 200 works by the Korean-American artist who was a key figure in 20th century art. The exhibition will shed light on the pivotal role he played as the founder of video art.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support a traveling exhibition and catalogue of the work of photographer Dawoud Bey (b. 1953). Developed in partnership with the Whitney Museum of American Art, the exhibition will include more than seventy-five works and cover four decades of his early portraits in Harlem, his Polaroid series, and work that examines significant events related to civil rights and the nation's history.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support the retrospective exhibition Suzanne Lacy: We Are Here and an accompanying catalogue. The exhibition will cover almost five decades of Suzanne Lacy's (b. 1945) work from the 1970s to the present, including her social practice of community-based projects. The exhibition will feature approximately 80 works, including 42 core works and related ephemera, and many of her immersive installations. A range of large-scale displays will be produced in close collaboration with the artist. Lacy's art takes multiple formsperformance, sculpture and video installations, photography, and community-based projects that center on public encounters that combine dialogue and collaborative choreography on themes of feminism, aging, violence, and community building.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support the exhibition "Rene Magritte: The Fifth Season," and accompanying catalogue. The exhibition will explore the artist Rene Magritte's (1898-1967) late paintings, focusing primarily on the final 25 years of his career. The oil and gouache paintings will demonstrate how Magritte questioned avant-garde movements of his youth, through works that deftly copy, mimic, and even mock elements of Impressionism, Fauvism, and Expressionism, exposing one's confusion between appearance and reality. The works in the exhibition argue for an understanding of Magritte as an artist acutely aware of the social significance and power of image-making in post-war Europe and as an advocate for the enduring value of mystery in art. Related education and outreach activities will include a continuing education course inspired by the exhibition, professional development opportunities for teachers, and free school tours.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support the "Matisse/Diebenkorn" exhibition and related programming. Co-organized with the Baltimore Museum of Art, the exhibition will feature approximately 60 drawings and paintings by Henri Matisse (1869-1954) and approximately 60 works by Richard Diebenkorn (1922-93), creatively juxtaposing and pairing the artists' works to articulate the influence of Matisse on Diebenkorn. Free school tours, educational outreach activities, exhibition mobile guides, and other programs will enhance the experience for thousands of audience members.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support a retrospective exhibition of the work of California contemporary artist Bruce Conner (1933-2008). "Bruce Conner: It's All True" will showcase the diverse range of Conner's multifaceted work dating back to the 1950s, including approximately 200 paintings, assemblages, collages, drawings, prints, photographs, films, and tapestries. Educational programs will include daily guided tours for adult and school groups; sreenings of Conner's films; a continuing education course on the artist; and a weekend-long community celebration of Conner that will include curator talks, films, and performances.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support reinstallation of two of the museum's collections. The reinstallation project will combine the museum's painting and sculpture collection with art objects from the Fisher Collection of Postwar American and German art for the first time. Coinciding with the opening of the museum's expanded building, the reinstallation will more than double the amount of gallery space and will allow for a comprehensive survey of the collection. The reinstallation will expand upon the current chronological and thematic approach with presentations of works by American painters Marsden Hartley, Charles Sheeler, and Stuart Davis, along with their European contemporaries. The reinstallation also will allow for rotating galleries permanently dedicated to artists such as Paul Klee and Alexander Calder as well as other galleries devoted to Surrealism and Post-Minimalism.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support an exhibition and catalogue of the work of photographer and video artist Rineke Dijkstra (b. 1959). The exhibition will feature color photographs and video installations, including new work that has never been shown, presenting Dijkstra's reexamination of portraiture in contemporary art.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support research and planning for the catalog and touring exhibition Garry Winogrand's "America." The exhibition will include 250 photographs, as well as books, magazines, and other ephemera divided into three sections "New York City", "America", and "Late Work".

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support catalogue, courier and shipping costs for the San Franscico presentation of the touring exhibition "The Steins Collect: Matisse, Picasso, and the Parisian Avant-Garde." The exhibition will illuminate the Stein Family's role in the early 20th century revolution in the visual arts through both their patronage and the intellectual and artistic stimulus of their salons.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support a touring retrospective of the work of South African artist William Kentridge (b. 1955), with accompanying catalogue. The exhibition is being co-organized with the Norton Museum of Art in West Palm Beach, Florida.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support the exhibition "Take Your Time: Olafur Eliasson," with accompanying catalogue and education programs. This will be the first American retrospective exhibition of this Icelandic born (b. 1967) artist's career, surveying his sculpture, installation work, and photography.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support the presentation in San Francisco of the exhibition SHOMEI TOMATSU: SKIN OF THE NATION, with accompanying education programs.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support a retrospective of the work of American artist Richard Tuttle (b. 1941) with accompanying catalogue and education programs. Tuttle is celebrated as one of the most significant artists associated with Postminimalism.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support a traveling retrospective exhibition of the work of American artist Eva Hesse (1936-1970), with accompanying catalogue and education programs. The most comprehensive presentation of Hesse's work to date, the exhibition will offer new research into her career and reveal her significant influence on contemporary artistic practice and thought.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support "Making Sense of Modern Art," an interactive, multimedia education program, and associated curriculum and training materials. The program serves as a guide to the major artists, works, and themes represented in the museum's permanent collection.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support the touring exhibition "Sol Lewitt: A Retrospective," with an accompanying catalogue and public programs. The exhibition will survey the artist's 40-year career and will include his three-dimensional structures and wall drawings as well as works on paper, artists books, drawings, and photographs.

Organization Name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Project Description: To support Widening the Circle, Bridging the Gap, a combination of outreach and education programs and materials that will enable the Museum to promote access and expand opportunities for arts education, and to serve a larger and more diverse audience. The intended audience for "Widening the Circle" are the general audiences for two exhibitiions, "Inside/Out: New Chinese Art" and "Alexander Calder," and families and teachers. The five components of "Widening the Circle" are community partnerships, the integration of new technologies, training programs for teachers, outreach to families, and docent programs. Two community advisory committees will be instituted as part of the project: a teacher- artist committee will contribute to the presentation and evaluation of family and teacher programs, and a committee representing San Francisco's large Chinese-American community will be involved in developing programs in conjunction with the "New Chinese Art" exhibition. Other aspects of the project will be the addition of a staff person to the School and Youth Program which oversees teacher and family activities, Teacher Institutes devoted to specific topics in modern and contemporary art, and Self-Touring Workshops which train classroom teachers to conduct their own tours with their students.

Purpose: To support the presentation of Omar, a new work by composers Rhiannon Giddens and Michael Abels. Additional Project Description: The work is based on the life and the 1831 autobiography of Omar ibn Said, a West African scholar of Islamic faith enslaved in the Carolinas. This new opera explores issues such as personal strength and dignity, resistance, religious conviction and redemption. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances will benefit audience members in the San Francisco Bay Area, including students from local schools and colleges. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the world premiere of Antony and Cleopatra by Pulitzer Prize- and Grammy Award-winning composer and librettist John Adams as part of the 100th anniversary season. Additional Project Description: As a co-commission with Gran Teatre del Liceu (Barcelona, Spain) and Teatro Massimo (Palermo, Sicily), the composer will adapt the libretto from Shakespeare's play with supplementary passages from Virgil, Ovid, John Dryden, and the Egyptian Book of the Dead. The creative team will include conductor Eun Sun Kim, director Elkhanah Pulitzer, Tony Award-winning MacArthur Fellow set designer Mimi Lien, Tony Award-winning costume designer Constance Hoffman, and a cast to include American soprano Amina Edris, Canadian bass-baritone Gerald Finley, and American tenor Paul Appleby. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances will benefit audience members in the San Francisco Bay Area, including students from local schools and colleges. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support the American premiere of Innocence by composer Kaija Saariaho and librettist Sofi Oksanen. The focus of the opera is the exploration of generational conflict in the wake of traumaa random attack targeting innocent young students. The production was co-commissioned by the Aix-en-Provence Festival, Dutch National Opera, Royal Opera House Covent Garden, and the Finnish National Opera.

To support planning for the west coast premiere of The Handmaid's Tale by composer Poul Ruders and librettist Paul Bentley. Based on the 1985 novel by Margaret Atwood, the story takes place in the early 21st century after earthquakes and nuclear plant meltdowns have caused environmental devastation, famine, and infertility throughout the United States.

To support performances of The (R)evolution of Steve Jobs by composer Mason Bates and librettist Mark Campbell. Based on the life and work of Steve Jobs (1955-2011), the story is about a man reflecting on the formative events in his life while learning to acknowledge his own mortality. The work is the composer's first full-length opera. A co-commissioning project with Santa Fe Opera, Seattle Opera, and co-produced with Indiana University's Jacobs School of Music, the opera will be directed by Kevin Newbury and the cast will include Edward Parks (baritone) in the title role and Sasha Cooke (mezzo-soprano). As many as eight performances will take place on the main stage at San Francisco's War Memorial Opera House.

To support the West Coast premiere of "It's A Wonderful Life" by composer Jake Heggie and librettist Gene Scheer. Based on Frank Capra's 1946 film and the short story on which it was based, "The Greatest Gift" by Philip Van Doren Stern, the opera will depart from the film in important ways, especially through its telling of the story from the perspective of a female angel, reimagined as Clara. Co-commissioned and co-produced with Houston Grand Opera and Indiana University's Jacobs School of Music, as many as ten performances will take place in winter 2018 at War Memorial Opera House.

To support the world premiere of "Girls of the Golden West" by composer and NEA Opera Honoree John Adams and librettist Peter Sellars. The opera interweaves the true stories of three women during the Gold Rush whose lives intersect in a small mining community of the Sierra Mountains in 1850. Outreach activities will provide context for the role of women in the Gold Rush and the Mechanics Institute Library will lead a discussion about the process of mining in the 1850s.

To support the world premiere of "Dream of the Red Chamber" by composer Bright Sheng with a libretto by playwright David Henry Hwang and Sheng. The text was written in the 18th century by Cao Xueqin, and is considered one of China's four great classical novels, telling the story of a heartbreaking and timeless love triangle. The creative team includes Tony Award-winner David Henry Hwang, playwright and director Stan Lai, Academy Award-winning designer and art director Tim Yip, conductor George Manahan, and contralto Qiu Lin Zhang. Outreach activities will focus on the local and national Chinese-American community, college/university programs in music and Chinese/Asian studies, and cultural institutions in the Bay Area.

To support performances of "Sweeney Todd" by composer and librettist Stephen Sondheim. The opera is a co-production with Houston Grand Opera and Theatre du Chatelet (Paris, France). The creative team includes conductor Patrick Summers, director Lee Blakeley, and designer Tanya McCallin. The artistic team includes baritone Brian Mulligan (Sweeney Todd), mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe (Mrs. Lovett), bass-baritone Wayne Tigges (Judge Turpin), and soprano Heidi Stober (Johanna).

To support a new production of "Les Troyens" by composer Hector Berlioz. Based on Virgil's epic "Aeneid" the production may feature mezzo-soprano Susan Graham (Didon), tenor Bryan Hymel (Enee), bass-baritone Christian Van Horn (Narbal), and tenor Rene Barbera (Iopas), in a production created by director David McVicar, set designer Es Devline, costume designer Moritz Junge, and conducted by Donald Runnicles. Considered one of the most important French operas of the 19th century, the composer's greatest opera, and his greatest musical achievement, the opera is rarely programmed or is produced in a reduced version-due in part to its grand scale comprising numerous large chorale and ballet scenes.

To support the commission and premiere of "Dolores Claiborne" by composer Tobias Picker and librettist J.D. McClatchy. Based on the novel by Stephen King, the production will include a title role brought to life by Patricia Racette, alongside Elizabeth Futral as Vera, and will be conducted by George Manahan and directed by James Robinson.

To support the premiere of "The Gospel of Mary Magdalene" by composer and librettist Mark Adamo. Community outreach activities include panel discussions with the artists, biblical scholars, and authors allowing for questions and answers, lectures, films, and artwork displays about Mary Magdalene in the Opera House lobby.

To support the world premiere of "Heart of a Soldier" by American composer Christopher Theofanidis. The work is based on the non-fiction book by James B. Stewart about a Vietnam War veteran who uses his prior training to rescue victims trapped in the World Trade Center towers.

To support Wagner's "Der Ring des Nibelungen" (the Ring cycle). Education outreach and enrichment activities will include an "Insight" panel discussion in San Francisco's Herbst Theater featuring members of the cast and production team and preview lectures that will be held at various venues throughout the Bay Area.

To support performances of Puccini's La Fanciulla del West and related educational outreach activities. A panel discussion with members of the cast and production team, Opera Guild-sponsored preview lectures, and pre-performance lectures about the work will be offered to enhance the audience experience.

To support the world premiere of "The Bonesetter's Daughter" by composer Stewart Wallace and librettist Amy Tan. Education and outreach programs will include a panel discussion featuring members of the cast and the creative team, preview lectures at various Bay Area locations, pre-performance lectures, and a dress rehearsal for Bay Area middle and high school students.

To support the world premiere of "Appomattox" by composer Philip Glass and librettist Christopher Hampton. The opera is based on the final encounter of Union General Ulysses S. Grant and Confederate General Robert E. Lee during the last days of the Civil War.
To support a new production of "Iphigenie en Tauride" by Christoph Willibald Gluck. The 1774 work embodies significant reforms to opera that forever changed the development of the operatic genre.

To support a production of "Doctor Atomic" by composer John Adams and stage director Peter Sellars. The world premiere and six other performances will take place at San Francisco's War Memorial Opera House in October 2005.
To support the United States premiere of "Le Grand Macabre" by Gyorgy Ligeti. Six performances of the opera will take place at the 3,148-seat War Memorial House.
To support a production of Virgil Thomson's THE MOTHER OF US ALL with libretto by Gertrude Stein. Performances at the War Memorial Opera House are expected to reach an audience of more than 17,500.

To support a new production, the North American premiere, of the opera ST. FRANCOIS D'ASSISE by Olivier Messiaen. This work, composed in 1983, will receive up to six performances at the War Memorial Opera House.

To support the western premiere of the nineteenth-century Armenian opera "Arshak II" by Tigran Chukhadjian. The opera will receive six performances at San Francisco's 3,148-seat War Memorial Opera House in 2001.

To support the world premiere of the opera "Dead Man Walking" by composer Jake Heggie with libretto by Terrence McNally. In 1999-2000, seven performances will take place in the renovated 3,148-seat War Memorial Opera House, which is equipped with state-of-the-art technical equipment.

To support a national tour of Mozart's "Don Giovanni" performed by the Western Opera Theater. The tour will be presented in collaboration with local presenters throughout the United States reaching approximately 36 towns in 14 states.
To support the creation and premiere performances of an opera based on Tennessee William's "A Streetcar Named Desire," written by composer Andre Previn and librettist Philip Littell.

Purpose: To support a chamber music presenting project. Additional Project Description: Programming will feature innovative women's voices with guest artists soprano Dawn Upshaw and mezzo-soprano J'Nai Bridges. San Francisco Performances also will feature violinists Nicola Benedetti and Alina Ibramigova, as well as Catalyst Quartet, Brentano String Quartet, and Chiaroscuro Quartet. Repertoire will range from works by Henry Purcell and Florentine Price to those by Melinda Wagner and Carlos Simon. Intended Beneficiaries: The performances will benefit audiences of all ages. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support a music presenting project. Programming will feature chamber music performances with guest artists such as clarinetist Anthony McGill, pianists Michelle Cann and Stewart Goodyear, the string quartet Brooklyn Rider, as well as the Catalyst Quartet performing works by composers such as Rhiannon Giddens, Nico Muhly, Tomeka Reid, Matana Roberts, and Tyshawn Sorey.

To support a music presenting project. Co-curated and performed by violinist Jennifer Koh and pianist Timo Andres, programming will feature chamber music performances with guest artists such as counter tenor Anthony Roth Costanzo. Some activity will be virtual.
To support a series of music and dance presentations. San Francisco Performances will present Paul Taylor Dance Company.

To support a music performance presenting project. Programming will include performances by artists including the New York-based early music ensemble TENET with members of the Quicksilver Baroque Ensemble, violinist Daniel Hope, cellist Matt Haimovitz with composer/pianist Vijay Iyer, and the Grammy Award-winning Third Coast Percussion Ensemble performing a new work commissioned from American composer Philip Glass. Venues will include St. Mark's Lutheran Church and Herbst Theatre in the Veterans Building of the San Francisco War Memorial.

To support Contemporary Composers and Composer/Performers, a presentation of musical works by 20th- and 21st-century composers. The project will include new works commissioned from American composers Caroline Shaw and Lera Auerbach. Programming will include performances by musicians such as mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard; soprano Dawn Upshaw, pianist Gilbert Kalish and So Percussion; violinist Leila Josefowicz and pianist John Novacek; as well as composer and pianist Lera Auerbach.

To support a series of music and dance performances. The series will feature performances by pianist Leif Ove Andsnes (Norway), pianist Jonathan Biss, the Brentano String Quartet, Dorrance Dance, the Dover Quartet, pianist Marc-Andre Hamelin (Canada), cellist Harriet Krigjh (The Netherlands), tenor Mark Padmore, Paul Taylor Dance Company, and pianist Javier Perianes (Spain). Educational and outreach activities will include lectures, open rehearsals, and workshops.

To support a series of music and dance performances. Proposed artists include violinist Jennifer Koh (United States) and pianist/composers Thomas Ades and Gloria Cheng (England and United States) performing a duo recital. The series also may feature butoh dance troupe Sankai Juku (Japan) and Wayne McGregor with his dance company Random Dance (England). Each artist also will participate in engagement and outreach activities.

To support presentations of music and dance performances. Proposed artists include the Brentano String Quartet, pianist Garrick Ohlsson, baritone Christian Gerhaher, dancer Wendy Whelan, dance company Batsheva, jazz composer and pianist Vijay Iyer, cellist Alisa Weilerstein, and the Paul Taylor Dance Company.

To support the American Artists performance series. Presentations will include performances from the Pacifica Quartet, the Juilliard Quartet, soprano Stephanie Blythe, cellist David Requiro, and the Stephen Petronio Dance Company, among others.

To support the presentation of commissioned works, as well as world and regional premieres of music and dance works. Related workshops, master classes, and lectures will help audiences increase their understanding and enjoyment of the live performances; artists include pianist Jonathan Biss, Elias String Quartet, tenor Mark Padmore, clarinetist Carey Bell, violist Scott St. John, The Bad Plus jazz trio, Philip Glass Ensemble, and Paul Taylor Dance Company.

To support the presentation of commissioned works, as well as world and regional premieres of music and dance works. Related workshops, master classes, and lectures will help audiences increase their understanding and enjoyment of the live performances; artists include the Brentano and Alexander String Quartets, jazz pianist Fred Hersch, and choreographer Karole Armitage.

To support the presentation of chamber music, instrumental recitals, jazz, and contemporary dance. Related workshops and lectures will help audiences increase their understanding and enjoyment of the live performances.

To support the presentation Lucinda Child's DANCE, and accompanying outreach activities. . Outreach activities will include master classes, post-performance discussions, open rehearsals, exhibitions, and video screenings.

To support the presentation of chamber music, vocal and instrumental recitals, jazz, and contemporary dance, as well as related outreach activities Related workshops and lectures will help audiences increase their understanding and enjoyment of the live performances.

To support a festival celebrating the 100th birthday of American composer Elliott Carter. The performances and community educational events will take place in the Concert Hall at the San Francisco Conservatory of Music.

To support the presentation of chamber music, vocal and instrumental recitals, jazz, and contemporary dance. Related workshops and lectures will help audiences increase their understanding and enjoyment of the live performances.

To support the presentation of chamber music, vocal and instrumental recitals, jazz, and contemporary dance. Related workshops and lectures will help audiences increase their understanding and enjoyment of the live performances.

To support the presentation of chamber music, vocal and instrumental recitals, jazz, and contemporary dance; including related educational activities. Workshops and lectures will help audiences increase their understanding and enjoyment of the live performances.

To support residencies and performances of Meredith Monk's THE IMPERMANENCE PROJECT, in consortium with the University of California, Santa Barbara. Activities will include performances, master classes for dancers and vocalists, post-performance questions and answers, a composition forum, and a lecture.

To support the presentation of chamber music, vocal and instrumental recitals, jazz, and contemporary dance. Related workshops and lectures will help audiences to increase their understanding and enjoyment of the live performances.

To support commissions and presentations of dance companies. American and international companies will offer performances and residency activities. Companies to be presented include Stephen Petronio Company (New York), The Paul Taylor Dance Company and Taylor 2 (New York), and Batsheva Dance Company (Israel).

To support "Performance Poetry" and "Jazz Intervention."
