Jazz vibraphonist Stefon Harris and baritone Christopheren Nomura will work with high school students (primarily inner-city teens) in lecture- demonstrations, workshops, instrument and creative writing instruction, and culminating performances for family and friends.

To support long-term artist residencies and community education activities for audiences of all ages in school and community settings. World-class artists will participate in lecture-demonstrations, workshops, instrument instruction, pre- and post-concert discussions, in-service programs for teachers, and family matinee performances.

To support artist residencies in the San Francisco metropolitan community and local schools. The project will extend ongoing residencies with Stephen Petronio Dance Company, classical guitarist Manuel Barrueco, and jazz violinist Regina Carter.
To support targeted planning for an endowment campaign during 1998-1999.

To support the Sandbox New Play Program. The program supports playwrights through the commissioning and development of new works. Development opportunities will include a monthly reading series, week-long workshops with professional artists, and the Sandbox Series of world premiere productions. Designed to serve as a bridge between readings and mainstage productions, the program will provide a low-risk environment and community of support in which playwrights can hone their craft. The project includes the world premiere of a new play by Theresa Rebeck.

To support the Sandbox New Play Program. Through the commission and development of new works, playwrights will be supported with a monthly reading series, week-long workshops with professional artists, and the Sandbox Series of world premiere productions. The program will serve as a bridge between readings and mainstage productions by providing a low-risk environment and community of support in which playwrights can hone their craft.

Purpose: To support a series of temporary public art installations reflecting on sculptor Ruth Asawa's (1926-2013) permanent public art work, the Garden of Remembrance and related activities. Additional Project Description: Created to memorialize the incarceration of Japanese Americans during World War II, Garden of Remembrance was installed on the San Francisco State University campus in 2002. Contemporary artists Mark Baugh-Sasaki, Tina Kashiwagi, Paul Kitagaki Jr., Lisa Solomon, and Tina Takemoto will create new installations reflecting on Asawa's original work. Public programs will take place and a publication documenting the project will provide audiences with additional historical and archival information about the artists and the site. Intended Beneficiaries: The Japanese-American community of Northern California and the general university audience which includes students, faculty, administrators, and staff will benefit from the project. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support the Poetry Center's reading series. Featuring readings and discussions with contemporary poets and writers, series events take place at the Poetry Center and at other venues across San Francisco and the East Bay, and often showcase writers not previously presented by the organization.

To support the Poetry Center's reading series. Featuring readings and discussions with contemporary poets and artists, series events take place online, at the Poetry Center, and at other venues across San Francisco, and often showcase writers not previously presented by the organization. Each event will be filmed and made available free-of-charge in the Poetry Center Digital Archive; shorter clips of event highlights also will be posted on YouTube.

To support The Poetry Center's reading series. The series will feature contemporary poets and artists at the Poetry Center Reading Room and other venues across San Francisco. Each event will be filmed and made available free-of-charge in the Poetry Center Digital Archive.

To support The Poetry Center's reading series. Showcasing writers from across the literary spectrum, the series will feature contemporary poets and artists in readings at the Poetry Center Reading Room and other venues across San Francisco. Each event will be filmed and made available free-of-charge online in the Poetry Center Digital Archive.

To support the preservation, transfer, and cataloging of audio recordings for the Poetry Center Digital Archive. The archive features recordings of rare poetry readings from the 1970s and '80s that are vulnerable to damage.

To support the preservation, digital transfer, and cataloging of at-risk audio recordings of poetry readings from the 1970s. Early analog recordings will treated and posted on the Poetry Center Digital Archive website.

To support in-house conversion of hours of digital video-tape masters to MP4 video distribution files. The university will preserve, transfer, catalog, and make accessible for free 50 hours of additional at-risk original videos of poetry readings between 1973 and 1986.

To support the Poetry Center Digital Archive. The university will preserve, transfer, catalog, and make accessible for free 125 rare, at-risk original videos of poetry readings between 1973 and 2000 and early analog audio recordings from 1953 to 1974.

To support a recording of composer Richard Festinger's "The Coming of Age," a chamber work for soprano and chamber ensemble, in consortium with the New York New Music Ensemble. Featuring guest violist Lois Martin and soprano Elizabeth Farnum, the work will be released worldwide on the Naxos label.

To support the reconstruction of choreographer Brenda Way's "Investigating Grace," created in 1999, presented by the School of Music and Dance. Performances, master classes, lectures, and additional outreach activities will provide educational and artistic opportunities for the San Francisco Bay Area community.
To support free Web access to selections from the Poetry Center's Digital Archive. The archive includes more than 3,000 audio recordings of poets from 1954 to the present.

To support the continued cataloguing and digitizing of audiotapes from the Poetry Center's American Poetry Archives. The center will record, catalogue, and make available parts of the most 56significant audiotapes dating from 1954 to 1974.

To support the cataloguing and digitizing of audiotapes from the Poetry Center's American Poetry Archives. The center will record, catalogue, and make available parts of the most significant audiotapes dating from 1954 to 1974.

To support the cataloguing and digitizing of audiotapes from the Poetry Center's American Poetry Archives. The center will catalogue and record detailed contents for the most significant audiotapes dating from 1954 to 1974.

To support the cataloging and digitizing of audiotapes from the Poetry Center's American Poetry Archives. The center will catalog and record detailed contents for the most significant audiotapes dating from 1954 to 1974.
To support the Poetry Center's Being a Poet youth residency project. A pilot program will bring renowned visiting writers to local classrooms, using current literary efforts in the Bay area.

To support the preservation of audio and video recordings from the American Poetry Archives. The center will develop and implement standardized procedures for digitizing, storing, and cataloging its audio and video recordings.

To support the continuing restoration of historical film footage from the American Poetry Archives. Authors featured in these original recordings include Ernest J. Gaines, Audre Lorde, Allen Ginsberg, Charles Reznikoff, William S. Burroughs, and Ted Hughes.

To support the restoration of historical film footage from the Poetry Center's American Poetry Archives. Authors featured in these original recordings include William Stafford, Audre Lorde, Allen Ginsberg, William S. Burroughs, and Ted Hughes.
To support the production and distribution of a comprehensive catalog of The Poetry Center's audio and video recordings.
To support the restoration of historical film footage from the Poetry Center's American Poetry Archives.

To support the restoration of historical film footage from the Poetry Center's American Poetry Archives of authors such as Eudora Welty, Louis Zukovsky, Janet Flanner,and Frank O'Hara; and the continued videotaping of the Poetry Center's reading series to make available for loan or rent the most extensive collection of poetry videos in the country. PROJECT SUMMARY: Scheduled readers to be taped in the Center's reading series include Dorothy Allison, David Leavitt, Toi Derricotte, Sherman Alexie, Philip Levine, Tino Villanueva, Paul Beatty, and Eilzabeth Alexander. Founded in 1954, The Poetry Center's American Poetry Archives now hold over 1,000 taped presentations which are available for loan or rent nationwide, and have been used by ABC News's Prime Time and Nightline. Selected Archive tapes now are available in Embassy libraries worldwide through an agreement with the United States Information Agency.
To support the Third Annual San Francisco Tamburitza Festival. The festival will feature traditional artists and ensembles performing the tamburitza music indigenous to the Balkans.

To support the Lorraine Hansberry Theatre's production of "The Urban Retreat" by A. Zell Williams. The play tells the story of an English teacher and long-rejected writer who is hired by a publisher to turn the grandiose ramblings of a young 25-year-old rap superstar into a compelling memoir. The writing process becomes a surprising and deeply honest exchange about survival, selling out, and what it means to be a Black man in America today. The playwright will work with Daveed Diggs to use hip-hop lyrics to bring the script to life.

To support the production of "Thurgood," a one-man play based on the life of Thurgood Marshall by George Stevens, Jr. First produced on Broadway in 2009, the play follows Marshall's rise from an impoverished childhood in Baltimore to become the first African-American Justice on the U.S. Supreme Court, and tracks his profound impact on the Civil Rights Act. Select performances will be followed by talkbacks with artists, lawyers, and civil rights experts.

To support a multidisciplinary production of "Mingus Remixed," an exploration of avant-garde jazz artist Charles Mingus. His identity and artistry will be explored during a three-act spoken word and music performance, written and performed actor Barry "Shabaka" Henley.

To support architectural studies and a feasibility plan to identify a new venue for the Lorraine Hansberry Theatre. Brian Rawlinson will serve as lead architect for the project. The organization will develop strategies to keep ticket prices moderate during transition into the new venue.
To support development of a new musical, utilizing guest artist Jared Crawford. The work will focus on issues facing urban African American youth.

To support the development of a new musical shadow theater work created in collaboration with the Paul Dresher Ensemble. Inspired by the science-fiction short stories of Chinese author Cixin Liu, the piece will consist of original musical composition, invented instruments, and cinematic visuals integrating shadow puppets and actors.

To support post-production and outreach costs for the documentary "Finding Kukan." Directed by Robin Lung, "Finding Kukan" chronicles the story of Li Ling-Ai, the un-credited female producer of "Kukan," an Academy Award-winning documentary about World War II China that has been lost for decades. Funds will support the creation of a 57-minute broadcast version of the film as well as a study and curriculum guide for middle and high school students and university settings. Additionally, the "Finding Kukan" website will be updated to include relevant links and resources, a downloadable PDF version of the study/curriculum guide, and translating much of the content to Mandarin Chinese.

To support production and post-production costs for the documentary "Finding Kukan." A feature documentary by Robin Lung, "Finding Kukan" chronicles the story of Li Ling-Ai, the un-credited female producer of "Kukan," an Academy Award-winning documentary about World War II China that has been lost for decades. The film's narrative focuses on Li Ling-Ai's pioneering path as a filmmaker, author, and activist who dedicated her career to shattering anti-Chinese stereotypes in America. To reveal key behind-the-scenes moments in the making of "Kukan," ShadowLight Productions theater group will collaborate with film's director and animation designer Chris Do to produce historical "shadow sequence" re-enactments. Like human shadow puppets, actors appear in silhouette, acting out scenes and reciting lines pulled from primary source documents. These scenes will be enhanced with animation and motion graphics to provide context and mood.

To support a shadow theater production. In the tradition of radio and television programs from the 1950s such as "The Weird Circle," "Science Fiction Theatre," and "The Twilight Zone," the project will explore the concepts of community, environment, and human connection using the conventions of science fiction.

To support the "Poro Oyna: The Myth of the Aynu." A new multidisciplinary shadow theater work created by Larry Reed in collaboration with OKI, a prominent musician from the indigenous Ainu tribe in Hokkaido, Japan, the project will explore the Ainu mythology, language, music, and history in order to introduce Bay Area audiences to the ancient culture and to provide a platform to reflect upon the effects of globalization.

To support the "Soy Newcomer!" with accompanying educational and outreach activities. Company and teaching artist Leonidas Kassapides will direct and collaborate with Everett Middle School's drama and multimedia teacher Martha Estrella.

To support a workshop and in-progress presentations of a new shadow theater work, "The Good-For-Nothing Lover". Artistic director Larry Reed, co-author/performer Karen Kandel, and choreographer/performer Wan-Chao Chang will develop the work.
To support the development and production of a new play. Ghosts of the River by Octavio Solis will be directed by artistic director and Balinese puppet master Larry Reed.

To support the production of a shadow puppet play titled "Journey to the West: Monkey King at Spider Cave." The project is based on "Journey to the West," the story of how Buddhism was brought to China.

To support an extended outreach program. The project will include the development of a quarterly online newsletter, an upgraded Web site, in-school workshops, and the engagement of an outreach coordinator.
To support the world premiere of "The Seven Visions of Encarnacion." This new shadow-theater performance piece will focus on Latino identity and heritage in California.

To support the commissioning of a multidisciplinary historical performance work by Latino playwright Octavio Solis. This new shadow theater performance piece focuses on the history of Latinos in California.
To support Tales from Native California. The project will consist of three or more stories translated from the Karuk language for shadow theater performances and recorded on video.

To support the premiere and presentation of an original interdisciplinary work, "Dreaming California." This company's full-length interdisciplinary performance piece drawn from the life of John Sutter, America's first millionaire, will commemorate the California Sesquicentennial.

To support the development of "Dreaming California," an interdisciplinary work that expands the range of traditional shadow theater by incorporating contemporary technology and stagecraft. This full-length interdisciplinary performance piece will commemorate the California Sesquicentennial. The project's principal collaborators are artistic director Larry Reed, composer Richard Marriott, dramaturg Mame Hunt and advisors Sandra Phillips and Julian Lang. The piece will track the continual re-imagining and renaming of California through the life of John Sutter. The work will neither document nor realistically recreate history, but will utilize shadow theater techniques to evoke the psychological, social, political and cultural forces unleashed by the Gold Rush that have dominated California history ever since. The production will tour throughout the state. Major festivals in the U.S. and Europe have expressed interest in presenting it. A collaborating ensemble of scriptwriters, choreographers, composers, visual designers, actors, dancers, musicians and puppeteers creates ShadowLight's productions. Much of the artists' work is rooted in non-western performing arts traditions. The company has used technological innovations such as specially designed projectors to cast shadow characters ranging in

Purpose: To support artist fees and staff salaries for the San Francisco Shakespeare Festival's touring production of William Shakespeares Much Ado About Nothing. Additional Project Description: The production, envisioned through an intercultural lens to explore societal inequities and to raise awareness, will tour to parks in Cupertino, Redwood City, and San Francisco, and will be made available to audiences at no cost. Intended Beneficiaries: The tour will serve residents of the San Francisco Bay Area region. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the San Francisco Shakespeare Festival's Free Shakespeare in the Park production of As You Like It. The production will be a new musical theater version of Shakespeare's comedy set in present-day San Francisco that will use the play's original songs, speeches, and dialogues.

To support the San Francisco Shakespeare Festival's Free Shakespeare in the Park production of A Midsummer Night's Dream. Directed by Artistic Director Rebecca J. Ennals, the fully mounted professional production will be presented in civic parks throughout the Bay Area. Without the barriers of cost and venue, the Free Shakespeare in the Park series will provide an opportunity for a diverse community to share an artistic activity, building a sense of civic pride and belonging.

To support the San Francisco Shakespeare Festival's Free Shakespeare in the Park production of "Hamlet." The fully mounted professional production will be presented in civic parks throughout the Bay Area. Directed by Associate Artistic Director Stephen Muterspaugh, the production will feature a diverse cast of actors. Related outreach activities will include an original Green Show to introduce audiences to the themes of the play, and public workshops at libraries and other venues, which will provide opportunities for contextualization and conversation. Without the barriers of cost and venue, the Free Shakespeare in the Park series is designed to provide an opportunity for a diverse community to share an artistic activity, building a sense of civic pride and belonging.

To support a Free Shakespeare in the Park production of "Taming of the Shrew," directed by Artistic Director Rebecca Ennals. The program has been a Bay Area tradition for more than 30 years, and serves the communities of San Francisco, Cupertino, Redwood City, and Pleasanton with free, professional performances of Shakespeare in public parks.

To support Free Shakespeare in the Park with a production of "Cymbeline" directed by award-winning Director Ken Kelleher. Twenty-nine public performances will be presented in public parks in four different Bay Area regions: Pleasanton, Cupertino, San Francisco, and one venue still to be determined.
To support Free Shakespeare in the Park. Ken Kelleher will direct the production of Two Gentlemen of Verona, with scenic design by Richard Ortenblad and choreography by MaryBeth Cavanaugh.
To support the Free Shakespeare in the Park tour. The tour will provide diverse audiences in the San Francisco Bay Area access to productions of a Shakespeare play free of charge.

Category: Challenge America Positive Alternatives for Youth
Project Description: To support a partnership project of artist-led activities that provides positive alternatives for youth. The partnership with East Bay Conservation Corps, San Jose Department of Parks, Recreation and Neighborhood Services, The Ark Refuge, and Morrill Middle School will implement "Midnight Shakespeare,"an in-depth study of Shake speare for youth in economically diverse neighborhoods in San Francisco, Oaklan d, and San Jose.

To support "Free Shakespeare in the Park," which offers diverse audiences the opportunity to enjoy professional productions of Shakespeare in San Francisco Bay Area public parks. The 2002 production will mark the company's 20th anniversary of offering free performances to the region.

Purpose: To support staff salaries for the San Francisco Silent Film Festival. Additional Project Description: Silent films with live musical accompaniment will be presented at the Castro Theatre in San Francisco. Some of the films were recently restored or preserved. Film screenings will be supplemented by special presentations to highlight the educational aspects of each film, alongside a comprehensive program book with original essays and articles written by experts and historians in film and music. The books will be distributed free to audiences during the events and to libraries, schools, and archives after the festival. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival will serve audiences including local residents and visitors, as well as participating artists, musicians, schools, students, archivists, and preservationists. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the San Francisco Silent Film Festival and related preservation and educational activities. Silent films with live musical accompaniment will be presented at the Castro Theatre in San Francisco, some of which were recently restored or preserved. Film screenings will be supplemented by a special presentations to highlight the educational aspects of each film, alongside a comprehensive program book with original essays and articles written by experts and historians in both film and music, which are distributed free to audiences during the events and to libraries, schools, and archives after the festival.

To support the 23rd San Francisco Silent Film Festival and related educational programming. Silent films with live musical accompaniment will be presented at the Castro Theatre in San Francisco. Film screenings are coupled with presentations and written materials by experts and historians in both film and music. Many of the works screened are recently restored or preserved films.

To support the 21st San Francisco Silent Film Festival. The four-day event showcases silent films with live musical accompaniment at the Castro Theatre in San Francisco. The festival will celebrate the centennial of a pivotal year in film history - 1916 - with screenings of films made in that year, such as D.W. Griffith's "Intolerance."
To support the 19th San Francisco Silent Film Festival The event showcases silent films with live musical accompaniment at the Castro Theatre in San Francisco.
To support the 16th San Francisco Silent Film Festival. Newly-composed live music will accompany the films presented at the festival's 15 programs.
To support the 15th San Francisco Silent Film Festival. Newly composed live music will accompany the films presented at the festival's 14 programs.
To support the 14th San Francisco Silent Film Festival Newly composed live music will accompany the films presented at the festival's 14 programs.
To support the 13th San Francisco Silent Film Festival. Newly composed live music will accompany the films presented at the festival's 11 programs.
To support the 12th San Francisco Silent Film Festival. Newly composed live music will accompany the films presented at the festival's nine programs.
To support the 11th San Francisco Silent Film Festival. Newly composed live music will accompany the films presented at the festival's nine programs.
To support the 9th Annual San Francisco Silent Film Festival. Held during the summer, the event presents film programs with live musical accompaniment.

To support the publication and promotion of a collection of poems, a chapbook of poetry and associated outreach activities. This project includes a Web site redesign, the conversion of inventory to e-books, and a "Senior Outreach Project," involving readings and workshops at Bay Area senior facilities.
To support the publication and promotion of a collection of poetry by Lynne Knight.

To support the presentation of dance works as part of the company's 25th anniversary season. Artistic Director Celia Fushille has curated a selection of artists to honor the past, present, and future of the company as part of the Dance Series O1. Choreographer Trey McIntyre will present Blue Until June, and company dancers Ben Needham-Wood, Nicole Haskins, and Rex Wheeler will each create and premiere new works alongside works by founder Michael Smuin's The Eternal Idol and Schubert Scherzo.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work by choreographer Adam Hougland, and performances of "Serenade for Strings" by choreographer Garrett Ammon. Hougland is principal choreographer for Louisville Ballet, resident choreographer for Cincinnati Ballet, and has created work for Smuin Ballet before. This project represents the company's first staging of a work by Garrett Ammon, artistic director of Wonderbound (formerly Ballet Nouveau Colorado).

To support the presentation of Jiri Kylian's "Return to a Strange Land" and a world premiere by choreographer in residence Amy Seiwert. The works will be featured as part of the ballet's 20th anniversary season.

To support the presentation of West Coast premieres of ballets by choreographers Adam Hougland and Helen Pickett. The works will include Adam Hougland's Cold Virtues and Helen Pickett's Petal. In addition to performances in San Francisco, the company will perform in Walnut Creek, Carmel, Livermore, and Mountain View, CA.

To support the presentation of a new work by choreographer Amy Seiwert as well as the commissioning and presentation of a world premiere by Ma Cong. The works will be presented in Smuin Ballet's home cities in Northern California: Carmel, Mountain View, San Francisco, and Walnut Creek.

To support world premiere works by choreographer Trey McIntyre and choreographer-in-residence Amy Seiwert. The company will work with the Community Access Ticket Service (CATS) to provide complimentary tickets to underserved community members who may not otherwise be able to attend the performance.
To support the presentation of new works. Performances will include a new piece by choreographer in residence Amy Seiwart and the company premiere of French Twist by dancer/choreographer Ma Cong.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work by Amy Seiwert, and the West Coast premiere performances of The Naughty Boy, choreographed by Trey McIntyre, and Carmen, choreographed by Robert Sund. Performances will take place in San Francisco, Walnut Creek, Mountain View, and Carmel, California.
To support the creation and presentation of a new work by Amy Seiwert and the West Coast premiere of Kirk Peterson's "Reinin' in the Hurricane."

Purpose: To support the creation and presentation of a multidisciplinary performance piece. Additional Project Description: "Water.Bodies.Land" will feature music, dance, and poetry celebrating Black women's voices around environmental issues. The piece will feature song lyrics from previously published poems by Black women writers including Lucille Clifton, June Jordan, Maya Angelou, and Nikki Giovanni. Accompanying community workshops will allow participants opportunities to discuss selected poems and create artworks in response. The results of these collaborations will be integrated into the staged performance. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit with general San Francisco-area audiences and artists, with a focus on serving Black women throughout the greater Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organizations constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support the exhibition component of a larger project exploring the impact of alternative art spaces on the Bay Area during the last 50 years. The project will be developed with curators, artists, and historians from artist-run visual art spaces. The exhibition will feature works that were created and presented outside the traditional museum and gallery experience from the 1960s to the present.
To support the Arts Access Program. The program offers venue access and technical services, at minimal cost, to six local arts organizations.
To support the Arts Access Program. The program provides venue access and technical services at minimal cost to local arts organizations.

To support phase one of the San Francisco Mural Archive at the San Francisco Public Library. The project will result in an image and text electronic database of the murals created in the Bay Area from 1900 to the present and will be accessible on CD-ROM.

To support a group exhibition featuring visual arts, a publication, and a series of public events exploring race, addiction, gender, and identity. Artists will receive stipends and assistance with installations for sculptural and performance works. Additional programming such as poetry readings, performances, and artist-led conversations will be developed in partnership with local cultural and community organizations.

To support a group exhibition and a series of public programs. The project will revisit historic narratives of the Middle East and Eastern Asia through the lens of contemporary women artists from these areas of the world. In addition to the exhibition of art work, the project includes a variety of public programs that will allow the artists to tell their own stories, in an attempt to demystify the unfamiliar and address bias, stereotyping, and religious discrimination.

To support the commissioning of new work by emerging artists for gallery exhibitions and a public art project. Participants, selected by a rotating curatorial committee, will receive conceptual, logistical, and administrative support, a stipend, and a materials budget to develop their work.

To support the commissioning of new work by emerging artists for gallery exhibitions and public art projects. This year-long project will include group exhibitions, public art projects, and additional events and performances highlighting the contemporary art practice of emerging Bay Area artists and art writers. A rotating curatorial committee will select the artists. Participating artists will receive conceptual, logistical, and administrative support to develop their work; a stipend and materials budget; and published essays.

To support the presentation of an exhibition series and related events in celebration of the organization's 40th anniversary. The year-long project will include group exhibitions, public art projects, and additional events and performances highlighting the contemporary art practice of emerging Bay Area artists. Artists will receive conceptual, logistical, and administrative support in the creation of new work.

To support the commissioning of new work by emerging artists for gallery exhibitions and public art projects. Artists selected by a rotating curatorial committee will receive conceptual, logistical, and administrative support to develop their work; a stipend and materials budget; a two-week installation residency; and a publication with a critical essay.

To support intensive visual arts education projects for San Francisco area teenagers in consortium with the Jewish Vocational and Career Counseling Services. In partnership with the Jewish Vocational and Career Counseling Service, Southern Exposure will have youth work alongside teaching artists to produce three major projects and exhibitions to be presented in the Southern Exposure Gallery.

To support the commissioning and presentation of new work by emerging artists for gallery exhibitions and public art projects. Artists selected by a rotating curatorial committee will receive conceptual, logistical, and administrative support to develop their work.

To support the commissioning of new work by emerging artists for gallery exhibitions and public art projects. Artists will be selected by a rotating curatorial committee of artists and staff through an open submissions process for a series of solo and group exhibitions and public arts installations.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support intensive visual arts education projects for San Francisco area teensagers in consortium with the Jewish Vocational and Career Counseling Services. Youth will work alongside teaching artists to produce three major projects and exhibitions to be presented in the Southern Exposure Gallery.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support "Mission Voices" in consortium with the Jewish Vocational and Career Counseling Service. The project will focus on arts-based community development by pairing local artists with underserved teens in the San Francisco area.

To support SoEx Off-Site. The project will feature new art work by local and international artists in various locations around the San Francisco Bay Area that invites public interaction outside of the gallery.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Mission Voices, a visual arts education program in consortium with the Boys and Girls Clubs of San Francisco. The community-based project will pair local artists with underserved teens living in the city's Mission District at the Columbia Park Boys and Girls Club.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Mission Voices, an intensive summer and after-school program of visual arts workshops for underserved teens, provided in consortium with The Boys  Girls Clubs of San Francisco. The project will focus on arts-based community development by pairing local artists with teens at the Columbia Park Boys and Girls Club.

To support The New Situationists. The project will feature new work by local and international artists in various locations around the San Francisco Bay area and will address the role of art in society through the exploration and mapping of public space.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support "Mission Voices," a consortium project with the Boys  Girls Clubs of San Francisco, Columbia Park Clubhouse that will focus on arts-based community development by pairing local artists with teens from participating youth organizations.

Organization Name: SPUR-San Francisco Bay Area Planning and Urban Research Association
Project Description: To support "Sound in the City," an exhibition exploring the role of urban sounds in shaping our experience of the city. The exhibition will showcase interactive and participatory commissioned projects from artists, urban designers, musicians, and scholars that will explore and map the soundscapes of different sites around the San Francisco Bay Area.

Organization Name: SPUR-San Francisco Bay Area Planning and Urban Research Association
Project Description: To support Grand Reductions: Ten Diagrams that Shaped the City. An exhibition, publication, and public programming series will feature simple diagrams that demonstrate the power of visual communication in conveying urban ideas and impact.

Organization Name: SPUR-San Francisco Bay Area Planning and Urban Research Association
Project Description: To support the development of a community plan for redesigning Stockton Street, a San Francisco Chinatown Main Street. Working with the Chinatown Community Development Center the partners will re-imagine a 10-block stretch of Stockton Street that will result in a plan that includes transportation, placemaking, and economic development goals while maintaining the corridor's vibrancy.

Purpose: To support the Stanford Jazz Festival concert series. Additional Project Description: The 50th anniversary summer festival on the Stanford University campus will include ticketed and free performances, jam sessions, and showcases featuring more than 150 emerging and renowned jazz artists, including NEA Jazz Masters, Stanford Jazz Workshop (SJW) alumni, and the SJW 50/50 Jazz Orchestra, a big band with equal numbers of men and women. Accompanying activities will include pre-concert talks and free public educational events. The Giant Steps Day Camp, Jazz Camp, and Jazz Institute for more than 800 students from ages 12 through adults will take place concurrently and participants may attend festival concerts at no charge. Intended Beneficiaries: The concert series will benefit San Francisco Bay Area audiences, including jazz fans of all ages and jazz camp students. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support Stanford Jazz Workshop Jazz Camp Online educational programming. Participating students will receive instruction through daily online lessons taught by musicians and educators associated with the annual Stanford Jazz Workshop. The camp will also offer master classes, private lessons, and panel discussions, as well as daily live sessions on topics such as technique, theory, ear training and performance.

To support artist fees for the Stanford Jazz Festival. Festival performances will reflect of the diversity of today's jazz scene, and will take place throughout the summer on the Stanford University campus. It will take place concurrently with the Stanford Giant Steps Jazz Camp for middle school students and the Jazz Institute for high school students and adults.

To support the Middle School and High School Jazz Initiative, including Giant Steps Day Camp, Miles Ahead, and Giant Steps Big Band ensemble. This jazz education program enables middle school students to interact with master jazz educators and artists through year-round, weekly after-school instrumental music instruction. The middle school programs all share the program name "Giant Steps" not only to indicate the progress the students make as a result of participating, but also to refer to the jazz composition "Giant Steps" by John Coltrane. Giant Steps program directors and faculty are selected for their extensive experience and recognized success teaching jazz at the middle school level. Taught at local host school sites and on the Stanford University campus, students follow a personalized curriculum that includes improvisation, jazz styles, ear training, technique, and playing in small and large ensembles.

To support the Middle School and High School Jazz Initiative, including Giant Steps Day Camp, Giant Steps Big Band ensemble and Miles Ahead. This jazz education program enables middle school students to interact with master jazz educators and artists through year-round, weekly after-school instrumental music instruction. Taught at local host school sites and during jazz immersion camps in the summer on the Stanford University campus, students follow a personalized curriculum that includes improvisation, jazz styles, ear training, technique, and playing in small and large ensembles. The program culminates in a final public performance at the end of each academic semester and at the end of each week of jazz immersion camp.

To support summer jazz education programs for teens, including Jazz Day Camp, Jazz Camp, and Jazz Institute. Students will study one-on-one with master jazz performers and educators, following a curriculum of ear training, improvisation, and small ensembles. Students will receive as many as 65 hours of jazz instruction, playing, and listening, with an average student-to-teacher ratio of 7 to 1. Students will be introduced to the Blues by performers such as Keb' Mo' and Charlie Musselwhite, and study one-on-one with NEA Jazz Masters such as Kenny Barron and Sheila Jordan. Students also will attend nightly Stanford Jazz Festival concerts for free. The program will culminate in public performances.

To support the 2013 Stanford Jazz Workshop: Jazz Camp and Jazz Residency. Students will study with professional jazz educators and musicians, with a focus on ear training, improvisation, and playing in small ensembles.

To support the 2012 Jazz Camp and Jazz Residency Programs. Students will study with professional jazz educators and musicians, with a focus on ear training, improvisation, and playing in small ensembles.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the 2011 Jazz Camp and Residency Programs. On Stanford University's campus, students will study with professional jazz educators and musicians, with a focus on ear training, improvisation, and playing in small ensembles.

To support the 2010 Stanford Jazz Festival. Programming will feature faculty and master teachers, emerging jazz artists, free events such as noontime jazz concerts and nightly jam sessions, and performances by students participating in the Jazz Camp and Jazz Residency Programs.

To support the 2009 Stanford Jazz Festival. The programming will feature faculty and master teachers, emerging jazz artists, and free events such as outdoor concerts, informal jam sessions, and performances by students participating in the concurrently running jazz camp and jazz residency program.

To support the 2008 Stanford Jazz Festival. The programming will feature faculty and master teachers, emerging jazz artists, and free events such as outdoor concerts, informal jam sessions, and performances by students participating in the concurrently running jazz camp and jazz residency program.

To support the 2007 Stanford Jazz Festival. The programming will feature Lee Konitz, Eddie Gomez, Wycliffe Gordon, emerging jazz artists, and free events such as outdoor concerts, informal jam sessions, and performances by students participating in the concurrently running jazz camp and jazz residency program.
To support the Jazz Mentors teacher internship and professional development program. Instructors will train young jazz musicians to serve as junior faculty members at the annual Stanford Jazz Camp.
To support the annual Stanford Jazz Festival. The festival will feature artists such as Regina Carter, Slide Hampton, Toshiko Akiyoshi, and Branford Marsalis.

To support the Stanford Jazz Workshop's jazz residency program, an intensive professional development program for emerging and established jazz musicians. The project will include artists such as Gene Bertoncini, Jimmy Cobb, Ray Drummond, and Branford Marsalis serving as performers and faculty members.
To support the 2003 Stanford Jazz Festival. The summer festival will feature such artists as Phil Woods, Harold Mabern, Geri Allen, and Branford Marsalis.
To support the continuation of "Jazz Camp." This two-week summer program uses a customized jazz curriculum, which is based on each participant's abilities and interests.
To support the commission and presentation of a new work by composer Sam Rivers. The composition will be scored for a 17-piece jazz orchestra and premiered at the 2001 Stanford Jazz Festival.

To support a composer-in-residence collaboration between composer Muhal Richard Abrams and Peter Apfelbaum with his Hieroglyphics Ensemble, culminating in the premiere performance of their new work at the Stanford Jazz Workshop's 1999 annual summer Jazz Festival.

To support the annual Bay Area Tap Festival and Santa Fe Tap Festival. Activities associated with the festivals will include workshops, mainstage performances, tap jams, and panel discussions as well as other events.
To support the annual Bay Area Tap Festival and the new Santa Fe Tap Festival. The festival includes workshops, mainstage performances, a tap jam, a panel discussion, and other activities.
To support the sixth annual Bay Area Tap Festival. The festival includes workshops, mainstage performances, a tap jam, a panel discussion, and other activities.

Purpose: To support artist fees for selected performances at the Stern Grove Festival. Additional Project Description: The festival will feature free outdoor performances by the San Francisco Symphony and blues singer and multi-instrumentalist Taj Mahal. Engagement activities will include hands-on workshops for youth. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve residents and visitors of the San Francisco Bay Area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support artist fees for selected performances at the Stern Grove Festival. The festival will feature free outdoor performances by artists including the San Francisco Symphony and vocalist Ledisi. Engagement activities will include hands-on workshops for youth, as well as pre-show arts activities and discussions.

To support artist fees for the virtual Stern Grove Festival. The festival includes the online Best of the Fest series, culminating with a season finale production featuring Los Lobos, Michael Franti, and other performances.

To support artist fees for select performances at the Stern Grove Festival. The festival will feature free outdoor performances by the San Francisco Symphony, the San Francisco Ballet, and musical ensemble Pink Martini. Engagement activities will include hands-on workshops and camps for youth, as well as pre-show arts activities and discussions.

To support the Stern Grove Festival. The festival will feature free outdoor performances by artists including the San Francisco Symphony and the San Francisco Ballet, as well as world music, pop, and jazz artists. Additionally, local artists from various disciplines will be commissioned to create and perform works. Engagement activities will include hands-on workshops and camps for youth, as well as pre-show arts activities and discussions.

To support the Stern Grove Festival. The festival will feature free outdoor performances by artists including the San Francisco Symphony and the San Francisco Ballet, as well as world music, pop, and jazz artists. Local artists from various disciplines will be commissioned to create and perform works. Engagement activities will include hands-on workshops and camps for youth, as well as pre-show arts activities and discussions.

To support artist fees and related costs for the 2016 Stern Grove Festival. The festival will feature free outdoor performances by artists including the San Francisco Symphony and the San Francisco Ballet, as well as world music, pop, and jazz artists. Engagement activities will include hands-on workshops and camps for youth, as well as pre-show arts activities and discussions.

To support the Stern Grove Festival. The festival will feature free outdoor performances, as well as education and outreach programs. Programming will include performances by the San Francisco Symphony and the San Francisco Ballet, as well as world music, pop, and jazz artists.
To support the Stern Grove Festival. The festival will feature free outdoor performances as well as education and outreach programs.

To support a series of admission-free outdoor concerts. Performances will include concerts by the San Francisco Symphony, San Francisco Opera, and San Francisco Ballet. An audience of approximately 105,000 people will attend the events.
To support a series of free, outdoor music and dance performances. Artists will be presented on Sundays from June through August at the Sigmund Stern Grove amphitheater.
To support a series of free, outdoor music and dance performances. Artists will be presented on Sundays from June through August at the Sigmund Stern Grove amphitheater.
To support a series of free, outdoor music and dance performances. Artists will be presented on Sundays from June through August at the Sigmund Stern Grove amphitheater.
To support a series of free, outdoor music and dance performances. Artists will be presented on Sundays from June through August at the Sigmund Stern Grove amphitheater.
To support a series of free outdoor music and dance performances. Artists will be presented on Sundays from June through August at the Sigmund Stern Grove amphitheater.
To support the "New Audiences Program," a series of performances designed to reach underserved ethnic groups.
To support the New Audiences Program. The project is a series of performances designed to reach underserved ethnic groups
To support the New Audience Program performance series and related educational activities. The project is a series of performances designed to reach underserved ethnic groups.

To support the Asian American and Pacific Islander Initiative. This project will consist of a mainstage concert featuring contemporary and traditional Hawaiian music and dance, and education programs for children and adults.

To support the Media Arts Storytelling Project. Through mobile media labs, youth will create autobiographical media projects while developing skills in technology, arts, and literacy. Streetside will utilize mobile iPad labs to ensure media arts access at partner sites, including public schools, community centers, and public housing sites. An online gallery will be created to showcase student work.

To support the Media Arts Storytelling Project. Through mobile media labs, underserved youth will create autobiographical media projects while developing skills in technology, arts, and literacy. A digital anthology will be created and distributed to showcase student work.

To support the Media+Arts+Story Project, a media arts education program for underserved teens. Through mobile media labs, youth will create autobiographical media projects while developing skills in technology, arts, and reading.

To support Growing Up With the Arts Project. Workshops with sequential, engaging art programs in reading, writing, and expressing stories dramatically or through digital photography will be offered to Kindergarten to 12th grade students during school hours and after school.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support "Streetside Community Programs," a literary and media arts program for youth. Teaching artists will teach students to write and revise stories that develop character, setting, and dialogue and read them in public, or use drawings, photography, audio, video, and music to develop short recorded stories.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Bay Area Youth Story Project. Workshops for middle school students providing instruction in the composition of autobiographical narratives, theater performance, and storytelling will culminate in a published anthology of the students' work.

To support the development of "Storytelling Exchange," literacy workshops for sixth grade students using autobiographical narratives, theater, and storytelling. Streetside Stories's staff and facilitator will lead the workshops, which will culminate in a published anthology of the students' works.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Purpose: To support a creative writing fellowship Additional Project Description: This Fellowship will support activities that contribute to the creative development and artistic growth, including writing, research, and travel of the recipient. Intended Beneficiaries: This fellowship will benefit the recipient. Intended Outcomes: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support infrastructure building programs for arts organizations in Chicago and New York. Teams of business experts will advise a number of arts organizations on marketing, IT, strategy management, and leadership development.

To support expansion of photography programming for artists who are homeless. The project is managed by the Sixth Street Photography Workshop for residents of single-room occupancy hotels throughout San Francisco.
To support production, installation, touring, and a catalogue for Stories of the City. The photography exhibit will feature the work of artists who are homeless.

Purpose: To support a residency and commissioning program. Additional Project Description: Interdisciplinary artist Carrie Hott will investigate the digital infrastructure and literacy of artists and arts organizations. Musician, multimedia artist, and producer Arto Lindsay will produce and stage a multidisciplinary, artist-led parade in San Francisco. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit Bay Area audiences, as well as the participating artists. Intended Outcome: Arts leaders develop professional skills and strategies.

Purpose: To support a residency and commissioning program. Additional Project Description: Poet Tongo Eisen-Martin will complete the work of Black Freighter Press by publishing six books, highlighting the voices of poets who are people of color, black women, or incarcerated. Researcher and artist Carrie Hott will experiment with The Lab's digital infrastructure and use it to build understanding of online environmental sustainability and ADA (Americans with Disabilities Act) accessibility. Multidisciplinary artist Indira Allegra will present an in-person and broadcast performance exploring indecision. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit Bay Area audiences, as well as women, BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color), and LGBTQ artists. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support professional artists fees and related costs for Inside of Inside, a collaborative exhibition of works by women artists exploring the concept of home. To support professional artists fees for Inside of Inside, a collaborative exhibition of over 100 works by women artists exploring the concept of home.

To support the consortium project Wunderkabinet, a large-scale interdisciplinary musical production and gallery installation. The work will be developed by composer and sound artist Pamela Z and media artists Jeanne Finley and John Muse.

To support the organization and dissemination of archive material documenting The LAB's 20-year history of contemporary arts programming. The LAB, located in San Francisco's Mission District, has presented hundreds of artists over the years whose work crossed the disciplinary boundaries of visual, performing, and literary art.

To support a residency, community programming, and exhibition by the collaborative artist team, London Fieldworks (Bruce Gilchrist, and Jo Joelson), a consortium project. The artists, through an investigation into the effects of polarized light on perception, seek to illuminate the intersections of art, science, and technology, interpreting and making them more comprehensible for the general public.

To support an international exchange of artists from London and San Francisco. Artists from each city will exhibit their work in various venues in both London and San Francisco during the summer and fall of 2000.

To support a comprehensive planning process. The project will entail a complete organizational assessment, the development of a strategic five-year plan, and a feasibility study for the purchase of its facility.

To support a residency and exhibition at the LAB of Rebeca Bollinger, a Bay Area conceptual visual artist who works with new technologies. Bollinger's current work addresses telecommunications and how the World Wide Web has transformed our ideas about place and identity. Her work is interdisciplinary and begins with a search for source material and found information from the Web. Bollinger compares her process to an archeological dig, where information, images, and text are excavated from the ephemeral spaces of the Web and then reimaged to create her work. For this project, Bollinger proposes an installation called "Home," which refers to suburban sprawl. As a Bay Area artist, Bollinger witnessed such sprawl first-hand, created by the expansion of Silicon Valley as the Internet and subsequent technology-related industries flourished. Her project will involve a visual environment inside the LAB's gallery and a World Wide Web site. The exhibition will recreate a model home tour where viewers will be able to "walk-through" the work both on-line and in the gallery. Viewers will negotiate the space as they would a model home tour. Bollinger will receive a two-month residency prior to the exhibition and will present public workshops.

Purpose: To support the Arts Leadership Residency. Additional Project Description: A professional development program for freelance directors and emerging producers, the residencies are designed for mid-career professionals to transition to senior leadership careers at nonprofit theater companies. During the residency, participants will engage in activities and events that will develop their skill sets (such as theater directing or theater producing), forge professional relationships, and showcase their work to the broader field. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve the participating professionals, while the nationwide theater field will benefit from professionally trained participants entering the field. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support a residency program for directors and producers. A professional development program for freelance directors and emerging producers, the residencies are designed for mid-career professionals to transition to senior leadership careers at nonprofit theater companies. During the residency, participants will engage in activities and events that will develop their skill sets (such as theater directing or theater producing), forge professional relationships, and showcase their work to the broader field. Project activities may take place virtually as necessary.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
To support a residency program for directors in the Bay Area. The program is designed to provide training for directors who aspire to become artistic directors of nonprofit theater companies.

To support a new equity, diversity, and inclusion training program for Bay Area theaters facilitated by Carmen Morgan of artEquity, including convenings, workshops, and webinars. The organization will work with Carmen Morgan, a national consultant and the co-founder of artEquity, to design and lead a year-long intensive for staff members from a group of participating theaters, as well as Theatre Bay Area staff. In-person convenings will be held in various Bay Area locations, and program strategies will include peer learning sessions, skills and analysis building sessions, and resource sharing. The project will increase capacity among participating theaters for EDI work; create theater-specific tools, resources and best practices to support ongoing regional EDI initiatives; and increase the number of theaters engaged in advancing equity, diversity, and inclusion in the arts.

To support a Theater Leadership Training Program. Intensive training in theater management will be offered to staff members and board leadership of small and mid-sized theater companies. The training will be theater-specific and practical, designed to enhance the skills of artists in administrative positions who lack formal training in organizational development and management. Training for theater board leaders will focus on nonprofit governance within the specific context of the theater field. Curriculum offerings will be structured as short courses for individuals covering skills-based topics, and longer courses for cohorts of participants for in-depth, project-based learning.

To support the second phase of Triple Play, an initiative designed to increase audiences for new plays by engaging playwrights, audience members, and theater staff in dialogue. Conducted in partnership with Theatre Development Fund, this phase of the project will involve revision of the surveys used to collect data from audiences and theaters; expansion of the pool of participating playwrights, theaters, and audience members; and equipping of theater-makers nationwide with audience engagement strategies for new work. As part of the project, Theatre Bay Area will commission a writer to distill the findings from the project's first two phases into a flexible toolkit of engagement strategies that can be customized by theaters and artists to meet the needs of specific communities.

To support Intrinsic Impact 3.0. Expanding upon the project's original, national Intrinsic Impact study, this phase is designed to measure audiences' individual responses to theatrical work. Participating Bay Area theaters will survey their audiences and will be provided with a peer learning tool to help them understand the results and to determine actionable steps based on the findings.

To support ATLAS (Advanced Training Leading Artists to Success), a career development training program for theater artists. Professional training will be offered to actors, directors, and playwrights to assist them in realizing their career goals and a textbook will be created for use by arts service organizations, training institutions, and artists throughout the country.

To support the Leveraging Social Media program. The training program will help theaters in five cities across the US and national service organizations to better utilize social media tools to deepen their relationships with their constituents and build new audiences.

To support the next phase of Intrinsic Impact, a nationwide study that attempts to quantify and standardize the measurement of patron captivation at performing arts events in consortium with the Alliance of Resident Theatres (A.R.T./New York). The focus will be on development and dissemination of a suite of tools that will enable theaters to assess the intrinsic impact of their programming on audience members.

To support "Mission Accomplished," a program aimed at capacity building for small and mid-size theaters. The year-long project will provide learning opportunities for staff and artists in all departments of participating theaters, impart an intensive set of tools and processes to define the organizations' central goals, and identify benchmarks for excellence.
To support Theatre Bay Area Online Redesign with accompanying educational and outreach activities. Executive director Brad Erickson will oversee the initiative.
To support the development and implementation of "Intrinsic Impact: Measuring How Live Theatre Affects Emotional, Intellectual and Spiritual Growth in Audiences" in consortium with A.R.T./New York.

To support the Theatre Bay Area Online Information Portal to serve as a central entertainment Web site for the theater going public. The new site will provide news, ticketing information, performance schedules, and audio/video content for the wealth of theatre offerings available in the area.
To support the Leadership Development Initiative. The project will offer an extensive array of services, programs, and resources to Bay Area arts leaders and future arts leaders.

To support an Audience Development Initiative designed to help Bay Area theater companies increase attendance and diversify audiences. Components will include improvements to existing audience development services and the pilot phases of new initiatives.

To support the "Mentoring Initiative" to improve organizational stability and the effectiveness of midsize theater companies. The project will create mentoring relationships between theaters in the Bay area.

To support components of a major upgrade to the Theatre Bay Area Web site. A members-only area will be added to increase professional communication among Bay Area artists and organizations, and the site will be assessed for accessibility issues.

To support the development and pilot phase of the "Mentoring Initiative." In order to expand the quality and visibility of the Bay Area theater community, this project will craft mentoring partnerships between emerging and established theater companies.

Organization Name: Theatre Flamenco of San Francisco, Inc.
Project Description: To support the premieres of "Siete Canciones Populares Espanolas" and "Sombras Flamencas." Captain from Castile is a full-length dance drama which incorporates both Spanish classical, regional and flamenco, and Mexican folkloric music and dance into a narrative format. Set in both Spain and Mexico during the Spanish Inquisition and the Conquest of Mexico, the story does not attempt to depict historical events but rather the personal struggles of the protagonists. The most innovative aspect of this project is its departure from the conventional concert or recital format employed in most contemporary folkloric and flamenco performance in which one number after another is presented in a random fashion.

To support the creation and performance a new work exploring the intersection of the Native American and Japanese-American immigrant experiences. The story will center on a Native American prison inmate and their Japanese-American therapist and will underscore similarities in spirituality, folklore, generational trauma, and historical experiences of Indigenous and immigrant cultures, as well as cultural and societal expectations.

To support the development and production of a theatrical event with dance and music elements around themes inspired by the process of fermentation. Exploring the potential of food to bring together diverse communities, the performance will take the form of a theater/dinner pop-up event. The development period, or "Fermentation Lab," will include educational outreach events and work-in-progress showings, reaching out to the local corporate community, prominent members of San Francisco's foodie culture, students, and scientists in the growing biotech industry, with both the food and the performance inspired by the many ways fermentation influences Japanese cuisine.

To support a regional tour of "Mystical Abyss," written by John O'Keefe, and directed by Yuriko Doi. The play is a multidisciplinary work inspired by Japanese and Iroquois creation myths that blends mythic storytelling, live music and dance, classic Noh theater, and contemporary animation. The tour will include a residency and series of performances presented by Cleo Parker Robinson Dance in Denver.

To support the premiere of "This Lingering Life," by Chiori Miyagawa, a play that retells stories from classic Japanese Noh plays in a contemporary style. Miyagawa will juxtapose traditional and modern dramatic forms, creating a distinctly Western contemporary play with the intensity of classical Japanese drama at its root.

To support the creation and production of "Emmett Till: A River." Developed by poet and composer Kevin Simmonds, and artist-in-residence Judy Halebsky, the piece will blend traditional Japanese theater forms with Western sensibility, and will feature poetry set to music, characters, a chorus, and an instrumental ensemble.

To support the creation and production of "Mystical Abyss," conceived and directed by Yuriko Doi and written by playwright John O'Keefe. Inspired by similarities between the Native American Iroquois creation myth and the Japanese Izanami (Goddess of Creation and Death) and Amaterasu (Sun Goddess) myths, the work will dramatize the need for connection and understanding across cultures through Native American storytelling, dance, and music with traditional Japanese Noh theater.

To support A MINOR CYCLE, a project consisting of original, experimental plays performed following the architecture of a traditional Japanese Noh Cycle theatrical events. The plays will draw inspiration from Western classics of children's literature including The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe (based on the The Chronicles of Narnia by C.S. Lewis), and The Steadfast Soldier by Hans Christian Anderson.
To support the creation and production of "The Iliad Project/Dogsbody." The work will be developed by director Dijana Milosevic and playwright Erik Ehn in collaboration with the Yugen ensemble.
To support the production of "The Cycle Plays." The production will include series of theater works developed by the company ensemble in collaboration with playwright and director Eric Ehn.
To support the multi-state tour of "Moon of the Scarlet Plums." The new theater work is adapted by playwright Erik Ehn and performed by the company's ensemble members in the Japanese Noh tradition.

To support the development and production of a play based on THE OLD MAN AND THE SEA by Ernest Hemingway. This theatrical adaptation will fuse the author's unique writing style with the structure and stylistic elements of Japanese Noh and Kyogen theater.

To support the development and presentation of a new theater work, "Noh Frankenstein." The piece will be adapted by playwright and director Erik Ehn and performed by the company's ensemble members using Japanese Noh theater forms and aesthetics.
To support the tour of a new theater piece. Theater of Yugen will tour AT THE HAWK'S WELL, a Noh Play recreated from the work by W. B. Yeats.
To support a new multidisciplinary production by Erik Ehn. Moon of the Scarlet Plums will blend Native American naturalism with Asian theater, visual arts, and dance.

To support expenses associated with the expansion of an arts education program targeted to inner city Asian American youth. The program will introduce the participants to a variety of traditional Asian theatrical forms and offer special performances, study guides, and post-performance discussions.

To support the tour of Kyogen comic plays in English and a Noh adaptation of W. B. Yeats' "Purgatory" Theatre of Yugen is seeking support for its East Coast tour of "Blood Wine, Blood Wedding," a large-scale fusion work that draws from traditional Kabuki and flamenco theater forms and fuses them to contemporary American theater and dance. The work will tour to Pittsburgh, PA, Baltimore, MD, and New York, NY. This experimental fusion piece, structurally inspired by Garcia Lorca's "Blood Wedding" and Chikamatsu Monzaemon's "Love Suicides at Sonezaki" tells the story of two lovers, one Spanish and one Japanese, in 1930's California. The work examines America's recurring societal problems of class conflict and racism, and highlights these contemporary issues against the facade of a documented event in history.

Purpose: To support the world premiere production of The Pride of Lions by Roger Q. Mason. Additional Project Description: Based on historical events, the play explores the plight of queer and transgender people in the U.S. legal system during the 1920s, a time where living one's life authentically and openly was a criminal act. The theater will engage audiences in discussions about the themes in the play including the treatment of minorities by the police, gay police officers, gender and sexual identity in the early 20th century, and the evolution of these themes in the 21st century. Intended Beneficiaries: The production will serve artists and the residents of San Francisco, while the nationwide theater field will benefit from the creation of new work. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.
To support the production of a play. "Women Behind Bars" by playwright Tom Eyen will be presented during the 2002 season.

To support the development and production of a new play. Theatre Rhinoceros will produce a work inspired by the stories from "Last Rights," Marvin K. White's acclaimed collection of poetry about being black and gay.

To support the development and presentation of a new play and expenses associated with a playwriting workshop. Playwright Ricardo Bracho's new play Fed-Up: A Cannibal's Own Story will be developed and produced in February 1999 in addition to his leading a 12-week playwriting workshop for young men and women of color.
To support the presentation of the American premiere of THE SOLITARY, an original Arabic-language production created by Al-Khareef Theatre Troupe.
To support the creation of a new play development project. The New AmericanDramaturgy Project will formalize the commissioning and development of new works.

Popular Name: aka Out of Site Youth Arts Center
Project Description: To support Visual Arts/Language Arts' guest artists program and a teacher and artist training seminar. The project will sustain and expand a guest artists program, extend teacher/artist training in creative writing and visual arts, and foster long-term partnerships among schools, artists, and arts organizations.

To support a series of outdoor public art installations about water stewardship in locations throughout Cleveland, Ohio. In partnership with the Northeast Ohio Regional Sewer District and LAND Studio, the program will invite artists and residents into a participatory design process. Community-designed public art installations will explore Cleveland's environmental history as related to Lake Erie and the Cuyahoga River. Installations will assist in long-term stewardship efforts and provide water infrastructure education opportunities for residents.

To support community engagement activities and the creation of public art installations for Chiloquin Elementary School in Chiloquin, Oregon. Local artists will collaborate with the community to develop public art installations for the 8.5-acre school campus, which is within walking distance for 98% of Chiloquin residents and has the potential to serve as a park and gathering space for the community. A partnership with the Klamath Tribes, the school district, and community organizations, the project will elevate cultural assets, Native languages, and encourage communal gathering as a way to unite and heal the rural community.

To support community engagement, training workshops, and the shaping of park equity policy in Camden, New Jersey. This project will inform the city's first city-wide Master Plan and also help to inform policy which mandates the inclusion of green infrastructure and nature-based solutions into capital projects, especially in schools and recreation centers.

To support the development of a creative placemaking toolkit for city and county health agencies, a Knowledge Building project. Trust for Public Land, in partnership with National Association of County and City Health Officials (NACCHO), will focus on how the design of physical environmentssuch as parks and public spacescan influence a community's health. Partners will conduct research and gather best practices on arts and cultural strategies that improve public health, particularly in low-income communities. The project will culminate in a convening of public health and arts leaders at the 2019 NACCHO Annual Meeting to develop a toolkit that provides practical guidance on creative placemaking strategies that advance public health concerns. The toolkit will be disseminated to NACCHO's extensive network of 3,000 local health departments across the country.

To support a national study that examines how parks are integrating the arts as strategies to strengthen communities. The study design will include several research methods, such as a literature review on public arts, parks, and community development; a geographically and socially diverse survey of parks and parks-producing organizations; and interviews with arts-in-parks practitioners. The survey and interviews will capture descriptions of arts/parks projects; reasons for integrating the arts in parks and parks development; and the perceived impacts and challenges of those efforts. In addition to yielding results for parks, arts and community-development organizations, civic leaders, and community residents, the study would buttress future quasi-experimental research on the topic.

To support a resident-driven creative placemaking process for Kiwanis Methow Park in Wenatchee, Washington. The project features workshops that include the community in the design of public art elements and arts programming of this 1.2-acre park and central community gathering space. Trust for Public Land will partner with the City of Wenatchee throughout this process. The goal is to use the arts as a vehicle to advance the shared mission of all 33,000 residents including local farmers, healthcare organizations, and community development stakeholders.

To support PARKXCHANGE city workshops and the creation and dissemination of a report examining creative placemaking projects in parks, a Knowledge Building project. The Trust for Public Land (TPL) will partner with the City Parks Alliance to continue building creative placemaking knowledge among park development professionals by piloting a technical assistance program. The collaborators will convene workshops with parks and creative placemaking stakeholders in two pilot cities. Best practices will be documented and disseminated to the City Parks Alliance's network, which includes thousands of civic and community leaders, city officials, funders, and parks and recreation authorities.

To support creative placemaking activities in Story Mill Community Park in Bozeman, Montana. Project activities support the community engagement process necessary to produce designs and create public art components for the park. The Trust for Public Land is partnering with the City of Bozeman to lead the park design, master plan development, and construction process. This project will benefit the residents of Bozeman, as it will provide an opportunity for neighborhood leadership to collaborate with public and private partners, capitalizing on community assets and identity through engaging culturally diverse youth to provide a safe space to share stories, which then will be translated into public art for the park.

To support the design of Lynnbrook Park in Chattanooga, Tennessee. Trust for Public Land will partner with Public Art Chattanooga, and local community groups to facilitate public workshops, select an artist/design team, oversee design work, and implement public art and/or arts programming. The transformation of this 1.4-acre vacant lot into a community park is a response to goals and needs articulated in a citizen-led planning process, Chattanooga's Neighborhood Assessment, and the city's Environmental Protection Agency Brownfields Assessment. The proposed park is accessible by a ten-minute walk to a diverse population of more than 2,550 Chattanooga residents.

To support the Nature of Community: Parks and Creative Placemaking colloquium and a Creative Placemaking in Parks field guide. The Trust for Public Land and City Parks Alliance will produce a dedicated colloquium to exchange creative placemaking strategies for public park spaces, facilitate peer-to-peer learning, and encourage dialogue among a diverse audience of parks and community leaders, landscape architects, arts and cultural not-for-profits, city leaders, and artists, curators, and art administrators.
