The outcomes and guidelines that will emerge from the colloquium will be incorporated into the field guide for parks administrators.

To support Parks for People-Colorado. Project activities for a park located in a historcially underserved, low-income metropolitan neighborhood will include identifying local artists through a comprehensive RFP process; building and refining relationships with community partners; utilizing a participatory design process that engages the community in the creative process; and preparation for installing the art. Parks for People-Colorado will contribute to the successful revitalization of this community by engaging the people who live there to create a sense of place.

To support the Railyard Park and Plaza Stewards program in Santa Fe, New Mexico. The program will offer educational workshops, tours, and community work days to maintain and conserve the Railyard Park and Plaza in Santa Fe, New Mexico.
To support activities that contribute to your creative development and artistic growth and may include writing, research, and travel.

Purpose: To support the development and presentation of a dance and storytelling work by dance company Sharp  Fine. Additional Project Description: Sharp  Fine, led by dancers Megan and Shannon Kurashige, will create an online series of short story-telling and movement works. The series will be based on community conversations and workshop sessions with Japanese and Asian-American Pacific Islander communities in San Francisco. Public performances will also take place. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances will benefit residents and visitors of San Francisco. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support an artist residency and public performances by composer and interdisciplinary artist Tomoko Momiyama. Momiyama will visit schools and senior centers to collect stories to use as inspiration for creating a series of performance events connecting historical and memorial sites in different parts of San Francisco. Japanese Koto player Shoko Hikage and artist Aisuke Kondo will join Momiyama to help complete the creation of the work and collaborate for public lecture/demonstrations.

To support "The Art of Wadaiko," a contemporary taiko (Japanese drumming) performance and workshop featuring taiko composer, musician, and author Eitetsu Hayashi and his Fu-un no Kai ensemble. In addition to a public performance, Hayashi will also lead a workshop for economically disadvantaged elementary school students.

To support the continued development and production of The Compton's Cafeteria Riot conceived by Mark Nassar and Katie Conry and related engagement activities. Inspired by the 1966 event that catalyzed LGBTQ+ activism in San Francisco, The Compton's Cafeteria Riot is both interactive site-specific theater and living history. The Tenderloin Museum's new production of the play will be performed in the Cova Hotel in the Tenderloin district, and the play will highlight an overlooked history of the neighborhood.

Organization Name: Voice of Witness, A Nonprofit Public Benefit Corporation
Project Description: Purpose: To support the development of an oral history title and associated public programming. Additional Project Description: The book will compile first-person stories of refugees who have settled in rural Appalachia. Planned programming around the book will include public conversations, workshops, and readings, and free lesson plans designed for high school students. Driven by the transformative power of the story, Voice of Witness develops its oral history titles using an approach that employs a novelistic level of detail and considers literary elements like voice and story arc. Intended Beneficiaries: Book-related programming will benefit readers from Appalachia as well as communities across the country. Intended Outcomes: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Organization Name: Voice of Witness, A Nonprofit Public Benefit Corporation
Project Description: To support the development of an oral history title. Voice of Witness plans to support a writing fellow in developing an oral history from Puerto Rico in the wake of Hurricane Maria. The organization will offer the fellow in-depth training in Voice of Witness's methodology and literary approach to oral history, as well as provide interview support and editorial feedback. Voice of Witness oral histories are rigorously fact-checked and meet a high literary standard, following the belief that a novelistic approach to writing is essential to engaging readers.

Organization Name: Voice of Witness, A Nonprofit Public Benefit Corporation
Project Description: To support the publication of, and related outreach for, an anthology of in-depth, oral history interviews with survivors of the earthquake in Haiti.

Organization Name: Voice of Witness, A Nonprofit Public Benefit Corporation
Project Description: To support the publication of - and related outreach for - new and recently published anthologies of in-depth, oral history interviews with survivors of human rights and social justice crises. Founded by author Dave Eggers and physician/human rights scholar Lola Vollen, the press will promote the following titles: "Invisible Hands: Narratives of Human Rights in the Global Economy;" "Throwing Stones: Narratives from Colombians Displaced by Violence;" "The Refugee Hotel;" and "High Rise Stories: Narratives from Chicago Public Housing."

Organization Name: Voice of Witness, A Nonprofit Public Benefit Corporation
Project Description: To support the publication and production of The Voice of Witness oral history book series. Acclaimed and emerging authors will conduct in-depth interviews with survivors of human rights and social justice crises and produce collections of novelistic, first-person narratives.

To support a year-long program of after-school production workshops for teenagers. Students learn to deconstruct and analyze popular media by way of creating and producing their own narrative stories.

Purpose: To support a collaborative performance project with BALAM Dance Theater. Additional Project Description: The cross-cultural music and dance project will explore folkloric themes of transformation from Balinese, Baroque, Spanish, and Chinese traditions. Programming will feature the premiere of a new work celebrating the Chinese Year of the Tiger. Concerts will be presented in the San Francisco Bay Area and recorded for inclusion in the organization's digital library on YouTube for free access internationally. The project also will include educational engagement in public schools and will feature a local youth dance group to participate in the performances. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve diverse audiences of all ages in the Bay Area, as well as online viewers. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support Musical Crossroads, an early music performance project. The project will explore the sounds of both Western and non-Western instruments from the 14th through 18th centuries from diverse regions such as Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Ireland, Scotland, and Slovenia. Founders and musicians/scholars Hanneke van Proosdij and David Tayler will curate the programming, which will feature artists including violinist Laura Risk, a specialist in Scottish and Quebecois fiddling, and kamancha (Azeri spike fiddle) player Imamyar Hasanov. Concerts will be presented in the Bay Area and will be augmented by performances and educational activities in local schools and colleges, with an online release of video from the concert via Voices of Music's digital library.
To support the translation from Spanish of Ricardo Piglia's novel "La Ciudad Ausente (The Absent City)."

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Composition Immersion Course. Over the five-week summer program, students train in musicianship, composition, receive individual tutoring, and interact with a Composer-in-Residence and an Ensemble-in-Residence.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Composition Immersion Course. A five-week summer music program for 9 to 18-year-old students will include daily classes in musicianship, composition, individual tutoring, and interaction with resident guest composers and musicians, leading to performances of original student compositions.
To support the Composition Immersion Course. Students will develop skills in musicianship, music composition, and improvisation.
To support an artist residency with a new music sextet. During the summer of 2002, the new music sextet Non Sequitur will be in residence for two weeks at the Walden School in Dublin, NH.

To support a residency with a new music ensemble at Walden School, a summer music school for young composers ages 9-18. During the summer of 2001, the sextet Non Sequitur will be in residence for two weeks at the School in Dublin, NH.
To support a production of "Caesar Maximus" in Golden Gate Park, an Imagine Your Parks project.

Purpose: To support staff salaries for Girls on the Mic, a free digital media arts training and mentorship program focused on girls and gender-diverse youth. Additional Project Description: Students from underserved communities will receive hands-on, project-based media arts and music production training in a professional studio environment. Arts instruction and presentations of student work will take place online and in-person. The project is designed to cultivate the next generation of women media arts and technology experts. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve students from the Oakland Unified School District, San Francisco Unified School District, and the San Jose Unified School District. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support teaching artists fees for Girls on the Mic, a free digital media arts training and mentorship program for girls and gender-diverse youth. Additional Project Description: Students from underserved communities will receive free, hands-on, project-based media arts and music production training in a professional studio environment. Arts instruction and presentations of student work will take place through virtual platforms and also in-person when possible. The project is designed to cultivate the next generation of women media arts and technology experts. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve students from the Oakland Unified School District, San Francisco Unified School District, and the San Jose Unified School District. Intended Outcomes: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organizations constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support teaching artist fees for the expansion of Girls on the Mic, a digital media arts training and mentorship program. Currently reaching students in the San Francisco Unified School District and the Oakland Unified School District, Women's Audio Mission will expand Girls on the Mic to the San Jose Unified School District. Students from underserved communities will receive free hands-on, project-based media arts and music production training in a professional studio environment. Arts instruction and presentations of student work will take place through virtual platforms and also in-person when possible. The project is designed to cultivate the next generation of women media arts and technology experts.

To support the expansion of Girls on the Mic, a digital media arts training and mentorship program. The project is designed to cultivate the next generation of women media arts and technology experts, and aims to expand to all underserved schools in the San Francisco and Oakland Unified School Districts. Students will receive free hands-on, project-based media arts and music production training in a professional studio environment. Participants will showcase their work at community venues, online, and via mobile devices. Some project activity may take place virtually.

Discipline / Field: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support personnel costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the expansion of Girls on the Mic, a digital media arts training and mentorship program. The project is designed to cultivate the next generation of women media arts and technology experts. Participants will receive free hands-on, project-based media arts and music production training in a professional studio environment. Students will showcase their work at community venues, online, and via mobile devices with friends and family.

To support the expansion of Girls on the Mic, a digital media training program designed to cultivate the next generation of women media arts and technology experts. Participants will create their own websites, podcasts, music projects, and other media arts projects that mirror professional activities such as creative coding. Students will showcase their work online and via mobile devices with friends and family. The project expansion to Oakland will allow additional students to participate in the program.

To support the expansion of Girls on the Mic, a digital media training program for girls. The project is a media arts education program for girls from underserved communities in the Bay Area. Project activities are designed to cultivate the next generation of women media arts and technology experts. Participants will create their own websites, podcasts, music projects, and other media arts projects that mirror professional activities such as creative coding. Students will showcase their work online and share via mobile devices with friends and family.

To support the expansion of Girls on the Mic: Digital Media Training for Girls. The project is a media arts education program for girls from underserved communities in the Bay Area. Project activities are designed to cultivate the next generation of women media arts and technology experts. Participants will create their own websites, podcasts, music projects, and other media arts projects that mirror professional activities such as creative coding. Students will showcase their work online and share via mobile devices with friends and family.

To support Girls on the Mic. The assessment tool is the required product. The project is a media arts education program for middle school girls which cultivates the next generation of women media arts and technology experts. Participants will learn media literacy and create their own podcasts, music projects, sound for cartoons, and other media arts projects that mirror professional activities and create websites to showcase their work online and share via mobile devices with friends and family.

To support Girls on the Mic. The project is a media arts education program which cultivates the next generation of women media arts and technology experts. Participating girls will learn media literacy and create their own podcasts, music projects, sound for cartoons, and other media arts projects that mirror professional activities and create websites to showcase their work online and share via mobile devices with friends and family.
To support Girls on the Mic. Targeted to girls aged 8-18, Girls on the Mic teaches them digital media production and music recording technology skills.

To support Composing A Career; a colloquium, advocacy campaign, and an annual music festival. The symposium will include Music in the Making, new music reading sessions that will showcase emerging American women composers.

To support "Music in the Making," a new music reading session. Held at the Yerba Buena Center for the Performing Arts in March 2002, the sessions will showcase American women composers in the early phases of their careers.
To support "Composing a Career," a composer symposium. The third Composer's Symposium will be held at Mills College in June 2002.

To support the broadcast and dissemination of the "American Women Masters Series," a compilation of defining compositions by women composers in the twentieth century. The Women's Philharmonic will identify, perform, and broadcast by radio key works by women composers.

To support the National Women Conductors Initiative, a consortium project. The Women's Philharmonic and consortium member Colorado Symphony Orchestra will provide women conductors who are at the most advanced career levels with opportunities to enhance their professional skills and earn positions as conductors and music directors with the leading national orchestras.

To support a consortium project of commissions and premier performances of the new works by the Women's Philharmonic, the American Composers Orchestra, and the Lubbock Symphony. Entitled "Fanfares," this two-year project will result in the creation of new works by American women composers and multiple performances around the country.
To support the restoration, performance, and recording of orchestral music of Florence B. Price (1888-1953). Florence Price was one of the first African-American women to write orchestral music.
To support the implementation of the Next Millennium project, a plan to strengthen the organization, including initiatives to increase earned income and to create a cash reserve.

Organization Name: Words Given Wings Literary Arts Project
Project Description: To support Mercury House's publication and national distribution of a culturally significant work of international literature. Mercury House will promote the title through trade publications, online, and through radio and television interviews.

Organization Name: Words Given Wings Literary Arts Project
Project Description: To support the republication and national distribution of Charles S. Wright's, THE WIG: A MIRROR IMAGE, with an introduction by Ishmael Reed. set in New York City in the 1950s, Night Song is one of the first works of fiction by a black author that depicts the world of black jazz musicians in America.

Organization Name: Words Given Wings Literary Arts Project
Project Description: To support the reprinting by Mercury House of IN FEW WORDS/EN POCAS PALABRAS: A COMPENDIUM OF LATINO FOLK WIT AND WISDOM by Jose Antonio Burciaga.

Purpose: To support the San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. Additional Project Description: Through mentorship, artistic development, and performance opportunities, the 45th annual festival will showcase and support an important and culturally diverse dance community. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival will serve dance artists, as well as a broad and diverse San Francisco audience, including fans of world dance and music. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support World Arts West Dances in the Park by the producer of the San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. Additional Project Description: Through mentorship, artistic development, and performance opportunities, the festival showcases and supports an important and culturally diverse dance community. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival will serve broad and diverse San Francisco audiences, including fans of world dance and music. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organizations constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support staff salaries for the virtual San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. Through mentorship, artistic development, and performance opportunities, the annual festival showcases and supports an important and culturally diverse dance community.

To support artist fees and staff and marketing costs associated with planning for the annual San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. Due to COVID-19, the festival which showcases and supports an important and culturally diverse dance community that encompasses many different dance traditions and forms, through mentorship and artistic development, and performance opportunities, had to be cancelled.

Discipline / Field: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support personnel costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the artistic direction and mentorship of dance companies as part of the annual San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. Festival Artistic Directors Patrick Makuakane, Latanya Tigner, and Mahea Uchiyama will select dance artists and companies whose work is rooted in a cultural tradition. The artistic directors will attend rehearsals of the selected festival artists and offer input and guidance, while also creating innovative transitions between dance pieces. The festival presents more than 30 world dance companies based in Northern California and provides artists with the opportunity to perform in a professional setting.

To support staff salaries for the annual San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. The festival will present world dance companies based in Northern California and provide underserved artists with the opportunity to perform in a professional setting. Artistic Directors Carlos Carvajal and CK Ladzekpo will attend rehearsals and offer input and guidance, while also creating innovative transitions between dance pieces.

To support staff salaries for the annual San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. The festival will present world dance companies based in Northern California and provide underserved artists with the opportunity to perform in a professional setting. Artistic Directors Carlos Carvajal and CK Ladzekpo will attend rehearsals and offer input and guidance, while also creating innovative transitions between dance pieces.

To support administration costs in presentation of the 38th annual San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. The festival provides underserved artists with the opportunity to perform in a professional setting. Artistic Directors Carlos Carvajal and CK Ladzekpo will attend dancers' rehearsals and offer input and guidance, while also creating innovative transitions between dance pieces. After a rigorous audition process, more than 30 Northern California dance ensembles, whose work is rooted in various cultural traditions, will be selected to perform at the festival.

To support artist fees and staff time related to the presentation of the annual San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. The festival supports thousands of dancers sustaining over 100 distinct dance forms by providing underserved artists with the opportunity to perform in a professional setting.

To support artists' fees for the 35th annual San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. The festival presents dancers sustaining more than 100 distinct dance forms by providing underserved artists with the opportunity to perform in a professional setting.

To support the 34th Annual San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. A panel of dance educators, performers, and ethnologists will select dance ensembles and solo artists, whose work is rooted in various cultural traditions, to perform at the festival. The project will present as many as 50 ensembles and solo artists, who will also receive professional advice about choreography, costuming, staging, professional marketing, and promotional material.

To support the annual "San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival" The project will present a series of performances of culturally specific dance traditions sustained by the diverse communities of Northern California; it will provide the artists with experience in a professional setting, and introduce the general public to the traditional dances of Northern California.

To support the "32nd Annual San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival." The project will support a series of performances celebrating traditional dance from the diverse ethnic communities living in Northern California.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support the educational program "People Like Me". Designed for kindergarten through sixth-grade students, the performances will be presented at California theaters in a one-hour session featuring traditional world dance and music genres in an interactive theatrical format.

To support the educational program People Like Me. Designed for kindergarten through sixth-grade students, the performances will be presented at California theater in a one-hour session featuring traditional world dance and music genres in an interactive theatrical format.
To support the arts education program People Like Me. Performances will be presented at Bay Area theaters for students in kindergarten through sixth grades.
To support the arts education program People Like Me. Performances will be presented at Bay Area theaters for students in kindergarten through sixth grades.
To support the arts education program People Like Me. Performances will be presented at Bay Area theaters for students in kindergarten through sixth grades.

To support fees for artists participating in the 2004 San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. Nine dance companies, representing African, Chinese, Hispanic, and Tahitian traditions, will perform for an expected audience of 3,000 during the festival weekend.

To support People Like Me. Through a unique educational performance of music and dance, the project will offer K-6 grade students the opportunity to experience and learn about the immense variety of dance that is rooted in the Bay Area's multicultural population.

To support People Like Me, a vernacular and world classical dance education project. The program offers Bay Area students in grades K-6 the opportunity to experience and learn about the immense variety of dance that is rooted in the Bay Area's multicultural population, performed by dancers from the San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival.
To support People Like Me a vernacular dance education project. Through a second expansion, People Like Me will go to San Jose for two additional weeks.

Purpose: To support a series of multidisciplinary arts programs at the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. Additional Project Description: The festival will present productions by performing artists, including works of music and dance that showcase local ensembles as well as touring artists. All performances will be free, outdoors, and open to the public. Programming will feature Native American art forms, a music and dance work by music and percussive ensemble La Mezcla, and ukulele and hula dance performances. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve Bay Area audiences and the featured artists. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support a series of multidisciplinary arts programs at the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. Additional Project Description: The festival will present productions by performing artists, including works of music and dance that showcase local ensembles as well as touring artists. All performances will be free, outdoors, and open to the public. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve Bay Area audiences. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support a series of multidisciplinary arts programs at the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. Activities will include Choreofest, a two-day festival of site-specific contemporary dance by Bay Area chorographers, and a performance of a new one-ring circus show by Circus Bella. All performances will be admission-free, outdoors, and open to the public.

To support performing arts presentations at the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival, as well as planning for future events. Selected artists will virtually share either a work in progress or a completed piece designed around the themes of endurance, hope, or community. Additionally, staff will work to plan for future performances.

To support performing arts presentations at the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. The free outdoor series will present performances by artists in disciplines including circus, dance, and music. Choreographers Wendy Rein and Ryan T. Smith will curate ChoreoFest, a three-day festival of site-specific dance by Bay Area contemporary dance choreographers. Circus Bella is a one-ring circus, including trapeze, rope walking, juggling, clowning, and acrobatics conceived by Abigail Munn and set to original music by composer Rob Reich. Oakland's Prescott Circus Theatre, a youth after-school program, will open the show. San Francisco Summer Uke-Splosion will showcase ukulele musicians from the region, and will include participatory events, workshops, and related hula performances.

To support selected activities at the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. The free outdoor series will include the presentation of new and existing works in a variety of disciplines. Activities supported by this grant include the Native Contemporary Arts Festival, as well as performances by Mariachi Flor de Toloache, composer Marcus Shelby, and Circus Bella. In addition to performances, lectures and demonstrations by festival artists will be offered.

To support artist fees and staff travel associated with the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. The free outdoor series will include the creation and presentation of new works by artists in circus arts, world music, dance, theater, and Latin jazz, among others. In addition to performances, lectures and demonstrations by festival artists will be offered in collaboration with community partners.

To support artist fees and travel costs for the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. The outdoor series will include world premiere presentations of new works and performances by artists in world music, dance, and Latin jazz, among others. The festival also will include partnerships with other local performing arts organizations.

To support activities as part of the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. Project activities will include a commission from composer Marcus Shelby, as well as the presentation of literary artists, free music concerts, and performances by theater and dance ensembles. The festival also will present engagement activities for the public.
To support the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. The festival will include free concerts and performing arts programs, cultural events, and engagement activities.

To support the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. This project will include nearly 80 live concerts and performing arts programs in a range of artistic genres and styles. An estimated 90,000 people are expected to attend.
To support the "Yerba Buena Gardens Festival." This project includes 80 concert and performing arts programs, plus new multidisciplinary commissions.

To support the "Yerba Buena Gardens Festival." The project will connect the diverse communities of the Bay Area in shared arts and cultural experiences presented by many local arts organizations, as well as national and international artists.
To support the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. The project will connect the diverse communities of the Bay Area in shared arts and cultural experiences presented by several local organizations.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.
To support the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. The project will connect the diverse communities of the Bay Area in shared arts and cultural experiences presented by several local organizations.
To support the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. The project will connect the diverse communities of the Bay Area in shared arts and cultural experiences presented by several local organizations.
To support the 2007 Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. The festival will connect the diverse communities of the Bay area in shared arts and cultural experiences presented by several local organizations.

To support music performances for the annual Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. Among the artists to be featured will be the San Francisco Symphony, San Francisco Opera, the Lamplighters, and San Francisco Lyric Opera.

To support Yerba Buena Dance Week at Yerba Buena Gardens. The project will include the Yerba Buena Choreographers Festival for local choreographers, a Butoh performance, and a performance by an American dance company.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support the presentation of work developed by YBCA Fellows. Fellows will participate in a year-long program during which they will investigate social issues and create new artistic works based on their selected themes. Fellows will receive artist fees, guidance from YBCAs curatorial team, and participate in monthly convenings. A series of public presentations will feature concerts, films, and multimedia presentations.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support planning costs for a collaborative public art project in San Francisco's Mission District. Artists Paz de la Calzada, Juan Carlos Rodriguez Rivera, and Jessalyn Aaland will be invited to work in a year-long residency with students from San Francisco's Mission High School. The residencies will be tied to the school's Wellness Initiative, allowing artists to engage with students, local residents, and community partners to create public art installations related to health and well-being.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Discipline / Field: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support personnel costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support a series of performing arts presentations. YBCA will present a performance by Dohee Lee, and a music-theater work by Rafael Casal. Artists may also participate in community-based workshops and engagement activities.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support The Oakland Projects and Retrospective with social practice artist Suzanne Lacy; the Requiem Mass with composer, singer, and performance artist Holcombe Waller; and related in-school youth media workshops and programs. Activities will include performances and exhibitions of works by highly regarded visual artists, composers, singers, and performers. YBCA will conduct in-school workshops with middle school students, who will create videos and performances in response to themes explored through the exhibitions.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support the development of an online civic communications platform and implementation of related community engagement programming, in partnership with Neighborland. The collaboration will focus on integrating the arts and technology to spur community participation and civic action leading to positive change in San Francisco and the Bay Area. A cohort of YBCA fellows will participate in a paid collective research opportunity investigating current social questions. Guided by YBCA and Neighborland, the fellows will hold quarterly cohort meetings, create project web pages on Neighborland.com, and establish a platform for ongoing online dialogue with the Bay Area community. Teams of fellows will develop community-driven art installations for public spaces, addressing particular social questions. They will curate vibrant community festivals, filling YBCA's indoor and outdoor spaces with creative multidisciplinary projects. Together, YBCA, Neighborland, and the YBCA fellows will use art and creativity to drive new possibilities in the public imagination, as well as find specific, creative, community-driven solutions to specific community problems.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support a series of exhibitions, performances, films, and public programs. The series will explore themes of shifting ecologies, water and food resources, and climate change. Artistic programming will include an exhibition of work by the Futurefarmers collective, a performance by Paul D. Miller, and a film series. Community engagement activities will include artist talks and workshops, as well as an arts-based curriculum for K-12 public school students centered on the environment and food justice.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support the Creative Ecosystem engagement program. YBCA will invite community leaders from diverse public sectors--academics, business, politics, technology, and social services--to convene at YBCA and participate in quarterly theme-based discussions. Participants will investigate themes of place and personal labor by attending, discussing, and engaging in artistic projects including an exhibition by sculptor Tom Sachs, dance works by choreographers Kim Epifano and Michelle Dorrance, and a festival of Filipino films.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support the Creative Ecosystem engagement program. The program will focus on four artists/events: a festival of films from the Philippines and performances by artists Kyle Abraham and Meklit Hadero. Yerba Buena Center for the Arts (YBCA) will invite community leaders from diverse public sectors - academics, business, politics, technology, and social service - to convene at YBCA and participate in quarterly theme-based discussions as part of their ecosystem cohorts. Cohort member will invite others from their community to join additional the next discussions and an annual cohort-produced Field of Inquiry community festival.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support the YBCA In Community and YBCA:YOU arts education and engagement programs. YBCA In Community will present a series of participatory arts experiences in non-traditional venues for underserved, intergenerational audiences. Participants will work with teaching artists to create multidisciplinary art works examining topics of personal and community relevance. Each participant of YBCA:YOU will work with a consultant to curate their own series of performances and engagement activities. The program will offer free enrollment to underserved low-income community members.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support "Big Ideas," a series of multidisciplinary performances, film screenings, and exhibitions. 2/12/15: per FDR, artists deleted...some participated, some did not. LL

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support Big Ideas, a series of multidisciplinary performances, film screenings, and exhibitions. The program of film, visual, and performance works will be presented and artists will include the Kronos Quartet, visual artists Nayland Blake and Shih Chieh Huang, and choreographer Maria Helena Pinto (Mozambique).

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support The Africa Contemporary Arts Consortium, an arts exchange between the U.S. and the African continent, in consortium with the Bates Dance Festival. Along with the other nine other leading performing arts presenters from around the U.S., the program will support internal networking and external programming.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support "Big Ideas," a series of multidisciplinary performances, film screenings, and exhibitions. The program of film, visual, and performance works will be presented in conjunction with curatorial themes, and artists will include photographer Ryan McGinley and sculptor Michael Arcega.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support "Big Ideas," a series of multidisciplinary performances, film screenings, and exhibitions. The programs of film, visual, and performance work will be presented in conjunction with curatorial themes that aim to contextualize the series.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support the African Contemporary Arts Consortium, in consortium with Bates College in Lewiston, Maine. The international exchange initiative is designed to create a new level of artistic collaboration between artists and arts organizations and develop cultural dialogue between the United States and African countries.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support Big Ideas, a series of multidisciplinary performances. The programs of film, visual, and performance work will be presented in conjunction with curatorial themes that aim to contextualize the series.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support the "African Consortium", in consortium with Mapp International Productions. The international exchange initiative is designed to create a new level of artistic collaboration between artists and arts organizations and develop cultural dialogue between the United States and African countries.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support Big Ideas, a series of multidisciplinary programs. The programs of film, visual, and performance work will be presented in conjunction with curatorial themes that aim to contextualize the series.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support "The African Contemporary Arts Consortium", in consortium with Bates College. The international initiative is designed to create a new level of artistic exchange between artists and arts organizations and develop cultural dialogue between the United States and African countries.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support a series of multidisciplinary projects. The programs of film, visual, and performance work will be presented in conjunction with curatorial themes that aim to contextualize the season's offerings.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support The Africa Contemporary Arts Consortium, a series of meetings, research trips, and exchanges in consortium with Bates College. The international initiative is designed to create a new level of artistic exchange and cultural dialogue between the United States and African countries.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support a visual arts exhibition, film festival, and artist performances presented as part of the "Risk and Response" project. The series of visual and performing arts educational and community programs will be centered on a theme that demonstrates how the arts have the power to overcome adversity.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support a series of meetings of the African Consortium in partnership with the Bates Dance Festival of Bates College. In partnership with Bates College, the national initiative is designed to create a new level of artistic exchange and cultural dialogue between the United States and African countries

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support artists residencies. Artists working in the visual, performing, and media arts will develop new work and engage in a variety of educational and community programs.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support residencies for artists of multiple disciplines. Artists in residence in the visual arts, performing arts, and media arts will develop new work and engage in a variety of education and community programs.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support residencies for artists of multiple disciplines. Artists in residence in the visual arts, performing arts, film, and video will be given the opportunity to develop new work, reformulate existing works, and engage in a variety of education and community programs.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Category: National Arts and Humanities Youth Program Awards
Project Description: In recognition of the Young Artists at Work program for linking accomplished artists to inner-city youth to encourage the creation of art, cultivate artistic literacy, and develop job and life-skills through a one-year paid training and residency program.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support residencies for artists of multiple disciplines. Artists-in-residence in the visual arts, performing arts, film, and video will be given the opportunity to develop new work, reformulate existing works, and engage in a variety of education and community programs.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support "Juvenilia", an arts and educational festival that will explore youth and culture through visual arts exhibitions, music performances, film and video productions, artists residencies, and an educational symposia. Planned for three months during 2000 and 2001, "Under 18", is designed to attract and involve the San Francisco youth and teen populations, their parents, and those who work with youth.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support Instrumentals, a project which explores the intersection of sculpture and music/sound composition. Activities include exhibitions, artist residencies, a film program, and extensive educational activities.

Organization Name: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support two exhibitions: "Labyrinth: A Day of the Dead Exhibition," based on the traditional Chicano ancestral tribute Day of the Dead (Dia de los Muertos), and "Mexcelente!: Hybridity and Travel in Art from Mexico City and Beyond," featuring contemporary artists from Mexico City. "Rooms for the Dead" will feature commissioned installations by 25 Bay Area artists from many cultural backgrounds who will create small works on themes arising naturally out of the holiday, such as mourning, respect for ancestors and traditions, and celebration of home and culture. The education department will host a day-long forum, bringing artists together to speak informally with the public about the evolving nature of this popular cultural holiday. "Migrant Artists and Migratory Ideas" will explore how the cultures of California and Mexico have merged in today's Internet age, showing contemporary work by younger artists of Mexico City. Through studio visits and the assistance of La Panaderia, an alternative art space in Mexico City, the curator selected six Mexican artists to participate. A bilingual catalogue will be produced to accompany the exhibition, with essays by the curator Rene de Guzman and Ruben Martinez, a noted Latino theorist on cross- border issues. Guzman, Martinez, and Ruben Ortiz Torres will organize a panel discussion and bilingual exhibition information on the Center's Web Site.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Arts and English Language Development residency program. School staff and artists will develop, implement, and assess arts learning in elementary schools.

To support the premiere of "Abraham in Flames" by composer Aleksandra Vrebalov and librettist Niloufar Talebi. The new 70-minute opera is inspired by the life and works of Nobel prize-nominated Iranian poet, writer, translator, essayist, and cultural figure Ahmad Shamlou. The title of one of Shamlou's seminal books, "Abraham in Flames" is a biblical metaphor for the purity of truth-seekers. Participants and audiences will experience a work that will enhance the role of choral music through movement and narrative, and will encourage performers and audiences to better appreciate the shared humanity between Western and Iranian cultures. The creative team will include director Roy Rallo, composer Aleksandra Vrebalov, and librettist Niloufar Talebi. In collaboration with singers from the Merola Opera program and instrumentalists from The Living Earth Show, performances at Z Space occur in summer 2019.

Purpose: To support a poetry festival. Additional Project Description: The Brave New Voices International Youth Poetry Festival will be held in San Francisco, with hybrid live and virtual programming convening youth poets from across the United States and around the world for activities such as workshops, poetry slams, showcases, and a concert. Intended Beneficiaries: The poetry festival will benefit youth poets and San Francisco area audiences. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the virtual Brave New Voices Festival. Youth Speaks will engage teen poets and spoken-word artists from around the country for the festival, which will be held in a virtual format. The festival will include the International Youth Poetry Slam, writing and performance workshops, and discussions. Professional development for emerging arts leaders, arts educators, and classroom teachers also will be offered.

To support the Brave New Voices Festival. Youth Speaks will work with the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts to host a virtual festival. Teen poets and spoken-word artists from around the country will participate online. The festival will include the International Youth Poetry Slam, writing and performance workshops, and discussions.

To support the Brave New Voices International Youth Poetry Slam Festival. The festival will include the International Youth Poetry Slam, writing and performance workshops, and discussions. Professional development for emerging arts leaders, arts educators, and classroom teachers also will be offered.

To support the Brave New Voices Festival, including the International Youth Poetry Slam, writing and performance workshops, and discussions. Support will be available for selected teen poets and spoken-word artists gathered from around the country for participation in the festival. Professional development for emerging arts leaders, arts educators, and classroom teachers also will be offered.

To support The Bigger Picture, a spoken word performance program presented in partnership with the University of California San Francisco Center for Vulnerable Populations. Through the program, youth poets will be trained to combine performance techniques with facts about the causes of Type 2 diabetes, while adult educators will learn how to use Youth Speaks' tools in the classroom. This project will situate young people at the center of the conversation around diabetes prevention, building awareness of the social and environmental causes of the disease which disproportionately affect young people of color.

To support the Brave New Voices Festival. The festival will include the International Youth Poetry Slam, writing and performance workshops, and town hall discussions. Youth Speaks will gather teen poets and spoken-word artists from around the country for the festival. The organization also plans to subsidize the housing, food, local travel, and festival costs for festival participants. Professional development for emerging arts leaders, arts educators, and classroom teachers also will be offered.

To support the Brave New Voices Festival. The festival will include the International Youth Poetry Slam, performances, writing and performance workshops, and town hall discussions. Youth Speaks will gather teen poets and spoken-word artists from around the country for the festival. The organization also plans to subsidize the housing, food, local travel, and festival costs for approximately 600 festival participants. Professional development for emerging arts leaders, arts educators, and classroom teachers also will be offered.

To support the Brave New Voices Festival. The festival will include the International Youth Poetry Slam, performances, writing and performance workshops, and town hall discussions. The event also will feature professional development for emerging arts leaders, arts educators, and classroom teachers. Youth Speaks will gather teen poets and spoken-word artists from around the country for the festival. The organization also plans to subsidize the housing, food, local travel, and festival costs for approximately 600 festival participants.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Youth Speaks Residency Program. Professional poet-mentors will work in and after-school to teach students poetry, creative writing, and spoken word performance, culminating in a variety of publications and public performance opportunities at festivals and poetry slams.
To support the Living Word Project's Artist in Residence Program. Activities planned aim to nurture the development of work by writers and performers, as well as to facilitate a mentoring process.

To support the creation and presentation of the dance-theater work Bopha. Collaborating artists will include choreographer Robert Moses, composer Ajayi Jackson, dancer Alseny Soumah (Guinea), director Marc Bamuthi Joseph, and writer Hodari B. Davis.

To support the 12th Annual Brave New Voices International Poetry Festival in Chicago in consortium with Young Chicago Authors. The festival programming will include performances, workshops, training for artists and educators, and community programs.
To support the Artist-in-Residence Program for emerging writers and performers. Artists will receive institutional support, including venues for previewing, creating, and premiering works.

To support a commissioned work, "War Peace: Homeland," in consortium with San Francisco Jazz. The spoken-word-musical theater work will reunite the American forms of jazz, tap, and poetry in the context of the 21st century.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Chapter ONE (Oral Narrative Experience). Urban youth in San Francisco and Oakland will participate in literary arts workshops, performances, and publication opportunities as part of the school day and after-school hours.

To support a project to commission new hip-hop works in consortium with the Hip-Hop Theater Festival. The new works will be created for presentation at the festivals in San Francisco and New York City.

To support the creation of a multidisciplinary work titled "The Breaks." The Living Word repertory company will collaborate with author Jeff Chang to create a work incorporating film, movement, and verse.

To support a consortium project for the creation of a collaborative work titled "Scourge." In partnership with the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, the work will be premiered at the Bay Area Hip Hop Theater Festival.

To support the development of an improved and expanded free afterschool literary arts workshop project and corresponding professional performance poetry series for inner-city teenagers. Designed as an after-school literary arts workshop, youth participate in mentor and teacher training, a reading series, and a corresponding professional performance poetry series.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel and facilities expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organizations constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nations cultural infrastructure.

To support the development of Shoshana in December with a book by Rose Oser, lyrics by Weston Scott, and music by Matthew Grandy. The musical centers on Shoshana, who wrestles with her own identity when she is invited to spend Christmas with the family of a new friend.

To support the development and production of The Red Shades, a new rock opera musical by Oakland-based writer Adrienne Price and composer Jeanine Adkisson. Inspired by historical groups of the early 1970s New York City, and activists who fought back against arrests in the Compton's Cafeteria Riots in San Francisco's Tenderloin district, The Red Shades tells the story of a group of trans superheroes.

To support the development and world premiere production of "A House Tour of the Infamous Porter Family Mansion with Tour Guide Weston Ludlow Londonderry" by Peter Sinn Nachtrieb. The play explores the secret pleasures people hide and the amusement people exhibit when revealing and shaming others.

To support a collaboration with composer/jazz musician Marcus Shelby and actor/director/singer Margo Hall to create "Miss Black World (Michigan)." The new musical performance piece, directed by Ellen Sebastian Chang, will explore the journey of a young black woman growing up in Detroit in the 60s, and will incorporate oratorio, original songs, chorals, instruments, storytelling, and movement.

To support Z Space Technical Development Residencies for local and national performing arts groups in consortium with Mixed Bag Productions. Z Space will make their new theater facility available to the selected groups: Living Word Project, LEVYdance, Big Art Group, and Mixed Bag Productions, and will cover all technical and production costs to enable the organizations to further develop their work.

To support the third phase of the Western Presenters' Commissioning Initiative in consortium with the Lensic Performing Arts Center. Z Space along with the Lensic will lead performing arts presenters in the commissioning, development, and touring of new theatrical works.

To support the second phase of the Western Presenters' Consortium Initiative in consortium with Lensic Performing Arts Center. Z Space will lead a group of performing arts presenters in the commissioning, development, and touring of new theatrical works.

To support the first phase of the Western Presenters' Commissioning Initiative in consortium with Stanford University's Lively Arts. The theater will partner with performing arts presenters to commission the development of theatrical works to tour among the partners.

To support a pilot New Works Initiative consortium project that will test a multi-institutional model for the development and production of new theater works. Jointly managed by Z Space and the Magic Theater, the pilot will bring together distinguished writers and California producing companies.
To support the development of a new play by Leigh Fondakowski. The Jonestown Project will commemorate the 1978 Jonestown tragedy that occurred in Jonestown, Guyana.

To support the production of a new hip-hop theater piece. Danny Hoch will direct "Flow," a solo performance piece in the form of hip-hop rhymes with choreography by Robert Moses to be produced by the AfroSolo Company.
To support Word for Word's educational outreach activities, including performances, workshops, and artist residencies in local schools and libraries.

To support developmental services for established writers with roots in San Francisco Bay Area theater. Through the Studio's acclaimed Z Commissions program, the artists will have access to a wide range of artistic, technical, and facility resources, including a three-week workshop production.
To support the expansion of Word for Word's educational outreach activities. The project includes additional performances, workshops, and artist residencies in local schools and libraries.
To support the Z Commissions program. The project supports the creation, development, and staged reading of two commissioned plays by Bay Area writers.
To support the expansion of Word for Word's educational outreach activities. The project includes additional performances, workshops, and artist residencies.

Discipline / Field: Creative Links: Positive Alternatives for Youth
Project Description: To support a Creative Links project to provide positive alternatives for youth. The partnership brings together Z Space Studio and the Walden House, an in-patient drug rehabilitation facility. Thirteen girls, ages 15-18, will participate in an artist residency project that will culminate in a performance, featuring the teens as actors.

To support the expansion of Word for Word's educational outreach program, The School and Library Tour. The tour will bring works of literature and short stories, performed literally word for word, to San Francisco Bay Area high schools for students whose literacy skills are below average.

Purpose: To support artist fees and production costs for the biennial San Francisco Aerial Arts Festival. Additional Project Description: Founded in 2014 by Zaccho Dance Theatre, the festival presents a diverse range of aerial dancers and circus aerial performers. In addition to stage and site-specific performances, activities will include workshops and discussions about aerial choreography. Ticketed and free events will take place at Fort Mason Center for Arts and Culture. Intended Beneficiaries: The festival will benefit diverse audiences of all ages, as well as students and the dance community in the greater San Francisco metropolitan area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
To support planning costs for the annual San Francisco Aerial Arts Festival. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic the Festival could not occur.

To support the re-development and performance of "The View From Here" by Artistic Director Joanna Haigood. The dance is inspired by the work of artist Marc Chagall, and will focus on specific paintings of his that explore the themes of circus dynamics, love, life in the shtetl, color, and multi-dimensionality. Preceding the performances there will be free panel discussions among artists and scholars. Additionally, the company will work with the Youth Circus and Acrobat performers in the Bay Area to coordinate audience outreach activities.

To support the SF Aerial Dance Festival. The festival will bring together aerial dance artists, students, and audiences for a dynamic week of performances, workshops, and discussions. Emerging and established aerial dance choreographers will be featured, including Flyaway Productions, Project BANDALOOP, and Zaccho Dance Theatre. Performances will take place at the historic Fort Mason Center, with workshops at the Zaccho Studio in Bayview/Hunter's Point.

To support the creation and presentation of "A Poet's Love," a new work choreographed by Artistic Director Joanna Haigood in collaboration with actor/tenor Jose Joaquin Garcia. Composed as a series of dance theater vignettes, the new work will be performed to composer Robert Schumann's song cycle, "Dichterliebe," sung by Garcia. The piece will feature a cast of aerial dancers. The process will culminate in a weekend of performances presented at Zaccho Dance Theatre's home studio, the Center for Dance and Aerial Art.

To support the creation and presentation of "Between Me  the Other World," a new work by artistic director Joanna Haigood. The work will employ video immersion technology by video artist David Szlasa to depict a poetic expression of the feelings described in civil rights leader W.E.B. DuBois's social concept of "double consciousness."

To support Zaccho Dance Theatre's 30th Anniversary Project. Highlighted programming will include the restaging of artistic director Joanna Haigood's seminal work The Monkey and the Devil in combination with outdoor performances at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts Forum.

To support the production and presentation of "Invisible Wings." The performance will include traditional dance, song, and storytelling from slave culture combined with theatrical interpretations and modern dance.
To support the presentation of a evening-length work choreographed by Remy Charlip and Joanna Haigood. Dances Around the House will premiere at the Exploratorium.

To support the creation and presentation of "Ghost Architecture" choreographed by Artistic Director Joanna Haigood. This piece will examine the relationship between space and time and how that relates to architecture.
To support creation and presentation of a new aerial dance work. Artistic Director Joanna Haigood will create a new piece that draws inspiration from the paintings of Marc Chagall.

To support creation and presentation of a site-specific dance piece. Designed for a silo at an abandoned grain terminal in San Francisco, the work will involve large-scale projections designed by video artist Mary Ellen Strom and music by composer Lauren Weinger.

To support artist fees for The Nile Project's United States tour. Musicians from cultural groups living along the Nile River Basin will will tour college campuses across the nation. Through performances, panel discussions, films, and workshops, Zambaleta will address water use and sustainability issues common to the Nile Basin and the U.S. Additionally, the project organizers will create a study guide with information about the Nile Basin's geography, history, cultural groups, musical traditions, and instruments, as well as information about environmental issues.

Organization Name: ZeroOne - The Art and Technology Network
Project Description: Purpose: To support an equipment lending library offering the tools needed to create electronic music and sound art, and related public programming. Additional Project Description: Designed to eliminate barriers and increase access for creatives to explore intersection of art, music, and technology, the library will be paired with access to technical support, workshops, and creative sound events led by teaching artists. The library will be made available to residents across the San Francisco Bay Area, with a focus on reaching students and creators from diverse backgrounds that are underrepresented in the fields of art, music, and technology. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit students and creators in the San Francisco Bay Area, with a focus on the Mission District and neighborhoods in the Outer Mission, Excelsior, and Bayview Hunters Point. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Organization Name: ZeroOne - The Art and Technology Network
Project Description: Purpose: To support a community resource lending library for artists producing work at the intersection of art, music, and technology, with related professional development activities. Additional Project Description: This collective resource is designed to eliminate barriers and increase access to tools and equipment necessary for artists to produce electronic, sound, and immersive media art works. Activities will include artist-led workshops, labs, incubators, and events produced in partnership with Crowbar Corner and Gray Area Foundation for the Arts. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit artists, residents, and community members across the San Francisco area, with a focus on neighborhoods currently limited in access to art and technology resources. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

Organization Name: ZeroOne - The Art and Technology Network
Project Description: To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Organization Name: ZeroOne - The Art and Technology Network
Project Description: To support the biennial exhibition, "Seeking Silicon Valley." The biennial will present an anchor exhibition in downtown San Jose; as well as public lectures.

Organization Name: ZeroOne - The Art and Technology Network
Project Description: To support the commissioning component for Build Your Own World, the 01SJ Biennial in consortium with Movimiento de Arte Y Cultura Latino Americana De San Jose Inc. Held in San Jose, the biennial's theme for 2010 will investigate how artists, designers, engineers, and others can interpret and affect the future through the creation of artwork that intersects with technology and digital culture.

Organization Name: ZeroOne - The Art and Technology Network
Project Description: To support the development of The Night Journey--An Interactive Artworld," a video game artwork by Bill Viola. The Night Journey - An Interactive Artworld is based on the universal story of a mystic's journey through seven different levels towards enlightenment.

Purpose: To support the publication and promotion of the journal ZYZZYVA. Additional Project Description: Reflecting a West Coast literary perspective, ZYZZYVA publishes fiction, poetry, and nonfiction by both emerging and established writers. Intended Beneficiaries: The journal will benefit readers nationwide. Intended Outcomes: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the publication and promotion of the journal ZYZZYVA. Reflecting a West Coast literary perspective, ZYZZYVA publishes fiction, poetry, and nonfiction by both emerging and established writers. Planned issues will focus on themes such as longform writing, family, technology, and the concept of "borders."

To support the publication and promotion of the journal ZYZZYVA. Reflecting a West Coast literary perspective, ZYZZYVA publishes fiction, poetry, and nonfiction by both emerging and established writers. Planned special sections of the publication will feature work in translation, with an emphasis on writers whose work has not been previously published in English, as well as fiction and essays celebrating the 100th anniversary of the passage of the 19th amendment. This project honors the Womens Suffrage Centennial.

To support the publication and promotion of ZYZZYVA and updates to the journal's website. Reflecting a West Coast literary perspective, ZYZZYVA publishes fiction, poetry, and nonfiction by both emerging and established writers. The journal's website will be updated to improve its visual appeal and to make content more searchable and will feature distinct pages for book reviews, video interviews, and works from the journal's archives.
To support the publication and promotion of the journal. Reflecting a West Coast literary perspective, "ZYZZYVA" publishes fiction, poetry, and nonfiction by both emerging and established writers.
To support the publication and promotion of the journal. Reflecting a West Coast literary perspective, "ZYZZYVA" publishes fiction, poetry, and nonfiction by both emerging and established writers.

To support the publication and promotion of the journal "ZYZZYVA." Showcasing the work of acclaimed and emerging West Coast writers, the journal publishes fiction, poetry, nonfiction, and artwork. The journal will be promoted at literary festivals and conferences; additional content, such as original writing and video interviews with contributors, will be made available online.

To support the publication and promotion of the journal "ZYZZYVA" in its 30th anniversary year. This project includes the publication of print journals featuring the work of acclaimed and emerging West Coast writers. The journal also will develop new online content including video interviews with ZYZZYVA contributors and a series of readings and anniversary events in the San Francisco Bay Area.

To support the publication, promotion, and related costs of Zyzzyva, a journal featuring the work of West Coast writers. Each issue includes approximately 20 writers, one-third of whom have never been in print.

To support the publication, promotion, and related costs for issues of ZYZZYVA, a journal featuring the work of West Coast writers. Each issue includes approximately 20 writers, one-third of whom have never been in print.

To support the publication, promotion, and related costs for issues of Zyzzyva, a journal featuring the work of West Coast writers. Each issue includes approximately 20 writers, one-third of whom have never been in print.

To support the publication, promotion, and related costs for issues of ZYZZYVA magazine featuring the work of West Coast writers. Each issue includes approximately 20 writers, one-third of whom have never been in print.

To support the publication, promotion, and related costs for issues of ZYZZYVA, a magazine featuring the work of West Coast writers. Each issue includes approximately 20 writers, one-third of whom have never been in print.

To support publication, promotion, and related costs, including authors' fees, for issues of Zyzzyva, a magazine featuring the work of West Coast writers. Each issue includes approximately 20 writers, one-third of whom have never been in print.
To support issue 61 of ZYZZYVA, a magazine featuring the work of West Coast writers. The proposed issue will be promoted through a direct mail subscription campaign targeting 100,000 readers.

To support authors' fees and promotional costs for issue 58 of ZYZZYVA. Featuring the work of West Coast writers, the proposed issue will be promoted through a direct mail subscription campaign targeting 100,000 readers.
